Title: Fidelity MADE is a SCAM!
View5: Decent PTO- you are going to need it, you will be burnt-out, I have had jobs with half the amount of PTO and not used all of it, I used every single day at Fidelity Paid Training and Licensing- They pay for your licenses and the time it takes to train for them, many people freak out during licensing and say how difficult it is, I found the time to be pretty good, you have most of the day to yourself to study with the materials they provide and then fill in the gaps with Zoom meetings, pretty different experience from when you get on the phones and are glued to your workstation because you never know when the phone will ring. Overall the exams are hard but I passed on the first attempt for each of them and didn't study a minute when I wasn't getting paid to do so. Having said that if you are having a difficult time with the material it may be a different story for you, also you will lose many co-workers during this time since they cant pass the exams. Our team was lucky and only lost a few but others had close to the whole team fail. If you can't pass the exams they often offer you a job with the 401k team but it is for lower pay and much higher call volume. Managers- Your experience may vary but every manager I had was very helpful and easy to approach Coworkers- Once again your experience may vary but I have had several teams in my time with Fidelity and they were mostly all good to work with Campus- This depends on your regional site but Durham has a very nice campus, with on-site cafeteria, albeit mediocre food, walking trail, very nicely equipped gym, Starbucks and ping pong and cornhole. In Durham's case it has some amenities you might expect from a tech site and that is because much of Fidelity's tech is centered in Durham, I have heard from co-workers in other sites that their campus is not nearly as nice and that probably has to do with the fact that non-tech at Fidelity are treated like second class citizens. Also you know what has many of those amenities, my house, so maybe don't force your coworkers to drive in so they can do the same thing they would have done at home but in an office, where it is louder and harder to hear clients Slow Season -During the summer months call volume slows dramatically and you may only take a handful of calls all day. It's not as great as it sounds though because you sit in ready for over an hour sometimes and you never know when you actually will get a call so you are stuck near your desk and if you have to go to the bathroom or get up for a minute you have go into not ready, do that too much and they are going to say you are avoiding calls and it will affect your metrics. Decent amount of off phone time when it is slow. - Not much to add to this one Benefits- This is the number one reason that anyone works for Fidelity, for the "amazing" benefits. While the benefits seem amazing at first, if you dig a little deeper they lose a lot of their luster. For example, the incredible match is only offered after your first full year with the company, in the meantime you get nothing and it takes a full five years to vest. The healthcare is pretty good but you are going to probably need it to go on anxiety medication, other benefits sound good but have pretty limited use, such as adoption assistance, commuter assistance that does not cover gas or vehicle payments but things such as public transportation, I don't know a single co-worker who used the bus to get to work nor if there was even one around and lastly, health reimbursement which sounds great but can only be used for classes and not equipment, so it covers Jazzercise but not weights or a treadmill. One benefit that was really great was student loan payments, which only knock on that was it was limited to 2k a year for up to 5 years. Overall the benefits are still really good, however Fidelity is run by smart people and they crunched the numbers and offering these benefits are cheaper than raising base pay.
View7: This first part only applies to those interested in getting into tech, so skip ahead if that is not you. Fidelity offers a non-tech to tech training program called Fidelity MADE, which sounds nice on paper and lures many to the company, however it is poorly run and if you do not check the right diversity boxes, you have no chance. It does not matter if you have a bachelors in computer science from a major state university, previous experience with the technologies they use, if you have had previous technical internships, if you have gotten a 100 on your first attempt on the pre-test, none of it matters because the number one thing they care about is satisfying a diversity requirement. Even the recruiter in charge complained that those running the program made them interview everyone that applied regardless of their qualifications and it set them back heavily. Ultimately it took them three and half months to send out rejection letters, a full month behind their schedule. When you get rejected its just a canned rejection letter that tells you to apply next time and continue practicing your technical skills, which is a joke because the interviews barely touch on anything technical and just a bunch of fluff, tell me about a time questions over and over, I suspect they did this so they could justify hiring blatantly under qualified individuals. This was not just me but several candidates with similar qualifications, the only similarity, our demographic. I wasted a full year before I could apply to MADE, practiced with the technologies in my free time and did everything I could do to prepare but it all was for nothing. If you want to break into tech this is not the way to do it. Future of work - They act like they are geniuses for coming up with the concept of hybrid work. There is no reason to have to go into the office when we worked perfectly fine remotely for over a year, but the billionaire boomer CEO thinks it is a great idea. At first it started as just three days every four weeks but then became five days every four weeks. I suspect they are going to go one week on and one week remote in the future but probably want to wait till after tax season so they can stomach the loss of staff better. The worst part about hybrid work is all the people who are only pay grades 1 or 2 can't generally afford to live near campus, so they have to drive, many well over an hour each way without traffic but all the higher ups do not have a problem with it because they get paid enough to afford decent housing near campus. Pay - The pay is mediocre and below industry standard. It is widely talked about how you can go to any competitor in the industry and make more money but the managers have to remind you how great the benefits are. I went up a pay grade and got to cost of living adjustments during my tenure and I barely noticed a difference. Schedule- Like working 8-5, well too bad because after training you will be moved to shift bid. You will be lucky to get anything before your 5th choice. The shifts start as early as 5am and go as late as 11pm so it is more than likely you will end up working odd hours. Tech Support - Fidelity's internal tech team is almost impossible to reach and it can take up to an hour to reach them, the digital tools that you have can be pretty hit or miss and some of them will just stop working randomly, so it would be great to be able to reach them. Also they are incompetent, when you leave the company make sure to get a receipt for your returned equipment because they will be hounding you to return it even though you already did. Client Obsessed - The company likes to say how client obsessed they are but I found this a joke. Very rarely does anyone at the company actually go above and beyond for the client, they mostly just tell you to let the client know you can't do something. Most of the people at the company are too worried about covering their butt rather than actually doing the right thing. Also it does not matter how great you are with the clients and how great your client survey scores are because how do you get promoted? By having enough calls per hour and if you are even a little under that, you are not getting promoted. You are incentivized to get the client off the phone as quickly as possible and if they don't complain it is good enough. Also I love how they say how client obsessed they are but this is the same company that is actively discouraging the use of mail in favor of digital, the clients who stuck with the company for a half century and helped build it into the billion dollar juggernaut today might not want to use a computer and they should not have to go through a lot of hopes to do so. It really won't even be a problem in about a decade since most of the clients that really care about the mail are in their twilight years. Promotions - The promotions are a joke when it comes to pay, you might get like a 5% bump in pay and a chance to make some more in bonuses. Also for auto promotions they only hire in certain departments randomly so if there is a department you want you will have to keep qualifying for them every single month and hope they are hiring that month and also hope you don't get a trade error because then you are disqualified for that month. Most people just take the first department they are offered rather than going through that. Any off phone openings are crazy competitive, they may have two spots open and get over 60 applicants because most people hate their phone role, so if you want off the phone good luck. Tax Season - During tax season, Feb-April you will be non stop busy and as soon as you hang up the phone another one comes in. I have worked in a restaurant for a long time and I was more physically exhausted after this job during the busy season than an active job like that. After spending all day talking to clients you just want to just sit there and do nothing and not talk to anyone, it is the most emotional and mentally draining time. Anxiety- Almost all your co-workers will talk about how much anxiety they feel all the time. This is not during the first few weeks either, we are talking about people who had been there for well over a year. The Sunday Scaries are real and you will probably get them bad. I ended up having to go on prescription medicine to help manage my anxiety and only got off as soon as I left the job. FINRA regulations - This one is not about Fidelity in particular but about the industry as a whole, FINRA regulations are very strict and require you to give a lot of personal information and limit outside business activities and amount of trading you can do in a quarter. Onboarding - The onboarding process takes forever with Fidelity and is pretty messy. The recruiter told me I had to get drug tested within a couple days but the place they wanted me to use was appointment only and did not have any openings during that time frame. Luckily they were able to reschedule but it was very inconvenient to have to panic that I wasn't going to have a job because I could not get the drug test done in time. Recruiters- Some recruiters straight up lie about the job and what it entails, one of them told my coworker that they mostly would be answering emails. The truth is it is a call center and we are not even able to email clients. How the job is advertised - Fidelity makes a big deal of being a financial professional and how you are going to have a series 7 job. The truth is it is a call center and you are going to feel like you work in retail more than working in finance, especially because you are going to be working retail hours most likely after you are done with training. There is a reason most of the people they hire have no financial background and come from retail jobs. The job itself - All this and I never even mentioned what the actual job is like , the truth is it is torture. One co-worker said it best when he said this job should be banned by the Genova convention, not only did I agree, I used those exact words to describe it to other people before. Surprisingly the clients themselves are not too bad and you even get some pretty pleasant and grateful clients but the job is a grind. Not only is everything you do monitored and recorded, it makes it difficult because you never know when the next call is going to come in. The best way to describe the job is like helping your grandma with her online banking details over the phone all day every day. Many of the people are technologically illiterate and almost everything has to be done on their end digitally. The simplest tasks like password resets and adding banking details can easily take over 40 minutes and wreck your stats. Also if you have to reach out to other departments many times they don't want to take the call from you or it can take a very long time to reach them. I have had to wait over an hour for the fraud department to fix simple issues, obviously the client is mad when you get back and the whole time your stats get destroyed. Many departments like fraud and transition services are chronically understaffed and as soon as you get a call that needs them you know you are not going to have a good time. As the client facing member of the team you are going to have to break a lot of bad news and hear some pretty tough situations. If you like waiting on hold and calling your bank's customer service, this is the job for you. Miscellaneous - The same time they required people to go into the office, they canceled the $10 lunch credit, I don't expect to get free food but the food was only worth it if it was free and I thought it was classless to cancel it at the same time as forcing people into the office more. Also no money for bonuses but a few days later we find out they are going to give a quarter billion dollars to underserved students. They virtue signal about diversity but the tech department is the least diverse place that I have ever seen. Wrap Up - Ask yourself why a company that has such "great" benefits, that brags about being voted a top place to work, has to spend so much on recruitment ads. The truth is it is a low paying call center and for every success story you see, there are dozens that washed out.

Title: Poor Experience
View5: The benefits and paid time off is pretty good.
View7: I worked at Fidelity for a year, if you don’t pass the test (SIE, Series 7, Series 63) you could be terminated. They don’t give you the options for testing up front if you have something going on in your life that could prevent you from passing. You have to research it, call HR, etc. I didn’t pass after dealing with many personal issues and was offered to apply elsewhere (WI, where the pay is less). They didn’t accept me after a year of work. You are a number to them, they don’t care about their people. The girl interviewing me was very young (early twenties) and did not have a personality to say the least. If you like being a number and answering angry calls all day for 20/hr this is the job for you! Personally, you can go work in a restaurant for a few hours and make more. In regards to the WFH environment, my manager asked to view my entire bedroom space where my desk is located. Is this normal? Seems very inappropriate to me. All together a pretty poor experience, lack of communication, lack of support.

Title: Crazy making place
View5: Pay and benefits. Paid training.
View7: Fake bro/cool culture. Training begins with a lot of hot air about how *awesome* the company is, to the point where they seem to be trying to convince themselves. Lots of promises made about moving out of the call center quickly. So much sizzle, no steak. So much sizzle, many reviews here echo how leadership doesn't want you to really see that you are getting into a call center job. Fidelity does not allow workers to discuss pay, which is illegal. You have the right - by law - to talk about your pay. Company does not want employees who know their rights. They want fresh-out-of-college young people who they can bamboozle. My manager would pull people out of training to talk about shopping. She didn't like my objecting to that and became a bully. Don't trust anyone. They all talk to each other. Very cliquey, high school atmosphere.

The culture seems fantastic in the office. Everyone seems happy to be here and there are a lot of perks, such as free lunches and coffee. I would say the reasons I'm staying here instead of accepting one of the MANY job offers I have for much higher pay in my previous field are:
Tons of room for growth - they make a huge effort to train people and move them around in the company.
Mentoring - it has been really nice having a manager that takes an active interest in me.

Low pay and it seems like pay doesn't increase a lot either as you move up.
Required overtime during the busy season.
Desk job on the phones - can be a bit of a grind feeling trapped to your desk

Title: Grow career and skills - then proactively leave
View5:
Profit sharing is the best in industry - you need to stay 5 years to keep it
Career growth and training is excellent - as long as you know the right people
Tuition reimbursement is excellent
Remote work is very nice
View7:
Read "Think Again" by Adam Grant - Fidelity is one of those companies that does not encourage thinking outside the box. 
Being wrong is not a virtue, nor is humility. 
Egoism thrives at Fidelity. 
Not a safe place for questioning the status quo. 
Do not criticize the process. 
Its all about who you know and not what you know.
Skills development is limited. Once you hit the limit, hit the door on your own and look for a company that encourages personal growth, otherwise you might get stuck in your role with no relevant skills. 
This is a spreadsheet and numbers company, not a people company. 
Your experience is highly dependent on your manager, who likely did not even do your job.

Title: Don't let the toxic positivity get to you
View5: Overall, Fidelity is a great company. I've met some amazing friends and I've loved all of my managers and leads thus far. Management can make or break your experience so its a blessing to have some that you really like. I came in apart of their new LAUNCH program, and the training and support during onboarding was superb!
View7: I've always had a gut feeling that things were going to take a turn for the worst after onboarding. It's not terrible, but you're tied to the phones for 8 hours everyday, minus any trainings you're subject to. That is the job we signed up for, but once you're actually doing it full-time, you'll start to hate it. At least I did. You get nice people sometimes, but the participants (people calling in) can be really entitled and annoying. It also seems like everyone is just as confused as you are. They preach about how the F in Fidelity is for flexibility, but it can quickly turn into organized chaos. Most of my training class is still confused about a lot of things when it comes to bonuses, PTO, etc. During training, they'll bring a ton of people in and host panels full of people that preach how awesome Fidelity is. They're not lying per say, but take it with a grain of salt. Go your own path and figure out if it's right for you. The CEO is also trying to make people come in 5 days out of the month (we do 3 currently) starting in January, and they only plan to increase the amount as we go through 2023 and onwards. She's getting a lot of pushback on it because going into the office is draining and a waste of time, since most of us can work more efficiently in our role at home. Salary is a bit on the low end, but they try to make up for it in "company culture" and benefits. Most of the benefits I honestly don't use so it would be nice if my salary was higher.

View7: going a little political and they are pushy about the vaccine. the office atmosphere is also VERY negative and winy. tough to just show up and work hard and go home without the micro managing culture to interfere. also the sales coach is VERY inexperienced and gets in the way more than he helps.

Title: Not terrible, but not good either for tech
View5: Very team dependent for any pros. Stable employment for the most part. Culture varies by role and team in the company too. If you're a developer or some other tech role, focus in on reviews only from those specific roles. Check the dates of reviews.
View7: Check Blind and Levels.fyi before anything else. Underpays a lot from tech industry norms, not a real tech company/fintech, not much developer work or real developer work for tech roles, the list goes on.

Title: Feeling regret
View5: Reputable corporation, base pay is fair to start, mostly good people to work with, benefits are good
View7: Originally was excited to join but almost immediately during onboarding I started to see the culture that was different from what was discussed during interviews. Feeling regret after taking this new job. You have to essentially sell your soul to work here, you have to hand over all your financial accounts and there are so many restrictions and requirements with what you can do from your accounts down to outside activity, to social media, and even access to your personal devices if you choose to use your personal phone for work. So many meetings, all are required to be on-camera. WFH here is so behind the times, they went from mandated 3 days/month during their “dynamic working” to now a full 5-day work week/month, boasting this dynamic model as some sort of super flexible way for their employees to work. Teams are spread across the country and even internationally, why must employees go into an office to take the same Zoom calls with their out of state team and managers? Dynamic working is a farce dressed up in an appealing package as if employees are considered first, when in reality this is a corporation stuck in micromanaging and sinking money into real estate for show when their talent can absolutely perform well and better WFH. What a blow to morale and how convenient this comes out of nowhere with no discussions with managers and after the pulse survey is complete. Onboarding is super overwhelming and stressful, it seems they have a structure with their training but you’re just thrown in with short deadlines and not much direction. CEO is very clearly struggling with adapting to evolving times and letting go of old ways. I could have dealt with some of these, even the original 3 day/month in-office work. But now I’m already on my way out.

Title: Fairly Chill (Sometimes too much)

"Career vitality" is a major focus of the organization top to bottom, and it has proved to resonate for me.

Title: Not a place for minorities or those looking for dynamism in the workplace
View5: Generous time off polices are probably the best selling point.
View7: Fidelity's claimed investment in Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion is only an investment in rhetoric and propaganda, in which they incentivize every employee to post on job sites with false, pre-packaged promises of their "great" attributes of being a superior place to work. Indeed, my experience as a member of the LGBTQ+ community was anything but safe. Rather it was hostile in a workplace that was toxic as a whole. As a private company in which structural resistance to change is entrenched like an anchor, inclusive of pervasive nepotism, expect to be a pariah should you try to effect such change in the workplace. In their current state, I would not recommend anyone to join their team, until they can properly align their values with their soaring rhetoric.

Title: Good Benefits

Title: Good for the first job out of college but will definitely dislike it after several months
View5: 1. Excellent benefits and lots of PTO days for entry level employees (23) 2. Lot of freedom during the day in offices. They could care less when you come in or leave or even if you play some video games in an empty meeting room or if you take your pet walrus on a walk.
View7: 1. Very low salary. For a resident of Rhode Island/Massachusetts, $70,000/year is surely not enough if you want a good apartment/townhouse and afford good quality food. 2. Very slow advancement for promotions 3. Tasks are very mundane for employees who are under 30 years old and without a master's degree. 4. Getting access to certain databases and tables takes very long. 5. Technologies that the company use are very outdated. 6. There is very prevalent ageism. I was 22-24 years old, and older employees opinions were always taken more seriously. 7. Obsessive compulsiveness with adhering to company standards, even in Microsoft Word documents, the specific dark blue font color had to be used for some columns. 8. NOBODY is open to creativity or new ways of doing things. 9. Company's median age is 45+. DO NOT work here for long if you're young. 10. Extremely cliquish. People almost always only hang out with others of their own team/squad/section or those they've known since age 6. 11. Very very vague performance evaluation criteria to the point where it feels like our evaluations are fake. Managers can EASILY twist the details of the evaluation form in your favor or against you. 12. Extremely terribly disorganized HR. I was called in for an interview for the June 2020 LEAP program in 2019, but little did I know that they already had filled up the June 2020 LEAP program a few weeks BEFORE my interview. But, they only told me AFTER I sweated through the 1-hour long interview. They told me this all ON THE PHONE and not in writing. Shady. They put me on a "waitlist" and gave me vague updates over the next several months. Eventually, they admitted me off the waitlist, but only after 8 MONTHS OF UNCERTAINTY.

Fidelity also sends out surveys about everything but never listen to feedback. For example, they're making everyone go back to work even though no one does (although very few admit it to suck up to management). Gotta get back that "office culture", right? Upper management never answers questions in company meetings and instead gives vague, political-like answers. Pay is low and benefits are VERY average. Other companies offer so, so much. This place will suck out your soul and personality.

People stay because of the benefits. Otherwise, a job that you would definitely leave ASAP.

Title: Stellar workplace for young professionals
View5: Due to internal promotion, management is typically someone who has spent more than a year in customer-facing roles and is highly competent. There's loads of room to grow, with career fairs held weekly in the office where you can network across the company. They recently started the Personal Investing Launch program, which gives those in service-based roles 10 hours a week to develop a growth skill set. The employee can opt for the growth skill set they are most interested in and can promote to a new role with relative ease thereafter. In the program, they also do resume and interview prep to help you transition to the next role (absolutely brilliant). Additionally, the benefits are ridiculously good. Who needs 12 weeks of paternal leave?? I couldn't be happier with Fidelity, they've been the best employer I've ever had by a long shot.
View7: Tax season can be very busy, and licensing can be difficult. Despite that, Fidelity is aware of these things and is very accommodating in terms of tax season and licensing incentives.

Title: Fidelity Investments, great benefits, compensation but a fast pace no excuses work environment.

View7: I worked at Fidelity for close to 20 years and the culture has shifted very dramatically to micro management, what have you done for me last week culture. In relationship roles your expected to produce unrealistic goals from existing client base while being compare to other reps receiving new clients with money in motion. Expectations presenting annuities is also concerning as a CERTIFIED FINANCIAL PLANNER. Too many good people leave sales and relationship roles to other roles in the organization due to burn out and which does impact the clients. FC roles are no longer a destination roles but rather a stop to some other role or outside the organization.

Title: Great company, poor management
View5:
- The company itself is amazing. The goals and intentions are clear and obtainable. 
- Benefits are second to none, even added extra relief PTO for Covid.
- Depending on the role, work from home is an option. But the FR role doesn’t allow for that.
- There are so many resources and learning opportunities.
- Your coworkers will always be eager to help you at any capacity.
View7:
- Management is more concerned on how well their profitable employees are doing, and taking care of them. They are more flexible and willing to bend for those employees.
- Micromanagement is an understatement.
- With all those learning opportunities, it’s still really hard to promote. You won’t promote unless the other people in your role are able to handle it themselves. Lots of people quit in this role because they can’t get licensed or the workload is a lot, so you’ll find yourself stuck in the role for 3-4 years (though they say 1-2 is average).
- They play favorites
- Moody managers that’s attitudes are just as volatile as the market

If PTO is used, one can assume their variable compensation will be reduce for that specific quarter.

Pay is always tied to extra performance issues.

Title: Salary caps for older workers
View5: Coworkers, Flexible work schedule, diverse responsibilities
View7: Caps salary around $63k for older workers in New Hampshire so your pay after taxes is about $2500/month. Average rent in Merrimack is $2000 or you can move an hour north and pay $1500 but gas/car expenses wipe out those savings. No overtime available and they never give cost of living adjustments. All promotions, even to a higher salary grade, come with no raises. Most benefits for younger workers. HR determines salary cap but they seem clueless on how expensive it is to live here. Utilities are doubling this year now, and inflation is surging so I am taking a huge pay cut every year. Disappointed that Fidelity is so cheap.

Title: Good WLB

Title: Extremely Friendly Work Environment

Title: Decent Pay & Easy Work

View7: - Low compensation for tech roles - Slow technology adoption - Bureaucracy is particularly annoying at Fidelity

Title: College Grads Beware, this is a call center
View5: benefits, beautiful campus, work life balance
View7: During the interview process, they change the wording to make it seem like it’s not a call center, but it is. We take calls back to back and follow a strict schedule. If we don’t follow the schedule, then we get yelled at by our managers. I was in a post grad rotation program and our managers basically treat us like kids. It’s pretty cringey and not professional. I felt like I was still in high school going through this program and I don’t really feel much growth. I didn’t go through college just to be stuck in a call center role, getting berated by customers on the daily. I felt like I was lied to during the interview process, because they market this opportunity in such a different way. Just tell us straight up that this is a call center and not waste anyone’s time. Majority of the roles within the company are call center positions, so there’s no way getting off the phones. The one thing I don’t understand about this company, is that the pay is so bad, but people are still so enthusiastic about their job, getting yelled at by customers and being “customer obsessed.”It gives off cultish vibes. Anyways, it takes a certain personality to really like being on the phones and following a strict schedule with a timed 30 minute lunch.

Title: One step forward, two steps back

Title: could be great

easy to get in through customer service and phone role

decent benefits package 
upward mobility available

View7:
self paced training which basically teaches you the bare minimum. 
a lot of trial and error, you learn by making mistakes everyday. 
a lot of research while having time constraints 
its a lot of work. and it can take anywhere from 3 months to a year to stop feeling like a ball of anxious mess, 
theres a certain level of fear mongering that is used to make sure you do the job like they want you too. probably not best if you already struggle with anxiety. it will definitely kick it up a notch... a couple notches. 
they calculate more stats than you can even think of. these stats will be thrown at you daily and you will be asked to explain every bit if its out of the desired window. bonuses and pay increases depend on that. 
if any of these feel like pros to you then it may be the right fit for you.

Title: NOT THE PLACE TO WORK IF YOU ARE A SINGLE PARENT
View5: Decent pay and sponsorship for licensing.
View7:
Lack of consideration for single parents who work from home with children. 
If you upset management in any way they will turn their back on you. 
Management should be more considerate and truthful. 
If you use your PTO too soon, but dont go over your limit, they will look to terminate you. 
If you fail the exam one time they will terminate you. 
If you have to take care of your child they will terminate you. 
You put in so much effort and time to study for the Series 7 and if you fail they will look at you badly. 
All in all, if you have a child and are a single parent and think Fidelity will understand if you have to help your child....they WILL NOT and will terminate you if you are a great employee who does their job well.

Title: Bad job but difficult to rate.
View5: They license you. You will think about this experience in future jobs and feel relief that you no longer work here. This job is probably more attainable than the vast majority of others job in "finance".
View7:
Ultimately the job title is "Customer Relationship Advocate", so I can't fault Fidelity for being dishonest in anyway during recruiting. However, if you are a college graduate looking for a job, even if you failed other interviews, do not take this job if you want to enter a job that is A) financial and/or B) analytical.

Firstly, Fidelity will advertise the SIE/S7/S63 as a good way to begin your career and potentially jump to something else later. These licenses are required from a compliance standpoint, that is the only reason they require you to take them. These licenses will not land you a job as an analyst or impress anyone who actually knows what they are. If you are only joining to take these exams, I advise against this.

Close your eyes. Do you want to take phone calls all day every for the foreseeable future, with the only promotions available being other roles where you get a slight pay bump and take phone calls all day? This is your life after finishing licensing, and if you're like me you will be put on a 10-hour shift against your preference. 10 hours all day every day of talking to customers is not going to make you very desirable in any actual finance or analytical job.

This job is 97.5% customer service and 2.5% finance. Some might argue it is not finance at all, the most sophisticated thing you will do on a daily basis is place a stock order for a customer who is too lazy to do it themselves. You will get trainings on concepts that most customers understand through internet articles, or you will be trained on proprietary systems, nothing you can even place on a resume to show you as a desirable candidate for when you will want to leave.

This job is basically an office version of a factory assembly line. The second you finish a call you're onto the next, there is no opportunity to extend to any meaningful project that will help you get out of the perpetual call center. The job is designed to keep you working for them in a call center, they already licensed and trained you so this is most profitable for them. 

The only person I can see who would like this job is someone who worked in call centers in the past and sees this as an upgrade since they can call themselves a licensed broker etc.

For anyone who wishes to have career advancement outside of customer service or potentially their wealth management branch (you will start off a brand new role, continuing to do calls all day every day and maybe after 3-5 years get promoted to a branch), extend your job search and look elsewhere.

Lastly, the reason I put "difficult to rate" in the title is because I might seem naive for giving a poor rating to a customer service job since it doesn't offer promotions into analytical or financial jobs. But ultimately I can't give this job a good rating whatsoever because everyday was dreadful; never-ending phone calls with no hope for meaningful advancement.

Title: Disappointed after reading all the good hype
View5: The work is extremely easy . They have good benefits 401k and profit share. They have everything at the company that you can think of as far a technology, so lots to learn for entry level people. Has a decent corporate culture that encourages a good attitude and free speech.
View7: Fidelity lacks technical leadership as a whole and does not value it! They value attitude over all else which means they hire people they like and contract out technical folks. They are not lean and Agile, lots of bloat and middle managers. The environment is extremely political and they accomplish very little. It's extremely hard to get anything done with all bureaucracy, meetings. Lots of non-technical folks blowing hot air and not enough GOOD developers. 90% of their developers are not employees but contractors and turn over is very high. As far as fulltime employees go, Fidelity hires low-level tech folks who have a good attitude but lack experience which further exuberates and compounds not getting things done. Lots of silos and teams that only care about themselves, Cross team communication is probably the poorest I have ever experienced in my career. To add to it all, folks regularly switch teams and so you lose people you trained and you have to start over again. As a whole, in my opinion, it's not a great environment to write and test code in. Everything is always breaking and getting things fixed takes days not hours while your whole team is idle. This encourages idleness and apathy.

Title: Not an expert
View5: Benefits, especially the help repaying student loans and paid parental leave. Up to 7 percent match on retirement contributions. The medical premiums cost more than my prior jobs, but other benefits cost a bit less. A lot of reviews on here are complaining about the base pay. For me, it's nearly a 50 percent increase over my old job in a different industry. That's not a raise, that's life changing. There are also opportunities for bonuses. I am going to be allowed to mostly work from home for a lot longer than I was led to believe during the interview process. It's totally okay if we'd rather go ahead and work onsite every day, too.
View7: Inconsistent support - my onboarding coach didn't work in my role. They clearly want me to do well and can coach on if I am hitting certain points when interacting with customers, but they have pointedly stated that I'm "supposed to be the expert" in my role. When I reach out to my team for help while assisting customers, I only get answers to the questions that aren't part of our specific role. However, I'm not going to be trained in that specific role until at least 4-5 months on the job. I'm willing to stumble blindly through an adventure of learning alongside our customers, but many of them don't have time for that, and me not knowing what I'm doing yet is leading to a poor customer experience for them. The headsets provided for working from home aren't compatible with the onsite phones, so that was an unexpected learning curve. My coach strangely seemed perplexed that I didn't know how to operate the call center equipment already on the first day of calls despite never having seen or used that equipment before. It is extremely difficult for clients to hear me clearly, and often vice versa, due to the background conversations when working onsite. Being able to hear clearly is the top reason I'd like to continue working at home. Some of our customers are intentionally cruel. There are rude customers everywhere, but I've never cried during work every day before.

Title: Not for those who want to be excited about a job or make a single connection in the workplace.
View5:
Very clear on corporate culture. 
Updates from superiors (CEO, etc.) multiple times a week.
Will pay for your licensing if you’re in a licensed role.
Pretty easy to get vacation days approved.
View7:
This is not a job for someone who can’t sit in the same chair, staring at the same computer screen for 8+ hours.
Working from home is miserable, but working in the office requires either weekly testing and tracking or the vaccine. 
I’ve never felt so lonely at a company, even though this is the biggest company I’ve ever worked for.
I barely even know my manager’s first name, that’s how disconnected everyone is.
I only lasted one month after I finished training because the job isn’t rewarding in the slightest.
Be prepared to get yelled at or called incompetent at least 5 times a day.
Don’t expect more than minimal support from any supervisor.
This position should pay much more than it actually does. 
During onboarding, they make it seem like you can move around as much as you want, as quickly as you want, and your manager will help you advance however they can, but that’s a joke.
By the end of my shift, I’m exhausted and can’t even build up the motivation to make dinner.
EVERYTHING is scheduled. You get two 15 minute breaks - one in the morning and one in the afternoon - and a 30 minute lunch, but you may not be eating lunch until hours after any normal lunch time should be scheduled. And you don’t get a say on that either.

Title: You must look at the total compensation package
View5: Fidelity provides paid training to obtain your FINRA licensure, the have outstanding benefits from day 1. The team I was on was awesome, we all got along -- we all tugged on the rope together in the same direction, the team was diversified, and I believe everyone felt included and had a voice. We were project managers, agile, scrum team, analysts, -- it was very rewarding & challenging work.
View7:
There is high turnover, once in a Financial Rep phone role it is hard to break free -- HR and mgt sees you only in that role even though you may have obtained your masters. There are lots of departments and opportunity -- unfortunately there are walls and barriers that prevent freedom of movement from retail phones to a branch, workplace savings, or institutional. 

I was lucky and got to move into non-phone roles within the organization and enjoyed my job tremendously and felt I was finally making a contribution to the company and helping our clients. 

Project management, analysts, scrum, advisors, problem resolution, FMR, is completely different company and greater opportunity than Fidelity phone roles -- do not believe you can take an entry level phone job and quickly transition into non-phone roles -- people do get stuck in phones -- still you'll have a good job with good pay, benefits, and obtain your Series 7 license. After a year or two you can apply directly for the job you want, there are some great jobs at Fidelity.

Fidelity can be great. It depends on two things: what department/role you are in, and your manager. My major complaint about WPC is that people who play the game and burn through calls get promoted and those who spend time with clients don’t. You are not encouraged to spend time and plan with a client. You are supposed to get your tool clicks, uncover assets and send a referral to a branch. Also, they required mandatory overtime on Monday’s and Friday’s for over 6 months. Demanding total flexibility from all reps and continually asking for more, more, more. But good luck using your PTO. Some managers will act like you are stealing PTO hours from their own bank when you ask. The “COVID relief days” they offered were total BS as well. Their policy stated you could use it for anything that required “flexibility” during the pandemic. However, most managers would only let you take it if you were sick COVID.

Title: Call Center w/ Lack of Promotion outside of that
View5:
Pros: 

-All of the managers/ colleagues are generally very nice 
- Work doesn’t come home w/ you 
- Several bonus incentive opportunities
- 4-day work week option 
-Tuition Reimbursement/ Student Loan Repayment
- Gym membership Reimbursement
- Constant Overtime Availability 
-Good resume builder
-Sponsored to get FINRA Licenses
-Work from home
View7:
CRA ROLE: I graduated with a Bachelor’s in finance last year (degree not required for role) and I took this job b/c they advertised being able to become a licensed financial professional with FINRA. My professor indirectly tried to steer me away from it but I was naive. I sat in on a seminar and was really impressed with how happy everyone seemed. I thought getting my foot in the door I would be able to easily navigate and move on to a more technical skilled role. Boy was I wrong… The CRA role is the lowest of the totem pole you can be on. They try to make you feel like you’re not working in a call center because of licensing and the culture but you really are. You take inbound customer service calls. You get trained and have to assist with a magnitude of differing requests such as the status of paper work or educating/placing trades for clients in margin. It felt like I was getting paid so little to know SO MUCH. You are also expected to work chat function several times a week and manage multiple chat conversations at once. 

The busiest times are Tax Season and the end of the year for RMDs. Summer is the slowest— you most often stare at the screen all day with maybe 5-6 calls your whole 8 hour shift. 

PERFORMANCE/ PROMOTION: You are graded on the criteria of the call model & grading is inconsistent. Additionally, the anxiety you feel when you get calls and don’t know what to expect is difficult. A lot of the clients are older and can be rude when they don’t get their way. You have to help them navigate the website which sometimes can take up to an hour. Clients receive follow-up surveys in 24-48 hours after interaction and if you get a 6 or lower it counts as a 0 towards that metric. A lot of clients are unhappy when they don’t know what they are doing and you get the blame for it instead of allowing you to support and expand their knowledge. Weekends are also tough working b/c a lot of supporting business units are closed on the weekends which results in disgruntled customers and call backs (also, a metric your performance gets graded on)
Fidelity allows auto-promotion when you reach certain call review scores and call metrics. They are just other call center roles with a $1,000-$2,000 yearly salary pay increase. After tax is an extra $50-80 dollars per month. Do not be fooled do the math. 
 
TRAINING/ SUPPORT: You will go through a total of 8 months of training. A lot of information to know. Difficult to retain as you will not be practicing skills daily. If you have a question about a procedure or process managers tell you to contact the Help Desk. Crazy b/c you depend on them to measure and assess your performance but they don’t know the job role specifics. 

Overall, this job left me feeling hopeless and unmotivated. I feel like they should be more transparent with what the job function really is. It is not just about becoming licensed and being a financial professional b/c the clients don’t see you as that, they see you as a customer service representative punching bag. Call center work is not for a lot of people, really think about if this is the type of role you see yourself in permanently.

Title: Life Changing Career Decision
View5:
Excellent Training, Outstanding benefits, Healthy work/life balance. Amazing tuition reimbursement. Great place to launch a career or facilitate a career change. 
Jaw-dropping 401(k) match and profit sharing. Best career decision I ever made! I am eternally grateful for the impact Fidelity has on me and my family. Transparently, my financial future will be dramatically and positively different because of my career at Fidelity. Very proud to tell others where I work!
View7:
The only con I have is that Fidelity is more focused on hiring externally than promoting from within. Much of this focus is due to recent cultural and economic events (i.e., 2020). From a business perspective, I understand the desire to capitalize on available and diverse talent but not at the risk of frustrating and overlooking your highly qualified and tenured associates. There is a simmering frustration among the ranks and will soon result in sizable attrition if not addressed. 

For example, I am the most credential and skilled associate of my team and keep getting overlooked for a particular role. The individuals that are being hired into this role are under credentialed and/or have less experience. It is the most frustrating thing in the world! For the first time in my tenure at Fidelity, I have started proactively looking outside the firm. It genuinely PAINS me to think I may have to join a competitor to advance my career and compensation.

Title: Toxic Culture
View5: Fidelity is well known for their great benefits. Although their salaries tend to be way below what other companies pay. It's a great place to start, get your certifications, and then go somewhere else where they'll double your pay. This is what most engineers were doing at the time I was there. After I left, I doubled my salary at another firm.
View7:
I worked at Fidelity from 2018-2019 and found it to be one of the most toxic cultures I’ve ever experienced in my 20+ years as a professional. 
I worked in ECC where, although being a highly technical BU, the Sr leadership (at the time), promoted several non-technical people into leadership positions. I worked under one of these, a woman (HJ) who had a knack for hiring and promoting underqualified people, thereby creating a situation where they needed to be “protected” and would be loyal to her. This included promoting an individual from QA to a PM role with zero experience, as well as someone from the event planning dept to a Dir level leading a UX team. 
The situation was so wily, that at one point, this PM (LV) held several meetings to explain to our highly experienced UX team “UX Strategy”. She’d done her research on Google. I wish I was joking. Later, she would hold “UX Strategy” meetings that only included the one UX designer and a young woman whose role was designing PP decks for leadership (SJ). She insisted on defining herself as the UX Researcher, even though (you guessed it) she had no experience doing research and never actually conducted any research. But she was really good at gossiping, slandering, and keeping VP abreast of BU gossip.  I wish I was joking. These people were not only unqualified and unprofessional, they were MEAN.
The PM for this team created a corrosive and toxic environment; she battled constantly with the PO in front of the full 20+ team, deliberately excluded key players from meetings, showed open aggression in smaller meetings, bullied several individuals, and was just a hostile aggressive person in general.
There was another individual promoted by this VP who not only lacked in technical or leadership skills, but was one of the most badly behaved individuals of the entire team (MVH). She led a team of several people and had the emotional IQ of a 13 YO girl. She also bullied members of her own team, behaved in a hostile manner, openly threated team members, and acted appallingly. When new leadership came in and there was a reorg, she kept her position but lost her entire team. That should tell you all you need to know about Fidelity. The fact that all these people are still employed there is insane.
And make no mistake, the behavior of this group of women was endorsed by their own leadership (HJ). They knew they could get away with it and they did. Tactics included: mobbing, bullying individuals and teams, open aggression in meetings, withholding vital information, excluding individuals from specific team meetings, openly threatening individuals, slandering those who refused to play their game, and even firing those who refused to fall in line or pushed back.
Many associates complained to both HR and the Chairman’s line about this group of women, but the only sense we had that they were taking any actions was when HR executives showed up to an offsite event. But you guessed it, nothing happened. HR exists only to protect the firm. If there are no lawsuits possible, they don’t care.
This “leader” is now a VP in PI and continues her abusive, toxic behavior, as well as promoting only those who show their loyalty to her, as evidenced by the woman she just promoted to Director. In fact, all these women still hold positions at Fidelity. They may be scattered across the enterprise, but it’s just a matter of time until VP brings them all back onto her team and it all begins again.

Title: Why didn't you refer this plan participant to a nearby Fidelity Investor Center?
View5: Financial planning tools are effective, if you slip up and actually provide real financial planning to the plan participant. Less than all of the participants are rude and ignorant. The Fidelity RSP 401k match is strong and, coupled with 10 percent profit sharing, makes it very easy to save a lot of money for retirement. So you'll only be poor during your career and not also in a long retirement.
View7: Fidelity wants Workplace Planning and Advice and its Workplace Planning Consultants to refer opportunities to the Investor Center. That's the job. Say whatever you need to get the referral and you'll advance in your career. Any personal ethos of Do what's Right will be compromised in WPA. The answer to everything, everything, is refer the opportunity to the Investor Center. Also there is no way that compensation for Fidelity phone roles is materially-higher than any industry average.

Title: Strong Community, Weak Pay
View5:
- Strong community
-Good job security
- They hire from within before outside, and there are always opportunities to move laterally. Which is encouraged every 3-5 years or so. 
- Many employee resource groups and support programs. 
- lots of networking opportunities. 
- If you want to gain a certain skill or a certain license, management is usually pretty good at finding a way to let you grow skills, even if that means you will leave your current team. Again, they are big on lateral moves.
- A much more relaxed environment compared to other high-stress brokerage firms.
View7:
- Depending on your position you can be working very long hours. ( Ie Tax season or "giving season" will have you working 8 am-8 pm)
- The pay is lower compared to other brokerage firms. 
- Pay is dependent on seniority, not ability. It's incredibly frustrating to be a top performer in a team, but know you make significantly less than a senior team member, who does not perform well. ( you will get raises but you won't be lifted up to the pay level of a person who has been there for 20 years and has grown complacent) The best way to get raises quickly is through lateral movement and negoation. 
- It is very difficult to get a management position, simply because the company is so big, there is always a large pool of applicants to compete against. 
- Many times when people leave, instead of hiring a new person, they pile that job on an existing team member, but will not raise that team member's pay. Just the expectations. 
- The quality of your manager makes a big difference in your experience. Sadly good managers get promoted and move on to better things, and then a novice is sent to replace them. Great for the managers, bad for the senior team members.

Title: Great for entry level, not if you have actual experience
View5: If you’re getting into the industry and can’t find anyone to hire you this is a great place to start. They at least offer benefits and a salary. The sales training is good and you’ll be exposed to HNW and UHNW clients to take with you when you leave in 2-3 years.
View7: Constant micromanagement around numbers. Calls, appointments, plans, sales pitches, etc.  They say that you are running your own practice but watch every move you make and tell you how to interact with customers.  When I tell other actual advisors what Fidelity does they think it’s criminal, they’re selling cheeseburgers and calling it steak. They want to be the largest RIA in the country but this isn’t it.  The investment management arm of the company (Strategic Advisors) is the RIA. This job is trying to use their watered down planning software to convince customers to buy managed products.  FCs are encouraged (read: compensated) to send the relationship to strategic advisors when it’s closed. This is nothing like a real RIA, trust me I’ve worked at two boutiques. Look no further than the WAS program, where FCs refer clients to actual financial advisors and boutiques. The longest tenured FC in my office was about 3-4 years. Some advice for job seekers, this should be your last option, try to get on with a real RIA first.

Title: Decent
View5: Great benefits, decent pay, work/life balance
View7: Too much emphasis on hiring managers with soft skills, not enough emphasis on hiring management/leadership with actual experience in the department they're managing.

Title: Good place to start

View7: You can get an increase in pay and job quickly but you do hit a ceiling at a certain point

* Slow to lay out concrete details for return to office

Title: It’s all about the metrics
View5: Nice people, good training, good benefits
View7: No matter how much they romanticize making a connection with clients, what truly matters in this role always comes back to metrics. If they can’t measure it, it doesn’t count, and you’re only as good as your metrics say. It’s relentless and offers little autonomy and a ton of scrutiny and micromanagement. If that’s not your thing, this isn’t your place.

Title: Very stressful
View5: They train you Health insurance starts day one
View7: The management hovers over you Micromanaged to the point they might as well take the call themselves Cared more about numbers of call than the quality of the call They time your lunch break and bathroom breaks to the minute and ‘ding’ you if you are a minute off the phones Staff are nervous to even go to the bathroom when needed!

Title: WPC
View5:
- Decent pay
- Good benefits (very long vesting schedule for some)
- Pay for training/licensing, although Fidelity does have a big problem of reps leaving after being paid to obtain the licenses
- They are currently promoting reps very quickly through the WPA department
View7:
- Taking phone calls all day long (the majority I had would message you within 5 minutes of not being on the phone, but that could help obviously vary with locations/managers)

- Very high turnover. My team had 5 different managers within 6 months. Reps also leave very quickly to get off the phones. The company really has a plan in place to make their reps stay in the call center as long as possible. Bonus payments are structured to make you feel like it is just close enough to stay for a little while longer. Also a year requirement of work after you obtain your licenses before you can move to a branch role (which are very competitive, and typically are outside hires anyways)

- Extremely sales oriented, but a lot of the clients think we are service. Be prepared for awkward calls where you and the client have completely separate agendas. Instead of servicing the clients need and moving on to help the next, the company would rather you run them through their retirement tools. These tools can be beneficial in some instances, but they are extremely general and many of these clients have recognized that they don’t help much. Seems the department is only here to promote these tools. Only goal on every single call is to take the clients need, acknowledge it while basically ignoring it, run them through the retirement tools so we can gather outside assets, and then set an appointment with a branch so they can move those to Fidelity.

I understand there are plenty of roles similar to this, the only difference is that a lot of the hiring managers at Fidelity do not warn you of this. Multiple reps on my team and I had this same experience.

Overall, this role and the constant phone calls will exhaust you. I would recommend looking elsewhere first if your goal is to get into financial advising. If necessary, this can be a decent role in the short-term.

Title: Awesome company!!
View5: I’ve been here for almost a year and waited until I had “seen it all” to post a review. Fidelity really cares for their employees, what they say is VERY true. We get bonuses on top of bonuses just by working and doing what we’re supposed to be doing. Amazing PTOs about 23 days for all associates that have been here for less than 2 years. Amazing health, dental, vision etc etc the standard basic benefits but what really got me was how much they invest in you as an associate. I’m truly blessed to work for such a great organization!
View7: Micromanaging can be a problem however, as to be expected if you are on a phone role. May feel like you are “stuck” and stagnant at a role but in the mean time I am seeing lots of employment opportunities to move around. It may take a bit longer for you to move around and the pay may be below average for the same job elsewhere but the benefits package are for sure to be top notch all around.

Title: Fidelity Will Ruin Your IT Career With a Smile
View5: The benefits package is above average.
View7:
Fidelity will destroy an IT carrier.  

They will work you to death on out date tech that won't do you any good outside their doors.  

Manager's are immune to repercussions for their actions. While employees are expected to follow very high standards of conduct.  Discrimination of all forms is common and well accepted by HR.

If you are going to work for Fidelity make sure you fall into a category of person your manager likes, or they will destroy you with the full support of the HR department. 

You also better make sure you don't have kids to take care of, or turn 40.  I worked there for a decade and no one ever retired by choice.

Title: Best place I've ever worked
View5: Benefits, pay, schedule, culture, management are head and shoulders above any other financial firm I have worked for in the past. The job is incredibly reasonable and the pay is significantly above competition. If you can get a job offer from fidelity and you are working for another BD just take it. Upward mobility is real and they push it. If you are happy in your role you can stay in it without absurd changes in metrics. The company is solely customer centric so if you make a suggestion that makes the life of the client better that comes before profits.
View7: I work fully remote so you do miss some human interaction but that is a downside of any fully remote job.

- There is a massive variety of calls you may receive, which can leave you juggling a client, researching a solution and reaching out to other departments to find a solution.

Title: High stress
View5: Good pay and benefits are provided.
View7: Almost every metric imaginable is tracked. This is an extremely stressful work environment with no down time. The extra money I receive from this company is offset by medical expenses to manage my anxiety and depression I’ve developed since working here. You will be continually told that relief is coming in the form of more employees, but for three years this has yet to happen to counteract turnover. If you want to take 6-8 phone calls an hour, be insulted daily by clients, work mandatory overtime, and develop crippling mental health issues, this is the company for you.

Title: Very Corporate
View5:
Work life balance
Pay/benefits 
Paid time off
Great 401k match and profit sharing 
Decent resources for training and development
View7:
Can be substantial micro management from the branch leaders in the investor centers. 

Investor centers always seem to be understaffed creating a strain on other roles. High turnover. 

Substantial concentration on metrics that drive your performance bonus with no consideration that some roles get wrapped up in service when their role responsibility doesn’t not include service and their main metrics don’t credit any service work.

No real autonomy to follow your own planning process. Their process is all by their book which can sometimes feel non genuine when working with clients.

Title: Unrelenting Work Environment
View5: Many very talented colleagues and depending on where you work you get to do very interesting work. Internal information and learning resources are great.
View7: A ceaseless grind. Nervous, risk-averse, fear driven work environment. Restructuring and layoffs were constant. Success is entirely in the hands of your direct manager, so while it depends on who your manager is, largely the culture reinforces doing what the boss says and being very cautious about expressing any alternate perspectives. Many people have been there for years and the inside club can be defensive of their turf. You are encouraged to not think of compensation and instead the 'total value' of the package, but never-the-less, I found overall pay to be below market.

Title: Management only cares about metrics and fails to look at bigger picture.
View5: -401k match -Tuition reimbursement -decent work-life balance -trauma bonds built with coworkers forged friendships that will last a lifetime
View7:
-Very political environment with lots of nepotism. This allowed many undeserving and incapable people to become management.

-True competence and hard work was noticed by managers, but rarely actually rewarded. Only numbers were considered important, and these metrics were easy to manipulate if the employees lacked integrity. If you wanted to succeed, you had to be prepared to cheat in one way or another.

-Complete lack of mobility between departments. Many employees joined the company because they were told that it was possible to transition to analyst work. When they became eligible to move departments, they were mysteriously kept in customer service (even if they worked very hard and networked well in order to be able to leave).

-Constant changes that made your job more difficult without any additional pay or thanks. This was a never ending flow of additional responsibilities handed to us.

Title: Bias work environment
View5: Amazing insurance and time off benefits , managers are great to work with, employees are nice and friendly
View7: My biggest con is around covid and others may see it as a plus. However, “equal opportunity employer” is not true. If you’re vaccinated, you get extra time off the phones, free lunches in the office, development opportunities not given to those not allowed to go into the office. Whether you have medical reasons or not to not get the vaccine. It doesn’t matter to them, you will be treated less than equal which does impact career development because you don’t have the same opportunities given to those who are vaccinated.

Title: Enjoyed my 21 years, left at the right time.
View5: Good Technology and tools, Brand Name. Good benefits.
View7: Behind the curve at times with products offerings. Hiring based on diversity, not quality of applicant.

Title: Better than the service industry, but still service
View5: Lots of assistance offered to get you licensed (SIE, series 7, series 63). Inclusive culture is pushed (don't expect everyone to be that way, but at least they try to make it welcoming). Better than minimum wage. Opportunities for growth.
View7: UNDERPAID! This role requires you to live within 100 miles of Fidelity, yet they do not pay enough for a person to afford to actually live by themselves near Fidelity which is absolutely shameful. It is like being in a minimum wage job except with better pay (though, like I said, still underpaid). You get limited breaks, you are expected to clock in ten minutes early each day, it can be difficult to use your PTO. The customer's rate us on a 7 point scale, but the only acceptable score is 7 points. If you get rated a 6, that is considered failing. This role is very challenging and directly customer facing. There is a lot of pressure because you are dealing with customer's money. Fidelity throws you right into it, I did not feel ready to be moving money for customer's on my own but you just gotta do it. It is great that they sponsor you through the licensing process, but it is really easy to get burned out by their pace. Then, if you fail, prepare to be "let go." It is a FINRA rule that licensed employees cannot work from home full time without an exception process that Fidelity is not interested in participating in (it would require them to inspect your home office so I can't blame them for not wanting to do that). We can WFH right now, but will be forced to go in at least part time once it is deemed safe. Fidelity is really pushing for people to return to the office, lots of pressure to participate in "connect weeks" which is where you volunteer to go back to the office. They send you a lot of free stuff but most of it is junk. Like cheapy backpacks/mugs/merch you didn't ask for. I am putting this as a con because even though it is nice to receive free things and in the moment it gets you feeling part of the group, this practice has to stop. It is not good for the planet to keep producing useless junk.

Title: Great Company for the Ambitious and Energetic
View5:
Lots of pros! The pay, the perks, and the people are all great. Fidelity has tried really hard to support employees during COVID, through extra paid leave specifically coronavirus-related, counselor-finding services, fun activities and food provided for people who are willing to come back into the office part time during virus lulls.

Fidelity is also working hard on diversity-and-inclusion, and on making sure employees' voices are heard from the ground up. The company supports outside volunteer efforts and onsite environmental initiatives. You can feel good about working for a company that wants to do good, not just do well.
View7:
Most people are hired into Fidelity at this position. It's a pretty rigorous process, from submitting the application through multiple interviews. Once you're hired, there are two potential hurdles: first in learning the job then in doing the job.

Oh, the learning process! Even entirely online as it has been since the pandemic, it's kind of fun. There are get-to-know-you activities with your newbie group. But there is also a LOT of information to absorb, and it doesn't let up for months. First you learn the Fidelity systems, then you go through licensing training. You must pass the licensing exams to advance within the company. From hire, this all could take 4-6 months. Yes, they pay you the whole time. Once you're licensed, you alternate more Fidelity-specific classes with actual customer support for a few more months before you settle into full time on the phones. After a few more months of that, you may start applying within the company for new skills and new roles, your options being more self-directed.

So, the cons: the pace of learning is set to warp speed, be prepared! Realize that while you're learning you cost the company quite a bit. It's a lot of stress, but they'll want to push you as fast as they can get you to go. And once you're on the job, well, it depends. Some people like inbound phone customer service, or at least don't mind it. Fidelity customers are usually quite pleasant really. But especially in the busy months, from maybe November through tax season, they can spend more time on hold than they like, which makes them cranky. There will be constant pressure from Fidelity for you to make each call as brief as possible: they will measure both your customer satisfaction stats AND your calls per hour. It can be hard to balance the one against the other. And, this is the job: call after call after call. There are breaks, of course, from weekly team meetings to personal lunch and break time to refresher education. If you can continue in the inbound phones roles long enough, you can eventually get promoted out of it if you choose: perhaps 1-5 years, generally?

Title: Overall Excellent Company

View7:
-Does not sponsor you for licensing unless you are in a role that requires it.

Overall most of the cons can be applied to any big corporate organization.

-Job growth and ability to be promoted within is definitely there, but I have seen some people become stuck in their roles if they stay too long or do not develop skills to move onto the next position. 
- In addition, moving up to management can take quite a while. I have seen it happen within the company, but a large number (especially an overwhelming number of upper-level management) either left the company and came back or were recruited externally. However, this is something that can be seen in almost any company you go to. 

- From the above my experience with management has been great, but I know on some high-intensity teams (such as sales or fund management) can have more stressful managers, but I have not heard anything terrible to note.

It’s a tough job and for those who apply and can make it good for you. I lasted five years and left once I was fully vested.

Title: Tech divisions lag the market in tooling, processes, comp, management, leadership, dev experience.
View5: The benefits packages are fully-featured and health insurance is affordable. The best perk of Fidelity is the 7% 401k match and the 10% annual profit sharing; 17% contributions to your 401k overall each year. The work/life balance ends up being very reasonable - it would be uncommon to work a 45-hour workweek more than a few times a year. 40 hours is the very common norm.
View7:
Fidelity does not use public cloud, which has many negative side-effects; they attempt to replicate that experience with older, internal tooling which dramatically slows developer velocity. For example, engineer's ability to access compute resources is blocked by request processes. Libraries are all subject to a security review which can take a small number of weeks if requested with priority, or many weeks without. Licenses are purchased by a remote requisitions team with a similarly slow resolution timeframe. Releases are produced manually, there is no continuous deployment. 

There is no universal devops/platform team, squads maintain their own services. 
This self-sufficiency produces isolation, practically and socially; process standards and tooling varies a fair amount between them. There is no architecture team or unified technical leadership group. Each squad has their own tech lead and that's it.

Pay for engineers lags the market, targeting approximately 80-100% of the market rate. There is no option to acquire equity. "Chairman shares" are offered to top performers, but those are simply 2-year vesting cash bonus - not actual equity. Anecdotally, the very talented engineers remain due to not knowing their own market value. 

The manager-to-report ratio can vary wildly, 50+:1 in some cases, offering virtually no manager facetime or development opportunities to members of those squads. The daily routine of managers and directors is primarily comprised of liaising with customers (other business units) rather than anything related to developing their engineering teams.

Because the tech groups service internal business units, customer requirements are often poorly defined, change frequently and are conveyed verbally to product managers over calls. Oftentimes a change will be reverted due to a customer's whim, not the functionality of the feature itself.

Leadership is adamant about working from the office and will not support remote work post-covid.

Leadership has frequent messaging about undergoing an agile transformation, yet none of the shortcomings described here are eligible for reevaluation. The remaining set of factors that can be changed are virtually meaningless in impact.

Talented top-level leadership want to lead other business units which are revenue centers (all are financial business units) rather than cost centers, so the tech groups end up with a steady rotation of SVPs (the head of the tech group, equivalent to a CEO elsewhere) every 1-2 years. 

In short, the engineer experience at Fidelity is stable, yet slow, uninspiring, and poorly-compensated when compared to the broader market.

Title: Unhealthy environment
View5: The people, the benefits are great
View7: The higher the leadership closest to the top, the more close minded and attached to old school culture they are, trying to force everyone into outdated thinking.  They will also lure you into new roles and lock you down without being honest about what the role really is.  You get “used” as a vessel to push upper leadership personal motivations and accolades, while slowly being quieted down and eventually silenced.  .  It’s just a bunch of senior leaders trying to outshine each other and get their name on something even if it’s not best for the employees.  Will get overwhelming associate feedback in surveys about wanting to work remote and will only tell you about the one comment from someone who wants to be in the office and then try to gaslight you into believing it’s the majority opinion.  Leadership will “threaten” that you’re luck the President is giving you any flexibility because she would prefer not to and force you to give up all of your flexibility if you don’t agree to work in the office sometimes.  Kind of like “ you’re lucky to get anything.  Don’t push your luck or she will take all your toys away.  The culture was going in an amazing direction the past couple of years.  But in a very short time it’s gone backwards and more toxic than it’s ever been.

Title: Data scientists go elsewhere
View5: It pays well and the benefits are good.  There are women in leadership positions.  For tech people at least, fairly flexible.
View7:
Oh where to start.  I worked in Fidelity labs.

The so called culture of "speaking frankly" and "taking risks" is 100% a lie.  You can speak as frankly as you want as long as you're saying what your manager wants to hear.   You cannot innovate.  My manager incorrectly considered himself an expert in the fields of every person on his team and never accepted any opposing views.   All the data scientists on my team quit.  No one reached out to us.  Nobody cared.  Take this warning seriously.

It’s an embarrassment of riches — I’ve never seen a company with this much money invested in duplicative teams and makes things more territorial and political then necessary
