Title: Benefits are the only reason I’m there
View5: You won’t find a company with better benefits. We had an unprecedented busy year and the job sucked more than usual. The company responded with doing an overtime incentive program where you could earn not only time and half, but another $25 per hour on top. In addition, they are rolling out another bonus, on top of the performative bonus we already have, for those who simply passed their license exams within a certain time frame of their hire date. In addition, we get 18 days of PTO, paid holidays, and this year, we got 40 hours of COVID Relief Time.
View7: The job itself is not fun and can be stressful. When we were busy, we would deal with angry clients every single call, and take about 4-6 calls and hour for 8 straight hours. It gets tiring and extremely repetitive. I also personally do not like staring at a screen for that long.

Title: Several Things To Consider
View5: There are several things to consider when start a job at Fidelity. The optimal situation is when you’re earlier in you’re career. Fidelity will help develop and manage career for the long term. Great benefits and retirement package (except the 5 year vesting requirement on 401k).
View7: Fidelity isn’t the best option for mid or late career scenarios. The pay isn’t as competitive and promotions are based on bureaucracy and not efforts. Work life balance is horrible in technical areas (80 to 90 hours a week is not uncommon), the on-call competition is below the industry standard and cell phone reimbursement is garbage. There is a passive aggressive expectation to work long long hours but take time off. The internal application process for careers is insulting and garbage. There are employees who applied for 100’s of jobs with no response or feedback.

Title: Fidelity Investments
View5: They're flexible with scheduling if you have a life circumstance that justifies it. Decent pay, they raise salary slowly based on the current economy. Hasn't changed much for this role in the last 15 years from what I have seen. Good benefits for people with families and medical expenses.
View7: I went through the hiring process three years ago with about 30 people. A bunch left during the first year. I've interviewed several times with a 20 to 1 ratio for applicants vs. positions offered. Everyone that stayed made a lateral move within the company. They changed positions but didn't get a bump in pay. A lot of promises and motivational meetings are given on career mobility, but most can't move anywhere easily. Climbing the ladder takes years. For most, it takes a lot of education, experience, and exceptional stats. I saw a guy with a CFP, 3 years of financial advisement experience, a degree in finance, and excellent testing/current role scores lose a job to a woman with 1-year furniture sales experience. He couldn't move out for a long time. I've seen that happen to several people where the promotions were not fair based on diversity hiring. Qualified people get passed up frequently for diverse applicants. I worked with several people that had multiple years of financial experience and a few that had MBA's that didn't move any easier than people in their 2nd year of college. Experience/education/certifications don't help very much. Lots of people apply for every job. If you're not at the top of performance, experience, diversity, education, and in some cases popularity, you don't have a great shot at moving around here.

Title: Pretty good company

Title: They’ve been pretty good to me.
View5:
7% 1:1 company match on base plus bonuses. Contribute up to 50% of bonus to 401k & they will match up to 7% 1:1 there too.

Tuition reimbursement 90% if you pass your classes with a C. Masters degrees converged at 10k per year if you major in a relevant field.

Flexible time off without fear of reprisals.
Stay employed even in lean economic markets. 
Fathers get 3 months of parental leave for new borns.
Adoption services.
Concierge services for those who want to plan that special date or marriage proposal.

Paid child care by the firm on days they need you if come in if another sight is snowed by request. Discounts on other days at approved sites.

Night time Differential pay at 5% for folks who work past 6 PM. That increases to 20% for those who work past 8 PM of your eligible based compensation per hour. 

Christmas bonuses 2 to 3 times every five years. Usually 1 pay period awarded. There have been other types of incentive pay depending on call volume to encourage us to not cancel auto OT when applied awarded in cash, stock grants, one day off, Fidelity cash for merchandise, etc.

No weekend requirements for those supporting workplace roles. Personal investments roles may have weekend hours depending on the job.

More Telework is available due to Covid19.

Real career development exit here. Some managers are better at this than others. I’ve always felt that they’re pushing me to take up the next challenge. Even at times when I wasn’t ready to move up or just getting complacent.

Fun stuff at call centers. Choose any of these clubs: Women in Leadership, Aspire, FidVets, FinTech, President Circle, Leadership Summit, etc... they always have something going on for you to network and use to move on up. It’s up to you to hustle and play the game.

Pre Covid19 we had hot air balloon rides, dragon boat competitions, BBall breaks, volleyball teams, zombie nights for Halloween, BBQ competitions, ice cream socials, team outings, camping trips, visiting chefs at some sights, team potlucks, free food and I’m talking about the good stuff NOT pizza. You can definitely gain major weight at certain sites.

No worries because some sites have a full service gym w/ personal trainers, classes, and nutritionists.

 At Our sites we got the choice to take a walk and discuss our development plans or monthly business results around one of the many nature trails.
View7:
Bonus metrics change a lot.

Managers depending on the site location change a lot in the call centers for sure.
 
Will push you hard to keep up with the ever changing metrics in order to stay relevant if you want to get promoted. Only to hire a guy off the street to the branch with 6 months of car sales experience, no degrees in the field, and has to still get his S7 & 63.

You have a better chance of jumping a few slots to get to where you want if you work at Fidelity for 1-3 years. Quit; then work elsewhere for 1-2 years only to come back to Fidelity.

Serious issues at to many of the branches when it comes to hiring women, professionals with ascents, or they may serve in locations with above average demographics or immigrants without one person in the branch that can speak their language. These folks tend to have small to midsize size businesses. They horde cash and don’t have someone they trust to reach out to them. However, executive management is aware and working on making the hiring process better. I can tell that change is happening. It’s not HQ more so the mindset of the financial industry at the local levels. 

Management feedback for the interview process can be largely lackluster. Heard from other top performers that the feed back was non existent or borderline suspect. Being told to smile more during the interview or joke more at team meetings is NOT productive feedback for a job interview. Especially when they seem to selectively provide this to certain “types.”

Healthcare plan is average. Family plan is 3k high deductible. They do give you $1500 per year to your HSA to offset that high @-&:?:?’ Plan. Prescription med and co pays prices were higher for me than my previous employer.

Pay is actually lower than the national average for a license professional.

View7: Drink that koolaid or else you won't last. This is an absolutely miserable job, manager was completely incompetent and was an absolute joke to watch her interact with other leads. Denied first time off request after 5 months of working. You're not going any where, once your're on the phones there is absolutely no movement. The internal technology is from the 1980s. I would never hold my money at this place and no one ever should. Fidelity definitely writes their own ratings because there is simply no way people give them such good feedback. The training program is actually horrible in covid conditions, if you need extra help good luck in a zoom class of 300 people. If you're a college grad and think this sounds like a good start, simply don't do it, you will have your soul sucked out of you 6 months into your career.

Title: Nepotism, Lies, Onliviusness
View5:
COVID so people could wfh because it’s a waste of company resources to have office space for a job everyone’s doing just fine at home. 

There’s a lot of really kind and good people at the company. They’re the one thing that makes it good. This is specific to lower level employees, not any form of leadership.
View7:
I wouldn’t know where to start. 

Abby Johnson attempting to create the cult called Fidelity is failing and outflow at the firm is coming. They’re anti-fiduciary approach will cost them majorly with the CFP Board.

 They take no feedback from employees with knowledge of this and other things that are unethical and would violate even Reg BI.

Recruiters will tell you that unless you have a CFA Level I upon graduation from an Ivy League school , or you can never be an analyst. After LinkedIn review this is not true, and I cross referenced who didn’t qualify for those “standards” I found those not from Ivy League had some nepotism within the company, generally at a VP or higher level 

This east coast bias here is incredible. Call centers everywhere else-with about 1/5 the pay of anyone in Massachusetts. 

I don’t recommend this firm to anyone. They’ll preach a holistic happy fun approach- the reality is nothing close. 

Abby Johnson just because you were born into the most successful mutual fund company- does not mean anyone should worship you the way it’s demanded from the top down. It’s actually pretty pathetic you feel the need to plaster your own quotes and face everywhere. 

Best of luck to all those who dare enter these jobs. Congratulations to those who’s dad bought them an Ivy League education and nepotistically raised the wealth differential in this country. Fidelity is the epitome.

Title: Will keep employees as temp workers for years
View5: A lot of company parties, lunches, etc. The schedule can be flexible for college students. Big Christmas party at the end of the year.
View7: They like to pretend like it's a friendly and great work environment; however, there is a lot of micromanagement and very few opportunities to advance. The work environment is not culturally inclusive and temporary employees are treated poorly. Temporary workers are expected to do the same job if not more than full-time employees and are told if they continue to do their job well, they will get hired on. Management will activily encourage you to apply for new permanent positions, only to hire a friend or family member from outside of the company. Permanent employees are giving annual bonuses every year, sometimes double for performing great that year, while the temporary employees, whom worked beside them the whole year gets nothing but maybe a free lunch. Their hiring process, specifically in the Covington location is severly flawed and unfair to the people who believe they will eventually get hired after working their for several years.

Title: Fantastic Company
View5:
Fidelity has amazing benefits - 10% profit sharing after 1 year at the company, 18 days PTO for new hires, 7% 401k match with five year vesting, low-deductible health insurance coverage, maternity and paternity leave. They are a very generous company, and they give employees great work-life balance. You will only bump into more financial benefits the more you work there. 

The company is also genuinely high integrity. They structure their company with customer obsession as the main goal. I enjoy making clients happy, and I go to bed feeling good about my work at night.
View7: Fidelity is a good company for someone wanting a corporate job. If someone is extremely entrepreneurial, they will probably feel somewhat trapped or undervalued at Fidelity. Fidelity has a process they want employees to follow, and sticking to their process is key to long-term success.

Title: Less Than Ideal
View5: - Good pay - No micromanagement - Learning days - Encouraged to move within company
View7:
The LEAP program has been terrible. It is essentially 4 more months of college after you graduate. Lots of hand-holding and forced classroom-style learning. Instructor-led training is mostly a waste of time here.

High chance that you will be working with an outdated tech stack after LEAP. You may also be placed into an unfavorable role with little to no technical mentorship and with minimal transferrable skills. They will try to tell you that Fidelity is a "tech company that does finance" but this is not the case.

In short, not a great place for new software engineers. If you have another offer, I would highly recommended considering working elsewhere

Title: Where college degrees die and anxiety is born.
View5:
Generous 401k match
Reasonably priced insurance
Flexible PTO
Positive company culture/values
They hire pleasant people
So many perks and benefits I literally cant fit it all on here.
View7:
Ever ask yourself "How can I simultaneously destroy my career prospects and waste my expensive college degree?" Well then , Fidelity Investments in Jacksonville has the perfect job for you! 

First, it's a call center people...through and through. You will talk to dozens of people on the phone. Every...single...day. Eventually, that "ding!" sound of a new call coming in will haunt your dreams. Most people don't last more than a year. You can either go the sales or service route. If you go service, there is very little room for advancement. In addition, if you move into whats called a "High Net Worth" service role, you will be responsible for a HUGE range of knowledge and actions without commensurate pay. One call could have you rushing to get a complex option trade placed within minutes of market close, while a pushy day trader berates you, and the next call could be spending an hour helping a 90 year old man reset his password as you bang your head on you desk asking "I went to college for this?!" If you go sales, then get used to working long, awkward hours and having your success defined in how many more calls you can take than the next guy/gal. 

The coupe de grace (ATTENTION ALL RECENT COLLEGE GRADS): None of the jobs they offer in Jacksonville are real finance jobs. They're just customer service/sales jobs parading as something fancier. Even the "Financial Advisor" roles are just sales, albeit well paying. Also, call center jobs are only marketable to other customer service careers. Having a call center job on your resume will actually HARM your chances of landing a job in world of ACTUAL finance. So, before you go thinking "I'll just work here for a year or two to get something on my resume"....DON'T DO IT.

None of what I just said should reflect poorly on the company itself, because Fidelity is a great company in terms of culture, mission, and values. That's undeniable. The problem is very specific to the extent of their operations in Jacksonville being call center based and that these are very stressful and career-limiting work environments. Consider yourself warned!

Title: Fidelity Clients with $10MM waited for 50-200 minutes to speak to me and were never in a good mood
View5: I got paid on time
View7:
This is, despite the description, a hard core call center job. But, because its Fidelity, the clients wait for 50-200 minutes or more to speak with you, they are, as you would expect, not happy by the time you speak with them. (These are the clients filling out your survey, and only PERFECT surveys count). The queue of clients to speak to is endless. Over time the bad attitudes and angry people yelling at me wore me down and I lost 15 lbs, because skinny anxious and depressed, and essentially sacrificed my personal self to chase my professional goal to move to a different job where the clients don't wait as long. However, the rhetoric and promise of changing jobs, the date keeps getting pushed back. Now they are refusing to do internal promotions, due to the egregious client hold times. This is a LOSING TEAM. Go join a winning team. 

If you don't live there already, you have to move to the city to WFH

No real team atmosphere

Clients yelling at you and disrespecting you.

In the words of management "this is the bottom of the company"

In the words of my former manager "this is the hardest year at the company, and this is the worst version of the hardest year at the company ever"

Except, this year is different, because the company is literally NOT PROMOTING the loyal employees who worked through the hell of December-March.

If you call Fidelity this upcoming December 2021, you will experience an unacceptable hold time of at least 70 minutes, and you will work with someone brand new and incompetent.

Since I joined, my class of 30 people, about 14 have quit or been fired for yelling back at clients, or failing their Finra exams.

Again, I cannot emphasize enough, this is a LOSING TEAM and the teflon-covered management give you lip-service about the future getting better, yet the carrot gets pushed farther and farther away.

Even in this terrible environment, when my peers got only 40% "perfect surveys" my record month was 91%.

I have been asking for help since January to get into a different role that fits my background and skillset.
Now, I have other companies offering me jobs that pay more than 2x the $48,000 at Fidelity.

BYEEEEEEEEEE

Title: Customer Relationship Advocate
View5: Outstanding benefits package. Very positive corporate culture.
View7:
Ever ask yourself  "How can I waste my finance degree AND make myself less marketable at the same time?" Well, have I got a job for you! Sarcasm aside, let's just be brutally honest here. COLLEGE STUDENTS/GRADS PAY ATTENTION!!! Unless you plan to become an advisor (cough...salesman), most of the jobs you will find in the world of personal investments/brokerage services are going to be a CALL CENTER JOB! This is just the nature of the beast, yet something that your career counselor at college probably wont tell you. Call center experience is only a marketable skill to more customer service jobs.  I have worked at Fidelity for several years and can honestly say that I feel I have wasted years of my life doing something I have grown to absolutely despise. Dealing with customers on the phone is a life-draining experience. So let's bring it back to Fidelity, shall we? Would you like a real-life sample of what your job will consist of as a "Financial Representative" or "Customer Advocate" at Fidelity? Well, say no more!:

8:00 a.m. - Distribution check request.
8:10 a.m. - Hour long password reset with 90 year old client. (College degree hard at work!)
9:10 a.m. - Distribution check request.
10:10 a.m. - Help client find tax form online. 
10:15 a.m. - Why wont my debit card work?
10:25 a.m. - Why wont my credit card work?
10:35 a.m. - Complex multi-leg option trade.
10:45 a.m. - 30 minute password reset with 80 year old client. ( I went to college for this?)

Now rinse and repeat this for 30 calls a day, day in and day out. Not exactly what you pictured yourself doing with that shiny, expensive college education, is it?
Look...I could go on and on about other details of the job (particularly the wacked-out survey questionnaire Fidelity bases a large portion of your bonus on) but I'll leave that for some other disenchanted soul. Here is the bottom line...if you want to do sales, that is great for you and you will find many career opportunities at any brokerage firm, including Fidelity, and you will make a great living doing so. However, if sales is not your thing then I highly suggest you look elsewhere.

Title: The definition of Gamification of the workplace.
View5: Do not need any investment knowledge.  Can be promoted simply due to "needs of the business".  If able to stick around for 5+ years, will be able to keep the 7% 401k matching and 10% yearly profit-sharing payout.  Great for recent college grads who have not developed professional workplace habits.  VERY hands on approaching to coaching and development; multiple people always providing career advice.
View7: Some of the lowest pay in the industry.  Previous experience is not respected once hired on; only benefits prior to being hired when qualifying for roles.  Micromanaged down to the smallest detail.  As the title of the review says, gamification of the workplace is in full swing (look it up if unfamiliar; may not be suitable for all individuals).  VERY negative attitude towards competitors.  Upon resignation of the firm all previous connections will instantly dissolve.  Senior management uses smiles and positive speeches to squash any and all critiques/feedback of existing processes.  "On-loan" roles are overused in order to keep from permanently funding very enjoyable roles.  Lower management uses toys (slinkees, pom-poms, hello kitty candy dispensers) to "encourage and motivate" their teams while in the middle of tax seasons.  Overall, very immature and unprofessional work environment.  Attrition is a constant battle that is verbally ignored and spoken against.

Most of these positive reviews are from newbies who are the only ones fidelity invests in. After a couple years, trust me, you'll be begging to get out of their militant and lack of resource style. Managers know nothing about your role, as Fidelity typically hires managers with no knowledge of the role as they believe managers are their to "manage" and not need be experts at the technical aspects of the role. With that said, where do you go for guidance? Glad the police, fire department or pilots aren't hired Fidelity style. Who is the go to contact if your manager doesn't have a clue about the day to day of your job? Being a manager is a great deal at Fido as they have zero accountability and throw you under the bus if need be. I've been there 7 years and have a rockstar performance record, so this review is not in spite, rather it's just reality. Get in, get your license and experience on their dime, get out. Was a great employer years gone by, but as Ned once said "Our employees are our biggest asset" has not been heard in years and years. They burn you out, WANTING turnover, just to hire somebody for half your salary.

are surprisingly backwards.

Title: Great company with pockets of terrible management.
View5:
Great benefits for employees. Salary+Bonus+Annual Profit Share+7% dollar-to-dollar 401k match.
Contractors treated well in most groups. (I have been contracting the last few years)
Durham NC location is pretty casual. Business casual dress with jeans on Friday. Relationships with management have always been casual side.
Some groups work with offshore resources and get to travel to other countries.
Some groups are in flexible work arrangement situations. Some people work from home much of the time. Even in other groups, you generally can work from home if needed for personal reasons from time to time.
View7:
Base salaries can be very low, especially when you get promoted to the next level.
Some groups work in crowded arrangements because leadership will not support any official work from home arrangements.
Lack of oversight on Directors and Vice Presidents with direct reports. A bad apple can really tear a department apart. 
Review process is not individual. People are stack ranked and there are quotas on high ratings. Even if you have 2 star performers, only 1 can receive the most excellent rating. The process is truly not individualized.
People provide reviews for employees they have had very little interaction with. Can get very personal.
You will have to change departments to earn more money as annual merit increases are often nominal.
Your career is in your hands here. You can not depend on any management or HR group to help guide you in advancing your career.

Title: Not What I Expected
View5: The pay and benefits are great for the Albuquerque area, they also offer some amazing perks to inspire you to make choices.
View7:
Fidelity does not practice what it preaches.. You are told when you are hired and during training that customer service and advocating for the customer is the main goal.  That you should "own the call". However as soon as you are on the phones, you are told that once the customer is handed off to what ever dept ,  you should not be involved anymore, that you should not make too many outbound calls to the customers because we are an inbound call center , I do not consider this owning anything.  The procedures and resources are time consuming and cumbersome.  Your computer is prone to freezing when you are in the middle of a call because of all of the resources you have to have up,  and yet you can not say anything about your computer not working properly. 
  Fidelity has compassion as part of it's mission statement , yet most of the procedures could not possibly show less compassion for the customer if they tried.  In short I feel like I was lied to about the position I was hired for.   
   Management shows favoritism as well as cliquishness, and though everyone appears to be friendly it is surface only.  You never know what management expects or what they are in charge of  because it changes constantly.

Title: Just okay
View5: I love my coworkers, they are truly nice people to work with. Fidelity has excellent benefits - medical, dental, 401k with 7% percent match (though you have to be there a year to get match and work 5 years to be vested), quarterly bonuses on performance and profit sharing. I truly love Fidelity and what they stand for. I just hate the role I'm in.
View7: The role just sucks, especially if you work nights because they never hire enough people to work late nights so people can wait up to 10 minutes just for a password reset! It's a call center so it's constantly taking call after call and people can be too needy or hostile because they can't treat their retirement account like an ATM. You have to be in the role for at least a year to even be considered for other roles though it will just be another job on the phone all day. Also your calls are graded all the time and depending on your manager... it's a miracle if you do anything right on a call. Some people call in to get a balance and just because you didn't get the persons life story doesn't mean the call was "inconsistent". Metrics are so whack.

Title: Positive, fun and challenging
View5: I would say that the best part of working at Fidelity are the benefits and the culture. The benefits are unmatched for New Hampshire (I would imagine the same for Florida, Kentucky, Ohio, Colorado and Utah but I'm not 100% certain). The culture is awesome. Lots of positive people and I've definitely gotten my share of great managers that like to promote within. I believe that management culture does trickle down and inspire new and up-and-coming managers. Being positive at this company will certainly get your far. I tend to be a naturally positive person who is extremely driven. That speaks volumes.
View7: It's stressful at times. The pay could be a little better, but it's not horrible by any means. I still feel like upper management is slightly disconnected to what we have to do vs. industry standards vs. their expectations. Lastly, we have an internal feedback board we can utilize to provide customer as well as coworker feedback, however the time frames from when the research of a project starts to when it completes can be well over 1 year. For a multi-billion dollar company, I'm not sure if that is truly acceptable.

Title: Decent compensation but all advancement is purely political.
View5: Compensation is comparable to other large financial services companies.  Benefits used to be among the best in the industry but that has fallen in recent years.
View7:
In my department advancement, whether in the form of formal promotions or stretch assignments, go only to those with contacts at higher levels.  Midlevel managers routinely tell subordinates that they believe the subordinates deserve advancement but that none is available unless the subordinate can figure out a way for senior managers to take notice.  Senior managers don't believe this is a problem because they see promotions going to the people they know are good.  They are oblivious to how many good people work there that they don't know.  That is because people rise to the top at Fidelity by managing up, not managing down.

There are two types of senior managers.  One is the Fidelity Lifer who understands how to play the game.  Don't try to change anything, don't take any chances, figure out how to not get your finger prints on anything that might fail and know that after 20 years you can retire extremely wealthy.  The other is the short timer who comes in from another company expecting to get things done.  They take chances, they get involved in new projects that take the company in new directions and they are the first to be blamed when things fail.  These people rarely last long.

Title: Portfolio specialist
View5: Great benefits package and a large company so lots of opportunity to grow. You can advance quickly if you have ambition. The retirement benefits alone make it worth it. 10 percent profit sharing...Seven percent 401k match. You can expect to make over 100k as a portfolio specialist which is decent and is truly under 45 hour work week. They are rolling out things like16 weeks paid maternity for women and 6 weeks paid for men. The best thing about the job is you do meet life long friends and work with a ton of amazing people.
View7: They are old fashioned. They don't have a work environment that inspires creativity.They have call models and sales models that they want you to stick to "to make you successful"...they actually focus more on those models than educating about the products they want you to sell...it can sometimes make you feel like a robot and clients pick up on it. They measure performance a lot by things that don't really make business sense and have particular buckets they want you to fill. If you can get past that aspect of the job it can be a nice career.

Title: Fidelity sucks for me, will it for you?
View5: Job security. For the most part it takes a lot to be laid off or fired.  Benefits are good, which include profit sharing, access to HSA/Health Flex accounts, etc.
View7: You won't get any significant raises unless you make it your priority to move departments when you can. This requires you to apply and search for internal jobs constantly, which I have seen work for some people. To sum it up, there is no autonomy in your job. From the start, they want you to buy into the "Fidelity Culture." However, they have the money to spend to be a successful company - at least for the short term. So if you want job security this is the place for you. If you're looking for autonomy in your job and play an active role in the company you work for, I suggest you look elsewhere.

Title: Good Company if You're in the Right Team
View5: Decent Salaries, great bonuses, great benefits, insane 401k matching, and generally fun coworkers. Fidelity tries to figure out what makes their employees happy - for example they recently started helping with student loans which was incredible. Certain teams have great dynamics and click really well with each other. There's a ton of diversity, so you get interesting perspectives from everyone.
View7: They tend to promote people based on who has the loudest mouth.  They also have a streak of hiring incompetent people and then moving them around instead of firing them. There are politics abound in most of the upper management and they try to obfuscate everything from lower employees. It is difficult to move around in Fidelity. I tried several moves, but kept getting blocked so I ended up leaving.

Title: Great benefits but low salary
View5:
You can’t beat the company match on your 401k, profit sharing and the retiree health credit.  Plus if you choose the high deductible health plan they give you 1k towards your HSA.
Other: good nice people/ coworkers. Some work/life flexibility depending upon the job.
View7:
No matter how many times employees tell them that Fidelity pays lower salary than other companies they always say it’s comparative to the current market, and of course they tout all the benefits. For some tenured employees the benefits package keeps them there but younger employees don’t see it that way and just want the base pay.  I was an employee for over 12 years and always felt I was underpaid at the base salary.  They don’t seem interested in retaining hard working, SP rating employees who execute on the work. You have to be a superstar to be recognized.
Other: so many layers of approval to get to any type of decision, lots of group consensus needed.
Career oops: they are all into talking about mobility right now but it seems to be towards more younger employees to keep them engaged.
When jobs are eliminated: it’s almost always people age 40 and above. You can have a department of 80 people and the people getting laid off are always above 40.

Title: Great benefits, but leaders can make it tough for new hires to thrive and grow their careers
View5:
Great and caring people all over the company if you can find them for your network.
Premium health insurance and superior overall benefits.
Employee Resource Groups for connecting with other employees.
Opportunities to volunteer with local charities.
View7:
Pay is lagging and not competitive or calibrated by location (no cost of living increases and most Director level salaries don't change year to year for multiple years).
Meeting-heavy culture...lots and lots of meetings.
Have to wait 1 year to participate in 401K.
Tenured employees (15-20+ year) are mostly unwilling to change or transform the way they work, or be influenced by new thinking.
Career growth is limited for back-office employees and most job requisitions require you to live in the geographical area (TX, NC, or MA) in order to be considered for the job.
Lacking leadership skills at Director level, VP, and above creating a micro-managing culture and toxic work environment. 
HR is passive in giving employee support and really only advocates and acts upon anything for the benefit of the manager and company.
Way too many Executives and layers of management.
Spending or investing via your Fidelity checking and 401K accounts are monitored by your manager.
Year-end bonus and performance evaluations are 100% subjective with manager discretion to give you 0% bonus.
Diversity and Inclusion is not a top priority for Fidelity, although they have taken steps to address some the gaps, but could still do more.

Title: Tenured Associate
View5: Great benefits, coworkers are awesome, if you weren’t a college grad you could have a good job with great benefits and pay. Often in areas where there aren’t many other good jobs. Upper management wants to do the right thing, but often dies in the middle.
View7:
My biggest issue is with middle management. If associates don’t want to go into sales, the only other option is management, which is often not a good fit. You’d have managers who just weren’t “people” people, who would be leading a team of 20+. Managers also have the ability to make or break your career. They control your pay, bonuses, reviews and even promotions. I don’t believe one (possibly inept) person should have control over basically your life. Favoritism runs rampant, which is awesome if you’re a favorite, sucks if you’re not. I had many managers, some who loved me and would mentor and promote me and sing my praises from the rooftop, and then others who gave me very low performance reviews (how is this possible?) 

They’re just SO HUGE with so many different business groups that people wouldn’t know what jobs are out there. Sales or management was all people knew, wish there was more transparency so people who aren’t fit for mgmt wouldn’t go into those roles. Upper management initiates also die at the middle management level due to their inertia and stubbornness.

Title: Highly political
View5: Decent salary. Good benefits. Some coworkers that can share your values about doing big things. A company that prides itself in conservative investing contrasted with technology and first-to-market product and services.
View7: A highly political company with unknown employee measurement and hidden scores. As a senior person in my position you get to know the skill set that is important for your job. When you do outstanding work you soon realize that advancement Is not based on merit but who you are aligned with. A company that is interested more in protecting management with an emphasis on the org chart and less about the work itself. Constant internal battles and intentional reorganizations. An internal employee goal program that ignores how you want to grow as an individual instead focusing on how a manager wants you positioned. If you get a good manager that focuses on the work it can be a wonderful place but soon there will be a reorg and and you will find yourself having to pay more attention to the political back channels and less on your passions and skill set. Politics is extended externally as well with profits spent on preventing governmental "regulation" but internally a love of regulating the employee. Highly protectionist from the top on down. This protectionism even extends to internal technology where systems in place are more about what management wants rather than what the employee needs.

Title: Very corporate culture, great benefits and pay, lots of bloat
View5:
Excellent 401K matching, but you're not fully vested until you hit your five years. Very good pay and benefits. 

Culture depends on the division you're in -- I used to work in Strategic Advisers, Inc. (later rolled up into Asset Allocation) and the majority of the people that I worked with in that group were incredibly nice and smart. I'd heard not-so-great things about some of the other divisions at Fidelity, though, so I counted myself fortunate. Compared to the other floors in my building (245 Summer St), my floor was relatively casual and the floor plan was more open -- large half-cubes instead of the cube farms at the Smithfield, RI campus. Because I worked on a floor with portfolio managers and other members of investment management, we also got nicer drinks in the fridge.

I also had a very kind and nurturing manager and a good team.
View7:
Even within the division that I worked in, there were a few deadweights -- people who had made it to middle management after being at the company for 15+ years and were really just complacent and there for the paycheck. Those people were always a drag to work with; fortunately, I was able to minimize my dealings with them and usually partnered with the research and investment teams, who were filled with smart, driven people.

One other con was that it IS a big corporation, so change does come fairly slowly, and there are constant re-orgs and re-branding initiatives, which can get a bit difficult to keep track of. It can also be hard to get things done in an efficient manner because there are always a million stakeholders on each project.

Title: Great place to gain professional experience out of college!

The company places major emphasis on customer service, and will reward its employees for meeting SLAs, daily metrics, and going above and beyond to drive customer loyalty. Also, the quarterly bonus potential,  employee match for 401k, and profit sharing is amazing! Plus there is plenty of overtime for those who desire it.
View7: Call Center Environment can be very stressful and is not for everyone. Employees have to go through too many avenues to find answers or confirm information, which can effect the employees call handling time and as a result can damage the employees daily metrics and bonus potential. Lastly, has a "Not what you know, but who you know" culture and as a result, the opportunity for growth within the company can be slow if you are not a Fidelity socialite!

Title: Good luck!
View5: The people and how you can move up on the corporate ladder in this position
View7:
I'm not a negative person but this topic makes me so angry so 

Compensation: The base pay (at least for my role) is way too low for what I do. 

Job: My job itself is manageable but stressful at times already. When people leave, they put that person's job on other people, with no raise or any acknowledgment of how the person's doing. The job you add on, you may not even be qualified for under in the industry. Also, they add on useless tasks to do (that other locations don't do) just for no reason at all. We have all of these tasks to do with no extra pay or help from higher management. The higher up people do not even know how to do the jobs we have which I can say from my experience here for sure.

Customers: some of the clients are absolutely absurd. they come in asking for things and you try to help them and give them caring honest answers and they dont care. it just adds on to the stress.

Company: During the pandemic they've put completely unrealistic protocols that do not make the clients happy (not being able to walk in places). Although I understand it's important to be safe during the pandemic, other companies allow it, so why not here? This just makes the clients very angry, more than already about their needs, and they go off on us service reps as if it is our fault. We take the heat. When we present it to a manager they do not care and tell us to try to resolve it more. If it escalates too much to a manager then they just blame the company and seem not to care. 

P.S. If you have a fidelity account and need help, do NOT call the service number because there is a 1% chance someone will answer in the first 10 minutes.

Most of the great benefits that used to exist have been taken away which now means most employees are underpaid compared to other companies.  Severe consequences for minor screw-ups. On that Tuesday I recieved a call from hr asking question regarding my pregnancy , on Thursday I recieved a very rude call stating they were withdrawing my offer due to "unspecified concerns that came up during background check" even though the background portion had already been completed and passed long before... There's no doubt in my mind that they changed their mind due to my pregnancy , which Im pretty sure is illegal. I'm very disappointed , I was looking forward to this job and wasn't even expecting a maternity leave from them, I was back at my current job when my youngest was only 6 days old. There's nothing in my background that should've kept me from getting hired , per their rules that I looked over carefully. Whatever their reasons, I know that my merit and experience more than qualified me for this position , and my character has never been questioned, especially by an employer or associate. Their loss I guess.

Title: branch representative
View5: The benefits are generally good.  Job security is above average
View7:
I want to set everyone straight on this company.  
This is a financial sales company, not a financial services firm.  The goal year in and year out is to maximize sales at the cost of providing true financial planning services to clients and developing relationships.
Book sizes are over 500 and by nature, representatives have little incentive to interact with current book clients unless there is new money coming in.  Reps are constantly not following up with their own clients because there is no incentive to stay true to a relationship model.  The planning is a masked service, run by computers and over complicated pieces of marketing material.  When each "solution" for a client is a fidelity managed account, you start to question what actual planning you are really doing.  If I client does not want a managed account, there is barely anything you can do for them, besides show them how to research on their own, defeating the purpose of a "guidance" appointment.  Management is constantly looking at ways to better the years previously at the cost of the reps and the clients.  More appointments, more phone calls is the name of the game.  It is impossible to keep a relationship model when this is the driving force behind it.  

If you want to provide financial planning guidance in a more meaningful way, it is best to join an RIA, which is where fidelity is losing most of its staff to anyway.

Title: Great place to learn the industry and get trained- then you should leave

Best benefits in the industry and they are now offering flexibility to work from home. They will pay for your licenses and CFP. You can learn as much as you want to learn, plenty of resources available for you.  Great place to gain experience.  You'll never have to cold call for prospects.
View7:
At the end of the day your job is to sell a managed solution to the client by giving the illusion that you are actually doing financial planning for them.  The turnover at the branches brings down client satisfaction. It is definitely a what have you done for me lately type of place. Monthly business reviews can be brutal for people who are not producing. 

You might have managers or trainers that have never been in your seat, or could not cut it so they transitioned. Makes it difficult to have them coach when they have not done it. 

 You make just enough money that its difficult to leave, and they do that on purpose. My advice for people is to get your certifications and a few years experience and then look elsewhere before you start making so much that its hard to leave.

Title: Great Brand-Name But Caveat Emptor
View5: Industry leader in many ways with one of the best brand-names in the business. Fidelity at the top of your resume or anywhere on your resume gets you noticed in the marketplace. It's a private company instead of public company so it's not pressured by the Wall Street quarterly earmings mentality, and that's a HUGE difference-maker in a great way. It's a well-capitalized company and they spend a lot on technology; I've honestly never seen anything like it. Some very smart people there, too, and some of them were even nice. Fidelity has a variety of businesses within the organization and people do move around.
View7: A lot of uncertainty from the top down, and most rank-and-file employees feel very out of the loop and not very empowered. Restructurings and management changes seem to be arbitrary and tend not to improve things; it almost feels like someone's tinkering with things because they believe they need to do something but they're not sure what. The people at the top are absurdly over-compensated and they don't spread it out as much as they could and should -- more employee ownership would be a great step. The people on the "inside" of the fund management shop, the core business, seem insulated and out of touch, kind of like a bunch of Roman senators.

Title: "Lions led by Donkeys"
View5: Privately held, lots of smart people, good benefits
View7:
"Lions led by Donkeys" - I'm stealing this phrase from Rodger Lawson, who mentioned it during one of his briefings. 

During this time of unprecedented change, it seems the place has become even more political and bureaucratic. Personally, I think Rodger Lawson is a much needed shot-in-the-arm for the company and has done much to infuse new leadership at the top. However, the next few levels down are in turmoil and disarray. Political infighting, turf wars, back-stabbing...it couldn't be further from the goals and objectives that Rodger laid out when he arrived at Fidelity. I think he would be stunned if he knew the truth about how some of his senior leaders were making decisions during the recent waves of layoffs, how good (but "non political") talent was being purged from the company, how things were being done more for "optics" than actual results. There are still many S and E level VPs in the company that need to find some religion...or seek other pastures.

Title: BEWARE!!
View5: They allowed workers to work from home.
View7:
Where do I start? I spent a decent amount of time working at Fidelity. Overall, I would say it’s not a great company to work for at all. From my observations, many people have gotten stuck in this company, and it’s drained the life/soul out of them. For starts, many full-time and contractors (Fidelity TalentSource) are underpaid for the amount of responsibility on them. Many people are very unhappy here, but their soul has been trapped here way too long. They don’t know how to leave; all they know to do is stay around and complain.

Racism is obvious in this company. After the murder of George Floyd and many others, there was a lot of lip service from upper-level leaders and money donated to non-profits, but the core of this company has not changed at all. It’s racist!

Human Resources and Recruiters for the most part are awful. I think this is one of the MANY reasons why they don’t attract quality candidates, let alone keep them exceptionally long. Speaking of that, turnover is HIGH.

The leadership is really what makes or breaks an organization. The leadership here is awful. I met with a Senior Leader about issues with a product that they oversaw, and they admitted it was problematic and had obvious issues. However, since our meeting nothing about the product has improved, it’s only gotten worst. Do companies think by ignoring constant issues/problems that they’re just going to float away?

I conclude by saying, proceed with caution. Don’t let the nice buildings, benefits, etc. fool you. Once you get in, you will soon realize it was a BIG mistake coming here. You deserve better in life, STAY AWAY!!

Title: Financial Consultant
View5: As mentioned, great benefits. 7% match and 10% profit sharing. If you do 7% your going to be putting away 24% of your total pay into retirement which is great.
View7:
Their Portfolio Advisory Service (PAS) is the key product along with annuities that you are pressed to sell. They train you really well on how to overcome the objections of Clients. You get paid 0.07% or 7 basis points for every dollar you put into these products - JUST ONE TIME - there is a tiny bonus based on Retention. The worst part is that every one in the Financial Consultant role knows the product is terrible and underperforms consistently by 1.5%-2.2% on a yearly basis. If you work here, prepare to exchange your conscious for your paycheck. 

Management will talk trash about you after you leave, there is no loyalty. You will work with 400 Clients, the best Financial Consultants don't develop deep relationships with Clients because you don't have the capacity to do that because you must sell about $36 million a year at a minimum in their garbage products.

Title: Inconsistent Values
View5: Abby Johnson, the CEO, is awesome. She repeatedly beats the drum of providing a great customer and employee experience. Some of the best benefits in the industry. Between its low cost platform to invest and its fabulous benefits, Fidelity sets the bar high.
View7:
The only concern I have with Fidelity is that it doesn't do enough to root out managers with direct reports who violate its values. The lack in accountability of its managers isn't unique to Fidelity. Yet, it's disappointing considering it sincerely strives to standby things it espouses. Everyone knows who these bad actors and bad apples are. Members of their teams can't move away fast enough to other teams, departments, or companies. 

Though the company allows them to punish or push out struggling yet sincere frontline employees, it does little to recognize that these ineffective managers are better at managing up to their bosses than lifting up their teams. Just recently, I saw a manager who was recently promoted to an enviable post who has a seriously horrible reputation. He is a poster child of everything I mentioned and is one of the worst managers in the building.

The environment can be quite stressful and some department management seems almost proud of the level of stress. When interviewing be sure to ask about the group's culture rather than the whole company's culture. Performance reviews can be problematic with some management teams. Title: "Active Trader"

Fidelity caters to new hires. They are like comcast: Throw the world at you if you are a new employee, but the people that have worked here and put their time in, and actually contribute to the company are rewarded with the opportunity to do more work.
 Every benefit is designed to get people in the door.  New hires got a  12% bump in pay, plus a signing bonus of $2500.   I have worked here for almost 10 years and I get to do my job, the help desks job, and the new hires job, and don't get so much as a thank you. Too much middle management that has no idea what goes on on the phones.   Work is not challenging.  Roles are not defined. Who does what... No one knows.  
Meet your sales number? Here's a Snickers bar.
Pay is low.  
I'm sure that there are some people that enjoy their work, but in the Active Trader  group, the morale is low, attitudes are awful, and suggestions are ignored.
Work site is in a horrible location- every time you go outside, you are accosted by homeless people for money.  Building is not owned by company.

Title: LEAP Associate Software Engineer = Grand Opportunity
View5:
Within the LEAP Program as an Associate Software Engineer, you get trained for roughly 12 weeks. After this, you'll have dedicated project time where you work on a real project within Fidelity Investments. A great plus is, you get paid during training. You'll learn things such as front end, middle tier, and back end technologies. You are basically getting equipped for your future role within the company. You work closely with your manager and they'll try to find the best role for you. Ie, if you want to work more on front end(html/css/angular), they'll try to find the best role for you. 

Trust me, as a recent college graduate, this program is unreal. It truly is a gateway to success for your Software Engineering career. It helps you get your feet wet, and feel the least bit comfortable to get off to a good start. 

Here is a list of Pros:
- 401k match (7% at 100%) + ~10% profit sharing (Ie: its ultimately 17% 401k match)
- Student Loan Assistance (Up to $10,000) 
- Great networking along the way (You are in classrooms with recent graduates just like you. Great life long friendships and connections were made!)
- Learning Front End, Middle Tier, Back End Technologies (The general ones Fidelity uses.... and no, these aren't legacy software technologies)
- Learning coding concepts/design patterns
View7: There aren't really any cons. You are getting paid to learn(say what?). It is what you make of the program.

Title: Trading Execution Rep. - Active Trader Services
View2: Trading Execution Representative - Active Trader Services
View5: Good basic market mechanics, personal finance, and trading training. Learned basics of retirement and brokerage accounts. Great FINRA licensing program. Paid to study.
View7: Joke managers who are less educated than most employees. Joke clients that think they are big shots because they trade 200 times a year in a $20k account. Management makes employees think they are actually making an impact on the business when they actually have no control whatsoever. Your bonus is 99% based on customer surveys which you have NO control over. And your manager has the authority to subjectively slice up the bonus pool based on who they like and do not like ( I did fine in bonuses, it is just a terrible way of handling it). Your variable comp as they like to call has very little to do with your overall performance. The Active Trader group has this allure of being a specialty group and close to an institutional trading desk, when really all it is is another phone site job. You just have to be a bit better at handling jerks on the phone and entering trades timely and accurately. Pay is very low, and exit opps are NON - Existent. It is nearly impossible to explain what you did in ATS to any future employers. Other than sponsoring to sit for the Series 4 exam you build zero career equity. Job and company is absolute joke, unless you are unmotivated and content being another # like most people who work there.

Fidelity tries to make it seem like their is "a ton of career growth", but really it is just customer service phone job after customer service phone job.

They move you around to different departments to make it seem like you are being "promoted", but really it is the same old crap.

I worked in the Stock Plan Service group in SLC, and was excited to find a career path I was interested in.... Only to find out that Fidelity's generous $10k per year tuition reimbursement policy doesn't apply to you getting THE ONE CERTIFICATION THAT IS 100% applicable to your job. 

You wanna know why? Because everyone who gets it leaves for way higher paying jobs elsewhere. Of course, Fidelity will never tell you that's the real reason.

As soon as I found that out, I started shooting my resume out to competitors in the industry. I easily received multiple offers, off the phone, for way more money. I suggest you do the same!

Oh, and Fidelity does this really cool thing called "loans". Basically they promote you to a higher position, give you more work and responsibility but don't pay you any more money. How generous of them, right?

Title: Great benefits, but two steps behind
View5: Benefits are fantastic. 7% 401k match and 10% profit sharing dump. Great health plan. Lots of vacation. Job Security. Great place to begin a career in Sales/Financial Planning. Great customer focus (in terms of interactions and handling issues). Great Integrity. One of those companies where it would take blatant action to intentionally hurt the client interaction to lose your job.
View7: Middle to Upper Middle management are pretty unqualified. When there is a problem with a system or process the resolution is to take down a list of everything that's broken, sit and wait to see how many customers complain about it over the course of 1-3 years, then prioritize funding to fix the issue, then make a video about how terrible the process is and show it to all of the employees in some sort of a backwards way to show their great problem resolution technique, and then maybe after 2 years its fixed. Meanwhile, front line employees have to constantly make excuses to clients and maintain a "can do" attitude.

Title: The Financial Representative is technically like a Pledge to a Fraternity/Sorority you have to swallow your dignity.
View5: Benefits, great training, company gets you up to speed fast, helps attain licenses.  Can pay for further schooling.  This is a great job to enter right out of college.  The pay is good enough.  Just get out of it as quick as you can, as it beats you down once the aura of the new job wears off.
View7: You are responsible for the whole office even though you typically are the least experience person in the office.  It's a great way to learn, but also a great way to have employees above you dislike you if you make a mistake.  The position can be quite demeaning as you order lunches for associates above you and will be treated like a secretary on numerous occasions throughout the week.  You are ordered around more so than any other employee in the office.  You are responsible for the whole office, but all the other employees are responsible just for themselves so you can get pulled many ways at once to keep people happy and of course, this typically will not help you be happy.

Title: "F is for flexibility"
View5:
Excellent benefits, great mobility into other positions if working in call centers to turn an "okay" base pay to solid. Top of the line training for licensing should your role require it off the bat, or sometime down the line.

The workplace culture is excellent- every single manager I've had is excellent, and that's likely a result of trickle-down from *their* higher ups. Willingness to accomodate work from home is an excellent push, as long as you're okay with online training.
View7: Certain products like the one I work with currently very much feel like they're on the backburner when it comes to updating resources, educating customers, etc. It makes a call with an insane hold time even more distressing, and just leads to more OT asks. I've had the term "F for flexibility" thrown around more times than I can count. Having covid PTO is great, but the distressing air of the call center floor makes associates feel almost guilty for not doing OT, nevermind taking days off during "peak season", which, since the pandemic, has been virtually every day. I love what I do and I love assisting customers- but beware, if call center work is exhausting to you, it's going to outweigh most pros I'm giving here.

Title: Great place to start
View5: Fidelity Investments is a great place to start your career. I started right out of college 2 years ago and the starting salaries are competitive. Plus, you get amazing benefits such as dollar for dollar match on 401K up to 7%. In addition they give you 10% of your salary for profit sharing at the end of the year. I have worked with a lot of very intelligent people that challenge me everyday to make me better. I enjoy the challenge because if we aren't helping each other improve and to learn new things a job can get stale very quickly.
View7: While the salaries are competitive at the beginning the raises are almost none existent. And, to get a promotion is even more difficult. If your looking for somewhere to grow quickly then Fidelity isn't the place for you unless your lucky. Also, there is a lot of politics involved in this company. You will see coworkers move past you that are terrible at their jobs (borderline clueless as to what is going on), but network very well and talk to the right people. This can be very discouraging to those who actually try and work hard. Because, at the end of the day your picking up their slack and they're reaping the benefits.

Title: Great benefits....career advancement revolves around sales
View5:
- Incredible benefits package, excluding paid vacation time
- On-site management teams have always been understanding of personal situations or need for time off on short notice
- Great opportunity to learn the industry
- Very customer friendly environment and great brand recognition
View7:
- Too beaurocratic - front line employees are asked to provide feedback to upper management on ways to improve but little is acknowledged, much less acted on
- Upon hiring they promote career opportunity, and even managers state career developement is something they want to help out with, but unless you want to do sales and/ or be tied to a phone doing different levels of customer service, very little career growth exists unless you have the right connections
- Compensation seems to be appropriate for entry level jobs but does not keep pace as you do move through the company
- Severe disconnect between upper managment and front line employees
- Contracting expectations - they promote world class customer service as being the number one priority in this particular role, but great interactions are rarely rewarded, and sales are what most non-base pay compensation is tied to

Title: Takes care of employees
View5: Experience varies widely based on groups. On the tech side PI is one of the most modern whereas FI is stuck in the early 1990s. My group is excellent and for Fidelity we are on the cutting edge. Work life balance is great - in general the management is very flexible. There are politics but a good manager will shield the developer from this. If you can prove your valuable by innovating Fidelity will take notice - if you do nothing new then you will stagnate. Base compensation is on the lower end of what a developer could make elsewhere but the wide array of benefits, especially the contributions to 401k (7% match and generally 10% profit sharing) are unheard of. Senior management seems to have a clear vision of what they want but the execution on it by middle management is variable.
View7: So much of Fidelity's tech is old and maintaining, enhancing the existing systems and building new capabilities requires lots of investment which up until the year the company had been pouring money into. In my opinion some of this money was wasted on buying expensive vendor products from the likes of IBM and Oracle that could have been done without paying for a license. Another issue is Fidelity still hires too many useless contractors and unnecessary project managers.

Title: Low Pay - Great Benefits - Degrading Culture
View5: The benefits are definitely pros. 401k matching up to 7%, tuition reimbursement and medical are all noteworthy benefits.
View7: Your pay will be low unless your are in sales. Service used to get paid well if you worked your way to the top, however, Fidelity recently restructured variable compensation and top performing reps are taking up to a $10,000 pay cut. While they cut your pay they are asking you to do twice the work by consolidating roles and drastically increasing calls per hour expectations. Expect to  handle complex problem resolution on matters like alternative investments, international wires, or incorrect cost basis research all while taking 7 calls per hour.  You will get paid around $50,000  for practically handling every aspect of service for all clients and financial consultants who very likely know less than you but get paid over twice as much. In summary the pay is low, the goals are practically (now) unattainable, job security is not the best.

Title: A big company with big company pluses and minuses
View5: I worked for Fidelity in two stints lasting a total of 12+ years on the IT operations side.  On the whole I was treated very well, but it was about what I put into it.  I felt that I worked hard and was rewarded (promotion and $ wise) appropriately.   As with any big company, your success is very dependent on your supervisor and how they choose to treat their staff.  But I always felt that if you worked hard and performed well, you got what you deserved.  Benefits are very good and I felt I more than compensated fairly for my work.
View7: Fidelity by nature is risk averse because of its reputation and that is also it's biggest issue when it comes to innovation.  Fidelity, for all it's lip service as a leading edge company, is behind the curve on technology and is working to make strides in cloud services and robo investing services to keep up with more innovative companies attempting to steal the millennial generation market.  In addition, there is no real accountability within technology operations (including the need to really measure performance against budget) so there is a lot of stagnation among long-time employees and in  management.  Fidelity moves very slowly on re-orgs and layoffs after telegraphing changes are coming, leaving employees in limbo for long periods and impacting productivity.

Title: Great to start
View5:
They have great training
Great work life balance
View7: They are the worst with their promotion metrics. I was performing in top 1% of the company 3 months I dropped 1 month and the used it as an excuse not to promote me up. If your a person of color as well there is no diversity at the the maagement level besides one woman of Asian heritage. Expect if you are white to be promoted even though you're not the most qualified for the role. Expect to be accused of being bad on the phone when you did everythign you did for a client yet they give you a bad rating for the 1 hour hold time they waited to talk to you, and the best part is then the company will use that against you to screw you out of your bonuses saying you didn't do a great job. Of course, there is no way to throw out the ones that that were just an upset customer and not your fault. We were told they didn't have money for raises then they cut their commissions and magically found a way to still give us a raise. They do not do any cost of living adustments so expect to live harsh while some people live comfortable in other states. So pretty much expect to be disregarded at this company they don't care about you.

Title: Four stars for the company, two stars for the job.
View5:
The people that make up this company are really great and not only care about their coworkers, but the surrounding community as well. I made life-long friends here.

The training teams were very helpful in helping my entire new-hire class pass our licensing exams and the information I learned has been very helpful for my life in general. 

My managers seemed genuinely interested in helping me find the right job internally--ironically this helped me realize that my dreams lay outside the company.
View7:
At its core, this is a call-center job--8 hours on the phone (or more). The information you discuss with clients is more complicated than other phone jobs, so you'll be relying on internal information systems since you can't know every little policy or acronym.

There's little time to breathe between calls at certain times of the year.

Meetings and coaching get cancelled all the time right when you're ready to take a break from the phones. I really could've used some help to improve the work I was doing.

Title: Great Entry to Financial Services
View5: Great scheduling options, great benefits, training, and especially coworkers.
View7: Call center - always on the phones, expected to take a certain number of calls per hour, no matter how much the caller talks.

Title: An amazing company
View5: Client and employee obsessed, with a wonderful diverse work force
View7: I truly have nothing bad to say

Title: Good people hamstrung by micro-managing senior management who won't make tough decisons
View5: Solid pay, decent work-life balance, excellent benefits. The people at Fidelity are smart, friendly and uniformly desire to do the right thing.
View7: Terrible disconnect between senior management and the people below them. Poltiical maneuvering among senior leaders is widespread, a result of C-level unwillingness to set direction clearly or resolve conflicts decisively. Company culture is consensus-driven - often from the bottom up in that individuals, groups and teams are left to work things out themselves - and when issues among teams arise that cannot be resolved below the SVP level, they remain unaddressed and left to fester until things get bad enough that someone senior HAS to step in, usually with more fallout than would have been necessary if the problem had been addressed earlier. There is a serious blind spot when it comes to recognizing the limits of consensus-building and the fact that leadership by directive is sometimes necessary.  Micro-managing is common, and far, far too much time is spent on producing presentations and reports.

Title: No longer a good place to work
View5: Benefits are very good. Lots to learn. Can be a good place to establish a career.
View7: Fidelity was a great place to work in the 90s but that's all changed. There has been a great deal of pressure on the employees since at least 2003 to perform. Review ratings are absurd. You can literally perform with absolute excellence all year and still be rated average...after all the managers are all under pressure to meet the numbers and submit ratings within the allotted quotas. So...it the whole department had a banner year don't think the whole department is rewarded...this would never happen and it's grossly unfair. You're expected to suck it up and move on...until the next layoff then you're gone. Who needs that!!!

Title: Financial Service Rep
View5: Open 24/7 so that gives you a lot of flexibility.  Great benefits! 6 weeks fully paid parental leave for males and 16 week I believe for women who had a baby.  Tons of overtime opportunities in tax season.  Low stress, pay is great for entry level.  401k match and profit sharing totals to 17% a year (profit sharing 10% and 401k match 7%) managers want you to do well, flexible breaks and lunches, flexible with school schedules and family schedules, Fidelity all in all is a great place to work!
View7: It's a call center, at least you get paid well.  Sometimes you feel like a operator transferring calls. Bonus is effected by how your team does as a whole.  They make a lot of changes throughout the year and you need to be on your toes to keep up with all of it.  Colleagues can drag you down by being negative about their job.  Customer experience surveys are a very big factor in eligibility for larger bonuses and annual raises.  You can take thousands of calls but 30 surveys can make or break your eligibility for a raise. Some other small things, but this position is a call center position it's not always easy but definitely a good starting job to get you comfortable with the lingo and customer facing position.

Title: Lateral Mobility , if you play the game.
View5: Benefits are pretty good, profit sharing.
View7: Worked here in many roles over 12 years. Culture has changed dramatically in last 5-7 years. Terrible team leaders that bully anyone under top 15-25%. They play favorites with people who are probably cheating the system. Was planning on retiring here, but getting older here is a death sentence.  Unethical mgrs who are puppets manufacture reasons to push you out the door. No respect for tenured reps and managers are usually just associates that couldn't compete. Blind side associates with nonsensical stats if they don't like you. Call review scoring lacks consistency. Returned to work after STD for surgery and everyday was a new nightmare until terminated without much evidence and treated like a criminal. Becoming pretty standard way of thinning out tenured reps. Loved this company and mgmt. in the beginning. Made a lot of good friends. Mgmt. now just worried their stats and look the other way when cheaters don't even care to keep their stats within reality. Very toxic and political environment with unbelievable micro-management pressure , if you're not cheating and getting these mid-mgmt cretons promoted. It's viral all the way through to senior mgmt who are conceited, entitled, no talent bullies. No loyalty among thieves either. Most jump ship with a title and leave their wreckage behind. AVOID THIS COMPANY. It's smoke and mirrors your first 5 years.

Title: Fidelity, from an insiders perspective.
View5: The people who work there are friendly and have an interest in the markets and business in general. They have a wide array of shifts to choose from. Managers manage effectively, thats not to say they are good leaders, simply they encourage working hard as well as smart, they provide feedback in a timely manner. Their benefits package is very top notch. The profit-sharing enables them to have a great benefits package from computer purchases to gym memberships and quarterly bonuses. Their lack of accountability to shareholders makes their business model more effective and gives them the incentive to work hard for the benefit of the customers
View7: being paid hourly and not being paid for lunch, therefore one must give up 9 hours a day to work an 8hour day. If you're not working in corporate, you're answering phones. Also their new hire training teaches the fundamentals of their systems, they dont teach anything stock related, the closest thing you'll get to learning how markets work is through the series 7 exam and talking with colleagues, but even they are somewhat clueless. Lastly, Fidelity, being a conservative company severely limits employee investing, for instance, any position thats considered bearish is not allowed.

Title: The big green line
View5: They have spent billions on the brand, and it worked, they spent billions on the tools, and they rock, the products are cheep and won't hurt anyone unless you lie to them in the sales process.
View7:
!Its a big company and if you are not aware of how you are perceived it could possibly hurt your chances to move up. This is not anything different from any other large company. To the people complaining about how they were passed over or done wrong, so sorry for you but getting ahead in life is about more than just how you think you did at your job, your bosses have feelings to and if you don't make them feel like they made a good decision (At any company) you will not get ahead. 

In terms of the people in call centers and computer programming roles, well it is probably tough to stick out from the thousands of other people, but it is still a great company and they don't really expect too much of you from a performance standpoint so why complain about it. Just do your job and try to improve.

Title: Great and efficient company. Very pleased so far.
View5: Tremendous brand-name industry recognition. Even though it's a large Co with a lot of layers of management it's actually very nimble and efficient when it comes to finding solutions for clients' needs and that keeps clients and customers satisfied.  The company spends a lot of $$ on innovation and technology and it's refreshing to see how it keeps clients' needs above everything else. Client is #1.  Benefits are great: 7% co match in 401k (dollar for dollar) and also a 10% Profit Sharing (on average) after 1 year of service. HSA contributions, plus incentive performance awards are above industry average. The culture is very conservative but they do respect all people no matter the associate's  sexual or religious background. Last but not least, the company is very committed to integrity and compliance standards so it stays out of negative headlines and it's extremely well run.  It's been a great place for me to work here and I'm very pleased to be part of this organization.
View7: Very large company so it's hard sometimes to get a lot of visibility and may feel lost without proper mentoring.

Title: Very tough and political, but you will learn a lot and be very marketable
View5:
- Tremendous brand name that helps your work have a big industry impact
-  Privately held company - doesn't worry about quarterlyy earnings
- Great resources to accomplish whatever you need to do
- Opportunity to grow for younger workers
- Excellent salaries and benefits
View7:
- Very tough and political organization. To be successful, you will have to be a strong corporate politician
- Not a very friendly place for older workers. The benefits and HR strategy focus on making Millenials happy while managing out older employees.  Fidelity is a great place to start your career.
- Privately held company - Since management isn't exposed to Wall Street pressure, they are slow to change.  For example, Fidelity has been a slow follower in developing online trading, launching an ETF business, creating passive investment products, and developing a robo-advisor.  The company is not innovative. It seeks to copy initiatives from other successful companies.
- Senior management is not willing to take risks. They are so well compensated that they have nos insensitive to put their lifestyles in jeopardy. 
- The company is very large.  Projects and product development have become very bureaucratic.
- Dogmatic commitment to active management.
- Products are too expensive and have seen erosion in their competitive position from companies like Vanguard
