Title: Financial Associate

Title: Financial Representative aka "this is not a sales job but it sure as heck is"
View5: There are many positive aspects of working as a financial rep at Fidelity Investments. Even though it is a call center job with stringent metrics and every move and word measured and recorded, it's not horrible. The pay is above average and so are the benefits. The standards are transparent. Not the easiest to meet but no smoke and mirrors except in one respect. When I was hired I was told that this is not a sales job. I was told that is customer service. Told the same thing in training. The truth is different.
View7: After about a month or two on the floor there began to be a lot of pressure to discuss about people increasing their contributions and trying to get them to speak to licensed representatives. We the "guidance" as a plan benefit that is a feature that doesn't cost anything but we're really selling the additional Portfolio Advisory Services that costs additional. Regardless of whether it is a good plan, and I do believe it is, I still feel it is misleading I also feel misled about what I signed on for when accepting the position. I said in the phone interview and in person interview that I did not want a sales job.

Title: Overall working at Fidelity was good.
View5: Great way to work your way up if you are fresh out of college.  Bonuses are higher in fin'l services than other places and Fidelity will pay you quarterly bonuses plus profit sharing bonus.  Fidelity teaches you how to ask questions in discussions w/ clients so you can better understand who your client is and what solution fits best. Good career path for goal driven young people as they can become managers.  Recreation room with video gaming system and ping pong tables. Company loves to hire internally for regional offices.
View7: Unfortunately to excel you simply have to take more calls than anyone so you can outperform in your metrics.  A 45 minute discussion w/ your client about how best to invest his/her money is a stat killer.  Big focus on pushing people to 'do it yourself' online. I've been in fin'l services for 9 years...young managers aren't good managers. Fidelity does allow people to become managers when they are not skilled enough to do it. As a seasoned outside person who started with Fidelity, their max starting salary to outsiders was $45k...below what seasoned people make.  Phone center will always suffer from the need to have people adhere to their schedules 'on phone' times.

Title: Relationship Manager
View5:
- Great 401k match @ 7%
- Good Medical-- FSA for low deductible & HSA for High deductible plans
- Annual fitness incentive to help pay for gym membership or exercise equipment
- Computer reimbursement (% of $ spent up to a certain amt.)
- Fun team building events and outings with colleagues

Good company with opportunity to learn about the industry and get licensed. 
Offsite training is excellent.

There are a lot of intelligent and friendly people. Actually, I'd like to add emphasis --there are a lot of genuinely good natured, friendly and pleasant people working for the company.
View7: There are claims of an opportunity for career growth, yet there's a disappointing air of bureaucratic BS and a bizarre expectation of gender roles. A heavy concentration of women work in entry-level and support roles and are blatantly treated as if it's the "natural order". It was disappointing to see smart and qualified women being promoted less often than male counterparts and even encouraged to remain in their current roles.

Title: Financial representative
View5: Good training program, private company with good job security
View7: This is a call center and you will be on the phone ALL DAY LONG.  There are no jobs in this co.that don't require you to be on the phone all day long regardless of the job title.  Benefits are great if you can stay for the 5 year vesting schedule which 90% of the people don't bc of burn out.  That's why the benefits are great bc no one ever vests so they never get paid out.  You get 1-2 hours off the phone per WEEk....not per day.  Eventually you can't take being on the phone anylonger and you either leave or get burnt out which effects your performance.   Pay is lower than industry average and the main goal of all 1000 employees is to get one of the 50 or so jobs that don't require one to be on the phone all day.  These non phone jobs rarely come up and competitive is fierce.   Decent job for first time out of college person looking to gain experience and then leave.  Also, everything is based on phone metrics so keep your headset on and don't drink much water bc that will require you to go to the bathroom and hurt your phone metrics.

Title: Design lead
View5: Fidelity is a great place to learn how to be effective in a huge organization. When I worked there, the company was eager to show off its design group--we were allowed to wear jeans every day and had very cool hexagonal cubes, because the company wanted to showcase the fact that creative people worked at a financial institution. There was also a full usability lab, which is rarity in any industry.
View7: It was really easy for people to do very little work. Inefficiency was literally built into the design review process; I had to run every finished design by a designer--a Fidelity veteran, natch--who might have half my skill level, despite their years of experience. I left because I knew that I wouldn't learn anything there, and my skills would inevitably get stale in an environment that lacked innovation. The management was just getting excited about Flash at the time, at the moment when the industry was moving toward abandoning it! Additionally, diversity was a problem. Fidelity had very few non-white/non-Indian people, at the time, and I don't think anything has changed. One buffoon of a manager (white) thought it was hilarious to spout "ebonics" at every opportunity. It was cringe-making, at the very least.

Title: Financial consultant
View5: Great place to start, learn the ropes and prepare for a career.  Phenomenal benefits/ 401k profit sharing.  Leads tee'd up for you. Great tech. Nice office. A lot of resources to learn and get better. A lot of nice people in branch offices. Easy to close business.
View7:
The longer you work here, the less you'll like it.  They micromanage you on everything, literally.  How many meetings, referrals, toa's, managed money, annuities, flows, mutual fund sales, how you say hello and goodbye to a customer. Non-stop meetings with "coaches", who are either people who never really did sales or did it for a few years here and ran for the hills to get out of the branches.  Some branch managers require a debrief with their consultants after every meeting.

The elephant in the room is that they have good products but we are constantly forced to push PAS which is their worst product.  

It's cookie cutter, they want every client to have a managed account and an annuity.  You definitely can't think for yourself, or help clients in unique ways- everything is run through a computer template. 

There is way too much garbage meetings to do any real planning for people.

Title: Good Company
View5:
Good training program
They care about their employees
View7:
Difficult to move out of your business unit
Everything seems to be phone related

Title: Meh
View5: Resources, benefits, people, industry leader
View7: Middle management is completely worthless

Title: Indifference and Abuse
View5: I made some friendships while I was there. Everything related to my actual job was horrible.
View7: The upper management all sort of do there own things and have their own expectations, creating confusion throughout the company. I don't think Abby really has control over some of her subordinates. Site management changed every year that I was there, adding to the confusion. Team managers have entirely too much power and there is very little recourse given to appeal their decisions or seek redress of grievances when they act in an inappropriate manner. The pay is well below industry standards and while you are able to make lateral movements within the company, moving up is EXTREMELY difficult. Pay raises rarely keep up with inflation and while I was there our variable comp was changed making it impossible for anyone to meet the new standards. My pay went down a couple of thousand dollars per year as a result. HR is not responsive and negligent at times. I went an entire year without insurance because I was somehow disenrolled in the plan that I signed up for when I got hired on. HR knew that this mistake had happened and it was documented in their system, but they didn't do anything in time to correct the problem despite my contant pressuring them. The company became even less invested in its employees during my time, essentially turning from a somewhat tolerable work experience into just another high turnover, turn and burn call center.

Title: Pays well, good benefits, not a good work culture
View5: Pays well and has good benefits
View7: Still old management, not a very exciting place to work

Title: Good, not great.
View5:
Licensing program
Supportive
Down to earth
Steady pay
View7:
Non-transparent
Stuck in role
Glued to your desk

Title: Lost it's Way
View5: Fidelity has a good brand and most of the employees are smart and want to do the right thing. It is nice that it is a private company with huge wallets which allows them to invest when the market (stock or job) is down. Good place to work out of school and get some good experience by moving around and trying different roles. There is also a student debt benefit which is good for anybody that can leverage it. Due to their volumes, they will continue to make lots of money.
View7: They have flattened the organization as part of the "agile transformation" and expect you to make lots of lateral moves (forget climbing the ladder unless you are very junior). They have pushed out most of the good senior level leaders or bought them out via VBO. They are catering to young workers who they can pay less and shuffle from one group to another.  Leadership is not engaging or inspiring.

Title: Amazing company & benefits, not enough flexibility
View5: There's always something new to learn in the job and being customer oriented was something I appreciated about the company. In addition, having a 7% company match and profit sharing component in the 401(k) plan was a great benefit. They also encourage employees to develop their careers so your job is never at a standstill.
View7: Since some jobs have you working in a contact center type of environment, there are a lot of months where call volume can be busy and it can be exhausting taking care of so many customers in a span of 9-11 hrs each day. In addition, you're set on a schedule (could be working an evening shift until further notice) and even though you might be working for a minimum of 8 hours, it can still be exhausting leaving the workplace at 8:30 pm closer to 9 pm on a Friday with hardly any other employees working with you during that time as well.

Title: Career or Next Stop
View5: Overall, very solid company with great benefits, opportunities for promotion.  Fidelity has multiple locations so there is potential to move around.  You can get in contact with the top easier than you'd think for a large corporation.  The old saying was you never get rich while at Fidelity, but because you worked there you will be rich.  I think this is true because of the incentive programs between annual bonus opportunities which can be a substantial amount of your income, phantom share program that pay out every two years and their profit sharing that was their year in and out.
View7: I thought that Fidelity got a little too big and struggled to find out how to structure itself to succeed.  It seemed like we would go through 3-4 organizational alignments each year.  It's not that it's bad, but they never seem to be able to stay the course with their decisions.  It really depended upon who was leading the charge.  Current senior management is more about the bottom line as oppose to prior leadership.  Prior leadership still looked at growth opportunities and current leadership wants to maintain and not necessary grow the business unless it is an EXACT fit or match.

Title: Active Trader Services Representative
View5: Benefits are great - 401K match is 7%, and heath/dental insurance are top notch.  Great cafeterias in the offices.  Some of the nicest coworkers you could hope for.
View7:
Getting promoted from this department is next to impossible.  This used to be a 'desirable' destination, with the potential to advance one's career.  No more.  They care less about the front-line folks helping clients, and more about 'stats.'  Your breaks are timed/measured, the length of your calls is measured (long calls = baaaaaad,) and getting promoted outside of the department takes an act of congress.
Management, in general, is a bunch of glad-handing guys and gals.  You seldom see managers let go/demoted, even if they are consistently poor performers/coaches.  This leads to a lot of stagnation, and little room for advancement (unless my manager would take the initiative to seek a different role or retire, which hasn't happened in the 5+ years I have been there.)

Title: Once a great place to work, but things are changing......
View5: Fair pay (not exactly up to industry standards, but OK) and AMAZING benefits!  Health insurance, life insurance, many discount benefits through a number of vendors (Verizon, etc.), great short and long term disability insurance and of course a decent retirement plan.
View7: When it comes to advancement at Fidelity the mantra is, "It's not WHAT you know, but WHO".  Your skills and experience mean very little when it comes to advancement.  To get ahead you just need to be friends with the right people.  It matter more who you play golf or poker with than what your experience or expertise is.  And it's starting to show in the quality of the firm.  As is the compartmentalization of duties and leaving major decisions to each units management team with very little oversight.  This has created a few sandbox bullies who have been allowed to run roughshod over their particular departments without any ramifications.  So weigh your options carefully if you're looking at applying at Fidelity.

Title: Used to be all about the customer
View5: Great benefits package, decent pay, great colleagues, various shift schedules to choose from, quarterly bonuses based on personal results. Great intro job to finance, and Fidelity will offer opportunities to move towards your finance-industry-related work, even if you have little to no experience. You MUST understand that this is a call center job, however. As such, your job is to take X number of phone calls each and every day, day in and day out.
View7: What used to be all about the customer experience has, over the past few years, heavily diverted into a metric-based environment. This leaves associates "kicking the can" down the road to the next associate who can help better, leading to a terrible customer experience, simply because associates are watching out for their KPIs. Poor KPI results will result in heavy-handed "coaching" sessions and absurd amounts of micromanagement.

Title: Highly Recommend
View5: - Work environment - Job Growth
View7: - Salary on low end - Co-Workers

Title: Great company and benefits
View5: Fidelity makes it possible for many employees to work from home, especially due to COVID-19. They continue to expand benefits every year.
View7: It can be a challenge to move between departments

Title: Excessive Turnover
View5:
Great benefits
Green Offices
Best health coverage for your money
View7:
No vision plan (for a job where you stare at a PC all day)
Excessive turnover
Management really does not listen to anyone but their closed circle of people
Egotistical Trainers
Low Wages
Manipulating statistics to make metrics
Lying to associates
Training is not as good as represented.
Trash talking associates who did not make the cut
Who fires their associates when they are driving their cars home?

Title: Challenging work, but 0 support from management when needed.
View5: The work was challenging and you learned something new on a daily basis.  There was plenty of room for growth and development within the role.  There was such a sense of satisfaction doing the analytical work and keeping the client satisfied with Fidelity's record keeping of their HW benefits.
View7: No work/life balance.  No support from management.  You are set up for failure if you are passionate about your work.  If you're good at your job then you are loaded down with the work of other employees that don't do well in their roles.  You are then given an impossible amount of tasks to complete in a deadline that will not be met, and you're given little to no support.  If you don't mine working 65 to 75 hours a week in order to keep up with the workload then this will be the place for you.  However, if you do not enjoy working weekends, holidays, cancelling vacations, etc. for work on a constant basis then look elsewhere, because management will really look down on you for not sacrificing everything to meet their impossible expectations.

Title: This place is horrible
View5: The PTO benefit is really nice, as well as the Student loan benefit. Only thing with the PTO is be careful of how you use it if you plan to leave the company, because they will make you pay them back once you leave.
View7: Open door policy is a lie. If you’re a minority keep your head down and do your work. This company lies about everything and makes up their own rules that goes against their written policy. If you are faced with a discrepancy, chain of command does not help. Managers are very controlling and seek to sabotage careers if they could. Micromanagement is very real in this workplace, management will yell at you in front of others and back each other up to make you look “combative”. Constant changes, no resolutions for errors the company is making. So basically you’re taking the brunt of the heat from clients all day. The pay is horrible, the managers try to make it seem like your raise is a lot, when in reality at most the raises won’t raise you above the $40k threshold. The company isn’t for the best interest of the client don’t believe that I’ve seen so much where Fidelity does things to hurt the client more than help them. I can write a book about this place. Don’t waste your mental health here and it’s a lie if you think that upward mobility is possible. I had a manager try to make sure I didn’t desire to be a manager because she didn’t want me trying to “take” her job.

Title: Fidelity Investments
View5: Great culture and benefits. Many opportunities to learn and grow. The best people!
View7: Large company where you can sometimes get overlooked if you aren't actively working on progressing in your career.

Title: Get out of the box
View5:
Good 401K/Profit Share
Educational Reimbursement
Friendly atmosphere
Good location for traffic/parking
Company is very clear in communicating job responsibilities within each role
Great place for young person to start/get licensed
View7:
Job Performance and experience have little or nothing to do with advancement. Most promotions go to younger less experienced reps and those that have "branded themselves"  properly. IMO the "Brand" they seek is someone that never questions anything and is perceived to have a clean slate that they can mold to do things as they say "The Fidelity Way' . My new employer values my experience and sees it as an asset rather than a liability.

Most opportunities are lateral and involve little or no pay increase 

They are so concerned with everyone staying within their predefined roles that customers get passed to 3,4, even 5 people just to get a 401K rolled over. Along the way each rep is charged with getting some sort of lead.

Title: I'd work at McDonalds or D'Angelos over this place (and some current employees have according to their resumes)
View5: It's impossible to get fired, but other than that there is not a single pro that comes to mind...how can there be pros when you have 7 long hours of customer service calls.  It's literarily call after call from clients who are pissed off and only call in because they have a problem.  Maybe flipping patties and making sandwiches isn't such a bad idea, huh?
View7:
The managers get paid to keep their reps in the call center aka prison.  You do not want to do a life sentence at this place because you'll wake up in 20 years and still be taking 7 hours of phone calls and making 40k a year.  There is no advancement at all!  This job will not help you get your foot in the door to move through the company...it will get you in the door to move from phone center job to phone center job to phone center job aka lateral movement with new job titles and more annoying clients.
This place hires photography majors, geology majors, heck even people without a college degree, so if you have a finance, accounting, or econ degree, look elsewhere if you want to start a real career in finance or any business field because this place is like a kindergarten for adults (why else are the walls painted mac n cheese orange, sun yellow, puke green?

Title: Easily the BEST run financial firm I've worked for.
View5:
I've worked for Scottrade, T. Rowe, and a couple others and this is by far the best run company I've worked for. You meet and work with the sharpest people and business partners. The exposure to products, investment strategies and financial planning subjects provides a Graduate level education in finance. 

Who your manager is makes a difference as far as culture and our is AWESOME. And for such a massive company, they are extremely aggressive with innovation and rapidly implementing changes to drive success. Top management really knows what's going on in the field and is nimble in providing solutions. Fidelity's value proposition and products often sell themselves so driving business is very easy. A FC role is highly coveted so if you can land it then it will fast track your career at Fido as its a gateway role to many other career paths.
View7: Multi asset class managed account performance.

Title: Call Center Representative: Great Coworkers, Somewhat Unpleasant Work
View5:
Wonderful, kind coworkers. 
Wonderful people in upper and lower management.
Some of the customers are the sweetest people you will ever speak with.
Really understanding and accommodating for disabilities (mental and otherwise!).
Great CEO.
Room for Growth.
View7:
The same problems as most call center work: 
The call center should have a more regular office-like environment and employees should be able to take their time with customer cases-- including necessary off-the-phone time (such as faxing, e-mailing, and account maintenance) without having to jump through hoops to do so.
The customers can be difficult to deal with and really unkind. Most people will be reasonable, but each day there are bound to be at least a few calls in which people are truly frustrated and you just have to have a thick skin about it or find another job.
Like with any job, there is always one manager who is very difficult to deal with. In the case of where I worked, this team manager ended up making the majority of her team quit because of her attitude. I'm lucky that I was placed with one of the other, excellent managers instead of her.

Title: Overall
View5: Great benefits across the board
View7:
Lower salary but overall comp
Is comparable

Title: great benefits
View5: great benefits, class A company
View7: too many of middle managers

Title: Good place to start
View5: Quality coaching and experience. Very redundant though.
View7: Fidelity’s call center revolves around Micromanaging. A good place to start but look toward a branch as a career goal.

Title: God Awful Toxic Sweatshop
View5: There are no pro's to this job
View7: Everything, forced OT, low pay, managers do not care about you. back to back abusive callers all day. 12/16 of my class quit within 6 months

Title: Nice benefits, good place to start, but opportunities may be limited
View5: They offer a good benefits package, including a 401k match of 7% and annual profit sharing which is normally 10%.  The health and dental are also good.  High deductible health plan with annual company contribution may be good for those without a family who are in good general health.  Good place to get started in the industry and get your license.  Also good foundation for your personal investing and retirement planning.  Some schedule flexibility, 4 weeks vacation after 5 years, and good place to meet people, for friends and romance.  Know a number of people who met their future spouse here.
View7: As it is a very large company, it can be easy to get lost in the shiffle and pigeonholed into limited opportunities.  You can also feel like you are just a number at times.  Individual talent and superior work performance is not always properly recognized and rewarded, it seems too often that cronyism and politics are more important for advancement.  Too many levels of middle management, often staffed by people less talented and motivated than those the are "managing"- a key point, as there seems to be too much managing and not enough leading.  In recent years, occasional layoffs are also a concern.

Title: Good Company for building up your retirement money
View5: Great Benefits. Fair Salary. For very good to excellent workers the annual bonus is nice. They provide 4 weeks vacation after 5 years on the job. Excellent 401K match at up to 7% and annual profit sharing at 10% of base pay or salary plus 3k yearly for a medical retirement account. They also have other benefit perks. They provide flexible work hours that take family issues into account.
View7: For at least the past 6 years advancement opportunities were limited. Merit raises have been meager. Due to cost cutting, departments are not budgeted fully (over the past 10 years or so) and goals of individual departments are not aligned to the corporate goals (except when it comes to cutting costs). This misalignment of goals causes friction and completion between departments.  Management is more top down as the company matures. Management tends to value, in all ways, those they consider superstars and "Outstanding" while ignoring the hard workers who come in every day and keep the company moving forward.

Title: Good Company
View5:
Good benefits
Good life/work balance
Good culture
Excellent training 
Paid licensing
View7:
Below National average pay
Less opportunities than promised
Takes a long time to move up

Title: Great culture - hard work
View5: Great teammates, great client offering
View7: Culture driven to perfection - work life balance not where it needs to be.

Title: Great company
View5: Company is great works with your schedule decent home life balance
View7: The technology is somewhat outdated and could use an update

Title: Great Company
View5: I love the company and the benefits
View7: really big and hard to find the right person to get questions answered

Title: Define Contribution Representative, working in the call center managing retirement plans
View5:
They sometimes give free food when you have to work overtime.
They REALLY care about the customer.....(not so much the worker)
View7:
There is mandatory overtime during the months that there is high call volume, i.e. January is when they send out 1099 R forms, customers call in for tax questions as well as statement questions. This is the time that the only way to get out of working overtime is to obtain valid permission through the program director. The overtime is 11 hours.
Another con is the phones are constantly ringing there is no break between calls as soon as the caller hangs up the next call is already through and you have to be ready.
If you want a job outside of the field you are in you have to wait a year to get to a different sector.
There are so many goals they want done on every call, you have to maintain a relationship with the caller, ask protruding personal questions of why they want to take out money out of THEIR 401ks, you have to get a guidance opportunity in where you feel like a seller, you have to get a PCC in where you talk about how much they are putting in their 401k...etc, etc. the list goes on, you have to get so much done in one call, every call.

Title: Hard work
View5:
1) 10% year end profit sharing (added to 401K account) and 7% 401k match
2) Stability of company
3) "Always learning" mentality, constant weekly coaching meeting to ensure we are on top of the market
4) Good pay if you can perform well (only speaking for branch positions ie VP Financial Consultant / Financial Consultant)
5) If you are new to the field the Fidelity call centers is the perfect place to start. Fidelity will license you, train you, and help you find the right department/branch to work in. Fidelity is big in promoting internal candidates.
View7:
1) Increased stress. Due to Fidelity's business model to constantly bring in new business we are focused on bringing in new business all the time. I never take full lunch breaks and leaving at 5 PM makes me feel guilty. 
2) Hampster wheel. There is no means to the end.  Managing a $1B book ensures you may get $50 - $60k a year in "residuals/trails" at Fidelity while at a wirehouse a $1B book may generate $1MM + in residuals/trails
3) Long hours. If you are looking for an 8-5 job, working at the branch sales level isn't for you. Work/life balance is tough.

Title: Overall like the company but major issues in some areas that need addressing
View5: Great benefits and pay. Senior leadership is wonderful, and so are the values of the overall company.  Many resources and benefits provided to employees including profit sharing, bonuses, training, tuition reimbursement and career development resources available.
View7:
Difficulty in advancing, it is a lot of who you know and are network with less of the skills that you bring.  Don't count on advancing unless you spend a lot of time networking with the people/ groups that you are looking to move into. 
Culture especially in the call center can be an issue. A lot of office politics and harassment issues that get swept under the rug by management.  Some are addressed appropriately (if HR gets involved) but there were numerous occasions I have seen management quietly sweep issues under the rug, discourage people from calling HR to protect other employees and things like people getting promoted after sleeping with their boss.  While this is not every area and all departments was something that was observed by myself and others in the many years we worked there.

Title: Great firm to work for!
View5:
Complete compensation package.
The company thrives on work life balance.
View7: No cons at this time.

Title: Terrible Employee Experience
View5: Hi pay, great benefits and 401K/Profit Sharing match
View7: Politics, Everything moves slow, Out of touch leadership - HR thinks they run the business

Title: Great Company
View5: Forward thinking, smart colleagues, opportunity
View7: Overall lack of transparency into reorganization decisions

Title: great place to start a career
View5: the culture is great and fidelity has great learning opportunities for people who want to grow and learn in their position.  the people are nice and the food is good at fidelity.  i like my co-workers and they promote a team atmosphere.  if you work hard you will make money but sometimes you have to be politically able to rise up in the company.  the work life balance is good and you don't have to work overtime unless you want to.  it is the type of job that when you leave the job and go home you don't have to think about anything.  i like that.
View7: sometimes the work can get routine.  you get in this rut and you just process things for other people.  the customers can be angry at times, especially in a downturn market.  sometimes the clients can be annoying as well but that is just the way customer service goes.  sometimes the bonus structure is very team oriented that if you are on a bad team then you can kiss a good bonus goodbye.  if you are on a good team then i guess things would be better.  sometimes meeting numbers can overtake doing quality work.  the company is putting in place a lot of systems that check closely what each person is up to.

Title: Stable and still a good place to work
View5:
Private company provides stability, and strong values allow true customer focus. 
Rocket-paced growth of the 90's has been replaced with slow growth and stability. 
Consistent organizational improvement. Sr. Management has improved over the last 10-15 years - the bad ones leave and the good ones stay are rotated through different areas.  
Although challenging personalities and work goals exist (as they do anywhere), respect and professionalism wins over personal ego at this company.  
Very good benefits, excellent 401k match, but health cost have risen substantially in past few years.  
Average employee tenure has risen substantially due to high retention rate and slower growth.
View7:
Long tenure in many areas limit promotion opportunities. 
Salary less than some competitors (but offset by benefits).
Management positions tend to be stretched thin, so expect some long hours.  Definitely some gaps in HR defined positions defined and business duties required. 
Salary growth has been non-existent since 2007. 
Hourly positions tend to have seasonal overtime which can be quite high.
Historically has been known by customers as a 'many-headed Hydra' due to independently managed business units and departments (this is changing due to customer focus).

Title: Painful Management
View5: Okay if you really need a job. Some departments can be very good. It all depends on the management. Decent benefits. good money management for employees.
View7: Overall very antiquated Vision and Resources. They overspend on garbage tech and cluttered interfaces and workflow. Very wasteful processes and time management. Depending on the department and manager it can sway to very, very micro management environment. Favoritism, politics. Managers and Directors with zero people and management skills. When people die at their desk and leave or take time off for stress, that's a big problem they need to address.

Title: Good for financial services.
View5: Good 401k plan and profit sharing.
View7: Compensation lower than full service brokers and RIAs.

Title: Great experience
View5: Learned alot along the way. Great benefits.
View7: Management not always the greatest.

Title: Ned Johnson is no longer in control of this company.
View5: If you want to be a low paid phone drone, Fidelity is the place for you. If you love being treated like dirt and feel that management should rightfully walk all over their employees, Fidelity is the place for you. If you have no ambition other than to make a paycheck and go home frustrated every day, Fidelity is DEFINITELY the place for you. On the other hand, if you are an IT Professional who places value on their contribution to a company and would like to feel that your efforts will be rewarded, Fidelity is a place you should stay far, far away from.
View7: Ned Johnson no longer has anything to do with the day-to-day operations of the company and consequently the goal of the current management is to take the company in the complete opposite direction to that which it was once directed. IT is now considered a low priority and the emphasis on using technology to stay at the forefront of the financial industry is a thing of the past. No new equipment, move as many jobs overseas as possible, reduce the technical staff to a shadow of what it once was, bring in the head choppers, and generally shift the emphasis to the sales force is Roger Lawson's method of running the company (into the ground).

Title: Great caregiver moany
View5: Salary and bonus and benefits package
View7: Long hours fear of layoffs.

Title: Good Place to Work
View5:
Great Benefits
Good Coworkers and Managers
Like the CEO
View7:
Poor training at higher levels
Basically Sales position

Title: Deceitful Management; Reckless Decision Making; Terribly Inefficient
View5: Pays is fair and when bonus and profit sharing is funded - compensation is fair.
View7: This company is horribly inefficient. Senior management changes frequently and with those changes is always a reorganization and change of strategy. Fidelity chose RTP in NC as the home for their $100  million dollar new facility and planned to add 2000 + jobs. They started off strong - bought the land, moved hundreds of folks down from Boston and then pulled the plug and decided they would rather operate in TX and other parts of MA. With hundreds of families making a committment to relocate for the company, leaving family, selling their homes in a bad housing market and taking losses on the moves and home sales - most that relocated were laid off before their 1st year finished in the 'new' location. Folks that relocated without a relocation package paid thousands of dollars to get to NC for the company - and the company decided to change strategy and then laid these same 'committed' employees off. Many folks made personal sacrafices for Fidelity - and the company just hung their employees out to dry. Very deceitful company - provides little information to the employees - and what is communicated is mostly not accurate/honest. The culture is highly politicized and very back-stabbing as the company has so many layoffs everyone is always trying to make the other guy look bad in hopes of saving their own position.

Title: Lots of opportunity for those who are hard workers and not afraid of change.
View5: I was able to grow into a career in software development, thanks to in-house and on the job training and opportunities.  The size of the company affords a great benefits package, with tuition reimbursement, and a variety of health plans, 401 K etc.   Because the company has so many different areas of business, employees can gain experience in different business units via internal transfers, and grow their career within Fidelity. Different areas almost have different business "personalities." The company also welcomes back any "alumni" who had left on good terms. There is a commitment to excellence and integrity to their customers.
View7: You will never work so hard!  Underachievers need not apply. If you don't like change, don't work at Fidelity!  (however, some people enjoy change, so this is a pro, not a con!)  Business units reorganize, individual jobs transform.  Depending upon the business unit you work in, there may be lots of bureaucracy or it may resemble a start up - this is why Fidelity is hard to generalize about.

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Great benefits (one of the best really!) the company trains you very well to get you licensed. This is a great place to start (but don't stay long)
View7: Fidelity is one of the lowest paying company in the financial industry. They start you at $38K. I have been offered $20K - $30K more doing the same for other companies. The quarterly bonus is a joke. If you are a decent rep you can max you bonus really fast. The company does not care if you have post graduate degrees--you will not advance for being better educated and prepared then the next guy. Also, the company has this weird mentality to promote women. If you are a woman and want to advance fast, apply here. Management will hire less qualified women over qualified men just because of their gender. I have seen friends who had 3 years experience or more apply for a job, and management will hire a girl who is still going through full trader training. If you are looking to get paid three times as much, get trained here and apply at Moran Stanley or eTrade. Fidelity does not seem to understand I cannot pay my mortgage with a class A medical insurance.

Title: Stable but bureaucratic
View5: Good work life balance despite being a financial company.
View7: Bureaucracy and lack of tech talent in senior management.

Title: Great culture
View5:
Work culture
Ethics
Flexibility
These are the advantages of working here
View7:
Work-life balance
Salary
Especially salary could be much better.

Title: Be ready to compromise your values...
View5: Base pay not so competitive, but generous bonus plans more than made up for that.  Good place for recent college grads to start their careers and get a solid foundation of experience.  Beautiful facilities, great design, and lots of art.  Lots of opportunities to participate in classes, seminars, information sessions, etc...both in person and online.
View7: Everything is communicated via 50+ page Powerpoint documents that no one reads beyond the 3rd slide during meetings. Annual increases are tiny or nonexistent, although the HR documentation indicates ranges for double-digit increases (dream on).  Some execs are reassigned to lead departments in which they have no experience and are clueless about strategies and issues.  Overall, they are very slow to take action on toxic performers, which causes turnover of  the solid performers who can get jobs elsewhere and not have to deal with the grief caused by the toxic colleagues.  Sr. leaders ask for feedback and suggestions, but rarely act on honest input - it's easier for them to manage the status quo.  Although the ongoing mantra is about ethical decisions and behaviors, I personally encountered an environment where confidentiality was breached and bullying was evident...the sr. exec chose to look the other way.

Title: Great job
View5:
Amazing benefits
The company truly values the employees
View7: The CRA role can be very busy

Title: Good retirement plan but pay and corporate values lacking
View5: Great profit sharing, 401(k) , match programs. Good training for someone new to the business
View7: Not easy to advance into management. More “who you know” then “what you know”. Pay is lower for such a large successful privately owned  company . Since Abbey had taken over most of Ned Johnson’s responsibilities, the company that was truly “ doing what’s right for th client is doing what’s right for Fidelity “ philosophy is out the window and it’s all about cutting costs and do more work with less support.

Title: Great Employer
View5: Salary, management, guiding values, team members
View7: Sometimes a little too fast-paced.

Title: Run Far away
View5: Benefits and education that's all
View7:
Branch micro management 
More worried about clicking than helping clients

Title: Overall, a great company
View5:
Amazing benefits - 401k (100% up to 7% matched), profit sharing, medical/dental, paid holidays, paid vacation, gym membership reimbursement, tuition assistance, student loan pay off, ability to work from home in many departments/roles...  I could go on and on!

Great work environment.  Nice facilities. Great culture.  Awesome folks to work with. Management  was wonderful.
View7: In my department  (Learning & Development), there are constant changes and reorganizations, thus leading to shifts in teams and eventually lay offs.  Fidelity is a chronic  "reorg and then lay off" company and I experienced it firsthand after being with them for 11 years, along with many others in my group - some with long tenure and even more with incredible talent.  Since the owner, Mr. Johnson, stepped down and allowed his daughter, Abby, to take over, so much has changed and not in a good way.  It is really unfortunate.

Title: None
View5: Financially solid company, Great benefits
View7: Continues to Purge the elders

Title: Great Place to work
View5: Great benefits and always room to grow.
View7: No issues as of yet.

Title: Alright
View5: Decent pay and remote work
View7: If you don’t pass the series 7 you will be fired

Title: Poor management
View5:
-Office Space
-Technology
-Support of Call Centers
-Good for someone looking to start their career and obtaining securities licenses 
-Benefits are okay - not as good as some companies but not bad either
View7:
This is a job - not a career.  Your role and upward movement with this company is dependent upon your relationship with senior management. It has little to do with the amount of work you do or your contribution to the organization. 

Extremely political atmosphere - most employees are afraid to raise concerns due to repercussions from senior management. There are some very good managers within the company however locally, our managers were very unprofessional and morale within the office was very low as a result. High turnover within company as a result.

Title: Retired after 20 years, Personal Investing side
View5: Private company.  The Johnson family is committed to the company & its clients. Reputation for innovation, eye toward the future, investing in latest technology and not afraid of shaking things up periodically. Great benefits. Great strides in opening up transfers to other Fidelity lines of business for employees wishing to transfer.
View7: Seemed to fall behind in leadership recently,  allowing competitors to jump in and grab credit for lowering commissions, other mgmt fees,  introducing  lower cost robo-advisor platform.  Mgmt did not tolerate and ushered in environment of encouraging change in all levels of organization.  Tone however seemed to be directed at older, longer term employees being labeled higher paid, against change and holding back career of younger workers.   I reluctantly accepted Fidelity's voluntary buy-out (VBO) sensing I would regret it down the road.

Title: Revoked Offer
View5: The employees dressed nice. (Read the Cons)
View7:
DO NOT EVER APPLY HERE. They could not care less about you as a person. They revoked my offer Today, a Friday and I was supposed to start on Monday. This is right before the Holidays and they knew about my current situation that a family member has CANCER. Not just a sickness, CANCER that I am paying OUT OF POCKET FOR. When they ran a credit report they found something that I didn't even know about, total around $4000. DID NOT KNOW IT WAS THERE. This happened on Wednesday. So I call the collections agency at their request, settle it, give them the information that things have been taken care of and they tell me today that my offer was still revoked. THEY DON'T CARE ABOUT YOU. They will screw you over, spit on you, and laugh about it. SERIOUSLY. The Recruiter did not care one cent. Now I'm completely screwed, no job, cancer, and bills. Oh, yeah! Happy Holidays! 
P.S. I have several friends who use them for their accounts and they will be closing them because of what they've done in this situation. And I will make sure this is all over my social media. This is REAL LIFE. I was COMPLETELY SCREWED OVER.

Title: Fidelity
View5: I think Fidelity is a great place to start your career. Their benefits are really good and affordable, and they have very generous PTO and 6 weeks paid paternity leave for men. I have read a lot of reviews about there being a lack of movement. I can honestly say that I could see that being an issue for some people. In my own experience Fidelity rewards being ambitious. A lot of people here have been in their role for a very long time and become jaded. Be ambitious,  take initiative, and it's not that hard to move up here. Comparitively there is a lot of opportunity here, if you miss out on that you have nobody to blame but yourself. Not to mention every manager I have met at fidelity seems to genuinely care about advancing your career. Quarterly comp is nice. Working from home is a other nice part if fidelity, but this also varies depending on your function.
View7: The salary is the worst part. You get quarterly compensation which is nice and can be a lot depending on your function but they rarely budge on raising your base pay. This is used as an excuse to not raise your base pay when you move around. Also, this is a call center job so not specifically a con to fidelity but these type of jobs have their ups and downs.

Title: Great company
View5: Compensation benefits facilities great people
View7: Lack of diversity at all levels. From the board to mgt

Title: Amazing Company Culture
View5:
Great pay.
Fair Vacation time.
Great Benefits.
Plenty advancement opportunities.
View7:
No merit raises. 
Only way to receive raise to move departments.

Title: Best job ever
View5: Awesome everything, literally changed my life.
View7: Nothing, absolutely nothing. Perennial in every way

Title: Know Your Management
View5: Fidelity is a strong company with a streak of independence allowed by private ownership. Good product recognition. Solid and very conservative with respect to financial responsibility. Many opportunities for career growth, change and diversity if you are able to adopt the culture. Good availability of resources including career education. Better than average compensation and benefits.
View7: Your success at Fidelity will depend largely on the ability of your manager to steer you within the maze and to protect you from the political environment. Don't stay in any one area/unit/department for too long as you will become "type cast."  This is not a paternalistic environment; do not expect to be taken care of. This employer typifies the characterization of the "disposable employee." They have a reputation for re-organizing every six months. This is, if not literally, virtually true. You must be very flexible and not cling to the past. Upper management is currently (May 2010) in a state of upheaval that has been ongoing for perhaps 5 years. Continuity and vision is lacking.

Title: Challenging work, decent starting pay
View5:
1. Starting pay is at or slightly above market rate.  Total compensation package including bonus, profit sharing, and 401K match are relatively good.
2. Many benefits including 7% 401K match, computer purchase assistance, inhouse gyms, excellent facilities, subsidized lunches, etc.
3. Relatively lax work schedule heavily dependent on manager.
4. Challenging fast paced environment built upon a foundation of chaotic reorgs.
View7:
1. Year over year pay increases, as well as promotion-based pay increases are way below market.
2. Benefits are being cut as a cost-cutting tool.
3. Seasonality of work results in very slow down periods and very chaotic up periods.
4. Promotions are rare; must be aggressive to pursue career growth.  Inhouse promotions substantially smaller pay increases than external candidates.  Very very illogical promotion system.
5. Technology is the bane of Fidelity.  Too many platforms that do not sync with each other resulting iin a plethora of manual processes that will inadvertedly crash one day!
6. There are so many process people; decisions take aeons to execute

Title: FPCMS
View5: The benefits are some of the best in the industry. The 401K match, profit sharing, bonus opportunities, student loan payments, etc. No firms currently come close to matching that level of benefits. They offer a lot of career paths and do a great job at hiring internally.
View7: With all of the job growth in the DFW metroplex, they are starting to struggle with talent retainment. There have been a few retention packages offered, but they are not working. FPCMS in WLK has gone through several leaders. The decisions made at times seem to contradict the firms values. The current leaders have their select few chosen ones, who can do no wrong. However, it is apparent that they have their own form of nepotism. They will force out people who may block their people from getting promo'ed. This has happened time and time again. People are taking on roles that they lack the qualifications for, just because they are favorites.

Title: Anxiety Inducing
View5: The pay and benefits are supreme. There is room for growth, but you have to actually like finance.
View7:
There are tons of metrics to adhere to, and managers are controlling. Let me be clear, you are not micromanaged, you are controlled to the point that you cannot get up to use the restroom. 

You will be berated if your computer does not work, as if you are supposed to fix that. 

If you bite back, your managers will gaslight you into thinking that you are the problem, not the super bizarre environment that they have created.They will ask you, if you are only "there for a paycheck?" The answer is yes, because they're only "there for metrics." 

The environment is not collaborative, and they will use you up until you are done. They are not dumb. They know exactly what the average associate's shelf life is(a manager told me so), and they will coldly and callously move on. 

I have seen world class people, get eaten up and swallowed alive. When you quit, you will be given a box and literally pushed out the door.

Title: It started out great and has slowly declined as management has changed.
View5: Benefits are good, pay is pretty good also. Trying to move in the right direction at the upper management level. The message from upper management is very inspiring and motivational.
View7: Micro managing employees to the point that it inhibits daily job duties. The inspiring and motivational message from upper management gets lost in translation by the time it reaches the field. Middle management does not want you to think that you have a secure career.

Title: Good first job, but there are drawbacks
View5: Good benefits to regular full time and regular part time employees in terms of medical, dental, and vision- the higher coverage plan has a higher cost passed onto the employee. 401k plan available with matching.
View7: In the Albuquerque site, favoritism runs rampant. Managers play favorites with staff and will ignore employee concerns, this problem extends up to directors as well. Also, Albuquerque is excluded from the profit sharing benefit that ALL OTHER SITES enjoy and pay is low for the job. They will try and convince you the pay is appropriate, however, compared to other call centers it is lower starting by far. To be clear, this is a call center job, while it may have different ways of doing things, metrics are the only thing a manager has to use to grade your performance. If your manager doesn't like you, they can find a number of ways to get rid of you.

Title: Need better recruiters and training.
View5: Good hours, great pay, no working weekends.
View7: I was recruited strictly for my customer service skills.  I was concerned about metrics such as call times, call quota, and surveys and asked clear questions about these issues.  In the face to face interview, I was very mislead.  I was told the main focus was on customer satisfaction, and this was not true once I was on the floor.  Our training about the subject matter was excellent, but we received almost no training on the complex and multiple computer programs.  There was no hands on training of the system.  This lack of training on an absolutely vital part of the job is why I had to leave the company.  Also, many times we asked a manager or mentor a question, we were told something that was later disputed.  There was no consistency regarding information.

Title: Financial Customer Associate
View5: Good work/life balance, opportunities exist, the 7% match and 10% profit sharing 401k bonus are very nice, too. It is a company that is slowly but surely seeking to improve the work experience. My managers have been awesome, too.
View7: Most of the opportune moves are lateral, Fidelity takes it's sweet time on paying bonuses and raises, it is a call center job and if you don't enjoy this type of engagement, opportunities are severely limited. Not many jobs here that allow you to critically think, but rather answer questions. Most co-workers treat this as a job, rather than something they enjoy (though this is not true for all)

Title: 4 years and counting - So far, so good.
View5:
I started as an IT contractor and was offered full time employment.  Great benefits,  work from home,  good people.    The word on the street is salaries are lower but that has not been my experience.  My salary is average for my position.  The bonus and benefits more than make up for any shortcomings.  Yes, you can make more money elsewhere but for me, we are talking 5%.

Technology is older but not ancient.  There are opportunities to learn new technologies but are slow to move.
View7:
It's a big place, so there are some politics and bureaucracy you must learn to navigate.  

Too many "true believers" outside the I.T. group. .... it's almost cult-like among the managers and directors.  This is not unusual as good jobs in general are hard to find and people outside I.T. do not have the same opportunities as I.T. folks.

Recently went to new "open office" layout and it sucks big time.   If I didn't work remotely 3-4 days a week, I would not last.

If you are an I.T. professional, your skills could become dated if you are not vigilant about it.

Title: Very Disappointed
View5: None that would out weigh the cons
View7: It all begins with job satisfaction, people in general tend to do jobs they enjoy and are passionate about even if pay is lacking, but fidelity has clearly missed the mark. A volume based discount broker call center where even team leads (managers) are frustrated with leadership. Upper management is not there to help build a profitable successful environment but make sure numbers on spread sheet are met. 95% of the people I worked with actively are unhappy with their current job and only stay so they can get their 5 year vesting. I’m truthfully dumbfounded at the lack of communication with management down to reps. I’m disappointed to say I wasted so much time at the company and missed valuable opportunity actually being able to advise build relationships. This company the last two years had tried to put a square peg into a round hole and has lost a lot of talented people. This will continue to be the trend because Fidelity is slow pace when it comes to change. Culture there was absolutely horrible with people just struggling through daily life and I hope those who read this can take this as a warning! Unless you are absolutely desperate or doubt mind being an un valued easy replaceable cog in the Fidelity machine you can do so much better..

Title: Excellent Company
View5: Competitive salaries, great benefits, flexible work schedule
View7: There are no cons to list.

Title: Highly Political, Layoffs Often, No Job Security
View5:
Very good competitive compensation and benefits package.
Interesting and challenging work.
Reasonable work demands in most departments.
View7: Fidelity is highly political.  Basically no matter how high the quality of your work is, if you are not "liked" especially by your direct manager you will not be around for long.  Department and company reorganizations are often and many.  It is during these times you risk falling out of favor and run the risk of frequent job eliminations. Once you are out of the company due to a layoff or job elimination you are pretty much out forever - unless you have a contact manager that will hire you. There is no job security no matter your position or length of employment.  Fidelity will never win any best places to work awards but the they pay well.  If you are looking to be loved, respected, or for a friend - buy a dog.

Title: Depends who you are/who you know- things change daily at Fidelity.  Depends on which manager will implement it.
View5: Starting pay and yearly merit reviews based on performance Lots of OT.  The company match is 7%. You also get profit sharing.  Health and college reimbursements. Company discounts to many companies - just say where you work and most of the time you get a discount.
View7:
Heavy volume call center - can’t sip water between calls. Didn’t hire enough people to fill in after many took the voluntary buy out package 6/2017. 
You’re expected to know everything that has changed and is changing and not all teams are unison in the messages that is announced.  Branding - it’s huge - it’s bologna when you don’t even get a chance to get to know that person- and they don’t forget it no matter how many years have passed, what hardships you have been thru, and where you are now in work life.  Fidelity allowed for managers and interim manager to bully associates.  Managers have their clicks.  You will get wrote up for using PTO when your truly sick.... depends who your manager is!  You will get accused for something you didn’t do- bc your acting manager says you did- won’t pull the call up but purposely stops the audio to say call avoidance calls for immediate termination and I was escorted out.  I transferred the caller to another associate and I never disconnected!

Title: Great place to work!
View5:
Very friendly
Great practical projects which keeps you engaged
View7: None at the moment while working

Title: LOVE!
View5: Management, Coworkers, Work/Life Balance, Culture
View7: A lot of information to process

Title: Excellent Pay but Political Organization with  Lots of Hierarchy
View5: You are working along side very smart, capable, and engaging co-workers.  This is a company that is generally focused on doing the right thing -- for customers and employees.  They do this because they are  proud of their brand/ heritage.  They protect their reputation vigorously.  Be prepared for change:  The organization is constantly reinventing (or improving in a Kaizen manner) itself.   Heavy focus on technology.  Fantastic benefits package.   Reasonable work-life balance.  Coming in as a new employee will feel like you are drinking from a fire hose:  a lot will be thrown at you in a short amount of time.  Hang in there -- it is worth it!
View7: Its a very political organization with lots of hierarchy.  Senior management doesn't always listen to the feedback they receive from employees.  While things change frequently, the changes are typically from the top (and not in response to employee feedback).  Some of the politics are a pain and there are always the 'management favorites' (you will find that in nearly every large company), but you will be well paid for your efforts.

Title: Excellent Place to Work
View5:
Good benefits, Good Pay.
Management listens to suggestions and cares
View7: Nothing to say here now.

Title: Great company for savers!
View5:
Outstanding company retirement benefits
Solid company brand
Positive external reputation
View7:
Leadership aspects 
Culture challenges
Mechanistic workflow

Title: Conformity Culture.  Innovators and Fast Movers Stay Away.
View5: The firm's client service delivery is second to none.  Abby and her team have recognized that the culture is slow and have attempted to make changes over the years.
View7:
Legacy leaders point to minor wins as progress.  Small thinking and high school culture wins, and friends are rewarded.   Medium bets are avoided for less risky career steadying choices.  

The Voluntary Buyout program targeted legacy leaders over 55, while giving opportunities to legacy leaders...over 50?  A clear message was sent.  What sense is there waiting for higher positions at Fidelity if you are in the first half of your career.

The same leaders drive the same mediocre results, and continually keep positions in the firm.  Repeated service model and strategy changes cannot change the mediocre managers leading each team. 

Leaders in the business with finance backgrounds do not bridge the gap to "innovation" in products, they can measure but are not creators.  Always concerned that if the market tanked, I wouldn't be able to sell products at Fidelity's prices with the cost structure so heavy.

Title: Fidelity Investments: Retirement playground for washed up executives.
View5: Challenges. If you like to be challenged, there's many opportunities. Start a project, then half way through it 'poof' the people you were working with are gone, typically replaced by inexperienced Indian speaking low paid H1B candidates. Salary is ok, but don't expect too much in the way of a raise.
View7: Executive Management is a revolving door. Fidelity is the place where 'executives' like to end their days getting highly paid to put their 'stamp' on the company. Almost like clockwork, every 5 years or so, executive management changes. Then the newest group of executives start their own slash & burn program to make the company more 'productive'. Once they've finished this wonderful task and decimated the various groups they declare victory, collect their huge bonuses, and turn things over to the next group of bean counters. Fidelity is coming apart at the seams because there are so many chiefs and so few indians left to any real work.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to work, but the environment has become much more intense recently.
View5: The benefits are great. I have had a long career at Fidelity and been able to develop my knowledge of the 403(b) & 401(k) business. The clients I work with are great. Most of my collegues are top notch. There is a great deal of focus around data security and customer privacy. Fidelity has a strong balance sheet and is convervatively run. I think that senior management is positioning the company to be profitable for the long term, which means that the future will be bright.
View7: Recently there have been a lot of changes at senior management level. This has caused a great deal of uncertainty about the future of the company. My department was moved from the northeast last year to Texas, and I am not sure what career opportunities will come up in the future. Financial services right is an industry in turmoil. There is another round of layoffs coming in the 1st quarter.

Title: Fidelity Investments is a good place to work for someone who expects as much out of the company as they put in.
View5: Fidelity offers extensive growth opportunities to those individuals who display talent and a drive to succeed.  In most cases the managers are very understanding of family and personal time needs, coupled with an expectation that everyone is a professional and will make their hours up as necessary. Fidelity also offers excellent benefits packages.
View7: Depending on your position, there can be an expectation of working well beyond 40 hr work weeks, though that is not a consistent occurence.  Occasionally Executive Management may have plans in the works that are driving changes organizationally, but which not all employees are privvy to at the time, and which can then make some of the organizational changes seem inappropriate (at that time).

Title: Benefits are great, but NOT worth it.
View5: Great benefits, help with student loan payments, reimbursement for health/fitness things, gym on site, awesome coworkers, fun environment overall, great company match on 401k plus profit sharing, good health benefits, generous paid vacation time, very detailed training, nice salary with quarterly bonuses
View7: No mobility within the company, managers are completely fake and act like they care about your career development but really don't care at all, they blow smoke up your you know what and make it seem like there's a lot of opportunity, but that's only true if you've been with the company for 5+ years, unfair treatment of employees by upper management, immoral conduct swept under the rug, ridiculous expectations, micromanaging

Title: Just a Cog in the great machine
View5:
-Benefits
- Flexibility
- It honestly is a good place to start but dont plan to stay for too long
View7:
- Fidelity views all of its employees as easily replaceable. This was emphasized when Abby Johnson and Kathy Murphy said in the most recent town hall that because they always have so many people come back to Fidelity it doesn't really matter to retain them.

It's a good place to start, but there's only so much growth with in the company

There is no way to change things at a decent pace. In my role my manager knows there are issues with how things are run, our director is also aware of them, and the site GM has some knowledge. Each level agrees with our issues and agrees that present solutions make sense, but that they have no power or ability to do anything about it.

Title: Benefits Specialist
View5: Great Co-workers for the most part.
View7: Poor pay, over working employees, no  job security, management is terrible. it's about who you know there fore most of those who are friends of team leads or management received positions, are then trained by those who have been there for years only to be rewarded by witnessing those they trained get back to back promotion. Mind you seven years of working with the company and most ( mainly of ethnic background) are just getting their first promotion. I was there 7 years was give great feedback during review time but managers always found a reason not to give me a raise ( I received on raise the entire time I was employed). One made up reason given when my manager spent a min tripping over her words to think of what to come up with was that she heard I spend to much time in the ladies room (of course it was not true but it was good enough for her to justify when I again would not receive a raise) Most of my managers were up north therefore  managed at a distance and visited maybe every three months per year. I could go on and on but over all I would not recommend anyone in there right mind to work there ...at least not in the benefits department. I had enough of being used and overwork and constantly being told I was doing great here is extra work, but not receiving compensation.

Title: High Net Worth
View5: Overall, I was extremely happy with my experience with Fidelity. I chose to move firms due to issues I had with my site and my role, not with Fidelity as a whole.  I felt that the pay was reasonable, but any gap was more than made up with the incredible benefits. 7% 401k match, 10% profit share, 10k of student loan payoff (after only a few months in the role!), and great health and dental insurance. The people are friendly (for the most part) and I had a great relationship with my manager.
View7:
The HNW role could be extremely frustrating at times, to say the least. We were fully licensed brokers, but the majority of my time was spent doing password resets and distributions - I'm not sure why the firm would pay our licensing fees only to have us perform repetitive tasks any (unlicensed) customer service rep can do. Dealing with the general public is trying - people will call in and scream/curse at you over something you had no control over. To be fair, most conversations weren't negative but the really bad calls could ruin your entire day.

There is little opportunity for career development (outside of sales) and a large bottleneck for leadership/management positios.

Title: Workplace Guidance
View5: Flexible work hours, tuition reimbursement, respectable café, lots of career development.   Slightly higher salary for a call center for the area but much lower than the national average for licensed reps.  Heck, it's lower by 10-15k base pay locally.  Co workers are nice and the building amenities (Gym, Stress room, walking desks, basket ball court, ping pong,horse shoes, etc..)  keep the day moving quickly.
View7:
If you're in a license role you almost have to leave ABQ to advance.  The ABQ hub opportunities have maxed out. Denver or Jacksonville might be better places to look into for above normal growth opportunities.  Low pay compared to the national average. No profit sharing but other sites get it.

Location is not ideal.  They should have put this hub on the westside of town.
Hard to get good quality scores for a while because each manage score card was so different.  Fast tracking fokes and nepotism in play.

View5:
flexible 
competitive 
growth
development 
strong leadership
View7: difficult to move positions internally

Title: Good Company Toxic Culture in Finance
View5:
- Good retirement benefits
- Decent pay
View7:
- Preferential treatment & resources for full time MBA grads
- Political culture / who you know to get ahead

Title: Mixed bag
View5: Great compensation, very good benefits.  The company is privately owned, so you are not constantly worried about the vicissitudes of the shareholders and whether it's an up or down quarter.  Don't get me wrong, they very much care about making money, but it's not the same grind as a public company.  Their eyes are focused on the customer as the one to please, not the shareholders.
View7: There are really great organizations within Fidelity, but there are also some organizations that are horrible.  Where I worked before I left they had no management skills.  EVPs would have a tantrum at meetings - yelling at the attendees.  They nitpicked everything, and never showed any appreciation when you completed a project.  Other cons include the fact that you have to have all your investments at Fidelity or jump through hoops for compliance.  You also cannot mention that you work for Fidelity on social media.  You have to have all your political contributions and volunteering activities preapproved.  I guess that's standard for financial services, but it's still a con as far as working environment.  It's hard to know where they are going with the Merrimack site.  They keep moving the technology jobs to North Carolina.

Title: Great company
View5:
Great understanding people
Management takes care of people
View7:
Low base salary
Things can move slow sometimes

Title: Great opportunities if you are a self starter
View5: Good management of the Employer services part of the company meant it was a great place to work in IT. Many opportunities to shine but it required hard work and you need to be a self starter. If you want to gain skills in running projects, managing up or down and overall leadership, FESCo was a wonderful environment.
View7: Other Fidelity business units are not as well managed, if you do not work in a group with good leadership you may have a different experience altogether. Security is tight, you will go through extensive background checks and must adhere to the companies many policies. As with any large company, there is a reasonable amount of red tape and paperwork to get anything done. Internal IT services in this company are particularly inefficient.

Title: Great company to work for.
View5: Fidelity offers plenty of opportunities to grow, and rise in the ranks.  Their benefits are one of the top reasons to stay at Fidelity.  They really value their employees, and try to make sure they are being taken care of.  Their pay is good, although not the best out there.  They don't require you to work as many hours as other investments firms to make more money.
View7:
Fidelity has certain career paths are that almost set in stone.  There isn't a whole lot of deviation from what they've outlined as the path you need to take to move upward.  It would be good if management would recognize the efforts in other divisions, and reward those that are doing well with opportunities for advancement.  
You almost have to work quite a bit of overtime in order to stand out as a top performer.  There is no 40-hour work weeks for the successful there.  They do pay OT however, so the pay is nice if you have the time to work the extra hours.

Title: Flawed Employee Compensation Structure
View5: I worked at Fidelity for 6 years as a Client Service Manager in IWS. Overall, the job is challenging and rewarding but offers little flexibility in terms of how you structure your day. You have 30 minutes for lunch and be prepared for blackout periods for vacation during seasonally high volume periods (i.e. December and April). Regardless of the experience, credentials and skills you bring to the role, you will still be managed like a $10/hour customer service rep. In my experience, don't look to your manager to provide career and professional development, that is up to you. Lastly, depending on the level you are hired at (i.e. 25, 27, 29) you will not be eligible for the full, advertised bonus. This is the great unspoken fallacy of this position. Your time, effort and sacrifice will be rewarded by giving up a portion of your yearly bonus to subsidize the more tenured client managers on the team.
View7: Lack of flexibility, bonus "bell curve", adherence to high customer service levels at the expense of human capital, increasing micro management

Title: IT is treated as an expense, not as an investment.
View5: There are a lot of very smart people working in the IT area here, and it's been a pleasure working with them.
View7: There are also a lot of very lazy people working here who have adopted a "cover my butt" attitude.  Taking risks and initiative is actively discouraged by multiple layers of middle management who are afraid to be on the "wrong side" of a senior manager, so the safe-but-inadequate decision is preferred over a better solution which entails some risk.  Too much paper-pushing and red tape in getting things done.  HR & Management like to crow about paying "industry average" salaries, which to me seems like a way to guarantee you'll only retain "industry average" talent.

Title: Great company to start a career
View5:
- Managers that care about your career and personal development
- Great benefits - dollar per dollar match to 7% of salary in 401k - Having a ROTH 401k was a great attraction for me
- Currently growing - Opportunities to move into your desired career path - Great for people who get hired on just to get in the door with a less desirable position 
- The company is big on following the kaizen philosophy
- The company is moving a lot of positions from Boston to Westlake - Great growth opportunity as many of the Boston employees do not want to relocate - Not having a state income tax was probably a driver for the move
View7:
- Your desk moved frequently, within 6 months my team/department has relocated within the same building 2 times - I think they do this as it is the only way some people clean their desk
- Slow moving changes
- Lags behind industry changes - Needs to move faster with offering of ETF's

Title: A Cesspool That Sucks The Life Right Out of You.
View5:
There's a roof on the building, so you don't get wet when it rains. 
The knives in the cafeteria are not sharp enough to slit your wrist if you feel the urge.
View7:
It's culture of lip service, where you're not exactly telling lies but close to it. 
The pay is horrible. I was paid $20,000 under the industry average. 
It's  a political game from Day One.  If you want to get anywhere, you'll need to invest in a set of knee pads.

Title: 'Changing but not in the right direction'
View5: Lots of good people, friendly culture, great benefits, great campuses with nice scenery and amenities. Interesting and challenging work to grow your skills.
View7: Low base pay, hard to get promotions, in a cost cutting mode, decreasing work/life balance, cafe food not that good

Title: Phone Center Trader
View5: Probably the best training I've ever been through. I was hired on w/o my securities licenses and spent the first few months of work studying and in the classroom learning the Fidelity systems/culture/etc. (white getting paid). They hire great people, so everyone you work with knows their stuff and is enjoyable to be around. The company is extremely generous (10% of salary profit sharing bonus every year, fantastic benefits - I even got a $100 xmas bonus 2 mos. after being hired). If you're looking to get into the securities business this is a great place to get your licenses and cut your teeth.
View7: This is a phone center job. Your schedule is 100% set for you, down to the 15 min breaks before and after lunch, which is understandable, your job is to answer the phones.
