Most of the day you're not placing trades for customers but doing some sort of account maintenance (pw resets, IRA distributions, sending them forms, etc.). Everything is tracked and monitored (again, understandable, just be aware before you take the job). After training when you're on the phones all day you don't see much of your coworkers, it's mostly about talking to customers at your cubicle/desk. The job becomes very monotonous quickly.

Title: Good Start Gets Boring Quick!
View5: They pay for your licensing training and pay you a decent starting salary. 7% 401k match after the first year and 10% profit sharing on your second year.
View7: This is where your dreams go to die. You answer phone calls all day long 24/7. You feel like a robot with going over the same questions over and over again. Even at the prestigious higher roles you are still only offering two cookie cutter solutions PAS (Portfolio Advisory Service) and Life Cycle Funds both of which have mediocre performance. As a Financial Solutions Rep we aren't even allowed to sell the product on performance. Why else would you hire someone to manage your money other than performance? The people that sell it don't even know what the performance is and its so hard to find you eventually give up. If you want to be paid a lot to be a robot selling mediocre products this a great place for you.

Title: Great place to work, but its not a technology company like they believe...Software Engineer - Leap Hire
View5:
-Great retirement benefits
-laid back environment ( my business unit no longer has a dress code )
-great set up ( 2x 24" monitors for everyone )
-other benefits are really great (maternity/paternity leave was increased, tuition reimbursement, college loan help)
View7:
-pay, team quality, manager quality, and the projects you work on differ enormously between business units and groups within those units
-too many managers with little to no technical experience making technical decisions (my boss still thinks git and github are the same thing)
-managers seem to make decisions that please everyone vs making the right decision
-hiring process was terrible, my technical interview consisted of the following questions:
        1) is javascript a subset of java?
        2) how would you write an SQL query.
        3) what is a class?
        * this sounds awesome until you realize how dumb you could be and still get hired if this is all the knowledge you need

Title: the best place to start your career
View5:
- great benefits
- flexible work schedule (depending on your team, you could have the opportunity to work from home)
- lots of training opportunities
- a culture that encourages career growth and movement
- no dress code, definitely a relaxed company that's focused on what matters: the customers and the services
View7:
- some benefits take up to a year to kick in
- base pay could be more competitive
- leadership expects folks at the team level to be agile, but they don't drive agility amongst themselves 
- there's little communication among upper management to each other on what their teams are working on to prevent duplication of efforts... you could probably find 3 or 4 tools across the BUs that do the same exact thing

Title: Fidelity has good compensation and benefits, but can be very bureacratic.
View5:
There are a lot of different areas of the company which allows for a lot of opportunity.  You can spend many years there and actually experience a number of different careers.  Unfortunately, it takes a lot of personal career management and "political" savy to get the opportunities.  

Fidelity is very innovative in their use of technology.  They have an amazing technology research center where they are constantly are looking to improve their systems.
View7: Very old school culture.  If you haven't been with the company for at least 10 years it feels like no one listens to you.  There is also a very strong aversion to change, you hear things like "this is the way Fidelity does it" and "Ned (the Chairman) likes it to be this way".  Unfortunately, I think people are afraid to question the way things are done.  Also, it is a large (50k employees) private company that is mostly family owned, so trying to drive change is almost impossible.

Title: Long timer - been through the good, the bad, and the ugly - things are getting better.
View5: Great benefits. If you work for the right manager and are smart and diligent you can make Fidelity work. You need to put your networking skills to work. Fidelity weathered the 2008 rather well considering others in the financial services sector. Fidelity puts a lot of stock in personal integrity and doing the right thing for the customer.
View7:
The company has grown a lot over the years and now is bureaucratic. It is hard to be heard and get improvement ideas through the system. There are many roles now that are high throughput and that can be hard on the people.

There is a lot of talk about investment in technology, but it does not seem to be focused on the right technology and there are decades old back-end systems that badly need some upgrading.

Title: Worst Professional Experience Of An Otherwise Productive Career
View5: The Pay was good compared to the S. Ohio / N. Kentucky area as a whole. Benefits were good as well.
View7:
As has been stated in various reviews on this site, if you are too intelligent, attractive, or bring sound business experience with you to the role, expect to be shunned eventually if not immediately. In the S. Ohio/N. Kentucky region there are not many opportunities, even for college graduates so its easy to scare the majority into conforming into whatever management requires at the time. Where else can they go? This was true even before the world blew up.

They will hire minorities but they expect them to be docile, weak and just smart enough to do what is asked of them. No matter how smart you are, if you are a black male you have little chance of making any real progress. Of course there are the "tokens" to make things look good on the surface. Once a manager even sent out an email to his team that had a Martin Luther King speech in it that said the Negro was still not free. Imagine that in this day and age. This kind of behavior is condoned in Covington Kentucky.

Title: They should change their name to Infidelity
View5: Decent pay, decent benefits, workable facilities. It is difficult to find another fourteen words to meet the requirements of this posting.
View7:
Good old boy type of culture there. 
If you are the type that enjoys getting credit when deserved, you can forget that here, but they will let you know if they don't like something you are doing. 
Too much fraternizing with co-workers going on, and not just hanging out (Holiday Parties are for employees only, this is where a lot of the Infidelity comes into play).
If you are relying on your merits to take you places, you can forget that here. It's all about who you know and who's jokes you laugh at.
Too many double standards (what is good for one person, is not good for the next even if they are suppose to be a level above you.)
Middle management needs to be thoroughly investigated.
They throw around the VP title to anyone; deserving or not.
No promotional opportunities unless you know someone.
HR is a joke; not really a support system and they are somewhat difficult to reach.
Fear is often used to try to get you to conform or become friends

Title: Great people and working environment.
View5: People are professional and they care.  Leadership is excellent and C level executives are very in tune with what is happening in the business.  Open environment where ideas are encouraged.  Fairly conservative and cautious company which means quality triumphs over speed.  This means you actually have time to think and do things right with less pressure to simply deliver.
View7: Not a performance based company.   While they claim to be,  monetary reward system tends to be socialistic with little distinction for a person's productivity. Much of compensation is tied to 401K as opposed to cash in pocket.  Will know more on this once I've gone through the bonus round.  Once you get hired in you are fairly well set since they tend to steer away from terminations, rather they look first to place people in another position.   This makes it challenging for managers who are dealing with performance issues.  But even with this, the vast majority of people are top notch.

Title: Get Licensed, and get out!
View5: The best reason to go to work for Fidelity, is frankly that they will hire anyone, from any background, and fully pay for the employee's FINRA licensing.  The testing program is top-notch.  And the campus is very nice, although you will never see it because you will be shackled to your cubicle.  If you are lucky, you may be near a window.
View7: Management at all levels really gets in its own way when it comes to getting anything accomplished.  The sole purpose of your team manager is not so much to encourage, motivate, or lead, as it is to make sure every second of your day is accounted for.  This micromanagement is the main task of your supervisors, who can be very creative at coming up with reasons to charge you with errors, which in turn keeps the bonus and raise levels down.  So basically, when you are given errors for actually helping customers, it comes to a point when the employees just don't care anymore.  Everyone only wants to meet quotas to keep their job.  And this comes at the expense of the clients.  fortunately, I was able to move on to bigger and better things, and have the microscope removed from my rear end.

Title: Investment operations manager
View5: Good benefits package, good place to get foundational experience particularly in an entry level role. There are some great people who you can learn a lot from if you end up in the right spot!
View7:
Large company with lots of office politics and red tape, even at times folks engaging in group think. As you move into management this becomes increasingly frustrating. Decisions often are made at the top without involving those in the weeds who know details, ending up with a lot of poorly executed strategic decisions and frustrated frontline managers and associates. 

The work life balance is not always as true as advertised, particularly for those who don’t have kids. 


Salary not always up to par against the industry/ market.

Title: Used to be better.
View5: Benefits, some good managers, work/life (depending on your manager).
View7: Many poor managers, only "horizontal" movement - forget promotions.  Many employees that are just not qualified are put into positions (often of power).  Everything is a secret.  Who you know is key.  I tried for 4 years to get into this company, when it finally happened, I was so excited.  The benefits were amazing, the perks were fantastic and everyone seemed happy.  Shortly after, they restructured, brought in the car salesman (ax man) and it has all been down hill from there.  Took away the pension, didn't even grandfather people in - absolutely ridiculous, changed benefits, rules, compensation, and basically took the "You are lucky to have a job" attitude towards the employees.  Lay-offs, RIFS, "site strategy" (which is how they now hide lay-offs from the press).

Title: If looking for a "career" look elsewhere
View5: Good work/life balance, most of the people were very nice want to see you succeed. I think my experience was a problem at the branch I worked in rather than the whole company.
View7: Terribly run office, clear training structure not in place, letting one nasty angry employee affect the culture of the whole branch. Management did not have an effective way to deal with a problem employee. I was hired with all my licenses and 4 years of experience into the financial rep role to eventually move into a sales role (after 9 mos to a year). After 3 months I had been repeatedly told by management that I was not filling the role "effectively". I received almost no training and was expected to not make a mistake. The job is not hard but being "written up" and receiving "warnings" for every mistake caused a lot of issues. They did not use me for the talents I had, I started looking for other employment within 60 days of starting. I have worked at 100% commission and was less stressed out than here. Basically I was a scape goat because the manager could not stand up and lead the office.

Title: Cares about employees!
View5: I honestly love my job.  I'm so grateful for the opportunity to work for a company that truly cares about their clients!  Providing excellent customer service is absolutely necessary and we take it very seriously. Fidelity strives to hire like minded individuals that create a positive work environment.  They review their salaries to make sure they are staying competitive and there's plenty of overtime opportunity. The benefits are great. Tuition reimbursement, 10% profit sharing, 7% 401k match, health reimbursement (gym memberships), etc.  They are very lax compared to other companies when it comes to using sick time, last minute vacation, and changing your shift to accomplish a better work/life balance. Fidelity is very open about upcoming changes within the company with all levels of employees.
View7: Not so much Fidelity as it is the industry we work in but tax season (leading up to the tax deadline of April 15th) and distribution season (retirees requesting their minimum required distributions before the end of the year) can be incredibly draining.  Last year we were slammed and it made for a very long couple of months.

Title: Great Benefits, Good Company to work for
View5: I worked for Fidelity for 5+ years as an Administrative Assistant for a Sr. Vice President.  I thought the quality of the employees was outstanding!  It was very different from my last company, when someone said they were going to do something it was 50/50 if they would follow through.  At Fidelity I would say 90% of the employees actually do what they say they are going to do.
View7: As for the Cons, a lot of the employees came from Boston and they are not as friendly as people here in Texas.  When I say that I mean, I said "hello" to people for months it seemed like before they actually started responding back to me, "hello".  Quite a few people relocated from Boston to Westlake and they were all close friends. That made it tough as a new employee.  On the positive side, once they go to know me they were great friends!!

Title: Good Luck
View5: Very easy and money just falls in your lap cause of the brand name. Easy competition for the stack rank. It's fairly new so it isn't micromanaged yet but it is trending that direction. More relaxed than other roles in the phone site.
View7: The compensation is much less than what it should be for the money you move in and service provided. Confusing bonus structure that is constantly changing and bonus is dictated by manager entirely and not by production and stack rank so it can be very bias. In reality the stack rank is pointless cause 2nd place can get a bigger bonus than 1st. It is starting to become more and more micromanaged. It has become more of an efficiency role instead of quality even though the main point is sales and not service. Very unorganized part of the company. It's a little niche compared to the rest of the company so there is constant change and no one including directors know what's going on in the future. Also misrepresented growth opportunities. They say they are expanding and you can promote to the more prestigious phone role or into the field however when one of those spots is vacated they backfill it with two people in this role instead of replacing. So be prepared to be stuck.

Title: Great Company But It's Still A Call Center
View5:
- Good base salary
- 401K + Profit Sharing are good
- Nice co-workers (obviously anecdotal here)
- Quality cafeteria on site
- Lot of potential career paths (but it's hard to get off the phones)
- Work/Life balance is very good
- Usually a lot of overtime available (at least in the spring)
View7:
- Terrible Bonuses (Overall pay is inline with the industry but Fidelity has a higher amount of base, which is not necessarily a bad thing)
- Training is below par. Most new service representatives have no clue what they are doing
- Business units are very isolated 
- There often seems to be a lack of direction by mid/upper management
- There is always a weary feeling that another round of layoffs are going to come back

Title: Great Co-Workers and Growth Potential
View5:
- My co-workers are amazing people. Everyone is very friendly, outgoing, and generally positive. I look forward to seeing them every day and miss them on the weekends!
- The training is bar none. They give you extensive training to pass the Series 7 and 63 exams, making it almost impossible for you to fail, and every new skill set you master is accompanied by at least a week of intense training. 
- The work environment is very pleasant. My desk is very spacious, the break rooms are well stocked, and we have huge windows with views of the mountains.
- If you're willing to work hard and network with people, the growth potential for your career at Fidelity is unlimited.
View7:
- The pay is less than it should be. Considering the complexity and responsibility on our shoulders with all the regulations and rules, we should be paid much more than we are.
- Some managers exhibit favoritism towards employees who are clearly incompetent at their jobs but are likable people.
- The micromanaging of your schedule is obnoxious, but it's pretty standard in a call center environment.

Title: Great company but no loyalty to their good employees
View5: Great pay, benefits, bonuses, PTO.  Great opportunities exist if you're the right kind of people and you can avoid the RIFs.
View7:
Training is pretty much non-existent - it's sink-or-swim when you're thrown onto a project.  

We're told it's easy to move around and try new things within Fidelity to progress in our careers.  I never found this to be true.  When I applied to jobs within the xxx division, I was told by the internal recruiters that the hiring manager was looking for candidates who had xxx division experience.  It didn't matter that I had over 10 years of valuable experience in Fidelity with plenty of other transferable skills.  How is someone supposed to get the xxx experience if you're not given the opportunity?  

Way too many re-orgs and RIFs with the loss of really good people. This leaves others to pick up their work when employees are already overloaded with their own work.   

Frequent changes in  managers leads to inconsistent annual reviews and constantly changing goals. It's difficult to know what one has to do to get promoted.

Title: No Growth, Bad Compensation
View5:
Interaction with several areas of the company, including portfolio managers and traders if you work in FMR, FIMT

Best 401k match when compared to other Fund Management Firms.
View7:
Based on my experience in the IT Department. No growth, impossible review system. you are also subject to "common judgement" by others who don't know you nor have ever seen your work. Always a chance of your job being outsourced to their India or Ireland locations OR you being asked to move to Rhode Island, North Carolina or Texas. 
Most Product Managers are incompetent and have only been promoted because someone got laid off or quit for greener pastures.Almost impossible to get promoted by merit/hard work.

HR also reminds people that Fidelity only pays 75% of your worth in the Market Place. So the base salaries are quite low.

Big push to move low level employees into the next step on the ladder. People at senior/principal levels just stay where they are whether they slack off just enough or put in some quality hard work

Fidelity has never won the Boston Business Journals best places to work for award ever

Title: Great benefits, easy to burnout
View5: Amazing benefits, understanding boss, comprehensive training, learn a ton on the job, frequent bonuses offered, always overtime, 529 clients typically nicer, opportunities for growth, tuition reimbursement, affordable healthcare/HSA, great 401k match, work with intelligent self motivated peers
View7: Super easy to burnout, it’s been so overwhelmingly busy clients often want to vent or treat me like a punching bag. High expectations on our stats that feel impossible to achieve with it being so busy. Bonuses are based on these stats. Feel isolated working from home, sitting at a desk, and not being able to communicate with peers since I’m always on a call.

Title: Dissatisfied in Cary.
View5: If you can keep at job at Fidelity, that woud be a "pro"
View7: Fidelity use to be the BEST place to work and the most respected company in the industry.  To have Fidelity on your resume gave you the advantage over the competition.  However, that all changed in 2007.  The company culture, benefits structure and management style changed suddenly and negatively impacted clients and employees.  The company has considerable market share and has been wobbling ever since, trying to determine a direction to steer, go public, sell businesses piece by piece, not succession plan, etc.  I blame Roger Lawson for the down turn, but perhaps that was his purpose.  In 2010, the company still  has no clear direction and their current employees are not high the mgmt's priority.  The constant state of layoffs and restructure proves a detriment to moral and productivity.  Where is Ned?

Title: Big on Vision and Teamwork, Small on Compensation
View5: If you enjoy a team environment working with other highly motivated and intelligent individuals, Fidelity is a wonderful place to work.  The company survives on a high level of commitment from its employees, and has been incredibly successful as a result, even posting record profits during the worst recession of our time.  Particularly during the first couple of years out of college, Fidelity can be a rewarding and educational place to work.  Most people consider FIdelity a good training ground for better jobs in the industry that pay a decent salary.
View7: There are countless opportunities for advancement, but Fidelity has done away with most opportunities for actual pay raises.  All job opportunities are positioned as "Stepping up and contributing to the needs of the business", with vague promises of "potential merit increases" which never come to fruition, or "increased bonus opportunity", which likewise never comes to fruition.  Raises are only given for major job promotions, such as from manager to director, and even then they are minimal.

Title: Always on the phones
View5: Benefits are outstanding, management is very respectful of employees, more ethical than other companies, and flexible with schedules if notice is given in a timely manner.
View7:
No advancement. It's all lateral movement. Hard to go vertical.

There were a few situations where individuals with consistently outstanding numbers never got promoted to positions they earned. I personally knew such a person and from speaking to him it was due to some issues with his manager.

Very family / religious environment. This can be a good or bad thing depending on your personally situation. 

When I was there, Fidelity implemented a terrible business plan which made service's function more like sales. It was done by making certain metrics, one is evaluated on, excessively high for sales like responsibilities. By the time I left, these metrics had been adjusted to more reasonable numbers. However, the service department still had a major roll in bringing in new money, without any compensation other than miniscule quarterly bonus.

Way to many metrics. You never know where you stand. I excelled in certain areas but average in others. My manager evaluations always made me feel like I was doing a bad job.

Title: Great company
View5:
-Amazing training
-Great benefits package, 401k, tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment, HSA
-Salary took a turn for the better last year, however it still is very low for the job done
-Open comminication with managers
-Team players
-Great atmosphere
View7:
-Controlled, call center environment that sucks the life out of you. 8 hours on the phones, only 30 min lunch and 2 fifteen min breaks
-When you are hired, you are promised a career path, but it is hard to get out of the call center right away
-Not allowed to apply for jobs within Fidelity outside of the call center, before reaching 1-year
-Late night shifts until midnight, hard to get an earlier shift
-Impossible stats to reach, they only want you to be out of your phones for 6% of the day. So if you need to used the bathroom and it takes lonner than usual, you are already havint bad performance. 
-There is no time to use outside of the phones for customer resolution
-Work-life balance not balanced

Title: A lot of travel, low pay, but great experience.
View5: You learn a ton about the clearing and custody business. You are one arm of the full implementation spectrum, but it allows you client facing opportunities as well as exposure to all levels of management and different departments. The experience, knowledge and exposure are the biggest advantages to this job
View7:
Travelling can be extensive. Each implementation is at least 1 - 2 weeks (including the weekends) and it's not uncommon to go from one to another. Some implementations are scheduled and promised by upper management to the client, for 10 - 12 weeks. There were many instances where employees would travel from a 2 week conversion to a 4 week conversion to another 4-6 week conversion back to back. 

I don't know if the pay grades were appropriate for this sort of commitment to the employees.

Title: No movement out of Call center
View5: solid benefits and bonus, was able to get Series 7 +63 after a year
View7: You take about 80 calls a day, Managers are not helpful and make the job even more stressful. They care more about customer satisfaction than they do employee satisfaction. Under payed and over worked. Expected to work overtime hours and shamed if you opt out. Don't work here. my mental health is still recovering from this sweat shop of a call center. They rant about how great their benefits are (7% comp match) which would be good if you made more than what they pay. The calls suck, customers are incredibly rude. No flexibility on hours and not very understanding on leaving early. I would not recommend this role to my worst enemy. I left on my own terms and met some really good people their but everyone is miserable because the job is ..... also don't expect to use this as a 'foot in the door type' because once you're in the call center there's no movement out. I was their for 2 years and got promoted within the call center but never once met or saw anyone get an opportunity that didn't involve answering the phones. Look elsewhere

Title: Merrimack Call Center: Worst job I've ever had!
View5: Nothing, unless you're a masochist.
View7:
Big Brother is watching EVERYTHING you do.  All phone calls and all computer use is recorded, timed, measured -  Anything you say or do can and will be used against you.  Metrics for everything and anything - Did you leave for break on time? (doesn't matter if you're on a call with a client);  How many and how long were your bathroom breaks?;  Constant coaching of what you said on calls with clients.  If you're not perfect, you don't get a raise.
They want drones, not humans, you're expected to say the exact same script every single time, no matter what.  They should just have employees monitoring calls from clients and push "Button #27" for the script for that question, "Button #92" for script for this question...  As soon as you hang up from one call, the next call is coming in, virtually non-stop the whole shift.  I'd be surprised if they don't run out of people in the area soon to fill those jobs - they've burned out so many and/or fired so many for miniscule infractions of their rules.  Doesn't matter how many 'Kudos' you got from clients that were happy with your assistance.

Title: Find the right fit for you
View5: You will meet some phenomenal people at the company. You will also have pretty solid access to people/education that you would have to pay for elsewhere
View7:
Boy are these people good at telling people what they want to hear. We were all told (by the president of a business unit) that pay would not be negatively affected by an operating model change. I know multiple people who's salaries were adjusted down.

Upper management is extremely patronizing. Though they attempt to cover it up there is very much a culture of "Mommy/Daddy knows best" when it comes to making decisions. This thought process is extremely embedded into culture there; so much so that despite a huge organizational change, my team's day-to-day work is still prioritized by a person who is two or three pay grades above my "boss". 

They also say that career mobility is something they encourage. In practice, getting in tough with internal hiring managers is laborious and conversations are often derailed by administrative interference. 

If you do work here, do your due diligence when vetting who you'll be working with. It's easy to get with people that drink the Kool-Aid.

Title: Great benefits, too much office politics, no concern for employee's mental health
View5: Benefits are great. Work environment is casual. If you like investing and financial industry, you might be happy.
View7: Though the possiblity of starting in customer service and growing into other roles is highly used as a selling point in the beginning, it is nearly impossible to actually do it due to the office politics. Layoffs or forced resignations have become the norm- they are always trying to do more work with less heads. Finally, if you have any kind of personal crisis, it's fine for a day or two. but if it affects your mental health and ends up causing long-term issues...good luck! You'll likely be PIP'd out of there in no time.  As for the work/life balance they are currently advertising, the flexibility is a joke if you have a family. Yes, it's flexible for the young, childless demographic, but if you need true flexibility, steer clear!

Title: New leaders across firm changing the culture
View5: I loved the people I worked with at Fidelity - smart, creative, hardworking, fun.  Most people care about the customer and work hard to provide great service.  Operations and Technology groups had many talented individuals and middle managers, but lacked a cohesive strategy and strong SVP management.  I had excellent training opportunities and career progression.  Fidelity was a great company for the 15 years I worked there.
View7: With the overhaul at the executive levels from 2007 onwards, and the revolving door of external hires at the highest levels, the frequency of organizational and strategic changes became intense.  Major layoffs took place in 2008 and early 2009, due in part (but not entirely) to the market turmoil.  The whole financial services field has been downsizing, so think carefully before you apply for a job at Fidelity if the stock market is still very rocky.  Be prepared to manage your career and build a good network.  Have a "Plan B" ready in case you get laid off.

Title: Fidelity offers a wealth of opportunities and potential.
View5: Very good pay and benefits.  Opportunities for growth.  Tired of your current position?  You can move on without bad feelings and still maintain your seniority.  Interesting and enjoyable co-workers for the most part.
View7: Commuting from Metro West into Boston is like working a 2nd job.  Work-life balance is something they try to say they are all about.  I suppose it depends on your position.  As a cube dweller.... flexibility is not really an option.  Constant change in roles and management hierarchy is difficult for some people but is the culture at Fidelity.  You learn to deal with it or move on....

Title: Progressive promotions as knowledge grew and flourished from my entry level position and beyond
View5: Best benefits I have seen and researched throughout the industry. Work/life balance is encouraged, and the programs provided by the firm are abundant.
View7: The promotion opportunities are not direct, they promote more of a 'lattice' structure. Best advice is to be involved in projects, extra tasks, etc. this opened several more doors and expedited my career with Fidelity.  Some of the leadership is quite weak and the politics can outweigh the actual business at times, unfortunately.

Title: Fidelity is all smoke and mirrors.
View5: Very nice facilities, excellent licensing program for new brokers, great health and 401k benefits
View7: Where do I start? The unnecessary micromanaging? The months of brainwashing? (They force you to watch countless hours of internally-produced videos during new hire class on why Fidelity is the best company you'll ever work for...). The secrecy of everything, including the breakdown of the bonus structure that is supposed to make your miserable job worth it. They make you feel bad for hating your job while at the same time putting under unmanageable working conditions. I had to work 10 hour shifts with a 30 MINUTE lunch, and if I took 1 minute longer than that, I got a threatening email from my manger. SERIOUSLY? I could go on, but there's so much that I could say about this company. Do not work for Fidelity unless you are desperate and have nowhere else to go. I've worked in call centers before, and this, by far, was the worst experience I've ever had.

Title: Great company to work for, but with call center setbacks
View5: Great benefits, pay is decent, and staff is great. They will sponsor you and ay you to study for the series 7 and 63.They have CFP programs if you want to go the sales route as an account executive.  Management actually really does care about employees, and listens to their suggestions and ideas. This is a baby call center opened in summer 2013.  There is good potential for promotion, however, only in client facing roles.  In other words, it is a call center.
View7: It is a call center and it is hard talking to people for eight hours a day about their finances.  Clients are often old and sometimes senile, often needing help online or setting up transactions. The work can be stressful.  It is busy year round and expect to take calls all day, with maybe the occasional meeting or coaching hour to break up the day.

Title: Workplace Planning and Guidance I
View5:
Great benefits
Student Tuition program
HSA
Profit sharing after your second full year
100% up to 7% of 401k match
Pays for you to get Series 7, 66, 9, 10 licenses
View7:
Managers use fear tactics to drive numbers.  
Pitch that the role is to help plan retirement but it's honestly just a sales role where you strive to put clients assets in IRA's and brokerage accounts.
Call center environment
Outbound calls are requested by the participating companies but to the customer, it is just cold calling.
Due to the industry fears, target date funds are pushed on everyone without access to the management service so there's no actual financial advising or RIA work.

Title: Stressful Work environment, fast pace
View5:
Decent pay
Nice co-workers
Advanced technology
View7: Licensing is absolutely draining. Don’t expect to have any free time. If you’re new to the industry make sure to do some pre-studying to stay on track with the class. Fast pace. If you don’t feel comfortable with the material and you’re not sure if you are going to pass; do yourself a favor and start job searching. Retakes are not promised even if they make it seem like they are.

Title: Wonderful place to live a well-rounded life
View5:
The work-life balance, benefits, and compensation package are the best I've ever had at any companies. The culture is collaborative and not stressful. There are many senior leaders that are women, including many that have young children at home, which I believe helps set a great tone for work-life balance.

Given the business is privately held and family run, I've found leadership to demonstrate more long-term and strategic thinking compared to large publicly traded companies. There is a desire to deliver today and plan for tomorrow.

Over the last few years, there has also been an earnest push to keep pace on rapid innovation with the rise of fintech and operate under agile principles. People do value pace over perfection and speed to market, but there is still a ways to go to truly be agile.
View7: Like many large companies, it can be bureaucratic and slower moving than I'd like (although better than most of the large companies I've worked at). Some individuals are motivated by self-interest and politics and kissing up can trump business results.

Title: If you are debating between this company and another -- GO THERE!
View5: It's a job and pays the bills.  That is what I can say about Fidelity.  It USED to be a good place to work, but things have changed there dramatically.
View7: Very condescending, little or no advancement if you are female with children or an ill spouse.  They treat you like dogs because they know they can in this economy.  Best friend comes home in tears - lecherous treatment of women in the finance side of the business.  You have to be gorgeous and LIKE that kind of attention, or male and have little or no encumbrances.  They are turning all of their business over the India.

Title: Truly best company to work for in financial services
View5: You might hear "call center"and cringe but the Fidelity regional center are absolutely amazing. I've been with the company over five years now and couldn't imagine working anywhere else. Casual dress, awesome cafeteria very low cost healthy options, the Westlake location is on a nature preserve so there are awesome walking trails to use during lunch or breaks. Lots of windows and natural light. The best benefits like 28 days PTO once you're fully vested. I'm making a great salary that in a career I feel I can stick with forever.
View7: Be ready for change with technology (which I also see as a plus). The new system you're learning will probably change again in 3-5 years. If a review for Fidelity is negative honestly they're probably in the wrong role. It can take a while to navigate to a dream position within the company (five years for me), but work hard, dress for the job you want, and you'll get there! Not a ton of work from home opportunities.

Title: Customer Relationship Advocate/Full Trader
View5: Some good benefits, good people to work with.
View7: Constantly monitored by stats that are glitchy at best and downright dishonest at worst. Bonuses, reviews all based on these overwhelming stats where every thing you do down to your bathroom breaks is monitored and used to stack rank you. Policies are constantly shifting, trying to move and learn and grow is often stifled. I have applied for 3 or 4 different sales positions, and I can only assume because I am a woman, have been turned down for every one of them, even though my misleading "stats" were good. These are the only ways to make a decent salary. They change your role, requirements and expectations constantly, usually to save the company money, and then spin it is something AMAZING! It's laughable. It's been a decent job overall, but the last year has been disappointment after disappointment.

Title: CRA role review
View5: Great and honest company that cares about its employees and it’s clients. High pay and numerous bonus opportunities through out the year. Extensive benefits package. Fidelity wants to help you succeed and grow in your career!
View7: The Customer Relationship Advocate position itself is the most draining role at Fidelity Investments. It has the most turnover, not because of Fidelity, but because you are a customer service agent via call center that services over 10 types of accounts, and you’re a stock broker. You deal with about 50-70 clients a day and 90% of them do not understand their accounts and/or the stock market. Because it is a call center, every minute that you clock in is accounted for via statistics.

Title: Great company
View5: The benefits are generous, including tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment, 401k match and profit sharing. Fidelity has a robust licensing and training program for new associates. The focus on employee success and well-being is a top priority of leadership, especially during COVID.
View7: Like any job, there are little annoyances and parts that are less desirable. Like, chasing down time card approvals every Monday morning. Don’t you want to get paid? This list of ‘cons’ will be different for everyone. The pros greatly outweigh the cons. Sometimes I have to take a step back and remember that!

Title: Sinking Giant
View5: Privately owned, provides flexibility. Great benefits but getting weaker. Good individual technology, blackberry, laptop, etc. Lots of smart, hardworking people there. Well known name, brand recognition. Morally responsible people for the most part with minimal backstabbing.
View7: Ownership has let too many outsiders come in and has not protected internal employees. Many top leaders have been allowed to leave. This is completely opposite their prior approach. People have to work very hard to succeed with little reward or recognition. 55-60 hour weeks are not uncommon and are expected. Management does not prioritize and simply jump from one focus to the next with no continuity. They do not allow an idea or effort to develop and show results. Refuse to ask the hard question and demand results. They are drowning under the weight of their own size and becoming more bureacratic by the day.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to begin a career in finance, however you'll be burned out in a year!!!
View5: Fidelity has excellent industry training, will pay for the necessary security licenses such as the FINRA Series 7 and Series 63, and provide on going training through out your tenure.  I learned more in a year and half working at Fidelity, then I have at any other employer!!
View7: Heavy Micro-Managing, Bad Work Schedules, High Turnover Rate, and Bad Compensation.  Do not plan on working for Fidelity more than one to two years, because you will become burned and stressed out.  The work environment is high stress with little reward or compensation.  Plus, you will have to follow strict hourly work schedule which includes only two 15 minute breaks and a 30 minute lunch (This is monitored to the minute...literally)!!!  The work environment does not allow for one to build relationships with your fellow coworkers, because you will be on the phone non-stop dealing with customers, and plan on taking between 85-115 phone calls in an 8 hour period.

Title: My Honest Opinion, longtime FIIS worker.
View5:
This used to be a wonderful place to work. Now, even through staff may be all highly competent, you will be ranked on a bell curve. Expect layoffs every year. It is highly competitvie internally and lots of favoritism.

Check rank on the Country's Companies For Working Parents list -- it will not make the top 50% is my estimation.

Due to employees not moving on frrm Fidelity no one was getting promoted. To resolve this issue and to ensure all the competent highly paid workers were shown the door to make way for new and inexperienced people to come on board, Fidelity was able to save lots of $. This does happen with many compnaies, and finanical services was hit hard in the past few years. However, this started before that economic crisis.

They work you hard which is fine. Just don't expect to be fairly rated, and don't count on the bonus coming through. 

Great place several years ago, but now it is cut throat and highly political.
Other firms seem to be paying a lot more than Fidelity.
View7: Be prepared for change all of the time and "ride the wave." Ther eare many layoffs, reorgs, and other stressful changes.

Title: This USE to be the Best Place to Work.  Now, not so much
View5: You are surrounded by smart people and will learn a lot.  You will most certainly get experience that will translate to any other financial services firm in the world.
View7: They have everyone at each others necks now for survival.  What use to be an environment of constant improvement and making things better for investors is now an every man for himself environment with everyone worried about saving their own skin.  It is tragic what has happened to the once premiere investment firm to work for in New England.

Title: Bean counting company driven by metrics
View5: Bonuses, decent benefits, large company with lots of other job opportunities, health-conscious environment with fitness center, healthy meals etc.
View7: Too many metrics. Rep performance is measured every which way. Working under a microscope is discouraging.  Every new management regime resets expectations. Result: two steps forward, one step back. Latest focus is "being efficient" aka doing more with less. Lip service to Work/Life balance. Business needs come first. Company is largely segregated: Lots of India natives in IT. Blacks, women, the elderly in Phones. Promotion is based on who you know which means company loses some high potential employees who don't know the right people and don't see any growth potential.

Title: Financial Service Representative
View5: The benefits are great and the campus is beautiful
View7: They reel you in with the great benefits and the pay sounds good at first, but after training is over they throw you to the wolves and you’re expected to know everything single thing they never taught you. Once you’re in the call center, it’s impossible to get out, even if you’re the top performer on your team. They emphasize work/life balance but be prepared for a guilt trip and lecture if you ever need a sick day. Everywhere outside of the call center seems to be run so much better, people here are overworked, treated poorly, you can’t even take a sip of water between calls most days and if you do then your numbers are penalized. Managers ask you what career path you want to be in but then do absolutely nothing to help you get there. HR is a joke.

Title: Business Analyst
View5:
Working at the Durham office had its perks that start with the beautiful campus which had an on-site gym, lots of walking trails, decently priced cafe food and solid office space to work throughout.

Benefits are very good but don't expect too much of a work/life balance.  Fidelity didn't innovate/realize early enough to understand the changing employer landscape which has cost it a lot of turnover.  Around when I left there was a large effort to catch up to and implement changes from market leaders in employment statisfacation/culture.

I enjoyed a lot of the mid level management during my tenure, but never really found upper management to be helpful.
View7:
-Lots of change within to reduce spending which also reduced employee perks
-Too many folks that do the bare minimum and are showed favoritism by management
-Upper management rarely meets with their associates below, unless they meet quickly to announce something
-Pay is below market average
-A lot of interim positions open up, but not many full time positions are opened internally
-Tons of legacy systems you have to work with that are 15+ years old

Title: Burned out
View5: Benefits are good and building is nice.
View7: Position consists of taking relentless inbound calls. There is no time in between calls and you’re pretty much hooked up to the computer all day. The metrics they want you to meet are almost impossible to follow so employees purposefully transfer calls to keep metrics low. My Manager criticized my calls so much at one point I realized there was nothing I could do to make him happy. Mistakes are to easy to make even if you are laser focused all day. I found a new position and was walked out after putting in my two week notice. They are paying me but i was unable to say goodbye to anyone so it looked like I was terminated after being walked out by my manager which wasn’t the case. Employees complained of being burned out constantly and management does nothing. It’s sad cause the employees are wonderful people who deserve at least 5 seconds between calls to stretch or take a sip of water but upper management doesn’t notice at all. I couldn’t take it anymore

Title: Bad experience
View5: My co-workers are what kept me there so long.
View7: Management is a joke.  They were extreme micromanagers and very cliquey with each other.  They made it known who they favored and many deserving associates couldn't progress in their roles simply because they weren't favored.  You have to take your breaks and lunches at the exact times they schedule you for (which differed every day) and if you got stuck on a call and went on break late, it would negatively affect your numbers - which ultimately decided your bonus.  This place is a sweatshop.  You are expected to take non stop calls your entire shift.  There is no break in between calls so you aren't even left with time to make notes on the customers accounts you just spoke to - as soon as they hang up, another call immediately comes through with no choice to decline the call.  On average there is at least a 5-10 minute wait  for customers to get through to a representative.  Customers are already aggravated by the time you speak to them - it's like the company sets you up for failure.  They clearly need to hire more people for the role.  The turnover rate is so high because employees are so unhappy.  Glad I'm out of there.

Title: Like most very large companies, it's very hit or miss.
View5: Fidelity is actually a bunch of smaller companies. If you're in FIMT or one of the trading companies, you're going to have amazing benefits, great pay, even free Cokes, Izze's, and cappuccinos in the break rooms. If you have a good manager, the sky could be the limit when it comes to advancement and opportunities. They do generally take very good care of their people.
View7: If you're not in FIMT or one of the trading companies, you wear the badge, but don't necessarily have the good pay or benefits, and you can expect to pay dearly at the cafeteria. Fidelity's companies are VERY siloed, so if you want to advance from one group to another and don't know someone there, or your manager doesn't have strong connections, you are actually at a disadvantage to outsiders trying for the same position. If you aren't under a good, well-connected manager, expect to slave at your current role forever.

Title: Good company - feels underpaid
View5:
It’s a very, very easy job. 
There are a lot of hidden benefits like working from home and high PTO. 
Laid back office life
You’ll get dank karma on reddit with all the free time you spend on there at work
View7:
Feels slow paced
You’ll feel like you’re making 10-20% less of a salary than other firms in the feel
Depending on your department, you’ll work on old tech (software developer working with c98 standard and python 2.6). It leads you to have to redefine the wheel often
Standard 3% raises if you’re lucky
it takes your bosses a while to dole out new work. You’ll constantly find your 2 week sprints have two projects that will take you a max of 1week to finish.
Some days you reach the bottom of reddit and you feel like you’re in high school detention 
On the job experience of the systems you work on is given out painfully slow. 3 years in and I’m finally understanding how the system works

Title: Sub-Par Management and Work/Life Balance
View5: Colleagues; Cafeteria; Benefits; Licensing Process
View7: I left Fidelity Investments due to my manager and the position itself. I was a Customer Relationship Advocate (fully trained and licensed) and each day on the phones was anxiety-inducing. I did not feel properly trained, nor did I feel comfortable answering a ton of questions on margin balances, options, etc., and despite that, I was not supported further. Just about every day, I would get yelled at by clients, and yet nothing was done. There were also very few breaks from the phones, and I woke up each morning dreading work and realizing just how miserable this position was. At one point, I had to go on a medical leave and I think I went 5 weeks without hearing from my manager. He did not respond to any of the emails I sent to him, he did not check in on me, and generally, he seemed to care very little about the associates; instead, he was very focused on the metrics instead. All of this contributed to a sub-par experience.

Title: All in all, a good place to be.
View5: Fidelity puts a ton of resources into training and is absolutely all about doing the right thing for the customer.  They do a good job of attracting professional people who are willing to help.  There are plentiful development opportunities and networking opportunities in the form of employee resource groups.
View7: Politics.  They vary by business unit but they can range anywhere from a nuisance to absolutely noxious.  Yes, I understand this exists in pretty much every place, but there’s a long-standing impression that people tend to get ahead based on who, rather than what, they know.  The higher-ups also tend to play favorites and it becomes fairly obvious who those are and are not.

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Good Training, Great co workers, good benefits, good entry to financial knowledge
View7:
At the end of the day, it's just a call center. There isn't that much room for growing despite it being a finance company. The job itself is not finance related, so unless you develop your skills outside of work, you can't really move away from the call center.

Managers aren't that helpful. They will spend time trying to coach you on things that might not even matter, or might not even work. They will tell you they will look for opportunities for you, but you are on your own.

Required to stay at your role for 1 year.

Long term for vest/match to go through

Company values high metrics, regardless of how you handle your job. Good Metrics = good benefits, even if you don't do your job correctly

Lots of departments to work with. Very messy and your metrics are dependant on other people doing their job properly.

Lots of favoritism on the office.

Don't leave the position until after 1 year if you don't want to pay the bonus back.

Title: Will hire anyone  willing to work for their wages with  access to very confidential information!
View5: Nice working environment.   Great countryside -campus atmosphere!   Great eating areas.  Nice parking garages located far from buildings.
View7:
Have to be related to someone or willing to manipulate the supervisors.   Most
employees have access to all account holders information in the privacy of their homes.    Screening of  personnel before hiring seems short.   This company seems to hire  inexperienced people to handle millions of dollars worth of accounts.  I have never seen so many  confused  people under one roof.  The company  keeps increasing responsibilities and nothing else.

Title: Great 1st and 3rd place to work
View5: Unmatched Benefits package.  7% 100% matched 401K + 10% profit sharing dumped into 401K annually  (=24% into 401K each year).  Annual bonus for most positions.  Company values are truly top notch and I trust the company to always do the right thing for the customer.
View7: Great benefits offset the low pay but benefits don't pay your bills.  You can move up fast but hit a ceiling very quickly.  In line promotions not an option for most positions.  Almost impossible to make real money without bouncing around from job to job or leaving and coming back.  Company is very cost sensitive right now so there is a lot of anxiety about job security.  They claim to be very flexible with work from home arrangements and a more casual atmosphere, but the traditional must be in the office attitude still exists for most roles.

Title: Be careful not to think outside the very small box
View5: They offer excellent medical and educational benefits.
View7: Working at Fidelity will be frustrating for anyone who likes to think for his or herself.  In the call center, you are considered close to a trained parrot, and the only value the company recognizes is your ability to regurgitate the same lines over and over.  Even after considering very carefully how to word certain items with customers, a management intern with weeks of relevant experience who has very little understanding of your job will listen to your calls and tell you exactly how they want you to speak to customers, down to exact lines of text that won't work very well and will cause you more problems with customers.  Thinking people will hate this.  Work is very boring and rote.  The tools provided to get the job done are poorly designed, and can hurt your call statistics.  You will be assigned a queue for a specific pool of customers, and some are far worse than others.  This too will affect your statistics.

Title: Absolutely BEST Employer I have EVER worked for!!
View5: Superb management who are engaging and truly care about the future and current success of the employee. Very competitive compensation package including salary, bonus, profit sharing, retirement health funds, 401(k) match, education contribution match, fitness reimbursement, computer reimbursement, and MANY MANY more! Fidelity's health, dental, and life insurance offerings are PHENOMENAL!! Family type environment run by a family from the top down. Excellent opportunities to move globally and into other job types and businesses. Fidelity is a highly diversified corporation with abundant options. Depending upon the position, many teams offer flex-schedules, including working from home. Training is available in areas both inside and outside of the employee's current role enabling them to grow in areas they are interested in.
View7: Interviewing can be challenging depending upon the role you are applying for. Also, if you do not have work experience or financial industry experience, it may be difficult to get your foot in the door.

Title: Work 12 hours a day till you get fired .
View5: Computer equipment purchase program. Discount on healthy eating options. Wellness center on campus. 10% profit sharing. On campus fitness center(family members are not allowed)
View7:
. 15% lower salary then industry average.
. No work life balance.
. You need to have a very good relationship with middle management to get good bonus and hike.
. Lay offs are very frequent, recently they laid off many due to bad planning of the management. Incompetent upper management with no visibility for future (not even for 3 months).
. Unnecessary works imposed on you to impress superiors of your boss.
. No training , no support to do your work.
. They manipulate teams at will without any transition plans. 
. Hard work and success is never acknowledge or celebrated.
. No fun activities or team building activities.
. Many a time no place to sit, untill recently (after they fired many people).
. Very mechanical work environment.
. Only one boring party in entire year on Christmas that to you are not allowed if your are a contractor and families are not allowed.

Title: Vice President -- Financial Consultant
View5: Overall a very good company with great benefits and potential career growth if you are willing to move across the country, depending on your business unit.   Also, this is a great company in which to start your career.
View7: Very large organization with business units in all facets of financial services to the point that, in some cases, they compete within Fidelity for the same business.  In the branch network, the employee needs to be very careful about the manager of the branch.  There are some managers that are not equipped to deal with people.  The one I worked with tended to treat everyone like they are small, errant children regardless of age and/or experience.  I had worked in a different business unit for a number of years that had very qualified managers who knew how to manage and motivate adults .

Title: Not for young people
View5: There are some good people there but that place is not somewhere for young people especially if you want to learn and grow. Advancement is not something that happens much and promotions forget about it. People have been in the same roles for 5 years or longer with no promotions. Culture is old and many older employees do not value young people and see them as threats to their jobs. A lot of managers should not be managers as they do not possess the true qualities it takes to be managers. They are trying to make changes but a lot of employees are unhappy and leaving.
View7: Management, advancement, promotions, salary, mobility

Title: Very good place to start a job, tremendous place to establish a career.
View5: Very easily to be promoted within the company, as long as you excel at your previous role.  Challenging enough to keep you interested until you master that role, at that time there is opportunity to move along.  Benefits are unmatched compared to anywhere!  7% match on 401(k), 10% profit sharing into 401(k) each December, quarterly bonuses, health packages, fitness reimbursement, almost fully paid advance degrees (i.e. MBA).
View7: It can be monotonous at times.  Initially, you start out on the phones as a Customer Service rep.  As long as you aren't a screw up in that role, it's easy to move along to others with more responsibility.  It is very much an inbound call center, however, training there is very good.  Still good education when it comes to market knowledge and very, very good licensing training (7, 63, 66... possibly CFP pending on how far you move along).  I have no experience in branch roles.

Title: Overall a good company with good training, nice people, and pleasant environment.
View5: Chance to earn some small bonuses during the quarter and at year's end.  Company would show appreciation by catering food for employees from various restaurants during tax season.  Obtained Series 7 and 63 registrations.  Worked with a good group of people.  Learned a lot via training and by being on the phone all day with customers from all 50 states.  No take home work.  Able to leave the job behind each day at market close.
View7: Worked was mundane.  Even as a Trader, one is stuck in a cubicle all day with a headset on shagging phone calls.  Listening to abusive and ignorant customers gets old real quick.  Little room for advancement.  Company is big on looks.  You won't land an Advisor position in one of the retail investment centers unless you look like a Ken doll.

Title: A decent place to work if you are patient and don't expect to progress quickly...or at all
View5: Benefits are decent; Management supports work-life balance; Tuition reimbursement program; Intelligent people; Upscale place to work, Modern building with amenities
View7: Bonus has never been what I was promised at the beginning, it is controlled by upper management who do not know and work with the lower level employees. They are more concerned with controlling their budgets, rather than rewarding and developing talented people. Difficult to get interesting and challenging projects, management is guarding their turf and does not delegate. Which is understandable, considering the constant threat of layoffs. If you are eager to advance, have varying assignments, get exposure to high visibility projects and rise quickly on the career ladder, this is NOT the place for you...unless you have really good connections and/or a senior exec family member. If you are, however, content with 9 to 5, easy, mindless work, go for it.

Title: Finance
View5:
You can define your own career path. 
Some of the people are good and inspiring.
Investment in new hires / first time employees  (time, rotational programs, benefits and wages / equipment) is good - but they ignore more "seasoned" team members.
Values and mission as defined are good (just not always followed)
View7: Promotions based on whether you are liked and mostly internal to each business unit. Push in some areas of finance to keep to lowest common denominator for quality and creativity which is demoralizing to those of us pushing the envelope. My managers (VP and SVP level) only worried about their own jobs - and they lied to protect themselves at the expense of their employees.   Plus - do you really think someone with 1 - 3 years experience can replace someone you pushed out with VBO ?  the rest of the team were left holding the work and failing.

Title: OSG OVERTAKEN BY MINDLESS HUMANOIDS!!!
View5: Gain experience in the financial industry. Good pay and great benefits.
View7: At Fidelity Investments there are too many politics. I thought I was in the novel "Catch 22" but instead of the book being set in WW2, it's set in Corporate America. Some of the most asinine decisions I've ever seen, including those in movies and on TV, were made at the manager level. Too many layers and layers of middle management who don't really have a function other than to attend meetings and self-promote. Some of the managers even make the associates complete manager reviews for them.

Title: Slow moving company with great benefits. Not ideal for software engineers.
View5:
Great work life balance.
Above average benefits.
Good company image and demonstrated success.
View7:
Comparatively low salary. Fidelity claims it is competitive but it isn't.
Does not understand technology. 
Slow moving and not very many opportunities to build a resume with marketable skills.
Career advancement can be heavily based on the politics of your team.
Very lax interviews causes many of your fellow teammates to be incompetent and unable.
Lots of offshore contracting going on. This means you'll be getting up early to talk to your offshore team and hating doing it since of the probable communication barrier.

Title: Drains you
View5: The people you work with, and that they pay you to study.
View7:
This job will literally drain your life, you're answering 30-40 phone calls per day. You're graded on your CEI (customer survey) and your CPH (call per hour), which sometimes you get surveys for calls that is not your department (wtf 401k calls).

Promotion is not based on your CEI and CPH alone, they will promote you if they like you enough. Good luck on getting a manager that you'll get along with, some of them don't care (looking at you Lauren, coming in at 11am and leaving at 3pm), and some are so obsessed with stats that they'll work your until you die. 

Oh you're putting in overtime? That's great, we're expecting you to, who cares if you don't have work/life balance. 

Stay away from this job if you can get anything else. Don't believe it when they tell you 'oh here is a Ping Pong table you get to use', or 'you can sit anywhere you'd like', because they're too cheap to build their own place, and they're overcrowding this office. 

P.S. you better drink that koolaide.

Title: Unfortunately more cons
View5: Good name to have listed on a resume, good benefits if you're able to use them, good food on site.
View7: Passive aggressive managers who are simply looking to gain top awards for themselves and drive metrics and stats. Zero time to actually utilize the benefits that are offered. They tell you overtime isn't mandatory but you need to have a valid reason to opt out and then if you do opt out, you receive emails asking you to reconsider. High expectations and low direction from many managers. Stuck in one role for 1 year before the possibility of ever moving around within the company.

Title: Okay, for a call center.
View5: The company has a great work-from-home opportunity for a lot of roles, the health care plan choices are pretty good and are affordable, and there are a lot of options for schedules, making it easier to balance work/home life.
View7:
The pay is not comparable to other major investment firms, and it doesn't keep up with cost-of-living increases we've seen in the Denver area. 
There is also a big difference in what some managers bring to the table versus others. There seems to be a 50/50 spilt between managers who show up, coach their team, and support their associates and those who, frankly, don't. If you get one of the managers who doesn't, there is no opportunity to switch.

Title: Graveyard of ambition with better than average benefits
View5: Parking,  Coffee, HSA, nearby trails.
View7: Management is only interested in one thing,  and no one knows what it is.

Title: Not a place to work Long Term
View5: Its a great stepping stone in your career, they do have a flexible work environment depending on where you work, Boston is hectic and down sizing all the time whereas North Carolina folks are more laid back and slow. Ample parking space in North Carolina
View7: Very little professional growth if you towards the bottom of the totem pole, very high turnover rate and employees are constantly playing musical chairs with regards to cube assignments or reorg in the company. Some professionals are given too much power and run the place like total dictatorship. Would never want to work here again nor would I want to invest my savings with this firm. Loyalty, reliability and professionalism has no value here.

Title: Great place to start, but move on
View5: Fantastic benefits, above average compensation, great co-workers, and lots of professional training.  Great place to start a career, but not a place to work for ever.
View7: Fidelity does believe in its employees.  I experienced it multiple times, they only believe in their name.  On the surface Fidelity appears to value its employees, but in reality they have no loyalty to its workers.  That will only become apparent after 5+ years of working for them.  The pay offset the negative aspects of the company.  You would think that there is room for advancement in such a large company.  However, that is not case.  The Pros do out way the cons for a period of time, 5-7 years.  After that, take your experience and move on.

Title: Not a bad place to work, and so much potential to get better in the future!
View5: Fidelity has a very competitive benefits package, and good opportunities for training and extending your knowlege of financial services.  There are lots of opportunities for working in different departments during your career.  The average tenure of Fidelity employees is quite long - something like 10+ years, so you could build a long career here if you want to.
View7: Management is out of touch with market direction and needs, and technology personnel are viewed as "overhead" or an "expense" and not really an investment in the future.  There is a tremendous amount of bureacracy and layers of removal between the customer and the people actually doing the work.  Having "fun" at work isn't really a priority, eveyrone walks around with their head down hardly cracking a smile most of the time.  It's all business, all the time, but a lot of efforts being duplicated and /or wasted.

Title: Great company, good opportunities when the economy permits
View5: This is a great company to work for. Smart, caring people (for the most part), great benefits, lots of extras, beautiful facilities and great managers (for the most part). This, at least my department, is pretty laid back and it runs very smoothly. Low stress job.
View7: It is still a cubical farm. There is a lot of corporate non-sense that you have to put up with. There are still some unqualified, and not-so-great managers who sneak in to their positions from other companies. Hard to move up right now of course w/ the hiring freeze and the economy in general. We just went through a reorg so it was very unfun to work here for the last few months, but things are getting back on track now that the panic has subsided a bit.

Title: Great career jobs with layers of bureaucracy
View5: On-boarding process has plenty of Kool-aid to drink (aka. "we're amazing and nothing wrong") that gets you excited for your new job, Plenty of movement during certain periods of the business cycle, lots of cross training, great retirement benefits and health plans, investment in employees, pay is great, clean, bright work environment.  Perfect for a long term career employer.
View7: Leadership is sub-par, upper management is extremely disconnected with the front line representatives and doesn't enable mid management, lots of politics, office culture seems inauthentic, very low flexibility on work schedule, forecasting always off, talk about providing best customer service in industry yet not providing tools or hiring sufficient staff, extremely restrictive of employee trading (no "bearish" positions, very hard to qualify for upper level options trading) due to policy not regulation, few rewards for service reps - mostly available in sales.  Very hard to effect any real change.

Title: Amazing company!!!
View5: I am so lucky to work for this company, and no I’m not sugar coating it, it’s actually awesome! We are going through a pandemic right now and I feel so appreciated and valued. They have gone above and beyond to make this transition so much easier, not perfect, but it felt effortless. The benefits even prior are unmatched, you come to work but folks care about you and you leave work feeling like you made a difference. I haven’t been here but a few months and I’ve already moved up! Your career is what you make it, so you must be proactive and go after it yourself! Also, managers treat you like an equal and genuinely want you to excel!
View7: Overtime can suck, and you sometimes question how to move up, but you are never alone in it!

Title: Don't expect to think for yourself in the 401k department
View5: I like the benefits... the 401k matching and fitness money is great.
View7: You get knocked off on call scores for insane reasons. They expect you to follow a script and be able to click through a window that tells you how to do your job as well as help the customer at the same time. Transactions that I know like the back of my hand take two or three times as long because I have to read through the "call flows" and sound like  a complete idiot to the customer. I have to read through them to make sure I don't miss some inane bit of information that I have to tell the customer that really does not have anything to do with the transaction taking place. I have seen employees who have been with the company for a long time let go or on last warning because they know the job so well using this tool slows them down.

Title: Once #1 mutual fund industry leader now slowly decenting to the middle of the pack
View5: The money and benefits are excellent.  Salary, Bonus, Profit Sharing, Shares, Life Insurance, company match in 401(k), etc.
View7: Performance is not always valued.  Mediocre resources can flourish and even excel if they are liked by senior management.  Pay for Performance is not managed well.  New Senior Leadership is cutting staff based on money not performance.

Title: Excellent place to begin a career
View5:
- Generous compensation: overtime is available (and expected during tax season), company match is great if you stay with the company for more than one year, quarterly bonuses that can be up to 200% of goal provided you hit your metrics.
- Licensing training is next to none and you will be very prepared for your daily work. Great way to build knowledge of finance.
- Lots of chances at upper mobility as long as you are willing to work for it.
View7:
- Working on the phones can get a little dry after a while. Management seems to be aware of this though and they are attempting to improve employee experience.
- What you are able to do for customers is limited as a function of your position in the company. Thus, until you reach a higher position, you don't necessarily get to do a lot of the fun things. This can also lead to customers feeling like they are getting the run-around.

Title: Horrible, like a cult
View5: great licensing program, thorough training
View7:
Micromanagement 
Stressful work environment
Poor Morale

Title: Pleasant at times stressful. Limited ability to help clients efficiently and a glass ceiling after 2yrs.
View5: Benefit structure is great. It's a safe place to work if you're just looking for a starting place to work, and you are content to grow a career somewhere else.
View7: work environment is placid, juvenile management techniques, limited respect for capabilities of employees. Employee morale and attitudes are negative qualities. Lower level management with limited to no brokerage and finance experience. Get the impression that the organization is afraid to take chances and people are afraid to put it on the line.

Title: Working in IT at Fidelity will be the death of your career if you are a true Tech Person
View5: Generally competitive salaries and good benefits.  If you are very good with Technology no one is likely to ask questions as they wouldn't want to reveal how little they know themselves.
View7:
Fidelity is very political and top heavy.  Over 25% of IT people have titles of Director or above, however this is not because of ability, it is because it is the only way Fidelity can retain staff.  These people would not cut it at technology companies where engineering and merit are central.

In order to accomplish anything at Fidelity, you must have countless meeting with many groups of people, most of whom will not understand any technical aspects of the discussion.  Instead decision makers will rely on people with inflated titles whom they believe to be technical gurus, but who are simply the best at appearances and politics.

Fidelity is extremely title, appearance, and politics conscious.  Your actual ability to innovate, be creative, or lead is secondary to these factors.  If you are a true lover of technology who wants to learn and grow, then you should make every effort to join a proper technology company.  Avoid Fidelity at all costs.
It

Title: Great place to work if you are in the right role.
View5: There are a lot of very challenging, rewarding, and lucrative roles within the company.  If you find yourself in the right business unit at the right time Fidelity can be an amazing place to work.  While base salaries seem low, if you are in a role where you are compensated on performance (commission, cash bonus, stock awards) you can find yourself making a great living with a great work / life balance as compared to the rest of the industry.
View7: Entry level and back office employees are not paid very much and are not eligible for many of the performance based compensation incentives (stock awards, cash bonuses etc.).  This means that if you find yourself in the position of being dependent upon one of these people to do your job, you are frequently greeted with either incompetence or apathy.

Title: An Old, Tired Company that Needs Improvement
View5: Good benefits (profit sharing, 7% match for 401k)
View7:
Its an old, tired company that is way too top heavy.  Particularly with senior managers who have been around for 10+ year and seem to be in "coast mode" and are out of touch.  In my specific group there are twice as many managers as there are actual employees (developers, analysts, QA, etc.).  This makes for a politically charged  environment.  Promotions are based on who you know and how long you've been around instead of how good you are.  

The opportunity to move up in the company by moving on to other groups within the company has recently been removed.
