You can still transfer, but it must be a lateral movement (ie: they won't pay you more for doing more, and any type of promotion is out of the question even though they'll expect you to do the work of people with a higher job title).

Title: Ethical, customer friendly and employee friendly company
View5: Great emphasis on continuing education for Financial Consultants,.  The company always emphasizes creating financial plans that puts clients in a better situation according to generally accepted principles of financial planning.
View7: It’s best to join the company young and completely buy in to Fidelity’s view of how financial plans should be drawn up.   Those with a tremendous amount of external experience may struggle vs those who completely drink the Fidelity  Kool Aid.  There is almost no flexibility or creativity among Financial Consultants.  If Fidelity we’re managing their business 100% according to plan, it would not matter at all which FC you worked with because every single one of them would offer you precisely the same solutions.

Title: Every Minute is Timed - Customer Relationship Advocate
View5: - Wonderful benefits (specifically retirement/retirement planning) - Everything has a process (not enjoyable for me, but a pro for some) - Overall culture from top down was positive
View7:
- Dissonance between corporate culture and frontline culture (find this in many large companies though)
- Micro-management built into phone-based roles (every minute must be accounted for on computer) 
- Difficult to move laterally (plan on sticking in your initial-role or something comparable for several years)

Title: Cookie Cutter Metric Driven
View5: Health and Welfare benefits are good
View7: Talent Acquisition stated the C Suite recognized they needed diversity of ideas and to recruit experienced leadership and talent from other financial firms to get some fresh ideas vs. homogeneous atmosphere they have. Well their entire 10-20+ year Team Leader and Manger level folks that arrived at the firm in their 20’s and are still there aren’t on board. They want you do it “this old way” or you just don’t fit their metric driven, hourly only, completely micro managed way of doing things. It was promising in the beginning, but in 15 mos. it was obvious the firm has problems. They touted Agile ways of doing things, but that wasn’t really what was happening.

Title: I love this company.
View5: Fidelity investments has phenomenal benefits. The healthcare premiums are fairly low and provide full coverage. The firm matches 7% of your 401(k) contributions and adds annual profit sharing money which is a percentage of your salary. The quarterly bonuses are quite nice too! There are many other corporate perks/discounts as well. I like the fact that I work with young professionals that range in age, sex, and race. Everyone at the firm is very charismatic. I've been there for 6 months now and I can easily see myself retiring with Fidelity. I honestly can't think of anything bad, especially since there is PLENTY of room for advancement/growth.
View7: It can be tough to advance (change roles) if you are an introvert. Moving around in the company happens by shadowing others, so you better show charisma and the drive to take control of your own development. Many of the roles require communication skills, so if you don't feel comfortable with public speaking then this is NOT for you.

Title: Good company, middle management doesn't have a strong backbone
View5: Fidelity is a family friendly company.  Most executives / directors / managers work with employees struggling with family hardships as much as possible given the employees responsibility level.  The benefits are very good as compared to companies in general.  Certain positions are able to work from home.
View7: Being a large company, getting things done has way too much red tape.  The company is not nimble.  Systems are very complicated and that doesn't allow for quickly adjusting to market conditions.  Goals set at the executive level do not translate to all divisions with the company.  Most promotions are about who you know, not based on merit and experience.

Title: Retirement Solutions Representative
View5:
+Benefits are top notch (7% match, 10% profit sharing, great medical, dental, student loan repayment program, tuition reimbursement program, paid family leave, new parent leave- the works) 
+Ability to be promoted quickly. Company is large- plenty of options
+Focus on promoting from within
+Focust on technology 
+Some employees are bright and talented
View7:
+Complete lack of transparency 
+Company is so large there is very little opportunity to affect change
+Low base pay, total compensation is dependent on bonuses which are liable to change on company whim 
+Regional centers are under-appreciated
+Layoffs are poorly communicated 
+Branch locations are understaffed 
+Lateral moves do not result in compensation that could be achieved as an external transfer 
+Some employees are complacent and jaded 
+The Kool-Aid is THICK

Title: Great Company with some downsides
View5:
Opportunity to try different careers. I moved around from a contractor to full time then moved into 5 other types of positions within my 19 yrs at Fidelity.
Great benefits. I was able to use adoption cost benefits, PC purchasing 3 times, continuing ed assistance, fitness reimbursement, etc. while there.
Last job with Mondays off and remote work from home one day was great!
View7:
Company is downsizing and relocating workers in an ongoing basis for the past 4 years. Folks that relocated to NC found they were laid off soon after. 
They used to RIF in large volumes but appear to do 100 at a time now to go under the radar of media. 
They do have a great severance package though for those with many years.
Recently it's been more difficult to climg the ladder due to cost cuts.

Title: Don't waste your time.
View5: Fellow employees are great. The business casual environment is a nice touch even allowing jeans on certain days. The benefits are well above average and can rack up a nice retirement if smart and utilize all outlets avaiable. Always drawings and contests happening on the campus which produce gift cards for the winners. I surfed the net to kill time on slow days.
View7: The work itself is mind numbing and employees are micro-managed to death. I had at least 4-7 people telling me 100 different things to do at any giving time. It is nearly impossible to succeed giving the matrix they must use to promote; meaning there is no rhyme or reason to it, they throw a dart at a board. They don't have a problem training you in different aspects of the job but only so someone else that used to do it can take a nap. Everyone hates the place that works there and thats all they talk about, all the time. If someone messes up, everyone gets yelled at for like 2 months. Gets old.

Title: Fidelity was an extremely challenging yet rewarding firm to work for over the years
View5: Fidelity compensates its employees well and provides an exciting and challenging work environment.
View7:
1) Constant re-organizations make it difficult to make change initiatives stick within the organization.  Each new leader wants to dismantle previous leaders work and rebuild in his own vision therefore some employees choose to not embrace change because they know they can wait it out until the next re-organization.  

2)  Mid to upper management his very political and tend to focus on their own personal agenda's versus doing what is right by the firm which frustrates the people who truly want to do the right thing.

Title: Strong reputation but future is concerning
View5: Great brand name with a wealth of clients, albeit quickly aging. Unparalleled technology and integrity. Exceptional brokerage platform for the self directed investor. Excellent preparation for career in financial services. Privately held by the benevolent Johnson family.
View7: Very robotic, little room for personal expression. Template driven environment that frustrates top performers. Production pressure in insurance and managed money accounts. Proprietary offerings carry high fees and below average performance. Politics and finger pointing on the rise as competition erodes asset base. Product offering does not resonate well with sophisticated clientele.

Title: Hard work and skills don’t matter
View5: Benefits ..... that’s all I can say
View7:
Hard work and skill doesn’t matter. All based on favoritism so all you gotta do is kiss their butt. If you apply in a phone call center, expect to stay there and rotate between different call centers for the rest of your life. Only opportunity they offer is different call centers. Two 15 minute breaks, one 30 min lunch and they choose when you take it. YOU HAVE TO TAKE IT AT EXACT TIMES . They recently made it so that you can take it 20 min before or after . Break feels like 5 mins and lunch is 10 min cause the lines are sooooo long in the cafe and it takes time to get your butt up off your prison cell and walk all the way over there sooo technically you got 5-10 mins to shove the food in the mouth. Easy to get burn outs and forces you to do OT or else you’ll look bad and lose that opportunity for progression. Flexibility my butt! they give you a list of unattractive hours that is available and you just gotta choose from it.

Just avoid applying for phone call centers unless it’s your last resort.

Title: Borderline discriminatory management. Mediocrity at its worst!
View5: Nice campus, free coffee, free parking. Quarterly appreciation event with cupcakes and games.
View7: No career. Politics counts for 90%, which hurts the evolution of projects and deliverables. Improvisation, lack of leadership skills, and management that plays favorites, not with those that contribute the most, or who do the best for the company, but those who kiss the boss's behinds more often. People will often take credit for your deliverables, and will also blame you for their mistakes and snafus. Performance reviews are a joke in all areas of the company, and the employee has no chance of refuting the facts. Management is often clueless, and worse, it often lies about status of projects, impacts, deadlines, or deliverables. Everybody is a VP. The less degrees you have, and the more bs you can talk, the better.

Title: Premium Services Rep
View5: Great benefits, ample opportunity for growth
View7: Fidelity has a reputation for chewing people up and spitting them out.  There's a high turnover rate and you're typically either there for a very short time or for years if you can cut it.  During my lengthy multi-year tenure, Fidelity's focus went from a very high level of efficient customer satisfaction fading into higher and higher efficiency to the point of rushing people off the phone if they had no outside assets to consolidate.  Higher level management tends to be aloof as to the customer and employee concerns/issues that reps are having to face daily on the front lines, oftentimes blindly making decisions with no idea or regard as to the unintended consequences that negatively affect employees and customers.  Advancement is based on merit to a degree, but company politics and who you know is much more important despite management's efforts to thwart this.

Title: Good first job
View5: Benefits, office perks, decent coworkers. Good job to have straight out of college, but they definitely throw you right into the role so be prepared to work with little to no guidance.
View7: Work life balance can be difficult for this role because you’re expected to be the first one in & the last one out. You basically do everyone’s busy work & you don’t get compensated for it. The role has evolved a lot due to COVID, you’re basically doing the relationship manager role just without the extra pay. I worked in an investor center so you won’t be micromanaged, but it’s hard to do anything when you don’t know what to do. Clients can be hard to work with. If you’re not looking to get into sales don’t even bother. They advertise how quickly you can be promoted within the company but it’s harder than they make it out to be, doesn’t matter how long you’ve been there.

Title: Awesome Place To Work!
View5:
I worked here for over decade, and I really enjoyed my time here. I remember the day I got hired as a temp. My world changed, and I was so excited to start my new hire training class. The people at Fidelity are top notch from the security guards, to the cleaning crew, to the executives. This company is ridiculously good at finding the right people who fit the culture and help others grow.

My manager had flexibility where required, and demanded excellence where necessary. I was never unsure of expectations because of the constant feedback loop, and I always strived to do the best work possible because of it. In my group, we had executive leadership involved as well, and even though I was a lower level employee, they were fun, respectful, and always treated me like part of a very important team. I couldn't have asked for more from Fidelity, and I was sad to leave.
View7: I honestly never had any issues here that weren't my own fault (and I had a few for sure).

Title: It will just be another large corporation when Mr Johnson retires...not a good thing.  He's the backbone of the company.
View5: The benefits and pay are equal and/or above it's competitors.  Everyone takes pride in their work and they want to do the right thing.  The tenure is high.
View7: There's very little job stability...layoffs have been happening every year in certain areas.  Not sure why, we're swamped with work and the company continues to make a ton of money.  That is a good thing, but they need to cut in certain 'other' areas instead of the same area every year.  Some of the old leadership must go.  The new leadership I believe is strong.   Maybe they will help breakdown the walls between the groups so we can get a lot of work accomplished.  They also need to get rid of the 'good old boy network'...there's a lot of talent in the organization, but they can't get passed the 'clicks'.  This is very unfortunate.

Title: Fidelity used to be great but is now just good and hopefully stops there.
View5: Fidelity supports work-life balance and has excellent benefits.  The work is challenging and mostly interesting.  Fidelity has a high degree of integrity and is a place you can generally be proud to be associated.
View7: Fidelity is a large, lumbering organization that is going through significant change.  This can make for a challenging work environment.  Processes to get day to day work completed are often cumbersome and inefficient.  Decision making is often decentralized and requires buy-in from many different organizations.  Strategic decisions seem to take excessively long and sometimes waffle back and forth.  This makes execution of the strategy much harder than it needs to be and sometimes nearly impossible to meet required time frames.

Title: Great if you have never worked anywhere else and do not plan on working anywhere else.
View5: GREAT for young people just out of college looking to get their feet wet in the Financial Services Industry.  They give plenty of support to new and untrained/inexperienced employees.
View7: If you have EVER worked outside the firm before joining, you will be extremely surprised at some of the cultural differences.  You really have to drink the kool-aid and conform if you want to stay happy.  Really nice people, yet the firm is in a distinct identity crisis about who/what they want to be.  They can't seem to get passed the notion that if you want to have a "relationship" that means relationship, not buy  our products (proprietary funds, managed accounts and annuities)

Title: 529 College Planning Representative
View5: American Fork Team:  Great team and awesome manager.  The company and employees are fun and expect to make at least a few life long friends.  Fidelity uses great technology to make your job easier and your team will support you a lot when you're new.  This is not a sales job, they used to push a lot for leads and sales, but have really changed over the last few years.
View7:
After you know your job, expect to be bored.  It becomes super easy and you'll find that Fidelity does not value the Utah office.  The only career advancement will be on the phone, but your pay will stop topping out.  The best advice is, to get a job at Fidelity, then have them pay for your MBA or other schooling, then move to another state to work for Fidelity or find a job someplace else.

Builds your resume, but does not really give you many marketable skills.

Title: Stable, established technology-heavy company
View5:
- Long-established company
- Numerous business units offer a variety of lateral transfer opportunities
- Not one of the "bad guys" of the financial world
- "Fidelity nice": a culture heavily focused on comity and professional behavior
- Excellent compensation and benefits
View7:
- Probably the most hierarchical management culture I have ever experienced. Management evaluates ideas largely based on the pay grade of who submitted the idea.
- In the technology space, change is excruciatingly slow. Initiatives flow almost exclusively from the top down.
- Performance reviews are based solely on the feedback of your manager, so a poor relationship with your manager (or an indifferent manager) will doom your career.
- Underperforming employees tend to stick around in their current positions (making life difficult for their team members and customers) rather than being nudged into other roles.

Title: Very conservative and respected, reputable firm can improve in compensation department as an I-Management leader.
View5: Reputable firm. Leader in the MF industry. Very conservative business platform and compliance/HR department that constantly modifies policies and procedures in order to avoid heavy risks and excessive business expenses.  The company has very driven and intelligent individuals that strongly believe in a team oriented work environment. The branch work environment is much different than the phone sites where customer service is provided to branch representatives and clients.  Business processes are heavily outsourced by department functions and organized according to a customer service phone tree.  Overall, the only improvement to be made is in the compensation area and the technical development available to the representatives working at the branches.
View7: Business platform is too large and departments are outsourced; created as phone sites versus subject matter support staff to advisors. Financial advisors are too reliant on software and not enough technical (financial) development is promoted by the company in certain areas.

Title: It is better than a punch in the face.
View5: The money, especially bonuses in my experience exceed the market.  The base salaries are about on par.  There are a lot of good benefits beyond 401k and health care.  There is supposed to be a work / life balance at Fidelity, but like so many other things, it is very inconsistent from manager to manager and business unit to business unit.
View7: The company has institutionalized the acceptance of failure at worst and mediocrity at best when it comes to IT Projects.  As a software professional, it becomes frustrating to work furiously at solving every type of issue besides the technical.  Front line managers are ill equipped to manager software professionals, they are either bad developers promoted to the point of incompetence, or just do nothing know nothing MS Project jockeys.

Title: Good place to start a career
View2: Customer Service Associate II - Tax Exempt Division
View5:
Company does value all employees, very family-like atmosphere, your benefit package is awesome regardless of your position being "entry-level" or management. 
Personal development is highly encouraged- If you dedicate yourself to be successful in your position you will be reward faster than you think ( Fast growth potential - Even if you start in call center)
Work/life balance very important to company 
Very impressed with the level of integrity and emphasis on importance of customer service, 
- you will be very successful if you come in everyday eager to go Go above and Beyond - 

**Everyone seemed happy, excited, and coming in with a  smile every morning**
View7: As a Company, there is not much one can say that isn't positive, they value their reputation very much, you can be very proud to be an employee -

Title: Brokerage Representative
View5: Nothing good other than the benefits and pay, but depending on the department you work for, that doesn’t matter.
View7: Managers could be oblivious on how they treat they’re employees. Will put underachievers ahead of the hard workers. It’s tough to find a department with a good work environment. Sometimes the department you work for, will leave a bad taste in your mouth about the overall company and leave. Sexism plays a part in whether you can grow or not, but if that’s the case, find another department, and fast. Idk how Fidelity can allow sexism managers to be where they are. I’m sure there are other departments who actually value they’re employees but some who don’t care.

Title: Fair Comp System, Not Great For Career Analysts
View5: Pay system is pretty fair and straightforward. A lot of busy work, but great access and resources.
View7: Clique-y and clubby. A lot of Fidelity people socialize together as well as work together. Good if you like that sort of thing. PM driven. They have never gotten a career analyst role integrated into the system. Analsyts can burn a HUGE amount of cycles holding pro forma meetings that deliver no insight. Great access, but "water water everywhere, not a drop to drink" in terms of being able to really drill down into your companies in person.

Title: Institutional Trade Support
View5: It is a very fast pace role with hundreds of phone calls and trade issues need to be addressed on the daily basis. Such environment is good for a entry level individuals who would like to establish his/her career in trading. The team that I worked with are fabulous individuals with great industry knowledge and years of experience.
View7: Since it is family own, you really have to play politics well to survive and move up. There are individuals in the management team that are really not suitable for their roles while others that are really capable got ouster after losing the political fight. Also Fido's salary is kind of lag behind the industry, so do expect getting paid a little less than the peers.

Title: Great place to work but......
View5: Competitive salary and can provide great experience. I worked in several different groups including workplace investing, brokerage operations and technology and have been very happy working in my current role.
View7: Focuses too much on younger talent instead of looking at those with experience. work/life balance is good but can be detrimental if you want to move up. People without families are able to participate in after work socializing and are able to mingle with senior managers whose kids are grown up. As a result, those of us with families tend be left behind those who are single and can go out and drink with the V.P.s and get moved ahead.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to work, but could be limiting in career growth
View5: Outstanding benfits package, beautiful campus, professional atmosphere, good work/life balance, challenging projects, and Fidelity gives back to the community.
View7: Arbitrary performance review and bonus review ratings.  As a regular worker you are very unlikely to see the E (exceptional) or O (outstanding) performance review ratings, those seemed to be reserved for managers and connected people.  While many get promoted, they are usually "in-line" promotions worked out with existing managers.  If you post for a higher level position on the internal job board you are unlikely to get it.

Title: Nothing lasts forever
View5: The first 8-10 of my 16 years were good.  Work was challenging but rewarding.  New ideas and approaches were encouraged.  Teams of talented, hard working professionals defined the company.  Employees were told that they were the number one asset.
View7: Too much focus on process and too little on work that added value to the firm.  Offshoring and dumping people in Texas has eliminated nearly every tech job in Boston;  any honest audit of the 'site strategy' will show that it has been an ill-conceived disaster.  The costs are much higher and very little is getting done.

Title: Fantastic, everyones very kind and hard working. Food in the cafeteria is great and reasonably priced. Well managed.
View5: People as well as the opportunities to change roles within the company. Everyone here seems to work hard and their are few shortfalls with the benefits that we receive. It has personally led me to grow as an individual as well as gain valuable experience in the financial services industries. I personally feel lucky that I had the opportunity to work at such a wonderful company and hope to continue my career here for years to come.
View7: Can be stressful with the workload, half the time it seems like your in meetings receiving work than you are actually doing work. Will have to work late hours a lot to make up for the work you could not complete during the day and sometimes you are working 60 hour weeks to keep up with the demand. It is manageable but it can lead to stress, less sleep and worrying. The paycheck does make up for this however as they are a company that does pay pretty well.

Title: 10 year veteran
View5: Privately owned company with huge market-share.  Fidelity still keeps the customer-first approach and believes heavily in creating a great job-experience for it's employees.  The benefits are good and they seem to be continuously looking for ways to improve upon the existing benefits package.
View7: Fidelity isn't known for being the highest paying employment option.  They know that the trade-off is that you get a better overall day to day experience working here than you might working for a competitor who might pay better.

Title: Financial service rep
View5:
Great paid training program to pass 7 & 63 licencing exams. They pay you to study and train you well with an extremely high pass rate for the exams. 

Continued training and development is very good. 

A lot of good benefit programs like loan repayment, computer reimbursement, bonuses, 6 weeks of paternity leave, a lot of other random benefits that are great.
View7:
Very restrictive on personal trading. If you like to trade in your own account they restrict the number of trades you can do per quarter to about 60. This might not matter to some people but for others it is restricting. 
They limit you to long only positions in your personal account unless using it as a hedge. You can short index ETFs. Again this might not matter to some people but could be restrictive if you like to trade.

Overall it is a very mundane job. Some people love it and it is a great fit but you are tied to a desk and a phone which did not work for me.

Title: Representative
View5: Team managers are great but have a limited voice. Everyone is nice that you work with , but nice does not pay the bills.
View7: When you have three financial licenses and have been here for a few years you still make less than almost anyone you know, especially in the financial industry.

Title: Fidelity has Lost it's Way
View5: good benefits, good place to work right out of school (resume builder), opportunity to move around if you are not sure what you want to do with your career
View7:
They have bought or pushed out any decent leaders that knew how to lead, inspire and engage people. The focus now is on young, cheap talent and  "mobility." Forget about climbing the company ladder, they expect you to move around in lateral jobs like you are interchangeable pieces of a puzzle. ( I am on my 4th manager in a little over a year without even changing jobs). 

If you have more than 10 years in the workforce, I would not waste your time here as it will be a dead end.

Title: Workplace Planning & Guidance Consultant
View5: I enjoyed autonomy, I created my own schedule, although certainly certain goals had to be met. I was paid a salary, plus a variable compensation, which was largely derived from my activities, so I had a better chance to drive my own success.
View7: For my region, a huge amount of travel was required, which took much of my productive time. This was often not the case with my peers, whom I was ranked against. Certain employer events would also cause flows of assets beyond my control. They attempted to capture this in the goal setting, but that was done so far in advance that it was certainly not an exact science. The travel time made it very difficult to have much of a personal or social life as well. I often worked 12 hour days, and then spent the evenings doing all the paperwork and entering notes into our tracking system, so it wasn't unusual to have a 14-15 hour day, then have to catch a plane to another location and do it all again the next day.

Title: Top Tier Company
View5: Fidelity Investments is one of the top company's in the financial industry.  The firm's focus on workplace atmosphere, collaboration, career growth, benefits, and work-life balance make one of the most rewarding and enjoyable employer's.  Fidelity also regularly hires third party company's to conduct employee surveys, and that feedback is taken very seriously.  I say this because I've seen senior management respond to areas of improvement with meaningful and relevant changes that enhance the working lives of Fidelity's associates.
View7: The usual large company drawback's apply.  If you're looking to work on the most cutting edge technology or explore ways to disrupt industries, maybe it isn't the best place to work.  Although Fidelity focuses on innovation strategies and new markets, it's size means that change does not come quickly, for the most part, as there are many processes and controls wrapped around existing models. There are also significant regulations to which all players in the financial services industry must adhere, which is fine, but learning and adhering to those regulations limits flexibility.

Title: Enough fooling around - time to start focusing on the business at hand and your employees.
View5: Benefits and the employees in the Human Resources services company are great to work with.
View7: Constant distraction of reorganizations and reductions in force. No clear direction in the Human Resources Services Company. While this Fidelity Company is over 10 years old they are still trying to figure out who they want to be when they grow up. Opportunities, career advancement, salary increases and bonus are based on who you know not job performance. No consistency in roles, employees in team leaders and managers positions play the same roles with the same and in some cases more responsibility as the Directors and VP's but without the same salaries, title and bonuses potential.  Employees continue to pay for the sins of poor decisions made by Senior Management team by way of continued reduction in the merit increase and bonus pool to make up for financial losses incurred  by poor decisions.

Title: It once was a great place to work.  I'd stay away for a while until things shake out one way or the other.
View5: There are some very fine people who work there, and the environment is professional.  Many projects are well funded, and they take a long term approach to projects -- so you usually have what you need to get things done.  There is a commitment to integrity.  The benefits are quite nice.
View7: The management seems to have lost focus and is spinning around creating turmoil and fear. There is a lot of internal strife and politics.  Groups are set up to compete with each other, and this causes in-fighting.  They compete with each other, and loose focus on competing with their external competitors.  I think Ned lost control of the company, and it seems to me that the family cares more about their assets than about the company.  It's a family biz, and the family comes first.

Title: Great place to work, but you will get burnt out easily
View5: Fidelity really has the name brand recognition in the industry. People generally respect Fidelity as a whole. They also have a very good benefits package, and between a 7% 401k match and profit sharing, they take good year of your retirement account. Also, with Fidelity being a privately held company, they have a little bit more flexibility to do what is right for the employees.
View7: I have come to find that it is a very micro-managed company, where management really is not in tune with what is happening in the real world. With regards to work/life balance, there are too many times where you need to take your work home to get to know the materials better or study for a presentation, and there is definitely not enough time off. There is also too many worries about "perception is reality", and you always have to watch who takes notice or looks over your shoulder.

Title: Once a good company to work for but now it is just a sweat shop
View5: There are a number of different jobs, so you can move around and gain a lot of knowledge about different practices, procedures, environments, etc.
View7: At one time Fidelity was a premier company to work for but over the past 5 or 6 years it has gone in the toilet.  There is no longer any loyality to anyone, no matter how much knowledge they have, how beneficial they have been to the company, and their peers.  It is all about the bottom line and if you were paid too much, look out you may just get axed.

Title: Decent and Stable Place to Work
View5:
-Portrays a good image of how it cares for employees. 
-The profit sharing and match for the 401k is outstanding and the work environment is decent. 
-Stable job environment, do not like laying off employees.
Fair amount of time off for vacation and maternity or paternity leave.
-Clients are sometimes good and sometimes bad to work with.
View7:
-All jobs are very much dumbed down, verymuch top-down management.
-Gradually increasing benefits cost to employees, next year, health care costs will rise substantially.
-Very limited upward growth for higher paying rep based jobs.  (> 75k)
-Very, very political and favorite rep driven. Managers are notorious for promoting best friends
-Easy to manipulate the "system" and get credit for stuff reps don't actually do.
-Feels like people are treated as "human capital" and not assets to the firm.
-Higher education does very little for you. A college degree is all you need and lots of people don't even have that. 
-Very little innovation and slow moving. The 1000 lb Gorilla.
-Very much a CYA environment

Title: Overall, its a great company to work at - if one is looking for stability.
View5: The company is extremely customer focused. The management team is always trying to re-invent themselves to ensure they remain competitive.  The firm is also employee friendly and has the power to weather the economic ups and downs with minimum impact to employees.
View7: Change is constant.  Career growth prospects are extremely limited.  Anyone who is looking to move up the ladder will find it takes many years to get a promotion. In the past 5-7 years, the company's focus on cutting costs and improving productivity has resulted in fewer people working a lot more with no significant improvement in compensation. This is not a company to look at if you are looking for a 9-5 working day.

Title: Great Company, Incompetent Lower Management
View5: Absolutely great company to work for and great atmosphere. Best retirement benefits and 401k in the industry. Great place to cut your teeth and learn. Tons of opportunity. If you enjoy investments it's a phenomenal place to learn.
View7: Awful and I mean absolutely awful lower management. Do not recognize talent whatsoever. Production means absolutely nothing. Initial management are the employees who couldn't make it in what they actually wanted to do or just wanted to be lazy. Upper management is extremely smart but lower management is very petty and very likely to be as young or younger than you when starting. Fight your way through it and it is very rewarding but it can burn you out initially. Just realize you will be above them soon.

Title: If you want to be happy in the workplace, avoid this company
View5: If your just out of college, might be a good place to kick off your career
View7: Ok, where to start. Politics, rules this company, if for some minor reason they don't like you from the outset, you can forget about moving anywhere from your current role. Middle mgmt consistently talking badly about their employees. Pay is terrible, upward movement is slow and only to favorites, regardless of how good at the job you might be. The role itself didn't bother me as such, I knew what I signed up for (client services) its just all the BS that went with the role that finally got to me. Turnover rate was ridiculous, I started training in a class of 25, within 12mnths over half had left.  Oh and you will be micromanaged to the second.

Title: Too much change at the top
View5: Good benefits package.  Company was in good shape financially until recently.  Friendly people.  Involved in lots of charitable orginazations.  They have a nice Xmas party and do lots of things for families such as the Big Apple circus and the books fair.  If you need to travel for the company, cuh as going to India, they are generous on expenses for the trip.  Relocation packaages for people going to NC or Texas were good.  Working from home is something that seems to be available to most people.  Bi annual meetings with Sr management attempt to give you info about whats going on but they are usually a waste of time.
View7: Little to no room for a promotion.  Tiny raises for the masses.  No recoginition for doing a good job, unless your a major kiss a..  Poltics and lots of it.

Title: I really hate to say this but the people at the Smithfield, RI campus are not that nice ...
View5: In my role, the work / life balance seems to be good. Nobody bothers you. Very flexible. Corporate seems to be doing a great job.
View7: Training seems to be inconsistant. Nobody seems to be on the same page. The people are not friendly and can be jerks at times, arrogant and cold.

Title: Corrupted and Greedy - Culture is gone
View5: Good Branding for Resume; Diverse Product Range; Well Known Company; Decent technology Implementation to keep up with the current trends.
View7: Corrupt Managment; Cost Cutting at expense of Employees; HR does not hire quality personnel; Cheap wins always over value; Minimum investment into employee development; Inexpereinced managment without knowledge of industry or expereince managing employees

Title: WONDERFUL place to work!
View2: Director, Senior Client Service Manager & Project Coordinator
View5: Since it is a private company, we benefit from autonomy and under Abby's leadership there have been quite a few changes that positively impact employees such as paid time off is now pooled so you have many opportunities to take time off as needed.  Since there is such a large pool of talented employees, we each have access to a large network of people to help us grow both as individuals and as employees.
View7: Large size can be difficult to navigate at times, but all you need to do is network and ask for recommendations on who to talk to.  Work from home/remote opportunities are limited, which makes inclement weather work days a real challenge.  Employees have to endure terrible and risky commutes as they have no other choice.

Title: Great Benefits
View5: Benefits are top notch, there are few that can beat them. The number of days of is crazy compared to most other companies. All technologists are eligible for a bonus. The pay is good. Depending on the business unit you end up in will determine your work load and the type of work you will be doing. Flat company structure.
View7: They try to pass themselves off as a technology company that happens to be in finance, for the most part they try quite hard to maintain this image. Unfortunately, they, like all other companies in the finance field, always seem to slow try something new. Managers are overloaded with work and meetings, making them hard to reach and at times completely out of the loop, this also causes problems with guidance, and mentorship.

Title: Not a friendly place to work
View5: Benefits are good, location is nice.
View7: They promote people to management that don't have any empathy or soft skills and favor their "friends" reporting to them.  If you go in "new", you are an outsider and very few people will make an effort to be your friend or help you.  Very clickish, like high school, groups of people who have worked together a long time.  I had 3 managers in 2 years.  There's no consistency in leadership.

Title: Fair
View5: Salary is lower than industry standard, but made up for by benefit packages and little perks (fitness reimbursement, computer assistance, etc.) Great place to learn the ropes of the industry, sales techniques, etc.  Stable company, constantly changing internally to evolve with economy or client investment demand.
View7: I am in customer service so I've been getting burned out by the demanding customer expectations and Fidelity's policy that the "customer is always right".  I notice the sales roles have experienced greater pressure to fulfill goals due to the economy.  We have been short staffed for a long time, and they are slow to fill the roles (either internally or externally, and competition is FIERCE) puting added pressure and stress on the remaining employees.

Title: Amazing is an understatement!
View5: The benefits are incredible. Fidelity offers great 401k plans, corporate perks and impeccable developmental programs, this company is such an amazing place to work. People are very supportive in this organization and genuinely want to see you grow. Networking plays a big role at Fidelity, its all about who you know when it comes to advancing to the next step in your career so the more people you meet the better.
View7: The Talent Acquisition folks can be unpleasant at times even to internal hires. I have also heard from a few friends that working in the phones suck so if working in a call center isn't in line with your career objectives then I would encourage you to stay away from that area and actually find a position within other divisions.

Title: Sr. Manager
View5: As a ~20 year employee holding a variety of positions, the quality of people has always been outstanding. I've worked for (and with) some tremendous talent, and I've had the opportunity to lead some great people. I've also developed relationships that will last. Fidelity offers great benefits and the work environment and amenities are 2nd to none
View7: The work culture and expectations have become increasingly demanding and it's not uncommon to see e-mails (and sometimes phone calls) at all hours and through the weekend. Senior Teams are under a great deal of pressure to perform, and as a result, Fidelity feels more like a machine and less like the community it was 5 or 10 years ago.

Title: Good for short term experience, then move on
View5:
- Good student loan repayment system
- Gain some insight into the health and insurance or 401k business
- Good 401k  plans
View7:
- Rarely promotes from within
- stagnant wages (raises are not granted based on performance but by the starting competitive wages for call centered)
- Management will have your back one moment then throw you to the wolves the next
- No real ability to do anything besides take calls
- everything is monitored and you will get into trouble years down the road for any mistake
-  No translatable skills
- High turnover (about half do not make it past 1 year, one person in a class may last long enough to be vested after 5 years)
-  Did I mention that they do not promote from within, there is no upward mobility

Title: Product Management
View5: Lots of training opportunities, many different career paths, many niches, many locations, good pay and benefits, and awesome retirement benefits!
View7: Bureaucracy. Different cultures (silos) within the firm. Too top heavy (VP and above). Bending over too much for millennials. If you are over 35, be concerned. Career mobility only exists in certain areas. VPs, SVPs, EVPs, and Executives move around a lot but middle-management and senior associates are stuck. Firm is also years behind in technology compared to its competitors but it is trying to catch up.

Title: Great Place to Start you Finance Career
View5:
- Pre-pandemic office culture 
- Great place to get your education and licenses
- Benefits
- Established firm, respected in the industry
View7:
They have no clue how to keep their employees happy during this Covid world. Your voice will never be heard. The firm's true colors started to show once reps had to work from home. They don't care what your skillset is, what motivates you, and how well you can fit with another team. If your scorecard isn't green forget about moving up in the company.

There's a reason why people are sprinting to Robinhood, but the leadership refuses to acknowledge reality. Instead they spend the exit interview belittling their reps decisions to leave and it's not a good look.

Title: Great place to work for self motivated people.
View5: Knowledgeable staff, top notch technology, excellent benefits.  Hands down the leader in the industry in just about everything they do.  If you want to be surrounded by the smartest people and the best systems - Fidelity is the place to be.  401k and other benefits will not be beat by any other institution.
View7: Lower end of the salary scale.  Management is more supervisory leaving it up to you so search out ways to grow and learn.  Expect to spend your own time searching for ways to improve.  Prepare for a heavy workload which will only grow with the more experience you gain.

Title: Great place to work, but the pay for entry level is not so great
View5: Fidelity is a great place to work when it comes to work/ life balance.  Overtime is minimal (not necessarily a good thing).  There are currently alot of opportunities in Texas with several positions moving from the Northeast.  The atmosphere is a great team environment.  For entry level, this would be a great position if you are looking to go back to school.  Fidelity does provide tuition reimbursement up to $10,000 a year.
View7: Salary is less than competetive for entry level analysts.  It can be somewhat hard to distinguish yourself from your peers because there are so many analysts at the entry level.  Maybe it's typical for the corporate world, but it seems that most analysts get the same performance reviews.  So, if you aren't very good at your job, you will probably still get the same rating as someone who meets expectations... not a lot of motivation to do any more than the minimum.

Title: Fidelity is a great place for a hard worker willing to work for their rewards!
View5: I definitely think working at Fidelity has been my best career decision. I have worked at other places and seen many different management styles and business models, and while everyone has its downfalls. Overall Fidelity does a great job of giving workers the opportunity to grow professionally as long as you are willing to work hard enough to  take advantage of it. I think if you are not willing to work hard to get where you want to be than Fidelity might not be the best place to work. However, if you enjoy the opportunity to work hard and let your actions speak for themselves, as well as many different opportunities to keep you interested than Fidelity is the place to work.
View7: When you first start you do work twice as hard and the pay isnt that great. I think the biggest downfall is that compensation isnt as competitive as other places.

Title: A relationship company that cares about employee development.
View5: There are very clear pathways to advancement.  Fidelity really seems to take care of its employees.  I heard when I first joined, and it seems to be true, that you can do your basic 9-5 and be fine.  No one bats an eye.  But if you go above and beyond, then you'll be rewarded with promotions & salary.  Pays well with sizeable end-of-year and 401k bonuses.  Benefits are good, 401k match is fantastic, as you would expect of a company that specializes in retirement plans.  The only people I've seen be let go by the company really deserved it.
View7: "Relationship company" means politics are everywhere, especially in middle management.  Every decision is made by committee, which while great for consensus forming means that every decision takes 10x as long as it needs to be.    Constant reorganizations.

Title: Supportive growth, red tape being cut, and innovation focused
View5: The company stands by the principles it echoes - from wanting to focus on employee health by reducing costs of healthy meals (60% or less than "unhealthy" options) to allowing mobility within the company at countless levels, it is an amazing company to work for. The campuses are beautiful and well kept, the people give hours and hours of volunteer work because Fidelity cares and allows it, and everyone I've met has very little reason to want to go somewhere else.
View7: You're in an office. If you don't like sitting at a desk and knocking out work within a cubicle then this isn't the most modern work space. Changes are in place to move everyone to a more creative space but it's not quite happening yet. However, you can get out and move around and take walks around the campus (if you are not in Boston) to refresh.

Title: Good place to work for a few years, then get a better job elsewhere.
View5: Good place to start out, get some experience; and move on.
View7: I've seen people promoted to positions they did not deserve, while the person who puts in 100% gets passed over time and time again.  I have been through three major "re-orgs," and had my title changed, pay changed, managers changed (three times in one year once), and have seen good people leave due to the overwhelming feeling of discouragement when they are passed up for a promotion yet again given to an incompetent person who "knows" someone.  It is difficult to work like that everyday, and I can understand why people leave.  It is also highly compartmentalized, which means that once you have worked there for a few years or more; it becomes difficult to be marketable to another company.

Title: Used to be a great company to work for, but is slipping and is now just mediocre.
View5:
- Benefits and compensation are still good (although not what they once were).
- The company still has good core values thanks to the Johnson family.
View7:
- Short-sighted leadership lurches to a new strategy every 12 months, eventually coming back full circle but wasting enormous amounts of money in the process.
- Disorganized and you'll have a new manager every 6-12 months.
- Your job is very likely to be relocated to another state, or off-shored to cheaper labor in another country.

Title: Same thing, over and over and over
View5: Great benefits and resources.  In depth training.  VP's are great resources and very kind, understanding people.
View7: Montony.  If you are a phone representative, there is big brother watching over you.  Every second you are logged in, you are monitored.  You could give the best possible customer service, but if you are not meeting Fidelity's standards, there is an issue.  This place is micromanaged to a fault and gives little opportunity to let their employees shine.

Title: Fidelity is going through many changes but is still a great place to work.
View5: The benefits are excellent.  There are not many companies where you get 17% of your annual salary put into your 401K when you contribute 7% pretax.  The culture is excellent.  Everyone in the org chart is extremely easy to approach and is called by their first name.  There is an implied understanding that if work needs to get done it gets done.  Lots of overachievers in the company.
View7: The red tape associated with any large company can get in the way of progress.  Six sigma efficiencies are being applied to practices where the human element is a major factor in decision making.  The corporate culture that made Fidelity great is being shredded apart by huge veils of secrecy with the new leadership.  While Ned Johnson is still the chairman of the board a lot of the decision making is being done by the new president.

Title: Lost within Fidelity's vortex.
View5: I like it here because the people are friendly and smart. The managers are understanding of your family needs. It is within walking distance from home and it is very laid-back.
View7: I've worked at Dot-Com's, Start-ups and a few Fortune 500's and Fidelity has the worst management I've ever seen. The work is off the charts boring and the Business cares more about their bonus than the customer.

Title: This job will suck the life and drive out of you.
View5: It is easy because your job becomes repetitive. They have nice benefits that convince you to stick around.
View7: There is no end to the work load. From the second you pick up the phone, you will take call after call for 8-10 hours, day after day, year after year. I have been here a few years and have talked to 1 or 2 people who actually enjoy working here. Trust me or not, but if you make the move I want you to think about the moment you read this and doubted what you're reading.

Title: Good place to work with great people. Fidelity is a great company
View5: Benefits are great and the pay is decent. You won't feel rich by any means. The peers that you work with are great too
View7: Call center environment which causes stress and anxiety. Rude people are all over the place and you have the opportunity to speak with them all over the phone it seems. Not for someone who takes things personally

Title: Declining opportunities for IT staff
View5: Location (for Boston Employees), multiple fringe benefits. Some good middle managers. It really depends which part of Fidelity you work for though - FMR is the way to go with less likelihood of being outsourced or down sized.
View7: Lack of opportunity for career advancement in IT. Locations (non-Boston). There is an unspoken expectation in some departments that you will work above your normal hours and not complain or expect any compensation for the time.

Title: Overall, good place to work.
View5:
- Great benefits
- Some of the best co-workers that I've worked with; well educated, positive outlook on life, you can tell Fidelity picks the cream of the crop.
- Decent salary; bonus is based on how well you treat customers rather then on sales.
- Great opportunity if you work hard; everything is merit-based.
View7:
- If you're not willing to move (out of state for example) it's harder to move into a branch role.
- Being tied to the phones is exhausting; doing the same thing day in and day out can get boring fast, which is the reason why everyone wants a branch job which in turn makes it hard to get into.

Title: As others have said, It's a good place to start.
View5: Benefits are great - 7% 401k match, 10% profit sharing, paid vacation and sick time, medical, dental, life insurance... All around great benefit package. If you want to work overtime it's there and it's abundant. A lot of great people and excellent training.
View7: No matter how much you enjoy people, the phone eventually wears on you... I worked with a lot of very great people but you quickly realize the only reason they're still there is because it's a way to make ends meet. At the Jacksonville site, the vast majority of the jobs are on the phone so there's very little opportunity to escape it. You will quickly find yourself wanting more out of your day to day and start looking for a job elswhere.

Title: Financial Consultant - Branch
View5: Great training (actual curriculum and off sight classes), great benefits (7% match on 401k, profit sharing), great tools and resources (internal and external tools). Leads generated for you, and pretty good experience with all phone site reps and "spokes."
View7:
Great place to work for a very specific demographic. Everything is sales based, regardless of the "relationship model" that you hear about. Your success can depend on your geographical location, too. Some branches are extremely "flow heavy," while you really have to grind at others. 

There's a lot of talk about being wealth planners, but you may spin your wheels if you attempt it; there's simply no time to focus on anything that isn't closing a sale. 

Need to be employed for a whole year before match or profit sharing start. Vesting doesn't begin until you've been employed 2 full years.

Title: Sales Employee
View5: Good licensing and support for more certifications. Retirement benefits are good. Great financial license teachers and ongoing training. Good work/life balance. Good starter company for the industry then get out after vesting as so many do.
View7: Salary is the worst especially given the number of competitors in close proximity. No raises this year and many positions being cut. A fellow employee was literally let go due to persistently low customer surveys which you have to get a perfect score. Anything else counts as an F. If you get a good score you're still screwed. This employee had his CFP and masters paid for by the company. What an asinine  policy to spend all that money on someone and then walk them out.

Title: Financial Consultant
View5:
Great 401k match, profit sharing
Exposed to a lot of clients, so you get a lot of experience
View7:
Managers can dictate your future. They control lead flow, and can make you fail if they want.
Higher value leads are given to their inner circle
They say clients first, but it Fidelity's pockets first
They really only care about you selling managed accounts and annuities, and it's a big wheel you are running on. Every year it starts over, not what you did yesterday, what you are going to sell today and tomorrow.
They expect you to be making 40 calls per day, and having 3-4 appointments per day.
They attempt to stress work life balance, but it is impossible to take all that time off if you are running on the sales wheel.

Title: So-So
View5: The experience! You're surrounded by the best of the best-which makes you work that much harder. There can be great opportunity for advancement as long as you can keep your head down when need be, not step on too many toes and don't screw up.
View7: Ultra competitive, ALL THE TIME! Also not always the friendliest co-workers. It is often very political. If you rub someone the wrong way it can really set you back. It's also hard to get a lot of visibility for a job well done due to the shear size and the politics of the day to day.

Title: Fidelity has changed, but not for the better.
View5: Benefits were very good. In the early years there were people to share knowledge and people cared about one another. Back then it was possible to move ahead based on your work ethic and accomplishments.
View7: In recent years the company has created an atmosphere that seems to breed hostility and a need to put others down in order to keep a manager happy. No knowledge sharing because the general feeling is, if I don't tell anyone else, they cannot take my job away. Does not work, your job is probably going overseas anyway. Overseas not held to the standards stateside employees are. So it's not perfect, no problem. Not a way I ever thought Fidelity would behave.

Title: Past performance is not indicative of future returns-
View5: Finest facilities.  Great benefits and time off.  Flexible working hours for sales positions.  Terrific resources for information and training. done
View7: Lower level managers tend to be dropouts from the telephone rep positions.  They typically assume the "we" vs. "them" attitude toward reps.   The problem is that they stop listening to anything from below and develop a cutthroat attitude about their own careers.   Blackballing promotions of reps is common.   A manager has the last word on whether they want their rep to be promoted, regardless of who would like to hire them.    You will see managers advance many times before you move on yourself.

Title: It is very difficult to get ahead here
View5:
Profit Sharing/Company Match
Abundant work resources
Good camaraderie amongst most associates
The company genuinely puts the customer first
View7:
Compensation at Fidelity is extremely low. The company as an explicit policy of paying its associates far below market rate. The company cites its share programs and other ancillary benefits as a compensatory alternative. However, those benefits are doled out on a case-by-case basis. Most employees don't benefit from these programs. Also, compensation figures are arbitrary and there is a lack of transparency into compensation. Bonuses are literally figures on the back of a napkin
Management is generally clueless about the day-to-day and treats employees like indentured servants. Brown-nosing is the only way to get ahead in this company. Management only values the opinions of the sycophants within the company, which creates an acrimonious and preferential environment. The company is ultra-poltical; and, management is only concerned with appearances, as opposed to doing the right thing.

Title: Not Horrible- Not Great
View5: They pay for your 7 and 63 right off the bat. Young corporate culture, lots of room for growth
View7: Room for growth limited to positions in the call center. They will talk about other areas career-wise but those positions are extremely rare and very taboo to get into i.e. Branch, research, rotational programs, marketing etc. Hard time retaining talent because of pay scale and willingness to pay external hires much more than the people they hire in initially. Entry-level service managers come off arrogant and micro manage to the point the job is unbearable. Boast about retirement benefits when in reality you do not see profit sharing nor match for the first full year and none of it vests immediately after that. Job itself incredibly repetitive and not empowering for someone with a college degree.

Title: Fidelity - changing for the better or out of business in 5 years?
View5: Comp and benefits are solid.  Company is less "risky" than other financial institutions.  Even with the rough times over the last few months...some areas of the company are doing quite well.  Fidelity is also very large, so there are many internal opportunities.  Being private is also sometimes a positive since hitting quarterly earning targets is not a requirement and they can spend $$ if needed.
View7: Last couple of years have been a continual circle of re-organizations and changing priorities, projects are not finished before they are cancelled and the next one begins.  As a result morale is pretty low, and most associates are just going through the motions.  Many of the Sr. mgt team are from "the outside" so many of the strategies are new.

Title: Great company to start in
View5: Benefits are pretty amazing, 7% match dollar for dollar and 10% profit sharing as well.  great options for health insurance as well.  Training is also pretty good and you get a great opportunity to learn the industry.
View7: Depending on your role you could get stuck there for a while if there are no other job openings.  It's also pretty hard to move throughout different business units, so once you're in a certain business unit you're pretty much stuck there.  There's not a clear understanding of what other business units and do and what jobs are available there and how they pay.

Title: Director
View5: Great benefits, challenging projects, smart people who work hard and deliver quality output.
View7: Hard to move up in your career.  Your manager isn't really focused on your career growth just their success. I wish I could stay and grow my career with the company but feel like I am hitting a ceiling in my career. They really don't help you or encourage you to move outside of your group. You need to leave the company to pursue your next upward career move, get that next level of experience and then re-apply for a more senior position at Fidelity in order to move up in your career.  Sad to say but it is the reality at Fidelity.

Title: Old-fashioned giant in a shrinking industry
View5:
- Work life balance
- Good benefits
- 401k business is sheltered from global competition
View7:
- Technology org is extremely slow and inneffective
- Financial services industry is shrinking 
- Last real innovation from Fidelity was freedom funds which was decades ago
- Discriminates heavily against males
- Half the folks in leadership are empty suits

Title: Run FAR Away!!!
View5: Pretty campus,  promotes healthy eating, good benefits
View7: In accounting you are expected to make every deadline at cost. A co worker went to the hospital and was told "don't they have Wi-Fi?". They tout being able to work from home and having a laptop as a benefit. Sadly it just enables the expectation that you are available at all hours.  Tasks are often assigned with no training and there is a high possibility that most management doesn't know how to do it. However you are held to perfectionist standards with exacting measure. My department was constantly reorganizing and for several days in a row no one was quite sure what their job parameters or management was. Needless to say many people are leaving and they are not filling their spots. The poor people left are taking on the slack. It is not uncommon to see long leaves of absence due to the stress this job puts on your body. One co-worker had a medical exception on file and I constantly saw her having to work well outside what was advisable.

Title: Best Benefits Available, Great Opportunities For Advancement
View5:
Very focused on the employee experience.
The best, most extensive, and most customized benefits of any company I've ever worked for.
Well expressed values.
There is a lot of chance to try new things, moving  up, sideways, or diagonally while still remaining at the same company.
Leaving each day feeling that I actually had a down-steam impact on helping someone increase their financial wellness.
View7:
Pay tends to be lower than equivalent roles at other firms, but when you factor in the tax-advantages of the benefits offered, you often come out ahead of what a competing firm would pay.
There is a LOT of hierarchy here, So many departments and divisions that it is easy to loose touch with all that the company does.
It takes a couple years to get used to the internal Jargon - everything has an acronym!

Title: Associate Fund Reporting Analyst
View5: Low stress for associates and good flex to work from home. Bonus is decent if you get graded SP or above. Managers and most of the team are friendly people. It does provide good knowledge to take with you elsewhere.
View7: Pay is OK if you come somewhat experienced from the outside, but they screw over internal candidates which breeds a little bit of resentment from others (at least if you are on the outside). Recent org changes are causing frustration and gossip. Two team members in particular are complaining non stop.

Title: great company, great benefits, but things are different
View5: Fidelity has a great name.  Customers trust Fidelity.  The firm has tried to come up with innovative benefits to retain talent.
View7: Pay is low relative to the industry.  Fidelity's best days are behind it, but still a strong company.   Unfortunately management has evolved over recent years and now there is a bit of a toxic culture, where appreciation is not shown or felt by the rank and file.  The "new breed" of branch management is primarily to blame for this.

Title: Excellent Excellent Company— Terrible Pay
View5: Benefits, benefits, benefits. You’ve heard it before probably and they will drill it into your brain once hired. Their 7% plan match, 10% profit sharing, chairman shares, healthcare, and vacation structure is phenomenal. As a man, I received 6 weeks paid time off for paternity leave,  in addition to my regular 4 weeks PTO for vacation. Culture is great as well. Many things and perks to keep you happy while employed.
View7: You will hate your life. You will have mental break downs if you’re working on the phones. They push you to the absolute edge. The overtime pressure is relentless and the pay is below average for what you’re trained to do. Honestly the reason I left is the lay structure.

Title: I used to drink the green kool aid....
View5: The comapny has great benefits and the size means that for a smart, ambitious person, it becomes realyl easy to get ahead.
View7: You are just a number. The attitude was that if you didn't like the way it was, you were welcome to leave because there were always phone jockeys lined up behind you ready to take your job. In the phone sites, the training department and other off-phone jobs were so few and far between that politics and drama ensued as people tried desparately to keep their cushy jobs without phone headsets.

Title: Fidelity Investments is a great place to grow a career.
View5: Fidelity Investments is the ideal place to begin a career. The top-down leadership approach creates a culture of trust, transparency, friendly competitiveness and excellence. All levels of leaders invest countless hours in the development of their employees and the support provided to enhance your career is second to none. The company's values are visible in everything they do. It feels amazing to work for a company that sets clear direction, empowers employees to excel and then recognize and reward those who achieve.
View7: The sheer size of the company can seem overwhelming, but this is easily overcome by having such great leaders in place to provide guidance to their employees.

Title: Awful place to work.
View5: Decent, but expensive medical benefits, 20% computer purchase reimbursement, $250 annual fitness reimbursement, 7% company 401k match. Profit sharing.
View7: Pay below industry standard. They like to tell you that you are lucky that they hired you. Wear a short skirt, you can go far, or at least get paid for not working. If you make your CEI (Customer Experience Index) goals and lead goals, they raqise them so that you can't consistenly meet your goals so they don't have to pay you all of your bonus. Treated like your contribution is miniscule. This is a terrible place to work. Strange how so many young people are at Westlake. No one stays for very long. So many people just walk off the job, but they tell the new hires that "we're growing, that is why we're hiring". HA !

Title: Fidelity Financial Rep.
View5: The training program is one of the best training programs you could go through.  They do a good job of teaching you how to answer the phone in a professional manner and how to use the systems.  They give you study guidelines that will help you pass the Series 7 and 63 licenses.  Paid training, which includes studying for your licenses.
View7: Have to pass the Series 7 and 63 licenses within 3 months of starting there. They tell you that you will be studying completely for the first 6-8 weeks, but you end up answering phone calls for the 2nd half of the day starting the 4th week. And the first 3 weeks are teaching you how to answer phones and use the systems.

Title: general
View5: First and foremost Fidelity has been the best employer for my career  they hire great people and they know how to manage the potential of great leaders  many opportunities exist for transferring to other business units as well as locations which makes them Flexible  as a private company they value technology and networking with other great companies to remain the leader in the financial services industries of which I'm glad to be a part of
View7: Sometimes due to call volume overtime can be overwhelming therefore balancing life outside of work is a must  compared to other times of the year when call volume is not as much

Title: It's not quite the Borg, but it is an intense place to work. Not for the squeamish.
View5:
Diverse business lines present opportunities for internal movement
Many smart, customer-focused, collaborative professionals
Compensation including bonuses is lucrative, depending on job role
Many opportunities for internal training, especially for managers
Very structured, hierarchical environment which some people like
View7:
Extremely siloed, due to the diverse business lines and operational complexity
Constant, relentless organizational changes at all levels, with entire groups being relocated, realigned or disbanded without sufficient explanation
Communication from executive and senior management was lacking and/or confusing
Middle managers were under intense pressure to produce results but often not given the needed resources
Depending on group, morale was often a problem due to offshoring concerns

Title: Most toxic Corporate IT environment
View5:
Stable working environment and decent 401k benefits.
Working location in Boston is very good, right next to South Station
View7:
- Toxic and bullying IT environment
- Stupid and long-term relocation policy that alienates all IT workers. 
- Mostly a waste of time for any young IT professional I have talked to. Everyone left the company within 2 years. 

If you are a IT professional under age 30 and looking for a career, and not just a job that pays the rent, please stay far away from Fidelity. Do not believe anything they say. I once thought that a peaceful corporate environment would be okay. But I learned how a toxic environment can affect a worker's life and career potentials. It is not going to be worth your time to work in a company like Fidelity. I felt so much happier when I leave the place.

Title: Proud alum
View5: Fidelity is an evolving company with lots of opportunity for advancement. Excellent work life balance.  Excellent benefits.  Pay is good but more middle if the road compared to other companies
View7: Although advancement opportunities are good some areas are tough to advance in unless you are in Boston.

Title: Great start in the industry.....but it's a call center
View5:
Great opportunity to get your licenses(7 & 63)
Excellent benefits including tuition reimbursement and travel discounts
Thorough training program covering all manner of content
$1000 sign on bonus
View7:
Call center environment is physically and emotionally draining
Once you're branded a phone rep you have very little mobility unless you're willing to go to a branch or another phone role
Firm pushes career development focus but the only ones that move up either know the right people or get continually rejected for years until eventually getting a break
Having every second of your day tracked is nerve wracking

Title: I would not recommend Fidelity as an employer to my friends.
View5: The benefits are decent, you'll never get fired, and depending on the department, there usually is not much o/t required. Also they generally invest a fair amount in technology, unlike many other companies. The annual Christmas party is decent as well. There is no communication, within departments, from senior management on down, and within divisions. Most management is promoted to the highest level of their incompetence. The pay sucks, as do raises, because they think the fidelity name will make up for it (it won't).
View7: There is no communication, within departments, from senior management on down, and within divisions. Most management is promoted to the highest level of their incompetence. The pay sucks, as do raises, because they think the fidelity name will make up for it (it won't). The benefits are decent, you'll never get fired, and depending on the department, there usually is not much o/t required. Also they generally invest a fair amount in technology, unlike many other companies. The annual Christmas party is decent as well.

Title: Fidelity Investments Institutional Services
View5:
Very generous benefits - tuition reimbursement, computer & fitness reimbursement, $1:$1 company match on 401k up to 7%, free access to professional books with Safari Online, etc.
Comfortable working facilities.
Some really great managers (amongst those not so great).
Many career paths if you take the iniative to learn new areas of the business and are willing to relocate.
View7:
Unstable job security.
Frequent turnover of senior leaders which results in constant changes in direction.
Company is in a cost cutting mode and looking for opportunities to ship job overseas, even to places that do not have the experience to perform well (save a dime now to spend a dollar later to fix things up!)
New hires seem to be coming in at salary rates lower than what they used to offer - another cost cutting strategy.

Title: Living in the past, no opportunities
View5: Great benefits, beautiful campuses, great "fit" regime w/ great healthy food available in the cafeterias where it is dirt cheap for what you're getting, especially compared to the less healthy food.
View7: Very strict, living in the past, no opportunity for job growth. Employees are trapped in roles everywhere they go and are lied to about the role they are getting into. Management says one thing and does another - always tries to make things seem like what they are not. No vacation time available, ever. Only certain amount of hours on certain days allotted for the department and they'll be gone early in the year. Required overtime. "Clock in, Clock out" environment.

Title: Fidelity Investments
View5: Great company values - customers are first; generous benefits package (17% contribution to 401k); smart and dedicated employees.
View7: A lot of talk about career development and mobility but, unless you are SVP and above, efforts on this are check the box and not sincere. Biggest gap with this is at the VP/Director level since most SVPs don't sincerely help their directs with this since they have a "what's in it for me" attitude. To this - most promoted to SVP level based on being good talkers/managing up well even though they are horrible people managers (some of worst in firm).

Title: Not For Young Professionals
View5: Biggest selling point they offer is their benefits (generous PTO, student loan reimbursement, 401k match, etc.)
View7: I worked here full time for over three years and it was my first "real job" out of college.  Company has a very "boy's club" mentality. Most VPs, SVPs, Managers, etc. (in my experience and that I encountered) were men.  If you start here young and fresh out of college, I can almost guarantee you will want to leave after a couple years, but most likely sooner than that. The corporate environment is stifling. Position title means more here than the quality of the individual.  Fidelity's values and corporate policies will state otherwise, but that should only be taken at face value. You may luck out and end up having a great boss and senior leadership team, but from my experience, those are few and far between.  You are just a number here.

Title: Tiring and Thankless Job
View5:
- Will hire almost anyone who applies
- Benefits are good
- 401k match
- Potential to get licensed, where you go after that is up to you
View7:
- Definitely a call center, anyone who tells you different is lying
- Turnover rate is ridiculous, they hire 30 people a month to fill all the vacant roles
- Only real incentive is monetary
