- Monitored on every call and if you don't have a high enough calls per hour you get in trouble
- You do not learn any real transferable skills, unless you go to another call center
- If you think you will switch roles quickly so you are not on the phones, expect to do a minimum of two years answering phones for 8 hours a day
- They tell you the customers are nice, but that is very far from the truth I would say roughly half are very rude

Title: On the brink of success or failure?
View5: There are great people here.  You need to stay away from the bad people and do not let them get you down.  It begins to feel like family and co workers really protect each other in there own group.
View7: Pay can be stingy at times and dumb VPs are left to run aprts of the company when they should be booted. My biggest pet peeve is how other groups abuse the crap out of each other.  Within your own group things are fine, but it is your group against the rest of the company.  There is no team work across the company.  Many of our issues here could be solved by some good old teamwork and dicussion.  The Fidelity Fifedoms are still very evident and those barriers need to be broken down.

Title: An OK place to start a career, but greatly stifling to young talent.
View5:
Good benefits, excellent 401k matching and profit sharing opportunities.
Opportunity to work on very large and very visible systems.
High-quality employees, lots of talent.
View7:
Salaries are not competitive - below industry standards.
Lots of shuffle in upper management, too much "old" talent at those levels.
Salt Lake City in particular, not a great place to work at Fidelity due to lack of visibility compared to Boston/east coast locations.
No possibility for very talented young workers to advance to appropriate positions, leading to boredom and general lack of job satisfaction.

Title: HR and Management are good at using fear as a motivator.  Leadership is non-existent.
View5: Co-workers are pleasant and accommodating for the most part. Work environment is clean and well kept.
View7: Top heavy HR and management at all levels have created an environment where fear is the motivator. Knowledge, skill, and experience are not factors in determining raises and promotions. Managers and some co-workers who seek attention from management will agree to any ridiculous request and deadline. This company has lost many high quality employees and will continue down this long and slippery slope until they figure out how to create a real team culture.

Title: This place is a joke!
View5: Good experience to use on a resume, even though the job was absolutely horrible.
View7: If you want to work in a call center then this is the job for you! Mindless "diversified" managers who are absolutely clueless. They will say you are trained as a "trader" but you are only a client service rep working for crap money. They preach the "culture" and "what is possible". Well, the reality is the culture is corporately sickening and the fact that the ones who have a clue leave before the green Kool Aid totally zaps the life out of you. ISR managers are a joke. They call ISR a "sales job", but they are just phone jockeys who can only talk about target date funds. Good luck to any of you who get sucked into the rah rah! Get your experience and run away as fast as you can.

Title: Brokerage Operations Associate
View5: Benefits are competitive (401K, health insurance etc.). However, salaries are below industry average.
View7: Management disconnect (poor understanding) of the actual work their teams perform.... team managers are mainly responsible for administrative tasks to ensure teams continue to function! Many team managers lack the technical skills and professional certifications that many in their teams are required to possess. This leads to a very confined way of working and thinking about processes, problems, and solutions in the department as a whole. Plus the metrics used to assess employee / team performance are outdated.... based on production type of work environments (like sales call centers, manufacturing etc), and not suitable for a company operating in the financial services industry.

Title: Come for the salary but don't stay for career advancement.
View5: High salary.  Many offices subscribe to a 9-5 day and don't expect much overtime so it can be a family-friendly atmosphere. A lot of smart, talented people. Generally thorough review process means you'll get regular feedback (even though it might not turn into any recognition for a job well done).
View7: Very little opportunity for career advancement in a lot of groups, and unclear criteria for promotion. Top-heavy management bloat and low turnover prevents upward movement. There's a good chance your role & responsibilities will get narrower over time, rather than broader and more challenging/exciting. Expect many of your colleagues to be frustrated that they're not being used to their potential.

Title: Getting Better, still will work you to the bone.
View5: Benefits are the number one reason people work at Fidelity.  The 401k match is 7%, then another 10% in profit sharing in January each year. Its pretty amazing, but understandable since the money goes straight into Fidelity funds.  The people are generally good at there jobs and work very hard for the company.
View7: Fidelity will work you to the bone, especially in technology where Senior Management continually picks arbitrary dates for when projects need to be delivered.  This causes cramped analysis time and due to the archaic architecture, issues always come up at the last minute.

Title: Decent first job out of college but do your research on what career path you would like to take.
View5: Great people to work with. You go through extensive, thorough training with people you will get to know very well with great facilitators leading your class. Great benefits such as 401(k), medical, dental, life insurance etc. You may also attain a number of professional licenses in the financial industry depending on your position. Good opportunity for advancement if you are the type of person that can handle taking calls.
View7: If you work in one of the call centers, the work can become repetitive. You have to adhere to rather tight schedule requirements such as 15 minute breaks and 2-3 hours at a time taking inbound calls. Also, you are evaluated on criteria such as how many calls you take in a certain time frame and how long the conversations take you to complete. If you like speaking with people over the phone, however, you may enjoy it.

Title: Group's leadership is ruthless
View5: Compensation is generous. Time can be flexible. Benefits are outstanding. Negative culture is limited to my current group - however, it's a Con that the bad behavior is an open secret in the firm.
View7: Leadership is lacking. Fear is the current culture. Employees in my group are not valued. There is no credibility in reporting - negative messages are not accepted. Mobility is not encouraged or tolerated. Group leadership uses position and the necessity of partnering relationships with other groups to intimidate and manipulate outcomes.

Title: Great place to work, if you find the right people or work
View5: Senior leadership's heart is in the right place. They are trying to up skill their workforce and the technology stack. Decent incentives and benefits. Modernization improves every year.
View7:
Base pay is pretty good wrt their traditional competition, but not wrt to technology companies, you might be disappointed if you don't shop around first.

Senior leadership likes to start new initiatives, but not follow through on them for more than a year.

There are certain key people in the company who like to build kingdoms, and play politics. This can be tough for a naive hard working employee trying to get recognition for their job.

Business people are still very tech illiterate.

Title: Business Analyst
View5: Great PTO, Work Life Balance, Culture is non-competitive, and multiple chances for people to improve. In other words, you have to really do terrible, and I mean show up for work every single day late, talk back to the manager, never do any work, in order to be fired because if you are trying your best and doing okay they will work with you. This is a place I would love to have when I'm 40-Retirement.
View7: If you are young, it isn't a place where you are put under the gun. Extremely slow growth and tenor means everything. So if you are trying to grow your career I would not go here because it is slow and you will be extremely frustrated. In addition, pay is mediocre because they make up for it in benefits, which you aren't too concerned about when you are young.

Title: Workplace Investing transaction processor
View5: Great benefits - 401K, PTO, healthcare, profit sharing, etc. there’s almost no other companies that can match all of what fidelity offers associates
View7: They pay way less than competitors and keep you here due to the good benefits. Work life balance is bad and Workplace Investing does a terrible job of making their associates feel valued. Upper management seems to be completely disconnected to the associates who actually do all the work and put all the hours in to make the operation go smoothly. It’s hard to get out of WI unless you know someone or put the time in shadowing other depts for months and months before any position is available.

Title: Overall Incredible, typical challenges with large institution
View5: Unparalleled Benefits. Work from Home, Great Managers, Excellent leadership, Industry leader, Unbelievable training and development programs
View7: Company internal Politics, difficult to break out of certain role types

Title: High stress role, but an excellent place to start a career
View5: People are friendly. Management are very supportive. There is a lot of room to grow and change to new roles within the company. I'm a white trans woman and never got misgendered once while at work (except occasionally by clients), no one treated me weird and I even got offered promotions and things.
View7: The phones role is high stress, so an ability to separate work time from your personal time is vital. This is hard to do when everything is work from home. The licensing can be tough. There wasn't a lot of room for people with learning differences to get support during licensing. If you're not a good test taker and struggle to read all day and memorize information for an exam, you will have to advocate for yourself for the support you need.

Title: Lately it is not the "Great Company" to work for that it once was!!
View5: Benefits, education, and the ability to work with some of the best people in the industry.
View7: With the so called Global economy salaries and benefits are not what they once were. Also, with the recent layoffs and consolidation of jobs, this creates more work and hours for those of us who are left and for less pay.

Title: Employees are micromanaged "resources"
View5: It was until recently, in growth mode and was a very positive place to work.  The layoffs have put an extreme dark cloud on the job.  Coworkers and people there have been fantastic to work with.  I've made good friendships and have found it to be a professional and friendly environment.  Work-life balance in my group was really great.
View7: Serious lack of career growth and opportunities for advancement.  I am treated like a contractor -- not like an employee. And you can expect to be micro-managed to the greatest degree possible.     I would have thought it was just me, but it also happens to my coworkers.  Also, I am constantly referred to as a "resource" vs. a team member.

Title: Great benefits,but hard to move up the ladder
View5: The people are generally bright and very pleasant to work with.  The company invests a lot in training and development.  They'll pay for professional certifications and have a generous tuition reimbursement plan.  Retirement and health benefits are excellent- 7% match, plus profit sharing and a company funded retirement health savings plan.  Private ownership and strong financial status make it a relatively secure place to work.
View7:
The base pay is mediocre.  There is little opportunity to advance from entry to mid-level positions.  In some groups the politics and favoritism can be an issue, but it definitely not the case everywhere in the company. 
The review system does not do a great job of differentiating between employees, so it can be difficult to stand out.

Title: The most political and conservative organization in the world!
View5: Fidelity's name brings business, large book given to account executives to manage, decent work/life balance, good medical, good retirement benefits if you can make it that long
View7: pay between job functions is very unfair. people are promoted because they need to fill a seat. it is the most political organization in the world.  people are fired at the drop of the hat and are often targeted for termination. they often implement changes to the compensation structures well into the quarter and then make it back dated.

Title: Rep
View5: They have great benefits, although their employee insurance cost is still high.
View7: Not much opportunity for pay increases once you're hired even if you change jobs within the organization.  They have a superficial purpose to increase how many women work there.  They definitely try to keep the women out of the higher paying positions and o at them less to start  with.  They are very male dominating company because for years and still now in most of their departments it is run my (some older) white males, especially in Utah and for many remote positions.  They promote women or give them accolades only when they have to show they ate equal opportunity.   And that's just the beginning of their discriminating atmosphere.  Their CEO is amazing but she doesn't get any respect from her male EVPs or VPs from overhearing them talk.

Title: Wonderful place to work, if you’re in the right business unit at the right time given constant transformation.
View5: Oppourtunities and professionalism of the company.
View7: Depending on when and where “transformation” travels, can get tough.

Title: Fidelity has changed for good!
View5:
Lots of smart people
Excellent Benefits and compensation
Very good work life balance
View7: It's a very big organization and it can be complicated to maneuver around within different business lines

Title: Fidelity is great and Audit is an excellent place to start a career, but back office work can get stale after a while.
View5: Excellent work/life balance and culture. Benefits are unrivaled and base pay is competitive. Strong emphasis on collaboration and personal development. Exposure to a wide range of businesses and functions with room to specialize in areas of interest. Great pool of talent to work with/learn from. The work is dynamic and engaging, but never overwhelming.
View7: Highly political, promotions are generally based on time served instead of merit, adoption of Agile has resulted in more time spent in meetings than auditing. Leadership is more focused on pleasing clients than issuing good audit reports. High turnover as a result of top talent often being underutilized.

Title: Great company to work for
View2: Fidelity High Net Worth - Financial Representative
View5: Fidelity has a good culture and great group of people to work with. Very supportive and many opportunities to move up within the company. There are opportunities every quarter and you can get promoted multiple times in a calendar year if you're performing. And if you're not performing, they're typically very supportive and try to find constructive ways to help you improve.  Benefits are great. You start off with 18 days PTO and after 2 years you get 23 days PTO off per year. OT is frequently available if you want it.
View7: The calls can beat you up on some days. Majority of the managers I've had were good,  but just like any job your experience will also partially depend on who you have as a boss. There are some that are not ideal; however, most managers are encouraging and helpful in your career path.

Title: Fidelity is a good place to work if you want to work in the financial sector.
View5: The best reasons to work for Fidelity are the benefits, the compensation versus other financial institutions, and the ability to work from home when it is necessary.  I wa blown away by the compensation I got this year and how it shows that they actually pay for performance.
View7: There is a lot of red tape around getting things done, especially at the software development level.  Sometimes they also squash creativity but it gets better over time.  The one thing to know about this is that it is all about the group that you get into and who you work for.

Title: Mobility is the biggest benefit to Fidelity!
View5: It is unlikely that you'll ever get bored in a role at Fidelity.  However, if you do get bored or feel like you need a new challenge, Fidelity is usually able to accommodate!  Along with mobility, you get experience, and with experience you become more valuable to the company.  Fidelity is very good about allowing its employees to gain other experience.
View7: The company is very numbers-driven so, with that said, it should come as no shock that meeting and exceeding rigid quotas is of utmost importance...to the point where quality is sacrificed just to 'crank out the numbers.'

Title: Great company but something to consider
View5: Overall I think Fidelity is a great company, the fact that its privately own makes it more immune to market volatility and the year-end bonuses have been fairly consistent
View7:
The promotion process is a complete mystery and it appears to be highly political
Once you reach a certain level (director) within IT at least there are no annual market adjustments, so every year you are in theory making less money.  Plus there are no catch-up adjustments.
When applying to a job at the same level the policy is that you cannot get a salary increase, even if the job is vastly different and within a different business unit.  Which means overall you are stuck at your current salary unless you look outside the firm

Title: Financial Sales
View5: Very flexible with schedules and time off for family reasons. great 401k match plus yearly pension payment. health insurance is affordable, HSA yearly payment from the company.
View7: very very slow making changes to be more competitive.  There are some very poor EVPs, mis-matched alignments in upper management service groups managing sales organizations and the resulting loss of long term focus and goals.  This call center is very "good ole boys club",  promotion is all about who you know.  The pay is very low compared to competitors in the same region.  For being a privately held company who manages a trillion dollars have not had a pay increase in over 10 years and management of my group has very specifically changed quarterly comp goals in order to pay employees less for the same amount of work.  Can be a very toxic environment but those situations seem to come and go

Title: Limited career advancement
View5:
Good pay for a high school graduate.  Good benefits. Standard 40 hr week.  If you want a place where you can do minimal effort and answer calls all day, while still receiving a paycheck- this is it. 
Great company to start your career if you only plan to stay 2 years or less.
View7: No upward mobility. Top heavy senior management.  Company does not reward for education or experience.  Negligible pay raises.  If you care about advancement and challenge, look elsewhere.  Not a place to grow a career.

Title: Great but not perfect
View5: Great company with customer-centered culture. Great benefit package, and depending on your role, you may have flexible schedule or the ability to work some of your shifts from home as an option. Great at helping employees earn licenses, certifications, and business related degrees.
View7: They tend to compensate employees below the average for the industry and hope that the benefits are enough to keep employees around. If not, they seem to prefer hiring and training new employees to paying current employees more in an effort to retain them.

Title: Tough love
View5: Fidelity has some of the highest paying jobs out there in New Hampshire, but unfortunately that doesn't say much (see below). Fidelity is a very easy place to start a career in financial services and learn the business from the ground up.
View7: Being a huge company can make getting noticed not so easy here. The corporate culture discourages risk-taking but I think that is something upper management is starting to realize. Fidelity used to be a place that encouraged and developed risk-taking, entrepreneurialism and bold ideas. Office politics are rampant here. The pay is good but much more can be made elsewhere if you take the initiative to look and to relocate outside New Hampshire.

Title: Deteriorating culture, talent pool diminishing , management self serving, seasoned reps run.
View5:
Fast promotion early phase career due to seasoned talent leaving pockets for movement.
Fair work life balance.
Free coffee. 
Benefits are ok but they are slowly being taking away
50 years of brand recognition (good)
Great relationships with peers.
View7:
Firm having identity crises. Technology is getting worse with wasteful spending. Clients are treated like numbers, now that reps are forced to act like a Wire house brokers. I 
 Don't know many SAE's who want to stay. They are all looking they just don't want the firm to know. Reps know company surveys to employees can be pulled so it's incorrect data.
Micro management is immense!!! They even make the reps enter the data for the spreadsheets for upper management. Reps can not even do their job with these time wasters.

Title: Good training program, learned a lot, but definitely not a career
View5:
-Comprehensive Training
-Medical/dental insurance start immediately
-Plenty of overtime available
-On-site gym ($20/month), additional insurance $$ for healthy living incentives
-On high-call days the company tries to do something nice for the team (snacks, food, etc)
View7:
-Out of an 8 hour day, expect to be on the phones all 8 hours. Little development time
-Very poor optical insurance
-Overtime is expected and will effect your bonus
-Very repetitive (almost every call is someone wanting to raid their 401k)
-No discretion so customers will yell at you and there often are long holdtimes to get help on a call
-All your time is monitored (typical call center) so everytime you go on break, lunch or to the bathroom expect it to be tracked

Title: Great starter job
View5: My manager is really nice. The work and life balance is pretty good. Teammates are very willing to help. As a fresh college graduate, this is a great opportunity to learn about the IT industry and to sharpen my programming skills.
View7: There was a big learning curve about the application that I am supporting and a lot of knowledge are not well documented in the team. It was a lot of trial and errors for me to figure out exactly how things are being done here. Even though we are agile, people are working on their own stuff and there isn't a lot of communication between team members. It also seems like performance isn't really based on merit but rather the length of time you have been in the team.

Title: Great Company
View5: Benefits are awesome! I can't complain about any of them.  The cafeteria can be good.  It has a lot of healthy choices.  Most of which are cheaper than the less healthy choices.
View7: I wish it were easier to change shifts. The cafeteria is not available after the lunch hours.  I find this inconvenient for the later shifts.  There is a shop that is open a little later, however, the food available is not as good.  Mostly sandwiches that are not as healthy.  They are very limited in choices.  There is no time to leave, if you are on the phones, so bringing a lunch is almost always the choice.

Title: Work with clients that have assets of 250k or more.
View5: Flexible schedule and a lot of very nice people. There's very good support in anything you do. The benefits of having a 7% 401k match and 10% profit sharing is ok but not great.
View7: The pay is low compared to other companies and taking call after call is tiresome. Newly hired people are started off at higher rates than long term employees. They always brag about the benefits but don't pay enough to actually use them. It's possible to actually be driven to quit by management if they don't like you. I've seen it happen too often and the company is somewhat sexist towards men.

Title: Great place to begin your career in financial planning
View5: Good culture that rewards you for taking great care of clients. Fidelity contributes 17% of your salary into your 401k each year (7% match plus 10% profit sharing contribution). Health care plan is affordable and has amazing coverage (90 / 10). Great coaching and mentoring staff - you have all the other consultants in the office to learn from (many of them CFP practitioners), your branch manager who used to be a consultant, another dedicated coach to help you be a better planner, and various product experts (annuities, life insurance, LTC, managed money products, etc.). Fidelity also paid for 100% of my CFP coursework, classes, and exam.
View7: Compliance documentation can take some getting used to. Advancement has been limited to backfilling turnover right now (headcount neutral) as opposed to adding jobs. No ETA on if/when job growth will pick back up.

Title: Good Place to Work, but it depends on the project.
View5:
Nice people, good benefits.
The company is not publicly held so things are stabler than other large tech companies.
There's a lot of opportunity for growth if you stay in the company.
Many people stay for a long time because there is opportunity for good work life balance.
View7:
Business runs everything, ultimately.
Many resctrictions and blockers because of security and the scale of their projects.
 If you work in tech, this gets in the way of innovation and using the newest technologies. 
The difficulty and pressure of the job depends on the project you have.
The project I was working on was very high profile and very high pressure.

Title: A Great Place to Start
View5: Big Office environment with great exposure to corporate culture. Very friendly and open culture in the back and middle office, Great in the job training with a huge knowledge base within the company
View7: Its very easy to get lost and go unnoticed because of the size and scope of the operation. Trying to be an agent of change is also very difficult because of the size of the company. Benefits and pay are the best in the industry for middle office jobs but the grind and the lack of tools to use that are available in the industry are difficult to overcome

Title: Good postgrad job or for moving up the call center "status" ladder
View5: Benefits package. Onsite amenities. Weight "Fidelity Investments" carries on a resume going forward into any field, not just financial, due to reputation and vetting process.
View7: WAY TOO CORPORATE. Ramrod you through training and expect you to be an expert afterwards. "Coaching moments" just corporate bullet points, no concrete help to improve. It's a call center, and it's in regards to people's money to amplify it - very stressful being on the phone all day. The only vertical movement is moving up financial customer service rolls via licensing, etc. while still being on the phone all day. It's a meat factory. If you don't pick it up right away once you're on your own (become an "expert") you're in trouble.

Title: A retirement company you will not retire from. Over 8000 American jobs offshored.
View5: Good pay and benefits but over the years they have lessened as profits continue to soar.
View7:
Profits continue to soar but could start doom and gloom predicted. I mean how much many billions does the Johnson family need? 

18 years and replaced by offshore and then asked to train them. You will not retire here unless your executive management or in the circle of trust. Now they are offering age 55 and over buyouts even with 20% 3.4B in record profits  2/17.

Title: Excellent Community to be a part of!
View5: Fidelity is genuinely a good company that seeks to do the right thing for their customers and their people. They invest heavily in trying to improve and prepare for the future and respond to what clients and associates need to feel supported.
View7: Like all large companies, people quit managers more than they quit jobs. The company does try and help managers improve, but it is still a challenge if you do not get a good one. Also, many departments can feel like a silo; you may not like the lack in variety of jobs in your business arm and it can sometime feel difficult to move to a different department if you have already established yourself in another one. Again, I feel this is recognized and investment is made to try and fix it to move more freely across the company, but some roles will not change.

Title: Good place to work, weak management
View5: Excellent benefits. Health Insurance for a family is reasonable, the 10% drop into your 401K for profit share each year was always a plus in January. No vision insurance offered, but good dental, 4 weeks of vacation after 5 years, plus all market holidays. Seldom have to work weekends or past 6pm.
View7: Management has way to may priorities throwing you in a number of different directions. The fire drill method of management makes it hard to no what to focus on. The middle management is hit or miss, you either have someone to help you move up, or someone who is afraid you'll take their job.

Title: Associate
View5: great and knowledgeable associates, good benefits, just-announced student loan assistance program.  fitness equipment reimbursement program.
View7: The company's hyper obsessed with statistics, and although the benefits are pretty good, the pay isn't.  Fidelity demands a lot out of you.  It leaves very little free time.  The roles are sometimes very stressful.  As somebody in another comment said, this company's trying to be way too many things at once.  They send WAY too many "xxx manager's joining this team" emails that come across as self-congratulatory and crowd out more relevant messages.  Some managerial decisions--especially re: recent software updates--make no sense (financial or otherwise).  The company--and some managers in particular--love to micromanage associates, though I've heard that may change starting next year.

Title: Full Trader
View5: They will teach you everything you need to know about the stock market, the training is exceptional. Pay and benefits are average but they are very generous with bonuses. In the middle of a growth spurt so lots of new opportunities and career progressions. They are also hugely profitable and a Juggernaut in the industry, you will have no fear in the company going under.
View7: They are growing their client base faster then they can hire new representatives. As a result the work load is severe, inflexible hours and mandatory overtime. You have to book your vacations about 6 months in advance in order not to have corporate operations deny your time off requests. The job is also very repetitive once you know what you are doing and as such it is very easy to burn out.

Title: Employee-Centered
View5: Fidelity provides amazing benefits, looks out for their people, and makes sure to stay competitive in pay and perks. I have never encountered an employer that put so much toward the well being of their employees! Your manager pulls for you personally, even if you're applying for a different department, and coaches you to your full potential.
View7: With the amazing benefits, Fidelity does expect a significant turnaround of work. There is occasionally mandatory overtime for service-level associates, and average stats are expected, since there are so many associates to keep track of, so your evaluation isn't always very personalized-feeling when it comes to applying for other roles in the company.

Title: Work Culture is changing rapidly
View5: Good total compensation (Base+Bonus+Profit Sharing (10% flat goes to 401k account)+7% $to$ 401K match+ Good Health Insurance). That's why the total comp otherwise the base may be lower than other companies. It helps if you are more than 5 years with the company.
View7: Work Culture is changing rapidly. It is not the company that it used to be, regularly laying off senior people with some or other excuses and hiring at the same time at lower level. Being a very big company, groups works in silos. So, some group may be worst than the other, specially if you are applying in SIPD group, careful. Very unstable.

Title: very lukewarm, uxd intern
View5: Probably the biggest perk is the great pay as an intern. There are a bunch of really smart and friendly people to learn from if you seek them out, and the culture is really fun. People are generally  very friendly.
View7: Management was oppressive, even as an intern. No one seemed to know really what should be going on, and direction was incredibly scattered. Really likes to brag about their tech capabilities and resources, but interns were using incredibly old and faulty computers that many times would fail when we needed them to do our work.

Title: Toxic culture for those looking to become the best version of themselves
View5: The people I work alongside everyday and Fidelity's clients are amazing. They are what I'll always reflect back on as being the best part of my experience while being at the company.
View7: If you want leaders who are just as enthusiastic about the success of others as they are their own, you will never find that at any level of the company. If you are looking for a meritocracy where the best ideas win out, where the best performers are recognized, and where the right people end up in the right positions, you will never find that at Fidelity Investments.

Title: Great Company, Average Environment
View5: Great benefits, including tuition reimbursement and student debt repayment. Large company so it stands out on your resume for the future.
View7: Like with most larger companies, the people doing the most work are being paid the least to do what everyone in the company agrees is the worst job: answering phones. A lot of talk about mobility, but once you come into a certain position, you're pigeonholed into that career track unless you want to take a pay cut.

Title: Zero leadership, not worth the stress
View5: Large company, lots of designers, benefits
View7: Too large a company, the product teams you're working with are rarely if ever in the same state and there is very limited leadership or guidance from management. Onboarding took about a month, and there were delays in getting set up with equipment but meetings with teams and product were set up day 1, without any insight from leaders about what we were expected to design. Their mentality is to drop you in the ocean and see how you do, but it's unfair and unrealistic expectations.

Title: Love this place in 1999.  It is a completely different company to work for in 2011.
View5: a) Benefits - Medical, Vacation and 401k Match
View7:
I am not sure what happen between 1999 and 2011, but this place is completely different.  They treat their US employees like cattle that they can move to any location in the US to save a dollar and they think we will all follow like little lambs.  How much money does the Johnson family need?  Boston is where they made this company what it is today, and now they are leaving.  They say it is not due to costs - but is clearly is the reason.  

There are minimal promotion opportunities for the hard-working employee.  Only those who play politics get anywhere at Fidelity.  It forced the people who really get the work done to look elsewhere.

Title: Good for short-term
View5:
1. Beautiful Campus 
2. Nice cafeteria and break-areas
3.Professional and competent staff. 
4. Management is hands-off
5. Availability of resources required to complete work
View7:
1. Management is aloof, arrogant. Doesn't know whats really going on. Out of touch with staff. 
2. Management draws conclusions without investigating facts.
3. Contractors are not treated as part of the team. For example, contractors are three to a cubicle while employees have their own. There are many unoccupied cubicles.

Title: bad work environment and bad company policies.
View5: the pay was decent, the benefits are better than nothing and the 401K was ok but only if you work there your entire career
View7: the work place is very cliquish and catty. Women are treated badly, there is an undercurrent of sexism. If you are too intelligent or too attractive, be prepared for a lot of hostility. Also very bigoted. They employ minorities but then treat them as "token" employees and there is definitely an undercurrent among white workers that you don't socialize or date outside of your race. If your a conservative , very conservative bigot ..and a very suburban woman..then you'll probably do just fine

Title: Gave my all to a company that didn't give it back.
View5: The salary for entry-level associates is great and there are a lot of benefits given to the employees
View7: Fidelity's quality and effectiveness goals have been increased steadily so that even one misspelled word, missed punctuation, or keeping a client on hold more than 30 seconds can cause you to get written up. Also there's hardly ever openings for promotions.

Title: Good start in financial services but other firms probably pay better.
View5: Great training, opportunity to learn the business and get licenses. Challenging roles allow you to learn a good deal about the brokerage business.
View7: Squeeze every ounce of patience by adherence to at least 5-10 metrics while your also dealing with demanding customers. Rigid and non flexible hours. Internal staffing doesn't care about your career development, it actually seems easier to look for a job outside than internal. Limited opportunities to advance from a phone role, not much in terms of support, almost feels like the company doesn't want you to move.

Title: Solid salary, great benefits and hard-to-beat work/life balance
View5: 401(k) profit sharing plan appears unequaled, benefits truly show that employees are valued, salary is solid and the work/life balance is one of the biggest perks.
View7: Can only speak for IT, but management has demonstrated a remarkable disconnect with employees and created confusion and discontent with some of their most valuable employees through poor and inexplicable promotion and assignment decisions.

Title: Solid company (I'm in IT dept) who wants to stay up to date and ahead of the curve
View5: Work/life balance, pay and benefits, LEAP training program, opportunities for advancement, recognition for good work (I have a great manager and team, there's only so much the company can do vs the people you work with), internal moves not only available but encouraged. Tons of discounts, from cell phone bill to cars. NC offices received new desks that can raise and lower ans well as two huge monitors
View7: Some people can be difficult to deal with, but that applies to any job anywhere. That's about it in terms of the company itself.

Title: Great company  overall.
View5: Great company, with lots of resources. Fantastic benefits and good pay. Company is evolving, and well poised for the next phase of industry shifts. Incredibly strong brand in financial services. Highly ethical and virtuous company. Privately owned, less susceptible to market cycles.
View7:
Big companies can be slow to change, but Fido is heading in right direction. 

The fundamental belief in active management from senior leaders sometimes slows the pace of innovation and is too often the reason for decisions vs. data or industry trends. 

Like everywhere in financial services, expense management is intensely tight.

Title: Glorified call center job
View5: Reputable private company with good benefits.
View7: The company/hiring managers are not looking for experience, creativity, or diversity in candidates. They want young and cheap (and White.) They want you to advice clients with written scripts and one-size-fit-all investment models, albeit the obvious fact that each client is unique. Team-oriented culture usually means everyone looks and sounds identical. It is a private company, so they can run the business whatever way they want, without any pressure from the public in regards to diversity and inclusion. In interview, they often tell you that the median pay for FC is around 165k, with many earn above 200k. The base is about 45k, most people get paid around the base. That's one of the many reasons why the company struggles with high turnover.

Title: Be prepared to be pressured to upsell and micro managed.
View5: Benefits, technology and people are great.
View7: On surface, Fidelity tell you to do the right thing and best interest for client. On paper you are expected to push managed account, annuity, have 30 appointments. They will force you to hit metrics to avoid weekly one on one with management and come up with a plan on how will you improve going forward. They are constantly hiring of consultants, when I came in with another new hire. The other guy left after 4 months and I stuck it out for 8 months because I need a new job. You can expect weekly meetings on everyone’s production numbers and put you on the spot if you did not meet management expectations. Fidelity will churn and burn you and there will be a next person to replace you.

Title: I miss what it used to be.
View5: It's a solid company, for the most part, and I say that knowing that my job will soon be coming to an end. My business unit is going away, but they have been upfront with us about that decision and I appreciate that. I'd have no intention of leaving if it wasn't for the fact the my job is going away.
View7: It has been Dilbert-ized a lot in recent years. I have loved working for this company, but it has gone down hill a lot since Roger Lawson came in. I'm glad he's leaving, but I think it's a bit too late.

Title: A Great Place to Start
View5:
Series 7 & 63 are paid for and the training program is excellent, they are paying a lot of money to license you and really want you to pass.
There are multiple shifts available to you which you bid for, and most people receive their first choice in shifts.
Amazing, supportive co-workers.
The best technology I have used in the Finance industry.
401(k) matching is among the best in the industry, but annual salary is not competitive.
Good work/life balance.
Team outings each quarter.
View7:
The call volume is ridiculous, and you spend most of your time resetting passwords, even once you are on the full-trader gate.
Fidelity talks a lot about career development, but team meetings and one-on-one coaching sessions with your manager are constantly canceled due to call volume.  A manager cannot develop his/her employees without ever speaking with them.
Even when you are promoted you do not get a raise, you get an increase in variable comp, and that is determined by whether you hit your metrics.  You can get a "promotion" without ever getting a "raise".
Management is hit-or-miss.  I worked for a couple of amazing, hands-on managers who were very engaged with their teams. I also worked for a few managers that appeared to do nothing other than sit around and play games on their phones all day.
A lot of push-back from different departments when you try to transfer calls.
Metrics are constantly changing.  What is important one quarter may be meaningless the next quarter.  It makes it very difficult to try to establish a routine on your calls when you don't know what measurements your bonus will be based on.
This is a call center job.  Don't try to kid yourself, you will be on the phones 8 hrs/day.  Unless you get a position in a branch, you will be on the phones, even if you are "promoted" to another role.

Title: Disappointing
View5: Good benefits, Honest company with good morals
View7: Two pay cuts in less than 6 months, Overly concerned about liability to the point that it can be detrimental to the customer, Job flexibility and work/life balance has been significantly reduced

Title: Pay for Performance is not all it is cracked up to be
View5: Has opportunity for those willing to work extremely hard, Benefits are great, and the company is stronger than most financial services firms out there.  They are a private firm so there are no "Shareholders" to pander to.
View7: 40 hour work week is not an option need to work 55+ hours per week and not get paid for it, Bonus restructured so TOP employees get all comp others get minimum.  Employees who have worked there a long time get small changes in comp while new hires comp is more premium.  you need to leave the company and come back in a higher postion to get any significant changes in compensation or title

Title: Did a summer internship there.  Dilbert became less a joke and more of a documentary after.
View5: Paid very well, silly but nice perks with things like a gym with personal trainers and pretty nice cafeteria.  Nicely maintained grounds.
View7: Everything else, nepotism was king.  Meritocracy died a lonely death a long time ago.  Large meetings were sessions of the "blame game" with discussions about how things should be "moving forward".  X Y scatter plots are not to be used in presentations, even if they are the only sane way to display the information.  We love pie, and pie charts.

Title: Phone sites good, branches bad
View5: Great benefits, excellent training and if you are working in one of the large sites, there is lots of opportunity for movement.  Pay isn't based on commission and Fidelity has a great pipeline for business so the leads come to you.
View7: Pay is lower than at other firms and the company is super conservative.  Guidance and recommendations will be based on tools with almost zero actual input from the financial reps themselves.  If you want to interact with clients, you'll either be on the phones or in a branch.  The branches have very little room for advancement and depending on the manager, can be very frustrating and demoralizing.  Average tenure for an Account Executive is less than a year due to attrition.

Title: Good place to start...Positive atmosphere...Low pay
View5:
1.) The company invests a lot of money in Learning and Development including paying for your licenses and maintaining them in 53 states.

2.) The morale of the place is very encouraging for the most part. Upper management really does well at maintaining a positive work environment that is uplifting for its employees.

3.) Benefits package is pretty spectacular if you stay for over a year.

4.) You take so many calls that you are forced to learn ALOT and FAST! It's very good if you don't have a finance background like myself.
View7:
1.) Low Pay
2.) Small Bonuses
3.) The micromanaging of call stats
4.) On the phone all day and since the company is the biggest in the financial industry the calls never stop coming. ever.

Title: Decent place to get your financial licenses, and thats about it.
View5: Paid study time to pass exams.
View7: Fidelity is one of those "we grew too fast for our own good" companies.  From 1990 to 2000, the employee base grew exponentially and alot of people who had no business being in any sort of management role found themselves in charge of other people in management.  Fidelity now cannot care about their new recruits having bachelor's or master's degrees, because many of the site directors have only high school diplomas to their name.  The national director of phone centers is working on a bachelor's degree.  There is no reward for education or effort, and for a while the quickest way to get into a manager position was to be female--hardly any other qualification was needed.

Title: High Net Worth Representative
View5: If you are lucky to land on a great team there will be unlimited opportunities for your personal advancement and flexibility with your work schedule. High performers stand out and are quickly recognized. Very generous profit sharing and 401K plan matching.
View7: Conversely, the wrong team manager will make your life miserable by micro managing and being completely inflexible. There are many of these new managers that do not recognize the need to manage people as individuals - instead everyone is painted with the same broad brush and treated as an inexperienced new hire.

Title: Bit of a tradeoff...
View5: Good work environment. Great benefits. Fidelity cares about the customers and their employees. Flexibility with your schedule is also a plus.
View7: I worked at a call center and I can tell you that taking calls all day was very draining. I use to like talking to people but this job has made me antisocial. If you have the right manager, you can last there for a few years and you will want to because of all the great benefits. But when you start to feel like you don't even want to say "Hi" to the Publix cashier, thats your sign to either move into a more challenging role or time to get out.

Title: Great work life flexibility and culture!
View5: Great benefits, promotes from within, opportunity to move to various roles within the firm, work-life flexibility
View7: Pay is not competitive initially, only way to see big jump in salary is to move roles (yearly increases barely keep up with inflation and are pretty much up to manager discretion, not performance of the individual), be ready and open to change because your manager will probably change 4 times in a year

Title: Great mid term company
View5: Great company to start your career.  Opportunity is available to those who show desire to achieve.  Be prepared to be flexable with your career and change directions as the company changes.  As the internal saying goes "If you don't like something at Fidelity, wait a year and it will change."  Change is constant and those who adapt are rewarded.
View7: Company lacks loyalty to its employees while demanding loyalty from them.  I have seen numerous 20+ year employees let go in down times in the market.  I have been very suprised at this lack of company loyalty and it has certainly been an eye opener for me.

Title: Fidelity is a GREAT building block and FOUNDATION
View5: If you are starting out in the financial industry you can get your series 7, 63, and 66 within a year to a year and a half at Fidelity. You are constantly in training. I would stay at fidelity for at least the first 5 years moving from department to department learning as much as you possible can. Then if they do not compensate you the way you want...MOVE ON.
View7: The competition. I work in a phone site where there are over 1,000 people, and everyone wants the same higher paying jobs. The last job interview I had within the department was against 100 other people fighting for a handful of jobs

Title: Fidelity is a Great Place to Launch a Career
View5: Fidelity (CSS ) is a great place to launch your career. There is alot of support and systems that are in place to ensure you are successful. Fidelity is a great place for wholesome people who want to work and a friendly, family-oriented environement. Its not the place for a gunslinger who wants some action. Wrong culture.
View7: The use of call flows is like being a robot. You can't really help the customers on the call's because of the liability Fidelity feels comes back on them, in my opinion. However, I don't think Fidelity really encourages there employee's in CSS to be better at helping customers with Investment Education calls.

Title: Good Benefits, poor Salary and Management
View5: Very good benefits, strong 401K matching and profit sharing plans.  You get a pretty good amount of vaction after the first few years.  Fidelity seems like a pretty ethical place to work at with good people from good backgrounds.
View7: Very poor salary, bonuses, and raises.  There isn't a lot of opportunity to move within the company.  Everything is driven by leads and acquiring new business whether you are in a sales function or not.  If you don't want to go into sales you won't ever be given the chance to even interview for the job within the company you would excel at.  Management does a poor job of using the talent they have within the company to fill the positions where it is needed.

Title: A great place to work if you can stand projects moving very slowly
View5: Great benefits, competitive salary, lots of diversions in the way of talks by high profile outside speakers, art tours in the building, classes at the gym, etc.. etc.  Very nice and intelligent people work at this company and the majority are very committed to the firm.  In that way, it is truly refreshing.
View7: Projects move at a snail's pace.  A lot of politics three and four ticks down from the CEO.  If you like fast paced and challenging, this is not the place for you.  If you want to be more than just a small cog in a huge machine, this is not the place for you.  If you mind the ever-present feeling that Big Brother is watching everything you do (in and out of work), this is not the place for you.

Title: I miss working at Fidelity
View5: Fidelity has great benefits and pay very competitively. When I was there, they tried to hire and pay at the 75th percentile, so I had a lot of great coworkers. There were lots of opportunities inside the company, so it was pretty easy to stay engaged and content.
View7: It's financial services... not rocket science. Even though it's a fantastic company, I eventually got bored. I was in a smaller regional office, and there weren't a lot of opportunities to move around without moving. And I disagreed with the "culture" the local business head was creating - definitely not a Fidelity norm.

Title: 5 year+ veteran reflecting on current state of Fidelity.
View5:
Great retirement benefits, vacation time and profit sharing all though it's starting to get scaled back. 
The work/life balance is great. 
Great people in every department. Your co-workers really make Fidelity a great enjoyable place to work.
View7:
The base pay is average at best and merit increases are almost nonexistent. The increases are rarely reflective of performance, but really where you fall in the range of your salary grade compared to your co-workers. 
Their is a lack of opportunity for advanacement, politics are heavy, and to move up you really need to know someone.

Title: Above average
View5: Brand Name. Off on weekends. Plenty of OT if you want/need it. 401(k) - 1$ for 1$ Co Match up to 7%, plus Profit Sharing Contributions. Many Corp perks/discounts available. Family owned company. Huge on customer service 1st, profits 2nd. Classroom training (8 wks).
View7: Crazy call volume with recent market volatility. Call Center environment. Performance metric goals/standards are set too high and can be a challenge to achieve at times.Managers have way too much fun while reps are constantly busting butt. Managers are not proactive enough, so be prepared to take ownership of your development so you don't get left behind by your peers. Also, expect a new manager every 6-8 mths.

Title: Great company to settle down and retire from; not best for earlier in your career if you wish to learn.
View5: Great perks. In terms of bonus, profit sharing, 401(k) match, health and insurance benefits. If you are good management usually goes at length to keep you happy and retain you. Does respect work life balance.
View7: Bit of bureaucracy and personal interests make environment little rigid in terms of work and future roadmaps. Since a big part of salaries ( specially from senior levels) are tied to bonuses, focus changes from overall team goal to personal goals and marketing, making environment unpleasant. If you are a technical personal specially earlier in your career and want to grow technically, this might not be the right place to start.

Title: Financial Representative Full Trader
View5: The initial training in attaining your 7 and 63 is unbeatable. The support system is great, they don't just hand you the books and tell you to go study, they stay with you throughout the process to ensure you get licensed. Theres an initial self study period followed by a class that, if you put the work in, will thoroughly prepare you for the exams.
View7: The training thereafter in becoming a trader is incomparable. What apparently used to be a year and a half long process has been condensed into two months. They have a system of call overflow that results in inexperienced traders engaging with clients coded as private client group looking to do multi-leg options trades that their traders are not at all prepared for.

Title: Large company that provides all of the resources needed
View5: Fidelity is a very large company that provides lots of opportunities for career development and advancement. They have a history of filling openings with internal candidates. Benefits are great and they have a culture that encourages strong collaboration. Technology is the best that I have seen and they are constantly looking to plan 5 years ahead in order to constantly improve business.
View7: Opportunities to transfer can be limited if you restrict your search to one location. Company has a history of layoffs which can impact job security if an employee is not performing a critical role. On the plus side, they provide a generous severance package. Don't regret working there as the experience was great.

Title: Soul sucking
View5: Salary, Benefits, 401k matching, casual attire, beautifully maintained sites (that you cannot enjoy because of harshly restricted metrics)
View7: From the moment you walk in, your time is LITERALLY micromanaged to the MINUTE. Sexism, Favoritism, Hardcore metrics, high turnover, not open to suggestions for optimizing culture/customer experience

Title: If you work here, leave as soon you can.  If offered a job, respectfully decline it.
View5: There are no more good reasons to work here, they are all gone.  Over 15 years in IT at this company and they have layed off the brightest and most valuable employees.  The 'real' workers are gone, teams cut to the bone and expected to still get the work done.  Fidelity is cutting IT  and are preparing to outsource the whole thing over the next 5 years.  Get a job at a company who is going to provide the outsourcing.  You are expected to do your job with a blindfold on and both hands tied behind your back.  Benefits are going to be cut, demotions are days away, salaries will be cut and no pay raises expected this year.
View7: Too many to list in the space provided.  Run away and don't look back.

Title: Fidelity can be a great place to work if you get in the right group.
View5: Good employee investment plan (I've heard it changed since though..) Excellent intranet communications - including online training and other programs. Mature organization - policies and procedures are clear and well formed. Opportunities for reward and bonus are consistent. Strong. progressive corporate culture.
View7: Politics over substance in some areas with occasionally over-managed resources. Review process seems more subjective than objective. From my perspective, Fidelity can be a great place to work if you get in the right group. Unfortunately, I joined a group that had a high turnover rate that began before I joined and continued after I left.

Title: Constantly becoming more difficult
View5:
Retirement benefits are realtivley good compared to other companies.
Long term incentives exist to those with high potential.
The talent level of employees is exceptional
View7:
Becomes more difficult to work here each year.  All incentives for staying at the company are paired back with the downsizing of beenfits each year.  

Also, in the past 5 years the company has been developing and implementing a site strategy that has caused numerous people to be moved all over the country.  Taking the package also does not mean safety in your job as numerous people have been let go only a year into moving.

Title: Great company to work for if you are in it for the long term
View5:
-Very transparent for the client unlike a lot of Wall Street banks
-Excellent brand name within the marketplace and the general public
-Benefits 401k and work/life balance
-Quick opportunity for advancement, especially in the last few years
View7:
-Salary: The phone roles are grossly underpaid considering the amount of responsibility and the value the role adds for the company. This role is one of the most difficult in the company and is compensated the least.

-Extreme micro-management on the phone roles especially with metrics, breaks and lunch

-Lack of communication: Often times as employees we find out about breaking news/advancements the company is involved in, at the same time as the general public

Title: Good place to work
View5: Challenging environment, good benefits, great technology, always changing
View7: Lots of distributed technology teams offshore causes challenging time schedules if you want a good work/life balance.  Risk of New England based positions being moved is constant - but what is the benefit?

Title: Culture is Shifting
View5: Health/Dental/Life insurance. Unlimited growth potential. Tuition/Computer/Gym/Insurance reimbursements. Management is (somewhat) supportive of coaching/growth of reps. Sick days. 3 weeks Vaca. Paid holidays. Overtime is paid at almost 3X. Profit sharing is huge. Employer match is huge. Ability to work as much as you'd like.
View7: Culture is shifting within the firm to focus more on the bottom line rather than clients. Increasing micromanagement. Call center environment. There is a disconnect between decisions made from upper management and actual impact on associates/clients. 5 year graduated vesting for company match. MINIMUM 10% overtime during tax season to accommodate for inefficient/poor hiring schedule and practices.

Title: A Values Based Company that you can build a long term career with!
View5:
I am in my second decade with the firm and I am so happy I chose to work here out of college.

Family Owned:
This company takes care of its people.  I have been through 3 major economic downturns in my career and the firm always takes the long view and does cut into muscle and bone during trying times.  The Johnson family thinks in the here and now, but they also have a view 50 years out.  They are humble and grounded individuals that are always looking for opportunities to improve our business and our employee experience.  

Benefits:
We are industry leading, period.  Childcare assistance, tuition reimbursement, college loan repayment, healthy meals at a deeply discounted rate, onsite gyms, onsite healthcare facilities, onsite CFP programs, 6 months of leave for moms, computer purchase assistance, etc, etc, etc...  
If that wasn't enough, the firm isn't comfortable with out offering in this space.  We are in the midst of a major benefits reassessment.  Abby and her new head of HR are leading the charge in this effort.

Work Environment:
The family and the company goes to great length to ensure we have the best facilities for our teams.  Our major corporate campuses are spread across the country in beautiful locations.  While Fidelity is a conservative company, they build our buildings to last centuries and the are constantly refreshing them.  

I have read many posts about the call center environments.  I felt compelled to respond.  Call centers with any company are tough.  There is no way around it, it is a tough job.  However, it is an entry level position where you can learn a lot in and then leverage that learning to different roles in the future.  I know of 5 Executive Vice Presidents, several SVPs, and VPs who started in the same positions at the firm.  If you are coming out of college, you will likely start in an entry level position at some firm and you will have plenty of opportunities to work up and sideways from there.   

The firm could do a better job of facilitating that movement, but I will mention it further in the "cons" section.
View7:
Career counseling: 
Many of us were told early in our career that you needed to pull yourself up by your own bootstraps when it comes to career planning. Essentially meaning, the cream will rise to the top, and the driven folks will figure it out. 

While there is merit in this strategy,it is outdated for the size of our company.  Like many companies of our size it can become difficult to navigate.  I feel that is why many of the comments on glassdoor related to this topic are correct from the perspective of the person writing the review.  However, this is absolutely not the intention of senior leadership.  The leadership team wants to hire college grads and watch them progress out of entry level positions and branch out throughout the business.  The individuals who do, are generally immensely successful.  

The problem lies in the lack of programmatic career planning conversations and marketing of the internal opportunities and job matching. To their credit, the firm has recognized this issue and I have heard is working on building career centers to help facilitate these dialogues and career plans.  I would expect comments related to issue to start to subside as this rolls out. 

To make a long story short, the sr. team has shown that they care and want to help find the solution.

HR systems and training:
Simply put, we have antiquated systems in HR, and training needs to be modernized to adapt to the way college grads learn.  A better mix of classroom training integrated with a lacking digital solution that ties to our HR systems. 

HR system and staffing:
HR needs an overhaul.  Specifically in staffing.  We have a very traditional model and staffing and HR are loaded with career HR and staffing people.  We need to take a cue from Silicon Valley companies and add more business consultants and business leaders to the HR function to modernize it.  We need to keep about a 1/3 of this business unit as traditional HR and Staffing consultants, but there is a serious lack of creativity and challenge of old processes because of the the similar backgrounds of everyone in the group.  Until we do, we are destined to be average in this space.

Title: Great Benefits - Lots of Politics
View5: Company works hard to create a pleasant environment and provide great retirement benefits, standard bonus brackets, and private stock options for excellence in performance.
View7: There is a culture at Fidelity that you have to learn.  Your main success comes from ensuring you don't walk in the door from the outside and try and lead and influence people who have been in the company 20 years without their permission first.  A bit of political advice that can go a long way  People never leave there cause their 401K keeps growing and that creates some havoc for opportunities.

Title: Decent place to work
View5: Fidelity is a pretty good place to work.  I have been in the Corporate HQ for almost 3 years.  It genuinely cares about its employees and has great benefits (maternity/paternity, profit sharing, 401k plan).  I have worked on interesting projects in the fast-evolving financial services space and felt like i have made a difference to the business. There is reasonable work-life balance compared to many other managerial jobs.
View7:
- Below-market pay at mid-level and senior manager positions
- Bureaucratic and byzantine structure - lots of layers and siloed groups
- Can be political - more about who you know and how you're perceived than the actual quality of your work / ideas

Title: financial rep 15 years
View5: They have a great benefit package
View7: managers don't care about associates only stats. Advancement is all about who you know and who likes you not your skill level. Really just a glorified call center role. Pay increases are a joke. Management is awful and treat associates like children. To be successful you have to make friends with management outside of work to be in the click.

Title: Greatest Company I Have Worked For!
View5: I have worked for several financial companies. This company truly cares about the employees as well as the clients that it serves. I don't think i could find a job with better benefits. They also want you to grow in the company by providing opportunities to see how other departs are and talk with managers. Fidelity values the emotion well being of its employees as well. I have not had to work more than 40 hrs unless I wanted  to. It is a great company that allows you flexible hrs to have time with family or have a social life.
View7: I do feel like training was way to long but I understand they just want people to start at their best.

Title: Loved working with corporate management but regional management was very inexperienced  and lacked the resouces to grow.
View5: Pay and incentives are good but not always rewarded fairly.  If you align yourself with the right people you can move up fast.  The culture has changed a lot in the past 10 years.  Very different when Ned Johnson was in charge.  Not sure if that is a con or pro only time will tell.
View7: Many employees get positions on who they know not what they know.  It seems they only want to be seen as a company of miliniums and put very little value in hard work and a good  work ethic.  Trying too hard to be a tech culture without the knowlege of what it takes.

Title: Random reorgs and layoffs
View5: Great overall compensation and perks like subsidized healthy lunches.
View7: Periodic cost-cutting methods include layoffs of more senior, more highly compensated employees.  This was referred to as a "youth movement."

Title: Analyst
View5: Lots of opportunity to move to other positions
View7: No profit sharing for the New Mexico site. Also no retiree health plan Mostly entry level job roles, hard to move up or anywhere if you are tenured at the New Mexico site

Title: Nice company but very draining job
View5: Fidelity is very generous in terms of pay and benefits. It also grants a lot of time for training individuals for the job, no matter what background you may have come from before joining Fidelity, they will teach you all the basics of the industry.
View7: If you are joining Fidelity through a call center role, be prepared because it can be a very draining job. You will have nothing but back to back calls for a vast majority of your day and are lucky if you get a full minute or two to breath between calls. You will also have to keep an eye on metrics, one of which is regarding number of calls taken within an hour. Basically, if you are entering into this role just be prepared to take on extra stress in your life.

Title: Your experience will depend on your team
View5: Good pay, great benefits, and most of the people there are good people. The CEO really does care about everyone within the company. She takes a vested interest in her employees. I have nothing but respect for Abby.
View7: I say most because there are some people who love to play office politics and make life hell for the rest of their coworkers. There were times where I would get frustrated with the politics and eventually just decided to quit. It's not worth sacrificing my mental health over.

Title: They treat you like a computer
View5: Company match, salary, vacation time is front loaded. Fresh lunch options.
View7: No work/life balance. It's looked down on if you call in sick. Schedules are highly competitive. You must meet your quotas constantly on the phone. Calls must be dealt with as quickly as possible. If the rest of your numbers are good, but your call time is too long, no chance for any other opportunities in the company. Must have supervisors permission to apply for a different job in the company. If they say no, you will be stuck on the team. You work on a timer. You are given breaks, and a short 30 minute lunch which makes it difficult to eat the fresh lunch they provide since it takes almost 15 minutes to receive your food. You are expected to always be taking calls.

Title: An once great company that is going downhill.
View5: Fidelity is a large company with locations around the world. Compensation can be good, but the level of political game-playing is very high, making it hard to get ahead unless you are really friendly with someone at a higher level.
View7: Ned Johnson used to run the company in a way that treated most people fairly, but executive management changes constantly. Every time there is a new executive, the domino effect is seen and productivity is severely impacted. Roger Lawson is currently doing his best to decimate the company of the best and brightest employees.

Title: Project Manager Review
View5: The people I have worked with for the past 10 years have been great and have made it easy to come to work.  In the beginning there were many perks and management really made you feel good about working at Fidelity.  The campus is beautiful.
View7: The culture is very political.  Your manager may have been hired becuase of a realtionship he/she had with a director or VP not becuase they were great at their job.  Fidelity is not a place for great managers or leaders of people.  Since the introduction of Six Sigma Fidelity has become an assembly line, you have your job to do and I have my job to do and I will not help you becuase I may be held responsibel if something goes wrong.

Title: Opportunity for Advancement
View5: Within 2 years, opportunities to help train new hires, work in multi-practice customer support, and advance to provide interim team support have left great aspirations to continue to strive for success.  They do not reward showing off or doing what's expected, so to get ahead, you need to network and do something for your manager like being a load-lifter in some way to show your worth, in addition to doing your job well.
View7: There are so many people, it can be hard to stand out.  Not all opportunities will apply to you or your business unit and sometimes information regarding availability might not be available with much notice.

Title: Easy to get in, hard to move up
View5:
Fidelity does a lot of solid training, considerably more than a lot of competitors in the field. 

Benefits are very good. Pay is a little less at Fidelity but when you consider benefits in the compensation package it is competitive.

Workplace environment is reasonably professional and not stuffy.

For the most part front-line managers are willing to work with associates to find a favorable resolution to personal issues.

Managers don't throw you under the bus to customers just to make the customer feel better about a problem.

There are some great employees and managers who care about the customer and care about the employees.
View7:
Middle and upper management appears to have no idea where they are trying to steer the company, so the company swings from taking an idea to the extreme to a complete 180. Today they may be focusing on customer satisfaction and personalizing the interaction and in a few months decide to strip down customer interactions to scripted nonsense.

There are very few outlets for good ideas to arrive at implementation. Although there are feedback channels that may from time to time result in small changes, the bigger process issues or customer/client issues are completely controlled from the top by people who don't understand (and at times take pride in not knowing) what they manage so they don't know how to recognize or fix problems. So something may be a problem for years before somebody decides to do something about it, and even then the "solution" may aggravate the problem.

Fidelity is very political. Fidelity is obsessed today with it's brand image to the public, but one thing that is always constant at Fidelity is the constant obsession about your "brand". Gossip is taken as gospel and can ruin your brand in a second. What people have to say about you will override your performance in virtually all cases. Many managers would rather sink one of their employee's opportunity for advancement to be able to keep that person's performance in their numbers. A lot of backstabbing and stealing credit occurs.

There's not a lot of advancement opportunity. When the economy was great in 2007 it wasn't that hard. If you were great in your job, you could move on to a slightly better position, and when you did well there, you could move to another slightly improved position, until you were where you wanted to be. Once the economy crashed in 2008 that all stopped. I get it. That happened everywhere. However, it also stopped all discussions of professional development and no effort was made to give opportunities to develop skills for the current role or another. As a result, future promotion will be very difficult because internal candidates won't be as competitive against external candidates.

Recruiting/HR and their processes are absurd. It can take months after applying for a position before you get an interview. You can apply for a role, not hear anything for several months, and then get an email that you have an interview the next day. So you end up with no opportunity to prepare and made no efforts to prepare because you never heard anything back. Feedback from interviews rarely exists or is very generic. Hiring managers are lazy and don't follow through. 

For every great manager there are ten clueless unhelpful managers. It's obvious that middle and upper management have no idea how to manage their people because there's very little accountability or responsibility on the part of front-line managers. Directors believe yelling at people is the only way to manage, so they will yell at their managers when the numbers are bad, and that's pretty much the extent of direction or vision executed at the management level. I have heard several managers complain that they don't feel it's right that their performance is judged based on the performance of the people they manage. Well, that's what managers are there to do. If they aren't managing towards success, then they aren't doing a great job. I understand there are low performers, etc. but when I see managers playing ping pong for hours in the break room, there's not a lot of accountability in the system.

There's a lot of infighting between different business units. Everybody points fingers but nobody takes ownership over problems and fixes them. Customers and employees get stuck in the middle with no way to get out.

Fidelity no longer places a premium on its talent. Since 2008 the company has eliminated whole business groups with no effort to keep around people with tenure with tremendous transferrable skills. It does very little to help grow talent or keep it from leaving. Where a few years ago employees were loyal to the company and that loyalty was returned, the company has completely eliminated that loyalty. As a result, the company keeps losing great talent and keeps hiring new people who underperform and embarass those of us who strive to be great at our jobs. 

While all of the above things are common among businesses and I have, as most people, experienced similar trends at other jobs, what I will point out is that these problems were not institutionalized in a company that performs with mediocrity and accepts laziness in its overall perforamce. Fidelity is a top competitior in its markets and a lot of its strength historically came from the loyalty to and from its employees.
