Fidelity has worked very hard to treat its employees with indifference and management -- from the very top -- has set the company afloat with no real vision or guidance other than keep trying to make things that don't work struggle to work.

Title: Continuous improvement makes for continual employment
View5: Continuous improvement both technically and professionally is one of the basis-es of  employment.  FI holds all employees, business partners, vendors, and contractors accountable to the highest ethical standards.  Management is diverse, but most will provide defined expectations to give their employees the ability to improve and grow.  FI provides decent compensation to their employees.  The work environment is great = great people, quality professionals.
View7: Management expects proof of ability over word.  This means if you are being considered for a promotion, such an employee is given the ability to prove their abilities.

Title: Moving IT jobs out of Boston
View5: Some great people have gone through the doors at Fidelity.  Fidelity has traditionally invested heavily in technology and smart people.
View7: Unfortunately the company is relocating its IT jobs out of Boston and loosing its talent base and domain knowledge in the process.  The company is currently focused on cost cutting and outsourcing rather than talent retention.   A large inventory of legacy applications is a drag on innovation and its IT budget.  More cost effective products from competitors, such as ETFs, threatening their business model.

Title: Milk Them For All You Can
View5: Good place to build your career in financial services because of the training, structure, pay, and benefits.  Good brand recognition from customers, but this can turn into a negative if you lack humility.  Most reps are not as good as you think.  The green machine is doing a lot of the heavy lifting, but those who are good at building value and relationships can transfer those skills to an RIA and do really well.
View7:
- Although micro-management is mentioned in almost every review, I think it stems from not trusting your veteran representatives.  Fidelity feels like they have to control people from the top, having branch managers regurgitate sentiments from the top.  This also leads to *bleep* rolling downhill.  Some managers did prove themselves as good salespeople, but eventually have to drink the Kool-Aid or they won't last long.  Either that or they give up because they can't change the system.  Other managers were opportunists who rose through the ranks quickly, moving fast enough before people can realize they aren't as good as they appeared.

- Compensation:  Yes, you can make very good money here, but if you're really good, you can make way more outside.  Compensation is figured out ahead of time and they reverse-engineer the compensation plan to get AE's back to target comp.  The last couple of years, they've reduced some of the pay, like basis points on new flows, coinciding with the S&P at historical highs.  Oddly enough, they had a reduction in force in 2009 because they based payroll on the S&P and had to cut people.  So when the market's down, you're screwed, and when the market's up, you're also screwed.  Ultimately, you can't keep lying about AE/SAEs being in relationship roles when your compensation is still based on selling products.  And this relationship model is 5 years old.

Title: HNW Services Representative
View5: 7% company match. Good, but expensive medical / dental insurance and four weeks vacation after five years.
View7: Salaries are definitely sub-par. The company keeps raising goals, thus eliminating/ reducing quarterly bonuses. Often treated like children and insulting our intelligence. Office politics are the norm. Old and slow employee technology. Real problem of group think here. You HAVE to drink the cool-aid here or you won't go anywhere. Want you to think "out-of-the-box" as long as it's their box. Keep changing plans no real direction for this company. If you work here, get your licenses and leave.

Title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
View5:
1 ~ Many would tell you the best thing about Fidelity is the people you work with and I agree. I have made several life-long friends and look forward to seeing them every day. Asking around you will find many people also found their significant others at work as well.

2 ~ Upward mobility and job opportunities. I may be biased from working at the Westlake campus where there are over 6000 jobs but it is also relatively easy to move to other locations within the company. There was a time years ago when it might have felt like you had to go to Boston to move up in the company but those days are gone and there are many great leadership positions throughout the country.

3 ~ Brand recognition you can be proud of and sleep well at night. Fidelity is a discount broker so not ripping people off with high loads or fees. They did not get caught up in the mischief so many other firms did with the mutual fund scandals or financial crisis.
View7:
The best things about Fidelity are also the worst things about Fidelity. 

1 ~ If you end up in the wrong department with the wrong boss your life can be a living hell. Fidelity is very liberal in its HR policies which can be good but also means they let things fester for a long time before taking action. There is a percentage of people that will take advantage of this and especially if you are on a small team you may end up constantly covering for a weak link.

2 ~ It is an American dream to start in the mail room and work your way up to VP someday and that is totally possible at Fidelity. In fact, it may be a bit too easy. It is completely common to attend leadership meetings and hear from senior executives "I started on the phones just like you!"  Well, that is fine once in a while but at some point you do want people leading you to actually have some training and experience. Fidelity is full of hundreds maybe thousands of Directors, VP's and SVP's that started on the phone "just like you" and it shows.

3 ~ Fidelity has managed to stay out of the news but there are plenty of unsavory things they do behind the scenes. They are currently very worried about the Department of Labor proposed Fiduciary Rule. Their current employer benefits business model is already unethical but if the rule is enacted will be illegal as well. It has long been a major IRA rollover sales lead source to take advantage of relationships with employers to gain access to employees. Fidelity is the world's largest 401k record-keeper and should this lead source be taken away it will be a huge hit to their personal investing sales model in which two thirds of the new assets are from internal rollovers. The Fidelity brokerage business would be nowhere near what it is today without having taken advantage of these workplace business relationships.

Title: Good Benefits, Diverse Products, Interesting Projects, Much Politics
View5:
Opportunities for growth are plentiful along with the resources to enact on that growth. 

Benefits structure is generous with a large emphasis on health and retirement benefits.

Huge focus on delivering a good customer experience as well as a focus on ethics in its dealings with customers.

A varied and diverse product line that allows for personal development and varied experiences across business units.
View7:
Bureaucracy coupled with frequent organizational change. Structures are created and disassembled with lightening fast rapidity, inhibiting associates ability to deliver.

Managerial empire building is rife along with the political minefield that creates across the organization.

Title: Great benefits and atmosphere
View5:
The benefits are amazing. Between the health care, the on-campus cafeteria, and all of the various perks, it's unbeatable. The company pays for you to get your series 7 and series 63 exams. You work with licensing trainers to learn the material. You will have to sacrifice a lot during the licensing period, and won't have much free time. 
They really do work on making sure the employees are happy. They like to hire within for other positions, and encourage movement within the company.
View7: For the CRA position, you are expected to answer calls while in licensing. I felt as though it was difficult to talk about the investments while you were learning about them. This lead to customers being frustrated that we could not help them, and we would have to transfer them instead.

Title: Outstanding Company and Career
View5: Leaders and Managers truly care about your success and career. There is always help available including developmental opportunities, skills training, education, certification programs, tuition reimbursement, loan programs to test out other organizations and peer groups. Customers and Employees are at the center of every decision made by leadership. Major investments are made consistently in technology to perform job functions better and easier with customers and employees always at the forefront.
View7: Like any job, there are duties you have to perform. Business demand picks up heavily for this role during Q4 every year which means we travel a lot more and are away from our families. This is part of the role and understood and also balances out during the course of the year.

Title: Good company, but for how long?
View5:
Overall compensation at Fidelity is very good - however you are expected to contribute a lot to earn it.  Advancement is available for top talent.

Fidelity is very flexible with its work options - telecommuting, flex time, etc.  Management is very well versed in leadership and helping people to provide resources to bring out the best in their work.
View7:
Currently undergoing a transformation that may commoditize the company and make top performers leave.  Reluctant to eliminate low-margin business from its portfolio.

Much of the company is territorial and rather than working well as a team, things can be quite difficult to accomplish.

Title: High net work phone representative.
View5: Fidelity has a good compensation package. They pay better than most of their direct competitors. The training is also good.
View7: My division no longer exists. It was consolidated into another division. In the last few years before the consolidation, management did not seem to care that their approach to managing the company was very detrimental to employee morale i. e. revoking scheduled vacation for some employees within a few weeks of the scheduled vacation due to customer call volume. They knew the end was near for them and they simply did not care.

Title: Phenomenal employee relations...
View5: The training you receive at a job says a lot about your employer, and Fidelity invests a lot of time and resources in their new employees.  Throughout your training there are constant opportunities to sit down with your on-boarding manager to talk about your progress and career development, including what direction you want to take after your current position.  It's almost as if Fidelity wants you to improve and move onto bigger and better opportunities within the company more than you do.
View7: At the start there is a lot of time commitment that you need to make outside of the workplace.  Getting securities licensed takes a lot of time at work and a lot of time at home.  If that's not something you are used to or don't have available it can be a big adjustment.

Title: They do not value industry exp. or knowledge. A private company that is run more like a public one.
View5: Some locations offer free parking. Casual dress and jeans on Friday. Not much more to say than that.
View7: They don't provide formal reviews or offer development. You need to start there right out of school in order to succeed. Value isn't what you know about the industry but how to figure workarounds for their convoluted systems. Not a lot of opportunity for those coming from the outside.

Title: A great place to start your career so that you can move on and take your experience elsewhere.
View5: Over my career at Fidelity I worked with some amazing people, had a lot of development opportunities and great benefits.  I left voluntarily with a strong professional network and tremendous experience, for which I am grateful.
View7: The culture of the company has really deteriorated - there have been many management changes and shifts in direction.  The benefits are still great, but I don't think the compensation is as competitive as it used to be.  This is a big company and you must learn to deal with a lot of bureaucracy in order to accomplish things - a person who succeeds at Fidelity is flexible, patient, smart, politically aware, knows when to give up, and can shift direction with little to no lead time.

Title: A good place to spend some prime years in your career; comp can plateau out in some cases, but generally a rewarding pla
View5: Many high quality professionals at lower and mi levels within the company,particularly on the technology side of the company.  Within the business leaders, the typical political class emerges and operates as such.  Internal communications is a priority for most of these executives.
View7: Overt focus on personal brand management and career advancement by the middle class.  As these executives are often paid well, they can be defensive and self serving due to the low likelihood comp can be replaced somewhere else.

Title: "Leaders" are bullies
View5: A lot of career opportunities and ability to move around to work on new things. The work is very interesting and challenging. Performance is rewarded.
View7: This place is trying to go in too many directions at once and be everything to everybody....can't get out of their own way with products, technology, and initiatives.

Title: Firefighting every day is the norm at Fidelity.
View5: Pay and benefits are very good.  They spend money like it is going out of style.  The compensation is good but you have to be cautious what the HR reps promise you. They will promise you anyting just so you will accept.
View7: Fidelity is a lifestyle not just work. You work 24X7.  No room for family.  Way too much paperwork to do your job.  Boston rules, Raleigh is treated like India outsourced.  Where I worked, I only got to know the 5 people that I worked with. Also, if you work in Raleigh, be wary of the Boston people.  They  are not friendly and are  not interested in helping anyone new.  The NH office resent the Raliegh office with a passion.

Title: Long hours and little recongnition.  Management expects the world of employees but some how managers are able to slack!
View5: Tenure with the company and overall hard working people.
View7: No raise this year.  If you are exceeding expectations you are now considered proficient.  Too many hours and no recognition.  Contractors seem to have a better deal with no accountability compared to full time employees.

Title: Bi-polar
View5: Decent salary.  Huge investment in IT.  Able to move sideways to new jobs. Willing to try new things.
View7: Shuffle, shuffle, shuffle.  Lots of people movement which has to be expensive.  Cutting a lot of IT jobs in Boston and moving to TX, NC or overseas.  sometimes there is too much willingness to try new things; there are 4 tools for everything, little is integrated, and standardization is not often found.  Certain groups have lots of politics. Not a lot of upward mobility.

Title: Balanced Review
View5: Good life work balance and flex time. Benefits are good but not what they used to be. Business casual dress code with jeans on Friday.
View7: Upper management often makes changes or asks staff to participate in projects. These changes and projects have an obvious negative effect on staff ability to get their "regular jobs" done. First line management is required to support these changes and generally does not support staff. There are too many power hungry, hostile managers at all levels.

Title: Good at first,  then downhill from there
View5: I will say that the Series 7 training that they provide is excellent.  Ok for a year, if it's your first job out of college.
View7: Upper management does a great cheer-leading bit but the real world is quite different. Every move you make is recorded and monitored, if you make a rookie mistake they make you feel terrible,  very little praise without a "but". Lot's of nitpicking criticism.  You have no time to socialize because every minute is accounted for.   The work itself is ok but quite a grind when you average 50 calls a day with only 2 15 min. breaks.   Grueling for little pay.

Title: Product-Institutional Services
View5: Good work environment.  Very savvy employees who will go the extra mile for their clients/customers. Work/life balance is present, but as in all walks of life depends on project deadlines and seasonal obligations.  Good pay and benefits.  Many sub-companies enable opportunity to transfer and learn new components of the financial services industry.
View7: Management-information-gatekeeping by some senior level managers negatively impacts the outcome of projects and can be demoralizing to the team.  Some micro-management exists.  Where this occurs it is very difficult to complete tasks.  Periodic RIF activity to eliminate older, longer service employees.

Title: Financial representative
View5: Good environment, good people, good room for growth with in the company. Great pay, fidelity cares about their employees and will set you up with good bonuses, 401ks, and profit sharing.
View7: Every day is exactly the same as the day before it, some managers don't really understand the industry which tends to make the job harder at times specially when your manager is on the computer looking for shoes while you take 100 calls a day. Training could be a lot better then it is. Some of the trainers are horrible teachers and don't know what they are talking about or can't relate the training to the actual job.

Title: Solid Opportunity
View5: I have learned a lot about myself professionally during my tenure here. There have been plenty of opportunities to work with various teams and technologies and I am a much more well-rounded engineer because of it. You get as much out of it as you put in. The teams and management I have worked with have allowed me to gain plenty of visibility with upper management.
View7: Due to the nature of the financial industry and a large financial firm that has been around for over 70 years, it can be difficult to innovate and move quickly on new projects due to a lot of legacy software. There are times where it is difficult to function as a technology company when where are limitations on systems.

Title: You'll Love It Here
View5: BI-yearly bonus, BI-weekly pay,Profit sharing cash every January,Everyone is issued laptops and most teams can work from home, Business casua dress code l including jean's daily, Medical, dental, optical,  long & short term insurance,on-site gym & classes,New buildings redesigned breakrooms & cafes with Hoveys on rack floor, Free Wifi  in the building and while traveling,  Walking trails, Outdoor sitting by lake or waterfall, On-site bicycles to use, New furniture so you can work at your desk or on sofas or arm chairs.
View7: No way to get away from managers who promote those they like instead of those qualified. Promotion of unqualified  team members puts more work on those who have to work with them. Takes a long time to terminate people with bad attendance, bad attitudes, and lazy coworkers.

Title: Good Company - needs to show more organizational maturity
View5: Fidelity is good company for early and mid career opportunities.Excellent use of technolgy for building their business and getting your job done. The benefits are excellent, but you will need to work hard and sometimes work/life balance get be difficult to maintain.
View7: Can be very political and you need to spend a considerable amount of time promoting your accomplishments up the organization. Need to stay close to your boss and whoever he/she reports to to receive deserved recognition. If you want to move up you will need to an inordinate amount of time managing up. There can be a sense of entitlement amongst the longer term employees, but that is changing.  Fidelity makes money despite itself and spends money foolishly at times.

Title: No career growth or work/life balance
View5: Inexpensive insurance plans and good 401k match. They offer good options for healthy eating  and promote a healthy lifestyle and reimbursements.
View7: No work/life balance. They precode overtime every week because of their refusal to hire additional employees to ease the work load and look down on you for opting out occasionally. There is no opportunity to advance to different areas of the company even if you are certainly qualified although they lure you in with the promise of moving around the company easily. I would not recommend.

Title: Financial Service Rep
View5: This is probably the best company I have ever worked for.  Management is very organized and always there to assist you with any questions or needs you may have.  The culture here is absolutely amazing and the happiness of their employees is something Fidelity takes very serious.  The starting pay is $42000.00 which is very competitive for the industry.  You get bonuses based on your performance every quarter.
View7: The only con I can think of is this is a call center environment.  I am just not the type of person who sees myself working in a call center for the rest of my life and decided to make a career change.

Title: Land of lateral opportunity
View5:
There is significant opportunity to change jobs within the firm due to the diversified businesses within the company (employer services, fund accounting, capital markets, operations, technology).  

The benefits programs are strong.  Employees can receive tuition reimbursement, gym membership reimbursement, computer assistance and even back-up day care.  Some sites offer on-site health clubs and/or walking trails.
View7:
Employees are just cogs in the wheel at Fidelity.  Two examples reinforcing this opinion are: entire business units are relocated on a whim and development programs are non-existent.

Raises and bonuses are “capped” minimizing the importance of excellent performance. In the end, the really great performers leave seeking appropriate compensation. Many end up returning shortly after for a matching (or higher) salary indicative of their true worth (dictated by the market for their services).

Title: if you like to stay in one job for a long time go with Fidelity
View5: profit shareing bonus is awsome 10% of salary after the first full year of working there.  Also they match dollar for dollar up to 7% every pay check.  Great for getting securities licences.  Also the education match is helpful for people going to school they will pay up to $10,000.  However, my manager said this started right away when I was hired he lied I had to wait 6 months before they would pay me back.
View7: no upward movement... once your in a role you feel stuck in a box you cannot get out of

Title: Who you report to is critical
View5:
Retirement benefits are quite good
Physical workspace and tech support are top notch, typically not hurting for technology
Depending on the group, willing to take risks
Be sure to know the "star power" of who you work for - makes a difference for reviews and promotions
Major investment areas are FMR Co (asset management) and retail distribution, especially in the branch network
View7:
Going through a growing pain - condensing business units.  Constant spot layoffs as the continually try to right-size their new look.
A weak boss will leave you highly vulnerable to a layoff / demotion
Hyper-political atmosphere

Title: Great company, horrible, horrible job.
View5: 401k/health benefits are phenomenal, you can switch jobs almost ever 6 months to 1 year, quarterly/annual bonuses, easy to win other rewards which can add up to several thousand a year for doing almost nothing.
View7: Micromanagement.  Every minute of my day is tracked and translated into an efficiency percentage, which if it goes too low, I'm penalized.  I'm not allowed to spend more than an average 480 seconds on the phone with a customer, or I'm penalized.  I'm required to generate sales leads in a non-sales job, or I'm penalized.  I'm required to stick to my minute-by-minute schedule, or I'm penalized.  And last, the job is definitely dependent on if your manager likes you.

Title: Good place to work if you're having a hard time finding work
View5: Large company with great benefits. There is some opportunity for mobility within the company. Also, even if you start out on the phones, if you do well, they recognize it.
View7: Working on the phones is miserable. You're tied to your phone and it is very hard to earn your bonuses. You have to earn so many points and for every minute you are off on your adherence (to your alotted breaks) or if a customer gives a bad review for a person they talked to before or after you, it still affects your score. Also the wage is barely above the poverty line.

Title: Great Place to Grow a Career
View5: Fidelity cares not only about their associates, but cares tremendously about the customer.  They do what is right by the customer, not what is easy for them  They treat their employees and customers with respect and dignity, and make you proud to be a member of the team.
View7: There are not many downsides that I can think of, but if I had to provide one it would be that there is not a Utah site that is not located directly in a metropolitan area.  Some of the other locations are campuses, which is nice - it would be great if we could get one here in Utah.

Title: Solid and Steady growth opportunity
View5: Work-life balance is great. If you are performing well, most managers are very understanding of personal needs. Steady-safe employment, once you have a foot in the door and you are delivering satisfactory work there is very low turnover. People and culture are great, very supportive and looking to set you up for success.
View7: While steady and safe employment is a plus, it means that career advancement is slow going, so make sure you enter the company at the appropriate level to your experience and skillset.

Title: Experience varies with the groups
View5: Some of the best people I've ever met were my peers/coworkers, and I am still friends with them to this day!
View7:
It seems the higher up folks get, the more disconnected they become from the actual roles they manage, and they plan for and focus on the wrong things - what is best for their bottom line, not what is best for the customer.
There is an illusion of management caring about their teams, and while individuals might care, overall workers are just a number and are disposable.  Those with the loudest voice, not the best ideas, are heard - and it's often to the detriment of the team or customer.

Title: Focus Is On Call Volume Not The Customer
View5:
- Benefits
- High Quality Employees
View7:
-  Fidelity's HNW and PCG groups now focus primarily on call volume rather than the clients. Your goal will be to take 5.5-7 calls per hour with two fifteen minute breaks during an 8 hour shift.   
- Financial Representatives are undervalued and will find difficulty moving to different departments within the company.

Title: Good company to start, but you probably want to jump ship ASAP
View5: Very thorough and organized onboarding process & trainings. Lots of learning opportunities at Fidelity in the beginning. For the most part, co-workers and managers are friendly and competent. Good healthcare benefits & great profit sharing (6% match).
View7:
Almost all the job opportunities at Fidelity require you to speak to customers on the phone. Mostly horizontal movements unless you network well & have great relationships with your managers. Job can get stressful and at some point of time, you will get yelled at by customers. 

It's a big company, so even though sometimes management asks for your opinion, they'll make changes that does the opposite. You're just a number in the company and most people leave within a year or two.

Title: Get your license and quit
View5: -Paid Training and licensing during first several months. Classes ar e very educational and they set you up to pass all the Series licenses
View7:
-Absolutely no room for growth. They purposely have a system that keeps you stuck in the call center. My manager was there for 15 years and even he ended up leaving because he couldn't find a role outside of the call center. Fidelity Investments and the Fidelity call center might as well be two completely different companies. The only positions available to you are in sales or some other medial phone position. Managers either can't help you out or won't help you out. Like my headline says I would take the position, get the licenses and then start applying elsewhere.
-Pay is much lower for similar positions at other companies

Title: Great place to work if you are not out all for yourself
View5:
Privately held, they "Do the right thing" for customers.  Though changes take a lot of time to happen, they are on the right path.  They are very innovative and have been very successful over the last few years at using technology to build scale and profitability.
The benefits are fabulous, especially the profit sharing and match for 401k contributions.
Great to work for a private company that is not totally concerned about profitability and earnings from one quarter to the next.  Company is conservatively managed so they have not gotten tripped up by the credit debacles.  Growing company which has a great future.
View7: Somewhat political in promotion processes.  Probably could make more money elsewhere though the position would be less secure.

Title: Best company to work for in America.
View5: Great compensation structure, even for unlicensed Representatives starting out in the industry.  Company spends considerable amount of time and resources on professional development of employees.  There is a really strong sense of healthy competition amongst the associates.  The company does everything it can to recognize and compensate those who perform above their benchmarks.  As a matter of fact, I've seen approximately 10 associates get promoted in the less than 5 years I have spent here.  There is a lot of room to grow as well, even for those who have plenty of industry experience.  The support structure is amazing, the company really goes out of its way to make sure every associate is successful.
View7: Different demographic of the community is a big determinant of your compensation.

Title: Entrepreneurial Vision Hanging in the Balance
View5: Fidelity is a large, multifaceted umbrella of companies affording a range of opportunities.  Benefits are good -- especially the 401k since Fidelity is the premier provider of mutual fund services.  The entrepreneurial spirit of its Chairman still there but needs a boost.
View7: Fidelity is increasingly feeling its size and is not as nimble as it once was.  Investments in technology are there but so are attendant bureaucratic obstacles.  If Fidelity endeavors to retain the core cadre of good people it has recruited in the past and bring their insights to bear, they could well maintain their standing and, potentially, go on to new heights.

Title: Fragmented and constant restructuring
View5:
- Excellent benefits (401k matching, discounts with major companies, free portfolio mgmt, etc..)
 - Great if you want a job that is laid back
 - A lot of flexibility to move laterally
View7:
- Salaries are not competitive
 - Boss had very little power in giving reasonable raises because of "company policy"
 - The work is not as challenging as it could be
 - Lots of red tape when you wish to use software that is not on the company list of "compliant" software
 - Business casual dress code forced on software engineers is never a good idea

Title: Good benefits and compensation; sweatshop environment; they own you
View5: Excellent compensation, benefits and bonus.
View7: Company has you tethered 24/7 with remote and mobile access technology; highly political environment; tough to get ahead; co-workers compete with one another; company only values highly aggressive associates without regard to whether they are of good character; people always looking over their shoulder in fear of losing their well-paying positions; not a team-oriented environment and not for the faint of heart! 40-hour workweek uncommon. High burnout employer.

Title: Fidelity might be a good place for you to work, depending on what's important to you...
View5: The total compensation is very generous. I worked there for 10 years, from 2001-2011 and every year we received 20% profit sharing bonus, even though the economy was terrible 2008-2010. Which means they were always profitable.  They are focused on on growing their asset share, and if you are good at sales, you will excel and be promoted often.
View7: The employees aren't the most friendly and helpful people, it is a culture of help yourself and you will do well. They are always focused on the bottom line of reaching their outrageous asset goals, at any cost, even lying to their clients. They change CEO's every four of five years which means you have to adapt to a new "vision" to drive sales.

Title: Regional Investment Consultant
View5: Fidelity brand is strong in the industry. Nice place to go to work-cafeteria, gym, etc.
View7: Quantity over Quality is what the Sales Desk wants at Fidelity Investments. You are a dial monkey-simply as that. I had 4 years of being a internal wholesaler at another well respected firm prior to joining Fidelity. Westlake is in the middle of no where-terrible commute from Dallas or Fort Worth. Many of the Sales Managers were once Internals and understand the frustrations of the job but have little empathy. The turnover on the Sales Desk is the highest that I have seen in my career and through friendships build at other companies.

Title: It's OK for a financial company.
View5:
- Very nice facilities
- Cheap food
- Ability to work semi-remote
- Some really smart people
View7:
- Politically driven, high pressure culture. 
- People rewarded for being cozy with management instead of delivering work. 
- A lot of roles filled with mediocre people in order to check a box and feel good. 
- Clueless, jaded employees can get away with being on their iphone all day and still get paid.
- Super paranoid about data loss. You have no control over your work hardware.

Title: Good if you are a "follower or a conformist"
View5:
- Work life balance it almost impossible due to the company going lean.
- Ethical company.
- Company politics play a continuing theme and reward employees who conform to the 'kool aid' standard.
- Many layoffs and movement of positions to employees who earn less.
View7:
- Overly hierarchical in certain areas with little access to senior management. 
- Senior management makes all strategic decisions with little input from associate level.  
- Not much transparency when is come to plans from upper management.
- Pay is not industry standard.
- Work/life balance difficult with increased demand and less headcount.

Title: Don't Recommend
View5: They pay you through all of your studies until you get all of the required licenses needed for the job. There are also a lot of career opportunities as long as you are okay being stuck in a call center taking calls for awhile.
View7: I had such a bad experience with their hiring process, but I decided to take their offer anyway to give it a try. There is no flexibility with your schedule once you are out of training, and benefits choices are definitely not as good as advertised, especially with their health and dental insurance. They really don't offer a lot of options and they are very expensive comparing to what the market has to offer.

Title: We'll all judge companies by how they treat people during tough times.
View5:
Fidelity was always a great place to work, now that covid-19 has hit they have stepped up beyond compare. Within days most employees were working from home, a week later new benefits we're rolled out to support people in these tough times. Incredible 😍

Leaders have stepped up beyond belief, I've always heard over communicate but now after 20+ years in software I've finally seen it in action. Daily and weekly updates with videos and open sessions to ask questions and just talk. 🤩
View7: None that I know 💪

Title: It's a stepping stone at best.
View5: Fidelity has an incredibly in-depth four month long training program that will not only bring pre-licensed financial representatives up to speed to pass their Series 7 and 63's (even for those completely new to the industry), but will also familiarize you with all of the software that would be used on a day-to-day basis. Generally speaking, upon completion of the program, financial representatives are capable of adequately performing the job duties in what is objectively a complicated job function without any sort of assistance. Also, barring a layoff climate or doing anything illegal, job security is very, very high; never hitting your numbers will still get you your weekly paycheck. If you play the game, opportunity is most certainly there to advance (and your manager will be first in line to assist you in achieving your goals), but you can only go so far in the call center, both in terms of job duties and salary.
View7: Unfortunately, the training program is where my positive experience ended. Employees are reminded every day from the first time they peruse the careers website, to the job interview, to on-boarding, to training, to team meetings, that Fidelity isn't like Merrill Lynch, Schwab, JP Morgan, or any other player in the game; Fidelity is a family-owned company and doesn't have to play to it's shareholders, and thus they are one of the few in the business "for the customer". That sure sounds nice, but beyond being family-owned, it's just not true. This job is in a 24/7 call center, and just like every call center in the world, metrics are king. You'll never move up anywhere in the company for retaining a multi-million dollar account or preventing perilous actions through education of financial instruments or any other morally outstanding action... you'll move up for finishing your calls on an average of less than eight minutes. This "time = money" focus exacerbates an already-beaurocratic business structure by incentivizing representatives to transfer their calls or to be curt to the point of being entirely unhelpful. That's fine, and almost expected from most call center representatives with other companies, but in financial services, it's unacceptable; you're dealing with people's retirement accounts and livelihoods. On the sales side, recommendations are limited to proprietary target-date funds and bloated, high-fee "managed" accounts. Going above and beyond to solve problems that are repeatedly surfacing and are consistently unaddressed is a habit discouraged by management: "that's not your job". Other than their own propaganda, nothing differentiates this company from the other financial services firms--do not take a potential paycut to choose Fidelity over them with the idea that you'll be working for some sort of Red Cross organization, even though they will spin it that way. At the end of the day, this is a 24/7 call center (where your job is to verify customers, reset passwords, give website support, send checks, and enter trades at their direction...financial professional is thrown around very loosely around Fidelity, but I would not consider the FR to be one) that is ALWAYS hiring. If you weren't able to deduce, there is an unhealthy amount of turnover at Fidelity due to employees leaving for increased responsibilities and salaries (most Jax representatives went to Merrill, which was literally across the street!). On the other hand, if you have some sort of relevant degree or experience and are out of work, there is a ton of job security and experience to be gained here. It's a stepping stone at best.

Title: Leaving Fidelity was the dumbest thing I ever did
View5: Fidelity Investments’s is one class act. Great culture. An undying commitment to doing what is best for their clients, their associates and the community where they do business. I spent nearly eleven years at Fidelity and those years were the highlight of my professional life. I feel proud to say I’m an alumni and still consider the company as ‘my company’. I left on June 30 as part of an ‘early retirement’ offer that was to good to pass up. Four months later, I’m seriously regretting ever leaving.

View7: Even small infractions of company policy or procedures were a permanent part of your employee record. Even these minor things came up in my department transfer interview. In spite of this I was still successful. During a training week I was given a written warning about using foul language. I never had. That was someone else, but I was written up despite the fact it wasn't me. There was no process for defending oneself when accused.

Title: Depends where you are in your life
View5: Good benefits. Co-workers are nice. Work is super easy and doesn't take much time if you are smart. Great for coasting into retirement.
View7:
Not a good place for people who are implied leaders. It's a very top-down culture. You have no budget even as a VP, no freedom to push outside the "Fidelity way". Most people have been here for the last 20 years and it shows how out of touch these leaders are with how workforce of today looks at leadership and work in general. Long tenured middle managers and individual contributors also show a strange indentured servitude behavior. Many don't have the spine to say the truth, stand up for their beliefs and do the right thing. The culture is to sugar coat bad news and push all decision making as far up as possible. 

This might be fine if you come from a top-down, command and control culture. If you have worked in a culture of empowerment, this will be a stifling place. 

The company is headed towards uncharted territory but people up top lack the will to get rid of the "leadership" crud that only knows status-quo and actively tries to stonewall new ideas. A vast majority started their careers in phone sales - so they are not equipped for todays and tomorrows world. It will be an extremely hard task to correct the current heading of this ship. Drastic measures are needed to clean house but I doubt it will happen. I am waiting to see what happens in the next year.

Again, if you are a young, go-getter this might not be a place for you.  If you want to build a career that enables you to work in another company later, don't count on developing yourself as a leader here. If you want to be told what to do and just want to spend a few more years until retirement, this place is great and has excellent benefits.

Title: Worst environment I've ever seen for UX designers

Members of management are emotionally volatile, manipulative, and aggressive to the point of creating a truly unhealthy environment (something I wouldn't say lightly). There is an incomprehensible Mean Girls culture where no one talks to each other openly and everyone throws their other team members under the bus to get ahead. I walked out of this job (something I never thought I would do) and I can't recommend it to anyone.

Title: A great company that focuses on hiring and training quality people.
View5: An atmosphere that truly promotes personal development. I've never worked anywhere that cared so much about the services that they offer. I genuinely feel that everyone at Fidelity has the best interest of the customer in mind. Also, there is a lot of opportunity for growth.
View7: Entry level pay is low when compared to similar roles in the financial industry. The company can feel a little too big and that there is some disconnect between different functions.

Title: Financial Representative
View5: The pay is decent and the benefits are great. I love my teammates.
View7: They expect too much out of the employees. Certain months of the year overtime is mandatory, which they do not tell you when they hire you. If you get hired in through the call center it is nearly impossible to get a job off of the phones. They say they want to help you move up in the company, but that is only true if you want to get licensed and move into another job where you are still on the phones every day.

Title: Good Opportunity if you can put up with a lot.
View5: I received an opportunity to work at Fidelity as an Advisory Representative which is just a fancy word for customer service representative. The training at Fidelity is unbelievably thorough. Fidelity has its training down to a science and it is incredible. It is also a good opportunity to network with your fellow coworkers.
View7: Now, the actual work itself is not fun. Every other call is someone upset and ready to yell at you. It would feel a little more tolerable but you essentially get paid $12 an hour. Since this is a large company mobility is close to impossible.

Title: Below Industry Average Pay
View5:
- Good company culture
- Free fit meals in cafe and fitness reimbursement plan
- 401k match and profit sharing
- Good health benefits
- Large firm with lots of opportunities for movement (if you know the right people)
View7:
- Managers can hold you back from advancing in your career
- Poor management is rampant and though there are annual manager effectiveness surveys nothing changes
- Pay is WELL below industry average for most positions so good talent is consistently walking out the door, leaving only terrible associates who managers refuse to fire in some groups

Title: I thought it was a great place to work my first few years but the longer I'm there I see the true side of management.
View5: Benes aren't bad. Starting to offer more flexible schedules.
View7: Bonus based on client's surveys. Clients answer the surveys based on what they think of the firm not the rep. It's unfair for the rep to get a poor bonus when the rep did their job really well.

Title: Challenging place to work, in every sense of the word
View5: Privately owned company historically not afraid of investing in up and down markets.  No quarterly Wall Street pressure means management can take a long view.  Historically, very good compensation packages at all levels.  Intellectually challenging environment with lots of talented people.
View7: Recent, sweeping management changes have been tough on the rank-and-file, and the outcome isn't entirely clear, yet.  Technical innovation is often dampened by "big systems" thinking and, recently, tight budgets and timelines.  The downside of lots of talented / smart people is that one occasionally encounters staggering levels of arrogance.

Title: Fast-paced professional and ethical place to work
View5: The benefits ( 401k, profit sharing, vacation, health/dental) are top tier .  The access to technology to complete your daily job functions is tremendous.  There are a tremendous amount of resources (if you know who/where to look)  to help accomplish your job function.  The majority of colleagues/people very responsive to questions and inquiries.
View7: You must be self-motivated and have the ability to succeed with minimal training and guidance.  You really need to ask the right questions/get a consensu answer from multiple sources to obtain the correct answers.  Obtaining resources is very beurocratic and painful to get.  Too many forms/blind e-mail inboxes to submit to get things completed with great difficulty in getting updates on requests.

Title: Despite the recent events, all in all a good place to be
View5: With respect to the changes being made due to the economic downturn, through 2008 the benefits package was outstanding in my opinion.  Health care was well covered. Salary, bonus and profit sharing was a nice combo.  Additionally,  the work/family balance was very nice and there was a high level of flexibility.  I also liked the number of community volunteer activities that you could choose from.
View7: It had become a bloated company with too many senior level people (a number without staff to manage). Additionally, I believe the review process could use overhauling (mixed signals on ratings/ranking) coming from HR and the department management.

Title: Privately-held company offers major benefits...
View5: Smart, driven employees. Everything isn't governed by quarterly earnings like most investment firms. Leader in almost every space it operates in. Lots of opportunities to move laterally, explore other career paths. Multi-year phantom stock grants create super sticky employees. Great internal training and development programs.
View7: Competition can be cut-throat at times, advancement (in responsibility and earning power) can feel overly orchestrated and prolonged. Longevity of some employees can create inertia within middle management.

Title: Good Place to Work
View5:
Benefits - although prices of medical kept going up.
Growth Opportunities - lots of opportunity here if you put in the effort.  Have seen many success stories.
Compensation - very good overall benefits package.
View7:
Not as personal as it once was - you are expendable no matter how long you were there, how dedicated you were or what level you were.
Expectations have increased so much, work life balance suffered.
Strategic direction keeps changing with each new senior division leader.  Very frustrating.

Title: Recently changed for the worst
View5:
Awesome benefits
Incredible co-workers
In house subsidized cafeteria
View7:
Unstable, too many layoffs
Poor work life balance
Highly political, gets in the way of getting your job done
Constant change with lack of planning, lack of completely funding, lack of follow thru
So many layers of management that higher levels have no idea of true status of projects, or work conditons

Title: Great Place to Start a Career
View5:
-decent comp & especially benefits
-thorough review & training processes to facilitate personal growth
-relative autonomy (at least in my group) and recognition of contributions
-flexible culture, work-from-home options, etc.
-leadership is respectful and open to feedback
View7:
-it is VERY difficult to move and grow in your career across business units unless you know people...resumes are ignored and it's all about the name game
-lots of dead weight (maybe this is an issue at all large organizations?), especially directors and VPs who don't understand their subject matter but realized they can coast and still earn six figures at this stage
-extrovert bias, salesmanship is often prioritized over skill

Title: A Lot Like High School
View5: Well-known company with a diverse set of financial services businesses,   Well-established in its markets.
View7: Extremely bureaucratic organization. Company stopped rewarding risk-takers years ago.  Attitude of most employees. is is to get what they can out of Fidelity because Fidelity is not going to do much for them.  Huge amounts of expertise were  let go (ie, senior subject matter experts, IT people) in past five years to reduce salary costs;  now is literally hard to find people who understand the business they work in.  Company communications to employees are of the rah-rah We are Great! sort.  Compensation levels are below industry standards.  A policy of no promotions for past seven years or so for mid and senior IT people adds to dissatisfaction.

Title: A great place to get your start
View5: Every branch environment is different, this is very evident in the DC area because there are branches in DC, 3 or 4 in VA, and 3 or 4 in Maryland and they each have different cultures. This is a great thing, but also plays a big part in branch metrics, promotions, and availability. I have learned a lot and met some really fantastic people! The benefits package is top-notch!
View7: Upward mobility is limited by the size and availability of the next job up within the branches. If one were to consider moving to another branch, or geographic location entirely, then the availability greatly increases. Onboarding is definitely not very great, they have an OTJ training mentality, which can be difficult in the DC area with "DC-type" clients.

Title: Phone Associate
View5: It is a stable company so layoffs are extremely rare. The 401k match is pretty good. Overall their benefits are decent.
View7: Management has an agenda in terms of who gets promoted and quite often it is not based on merit. Nepotism occurs everywhere, but at Fidelity it's an epidemic. However Fidelity has mastered the method. If you don't fit into their cookie cutter template or don't have a close friend or relative blazing a trail, plan on being stuck in your role for years while relative new hires leave you in their dust.

Title: Financial Consultant
View5: Well run company with exceptional training and resources. Hard work is rewarded and the personal retirement benefits are best in class. The company has great benefits and annual profit sharing. Really looks after its employees.
View7: Depending on the branch you are in, you can find yourself limited in promotions if you are in a branch that has highly tenured representatives who never seem to want to move on. The sales goals are fairly aggressive and they always go up but that just means making more money if you hit them.

Title: Reverting to the 80's
View5: Benefits package is excellent, including 401k match and insurance.  Many of the people (not in leadership roles) have the best of intentions and treat others well.  Generally a positive culture.
View7: In the past couple of years the culture has reverted significantly.  Between leadership changes and major layoffs, the result is a leadership team with no other voices providing them with real info about how the rest of the world works in 2018.  Many long-tenured white males in New England in charge of national initiatives who are truly living in the past.

Title: Love my job!
View5: Amazing people, great culture that truly exemplifies the company’s values, and wonderful benefits all around. Fidelity has been great to me!
View7: Work/life balance is hard sometimes as a salaried employee. They fill my plate with many tasks, meetings, projects, etc. and I still have to find time to coach and develop my associates as well as show my face at events where senior management is present. If I could have a little less work and focus on my team a little more I’d have nothing to complain about.

Title: Like dating a complex woman
View5: Fidelity has a great retirement plan, great health insurance choices, and can change jobs internally with little difficulty.   As a salary person you start off with three weeks of vacation and after five years you get four.
View7: Working for a private company has both its ups and downs, sometimes you have no idea what top management will do.  If the owner has a strange dream we might be starting a new business.  Sometimes the pay at Fidelity can be less then at other companies.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to work.
View5: Great working environment.  Friendly atmosphere.  Micro-managing is NOT the style there, big plus for the day to day.  Great reimbursement programs for things like tuition (90%), computer purchase (20%), exercise equipment ($250/yr).  Flexible work environment. Fitness center.  Great cafeteria options.  Kitchenettes with sink, coffee pot, microwave and fridge in every area make it easier.
View7: Corporate politics.  Depending on the type of information you would be exposed to on a daily basis your own personal stock trading will be affected in the following ways: You'll need approval before every trade (buy or sell), You must hold any purchase for at least 90 days, If you do sell within 90 days you must surrender the profit.

Title: Decent pay, all positions are similar, has become much more "the numbers" in recent years and less about the people
View5: Decent pay, mostly intelligent co-workers, good benefits, good 401k matching and profit sharing, company as a whole does right by its employees
View7: Call-center environment, micro-management, bonuses are based on performance of others in department (team-based), very few positions outside of call-center positions in Jacksonville, FL, too much focus on call center statistics,  "thinking outside the box" or going above and beyond for customers ends up hurting you because you are straying from the strict structure

Title: Good place to work overall, but experience can vary wildly depending on manager and group
View5: Great compensation package- higher than average salary for IT, excellent health benefits, good bonuses, matching 401k, profit-sharing, yearly raises plus the chance for extra money through "internal shares" (it is a private company).  Can be a great place to spend some time and get some good experience.
View7: It's big, and made up of very individual groups that rarely interact with each other.  If you're not careful, you can get lost.  Same politics as everywhere else, and middle-management turnover is huge.  New manager comes in and brings all his/her friends with them (at all levels).  That's pretty much expected here.  If you're not part of that "in" crowd, you're on the outside looking in.

Title: 2-5 years and then move on quickly  (Technology Groups)
View5:
Benefits are excellent (retirement, health savings, profit sharing, education).
If you are lucky enough to receive training the you will benefit, but if you work for group that doesn't put emphasis on it then you are on your own.
View7:
Directors spend 80% of their time managing up and 20% of their time protecting their bonuses .
Some of the worst people managers in the business. 
Poor project planning which results in cost over runs and rework. 
The "Yes Man" culture is embraced and rewarded.

Title: Working at Fidelity is just like high school.  High turnover rate
View5:
Benefits are slightly above average, just as good as all other big companies.
They will hire anyone.
Good Training
Fidelity is a great place for a customer, great products, customer first culture is awesome.
View7:
The office politics are really bad
Very high turnover rate, highest in the industry
the computer technology is all over the place
Fidelity cares way too much about email Surveys.
Not much promotion from within
The promotions are like little baby steps and often never include a pay increase

Title: Financial Consultant
View5: Benefits- that's it.  Can't even come up with the five word requirement for this section.
View7: Treat you like crap. Worked there for 8 years finally couldn't take it anymore.  Can't decide what they want to do.  Decided to double the amount of people in my position in 2 months which is just reckless.  You are just another number to this company.  They do not value their employees or their clients.  The market manager told us to stop calling people in "our book" and only work with new clients.  Mandatory to have 18 appointments per week.  Leaves no time to respond to clients calls or put in any effort to plan for client appointments which is the most important part of Financial "PLANNING".

Title: Security Representative II
View5:
They usually train SR's in AML, which can translate to a great future job.

Lots of down time to work on AML cases and schoolwork if you have it.

Plenty of programs to take advantage of in order to advance your career.
View7:
Since its such a small region you will stay security with no promotion, most likely. Unless you get a degree or excel at one of the investigations programs. Even then there is no guarantee, unless you are willing to relocate. You could potentially work as an SRII for 5 years.

Might as well look at it as a career step and take the downtime and use it to advance yourself in some way.

Title: Sr. Portfolio Specialist
View5: Great company with amazing benefits, and high integrity. They are client obsessed in culture and put the customer first, and willing to make changes to improve things for clients and employees.
View7: Annual pay increase most years didn't keep up with national inflation rates. Most all employees love the company, but job satisfaction has declined in that last year or two.

Title: Fund Accounting Analyst
View5: Fidelity Investments is by far the best company I ever worked for.  The environment is top notch professional, yet comfortable and relaxed.  They're honest with their customers and treat their employees with respect.  My coworkers were always intellegent, caring individuals and good friends.  Most managers I worked with were equally caring, and tried to help you succeed.  I no longer work for the company (I was laid off with scores of others) but still hold the firm in the highest regard.
View7: The salaries were on the low side.

Title: Horrible.The manager I was under lacked knowledge on the job itself.
View5: The company has good benefits.
View7: Fidelity managers do a lot of double talk.Rigid environment and some employees are rigid.People walk around like zombies.The manager I was under always stated on our breaks to get away from our desk,go outside for fresh air but how in the world can you go outside when your breaks are 15 minutes and how the building is built it would be impossible to go downstairs,take in fresh air and be back upstairs and on the phone  in 15 minutes and your metrics are being monitored every second,what a joke.I was let go after being on the floor for a month stating my metrics wasn't where they should be and I was being rude to customers and this never occurred. This comopany

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Easy Series 7 training.  The benefits are pretty decent.
View7:
Phones, phones, phones, phones.... get the picture?

This job is mundane at the core.  Every single task is repetitive.  It is a constant stream of taking glorified service calls over and over, with the same requests again and again.  

There is very little outside opportunities, or work responsibilities.  

Managers are nothing but micro-managing and just want to see themselves go up the ladder.

All promotions are just another form of phone job in a service or sales related role.

How many times do you have to explain rules of IRA distribution before you go insane?

Title: Management Can Be Difficult
View5: They have great benefits, very competitive pay, and I was able to work from home three days a week.
View7:
Some management could be difficult, and it seemed certain employees were favored.  There was very little positive reinforcement in my group.  There were too many directors and managers, and there was a lot of bureaucracy at Fidelity.  It can be frustrating to get things done or affect good changes.

Also, while I was able to work from home, I also had offshore resources from China on my project teams.  This required me to conduct meetings either very early in the morning (around 6:00am) or very late in the evening (after 8:00pm).

Title: Just pay your reps
View5: Best benefits package in the industry. The best training to get your licenses in the industry. Impeccable company record throughout the industry.
View7: The best benefits package in the industry means below average pay regardless of profession. There are limited options once you reach a certain point at the phone sites. Fidelity is a great place to have a career but not for motivated reps.

Title: Good company, terrible jobs
View5: Fidelity is a great company with good benefits and strong ethics. Compared to friends who worked at other financial services firms, I never felt pressured to do anything unethical or against the best interests of the customer.
View7: Almost all the jobs in Utah are call center jobs. By their nature, they're like having your soul sucked out of your nose on a daily basis. I love this company, but if this is the kind of jobs they're offering here I'll never go back.

Title: Going through big changes, but slowly
View5: Fidelity generally treats its people very well. Great benefits, very competitive pay, generally decent culture.
View7: Far too many people have worked there 20 years or more, with little outside experience. Privately (family) held, difficult to advice for new ideas. Small circle of leaders close to Abby Johnson has too much influence. Difficult to do anything new or quickly. Very risk averse culture.

Title: Top Notch Company that allows harassment
View5: The employees outside of management are great. The cafeteria is awesome and the building is beautiful. There is a reason for this.
View7: The beauty covers the horrific harassment that is taking place in this company. There is a male manager that goes after women as his prey and tries to force them out of the company. The higher ups know about this and continually cover it up. I hope the owner reads this and goes to the Morrisville NC site to take a deeper look at all male managers. There are women managers that like to bully. This needs addressing as well. I would never recommend this company to anyone. As you see the beauty of the building it quickly deteriorates into a horrible reality that no woman should have to endure.

Title: Good for the right personality type
View5:
1. Structured - Every approach, every answer, every interpersonal communication is proscribed by the company. As a 22 year old, this was beneficial for me.
2. Hours - They never asked me to work weekends. They never cut my hours and demanded I work a greater number of hours.
View7:
1. Structure! - What was beneficial for my 22 year old self was stifling several years later. 
2. Office politics - Promotions were political, because the managers filled the majority of openings with girlfriends or boyfriends before the positions were announced to the office at large.

Title: Great company but has  its  challenges
View5: Progressive company trying to reinvent itself for the new age of financial services.  Great benefits and comp packages
View7: Some administrative areas of the firms are still in the old culture and haven’t been transformed. Additional senior executive need to be mobilized. Still a lot of passive aggressiveness and clicks, limited transparency and openness.  Too focused on who likes you.  Other BUs that are revenue focused are in a much better place.

Title: Working Here Will Turn You Into an "Accidental Diminisher" (See the book Multipliers)
View5: They pay OK and top-level management seems to have the right goals. Bonus's are basically a complete crap shoot because performance is likely to be evaluated by someone who doesn't understand your role and who has failed to set concrete goals or provide guidance.
View7: Culture is extremely negative, especially within the Personal Investing group. There is very little accountability for either management or other co-workers, and very little transparency into how to accomplish the goals of your job. Priorities shift like the wind, since concrete goals are rarely established.

Title: Fidleity is a great place to work
View5: Fideltiy is an organizatiion that demonstrates integrity in their policies and actions.  Individuals at times lose the vision at times, but the organition is self correcting over time. The products and services are excelelent and the vlue to the clients is as good or better than most competitors.  Fidelity has strong and solid senior management, fair treatment of employees, a excellent business plan in their retail services. Cannot comment on other parts of the organization.
View7: Politics, lack of recognition for excellent work.  Processes are in place to do so, but they are hollow at times.

Title: Micro-managed to death
View5: Friendly and supportive coworkers, decent benefits but not great, fun employee get-togethers, good work/life balance. Questions are encouraged and for the most part, more senior employees are willing to help new employees learn the ropes. I was impressed by Fidelity Investments' e-newsletters and client brochures. They're professional-looking and more importantly, easily understood by clients.
View7: I was micro-managed to death despite strong work performance. There is very little employee autonomy. Fidelity Investments is a highly bureaucratic organization that offers very little room for creativity. If you want to work in a branch office, there are limited career advancement opportunities. Fidelity Investments tends to hire smart, hard-working individuals, but then they are forced to follow a highly regimented structure.

Title: Has its benefits
View5: Great place to start right out of college. Good reputation, and you get licensed. In sales, you are mostly inbound with a couple outbound blocks to call out to current clients, no cold calling. Salary.
View7: Big corporate company. Give you a schedule you have to adhere to. With any big company there are politics, which can be good if your personable and can "play the game." Not always flexible when it comes to time off, they want phone coverage at the expense of your family trips. Efficiency efficiency efficiency

Title: Good introduction to retail finance. But this a call center through and through. Do not be deceived
View5:
-extensive training program
-licensing help
-good introduction to finance
-genuinely nice coworkers 
-good computer systems 
-get to be a customer as well
View7:
-extreme micromanagement 
-does not care for ability or knowledge, only that you meet your call metrics. There is a person on my team that has to call for help over 10 times a day, but no worries  because they take 50 calls. 
-job goes from remedial customer service work to having to explain complex investing and tax strategies.. no consistency in service. 
-management is all about the flavor of the day: for a couple of months it was having great conversations with clients, then it was all about having a good workplace to be in.. now it's about taking as many calls as humanely possible with no rest. 
-management likes to hype up the small things.. like wireless headsets, or taking a break when you want to... but they will pass a long all bad news to the lower level managers and will not face the front line reps at all. They refuse to hear any criticism on policy updates. Some are so far removed from helping any client that it's comical what they expect.
- lately they have been devaluing the high net worth service reps. They used to allow for casework and follow up on issues, but they've tossed that in favor of handling as many clients as possible. So now the client with 2 mill as equal standing as client with 2k. 
-management treats all reps the same, no matter fresh out the dorm room or seasoned worker. Can be frustrating..
-this is not a role to stay in for long. Go the sales route. Stay away from customer service. 
-refuse to be competitive in pay
- bonuses are a joke.. almost insulting 
- if all else fails, other firms in town have better pay.

Title: Fidelity Used To Be A Great Company
View5:
-Compensation used to be very good
-Smart people work there
-invest in technology
View7:
-Comp has gone down dramatically due to change to long-term share program changes
-layoffs of good people are making it very hard on remaining employees
-the company is doing well, but treating employees as if the company is not doing well
-it's become extremely political, which gets in the way of getting the work done.

Title: Great Starter Job
View5: Great Benefits, friendly people.  Not in downtown, location is perfect.
View7: Low pay, low bonus pay out, constant changes, constant reorgs, feedback not tolerated, behind on technology and services, low morale and negative environment.  Continuous layoffs the last 2 years.  Opportunities within the company hard to get unless you know the right person, jobs aren't posted.

Title: Lot's of career path opportunities. Great benefits. Great compensation.
View5: There is a lot of focus on helping you advance your skills and career. They reward hard work and the people you work with are typically very professional and passionate about what they do. It would be very hard to leave the generous benefits and compensation once you have moved into a more advanced role.
View7: Sometimes it feels that senior management doesn't realize that their metrics and standards actually make it harder to help clients. They are great at taking small rocks out of the way, but the bigger rocks are next to impossible to move. Even when it is clear that they should be.

Title: Good place to work...could be great
View5: nice facility, beautiful grounds.  Compensation is good once you get past a certain level but getting there can be challenging.
View7: Lot of variability in your experience depending on who you report to.  Not very many opportunities to advance, but a lot of chances to move around.  Benefits are great but would be nicer to make more money instead.

Title: Financial Associate
View5:
This is a company that cares and provides opportunity to show it.
1. Benefits
2. The pay is very good especially considering the work/life balance: I declined a job that paid 10k more, but fidelity pays overtime, where as the other job was gonna work me 55-65hours per week. NOT worth it. Fidelity provides a very good pay with the ability for those who want to work over-time to make more money.
3.Great opportunities for growth. They pay you to get your licenses, they have great tuition reimbursement benefits. If you are ambitious and want to grow, Fidelity is your place. I am already planning to get my licenses, an MBA, a masters in law, and move up in the next 6-7 years. 
4. A great culture with efficiency to its core.
5. Healthy lifestyle emphasis. They have the FIT food which means salads and healthy food is super cheap. How affordable? $2 for a salad vs $10 for hamburger. Yes, they want their employees to be healthy and thank goodness. They also have a recreation center and a health center.
6. Ability to get involved with community and company. They have great affinity groups for LGBT, AfricanAmerican/Hispanic, Women, and Veterans. They also have FidelityCares so it is great for people who enjoy social groups.
View7:
This is financial services and it is highly regulated, what does it mean, there are rules. LOTS OF RULES. But that is only a bad thing if you are one of those people that can't follow rules or can't follow order.

The rules are very simple: Don't be late. EVER. Not a minute. Why? Because it affects the entire company. This company handles big clients with big expectations. It handles other peoples retirements, which means their futures. Yes, there is a high level of commitment, but there is also a high level of opportunity.

Title: A company in a major transition, experiencing the pain of change; future is unclear.
View5: Large company with option of moving to a different group to gain career.  Different groups are often like different companies; therefore, having the ability to move between groups is a good way to boost your career.  Good compensation structure - historically anyway.
View7: Very political and bureaucratic.  Titles are very inconsistent across business units, meaning a VP in one unit is a director in another.  Accountability at the senior levels is weak.  Due to frequent re-orgs a senior business leader is often moved to a new area and therefore is not in a position to own the impact of the changes they make.

Title: Constant contact
View5: The benefits are amazing, the work environment is great and lots of good people to work with - very sharing and  helpful.
View7: There is no work/life balance. Workload is so heavy that I was never able to go on vacation without taking my laptop. Forget about taking a day off - the blackberry chirped constantly. Hundreds of emails daily and keeping up with everything was nearly impossilbe.

Title: Too much time spent dodging shrapnel.
View5: The company has tremendous resources.  I had the opportunity to work with some very smart and capable people.  Excellent work/life balance, and the benefits were very good.  Decent career opportunities *IF* you're willing to live where the company wants you to.
View7:
Not long after I was hired, the company went into a cut & outsource mode.  Salaries stayed flat during my tenure, as with most of the financial services industry at the time.  Too much of my time was spent changing jobs to avoid being relocated. 
Truly horrid 'Human' Resources.  While driving my child to school one morning, I learned of the latest RIF over the radio.  My child looked at me and asked, "Are we okay?".

Title: If you are willing to relocate multiple times you'll do well.  If you want stability, look elsewhere.
View5:
Exposure to some brilliant and highly educated individuals
Good benefits and programs such as healthcare, profit sharing, on-site fitness and health centers, fitness and computer reimbursement, bonus opportunities
View7:
Can achieve work/life balance but usually not without paying a price (limited or no advancement opportunity, limited or no pay increases)
Under-achievers often get recognized and promoted if they know the right people and can play them to their advantage
Jobs are constantly relocated or eliminated on senior management's whim with little regard for the impact to the people or businesses they support

Title: Welcome back to high school
View5:
Great technology
You have your own office
They have billions under management somehow
View7:
You are constantly told that if you are in the top 10 on the regional ranking reports that you will be promoted (this is totally untrue as I witnessed numerous people at the bottom get promoted over the highest performing colleagues).  
You are driven to set as many appointments as possible (and tag as much business as possible) so that you look better than your peers
The only way to get ahead is to brown nose your superiors and those that have access to give you potential leads (thus people are being promoted on the basis that they were  "liked" in the company and not by their performance).
All that matters is your Fidelity "Buzz" 
There is very little to no upward movement for promotions.

Title: Financial Red
View5: The company provides great benefits for this entry level position, and provided excellent prep for the series 7 and series 63. The people were very nice, and you build great phone skills.
View7: The job itself was rather unpleasant. You were essentially tied to a phone for hours at a time, and each minute on site was highly regulated. While the training and support was nice, the job itself was not fun.

Title: Fideility Investments (Good)
View5: Good pay and benefits.  Excellent 401k plan with 7% matching and 10% profit sharing.  Remote work options for many.  Fidelity knows how to make money.  Strong bottom line.
View7: Depending on the group, you could be working a good amount of time: averaging 50+ hours per week.  Can be very slow in receiving promotions.  You need to be prepared to specify your accomplishments in detail during promotions.  Do not be shy.  Expecting management to recognize your worth and reward you for it can many times leave you behind and frustrated.  Yes, speaking from experience.

Title: All Good until its not Good any more an the millennials run the playground
View5: Location, Parking, Cafeteria (expensive) Free Coffee (you will need it), Benefits, Bonus, Profit Sharing, Vacation PTO, Walking Paths, mobility, internal chat.
View7:
Management is very disconnected from associates below director  level. If you are a women dont believe the BS they want more women in senior level position. Very little senior women in technology side or any organization.
