If you are over 40 you are playing Russian rullet with career with fido. Culture  is being geared  towards millennial to make them happy only to turn around an layoff tenor employees 

12 year employee still trying to move up while fresh faced 20's come in an refuse to perform the same work as a tenors associate does and is praised like a toddler. 

Dont forget H1B1 visa associates  preferred associate than USA citizen!!!!

Title: Pay is low on the spectrum , but benefits are great, along with the culture.
View5: Benefits, experience, and work-life balance. Specifically, the work from home option is a big plus. The people who work here are really nice, as well. They are open to ideas, most groups really push creative thinking. Although, good ideas are not going to bring a promotion.
View7: No cons besides the low pay and the location is out of the way of the metroplex. Management also seems to have positions filled before they have even posted. Not much room for growth within the groups. It seems like most of the older people in management have spent their whole careers at Fidelity. As for the younger managers, they have industry knowledge outside of Fidelity.

Title: Fidelity needs to show me the money!
View5: 401k match of 7%, profit sharing, medical/dental/vision benefits, even know we offered Roth 401k to our clients for the past year or more just last week we now get to participate...why so long?...voluntary time off unpaid but useful when you need time off for appointments/vacation. I've liked my managers! People are cool for the most part!
View7: with the phones are schedules are dictated by a console...so a 15 min break can't be more or less. Unpaid lunch without the option of not taking a lunch. Not enough money!

Title: Summer Intern
View5: Generous compensation, lots of training & educational programs for interns.  Challenging work.  Friendly people for the most part. Great 401k plans and retirement benefits.
View7: Opportunities for upward mobility in the company are limited.  Management can take a narrow focus, often has a hard time seeing the big picture

Title: Company does not have a clear direction
View5: Benefits at Fidelity are great, but are more structured towards the long term.  Most of the management are long-termers, so while there is some political in-fighting, it's mostly limited and directed towards the "newcomers" in management.  Good and bad, depending which side of the coin you fall on.  Not a bank, but still nice to be privately owned in this environment.
View7: Corporate infighting, and some of the downsides of working at a large firm.  Adequate compensation just isn't there at the associate level.

Title: Overall, Fidelity is a good company but there is way too much bureacracy.
View5: Pay and benefits are pretty good for most positions. Work hours are not as demanding and unreasonable as other financial services companies I've worked.
View7: Too formal and bureacratic. You need to have a meeting about having a meeting to get something done. It is absolutely insane! Also, senior management is not hands on at all- they have no clue as to what their underlings are doing or often what their staff actually does in detail on a day-to-day basis.

Title: Management deficiencies at every level.
View5: Good compensation and benefits.  Beautiful campus.
View7: Management skills are not measured or appreciated.  Position is more often political and based on who you know rather than qualifications.  Mismanagement has resulted in a entirely dysfunctional IT organization that is hobbled by a bizarre anti Microsoft sentiment that is supposedly present at the highest levels.  Company spends millions trying to integrate mismatched solutions rather than just adopting any single vendor.  Used to be a technology leader but is currently technology schizophrenic.   This company also used to develop its management leaders internally, those days have seemingly ended with recent management additions brought in form various other Wall Street firms.

Title: Great place to coast by or finish your career ... otherwise avoid it!
View5:
- Good benefits plan and bonus packages, amazing 401k contributions/matches

- Large enough company to move around in and chart a career path

- Pockets of great situations (good leadership, interesting work, challenging opportunities)
View7:
- Those pockets of great situations are growing fewer and further between each day, the amount of influence one's boss can have on their career at Fidelity is astounding ... in 3 different jobs, I was rewarded (1) on par/average, (2) over-the-top with $$$ and shares and promotions, and (3) not at all .... my approach to the work didn't change in any of those jobs, so it shows that people of equal talent and skills could expect significantly different experiences at this company

 - Jobs are moving out of Boston, so local opportunities are few and far between ... those that pop up are usually pre-reserved for a hiring manager's friend (i.e. probably not the most qualified candidate), so the talent base is watering down, causing animosity, and those that want to advance their career in the Boston-area have to look elsewhere

- There is a layer of lifers at the Director / VP level that have settled into a comfort zone, earning high salaries from the days of raises/big bonuses (long gone), they are staying off the radar, and don't want to rock the boat ... so they are stifling innovation, they are roadblocks to progress, and they are blocking career opportunities for younger, talented, innovative staff members.

- Didn't get a raise in 3 years despite the company pulling in $2.2-2.4B in profit each year, was told it'd be made up to me in the form of a "higher bonus", but the bonuses were the same each year. The company manages the bonus %s, the share rewards #s, and the raise $$ in a way to keep people looking forward to something, but the overall pool of compensation rewards is shrinking every year.

Title: High Net Worth Associate
View5: Lots of great resources, training is definitely better than average for the industry, lots and lots of great employer provided benefits, facilities are very up to date and modern, tons of resources at your disposal, and a great place to learn more without necessarily having to be in a pure sales or commission environment.
View7: Pay and bonus structure is significantly subpar - every time this is brought up you're reminded "how great" Fidelity's non-salary benefits are, which is somewhat true, however the fact that I have access to all kinds of benefits that don't apply to me ,or don't really have any personal benefit to me, personally, irrelevant.  I can't pay rent, buy food, or pay all the other bills I have will my "great benefits."  Money is the only thing that helps with that - and the salaries Fidelity pays, compared to the broader industry, are ridiculously low.  Moreover, there have been numerous changes that have occurred in the last 12 months that are ostensibly to "make things better" for the customer, as well as the associate, but the net effect has been the opposite ... for both.  They've basically significantly increased the scope of the role, while narrowing the performance metrics ... all while creating an increasing environment where it essentially makes it impossible for you to provide the positive experience the customer is expecting, and meet your goals.  How this has played out out to associate is ... you can kiss making more than the bare minimum for your quarterly bonuses (which also ... in not very much at all) goodbye.  Also, over the last 12 months or so, there seems to have been a dramatic concern with turnover, primarily among the associates who have been with the company less than 12 months.  The company has become ridiculously preoccupied with finding ways to keep this demographic with the company that they're basically throwing everything but the kitchen sink at them in the misguided hope it will keep them from leaving.  Basically ... they're focusing all their measures on increasing salary, compensation, and quality at work to the employees who have been there the least, and contribute the least to the company's overall functionality.  I've been with the company, and in this function for years, and even though I've been given yearly bonuses and increases I sit next to people who have been licensed less than 6 months, and are making the same amount in salary as me, or more.  It's really insulting, not to mention makes all the experienced, and seasoned employees feel extremely unappreciated.  Then there's also the issue that performance and ability really have no bearing whatsoever towards promotions or recognition for achievement - the current situation at the location where I work reminds me more of my senior year of high school, and everything boils down to a popularity contest.  The end result is you have people who weren't even competent to begin with and routinely failed to meet even the most basic of their performance metrics, being given increased levels of responsibility and management if they're "popular."  Granted this exists to some degree or another no matter where you work, however the level I've witnessed over the years is on the order of 20 times worse than anything I've experienced in nearly 15+ years in the workforce.

Title: Financial Adviser at Fidelity  = Churn and Burn
View5: If you work hard and you are smart you can make an attractive income in the Financial Adviser (Consultant) role. Company benefits are fantastic. Fidelity has a very respected and recognized brand. Largest 401k provider in the US, provides amazing cross selling opportunities.
View7:
There are many.

1) Financial Advisers have 300-1000 households to support and no real help to do so. The support staff is too inexperienced to do much more than help with some admin stuff and if they are good enough to actually help clients they move into a Financial Adviser role.

2) Your experience as an adviser can be made much worse by terrible managers who micro manage and have little knowledge of what you actually do.

3) Assuming 1 and 2 above, Financial Consultant role is too much of a grind to be a career. You either spend 2-5 years there and then move into management or you burn out and leave.

Advisers have 300-1000+ households and there is no meaningful compensation for retention of assets given the book sizes. ($40k year for a $200 mil managed money book? - book generates $1.5 - $2 mil annual revenue and you give the adviser $40k?)

Vast majority of your comp is tied to annual sales and what you have done in the past means nothing. Therefore clients that have a plan and 100% wallet share are undesirable.

Since company is so large and has so many clients they need to fill the chairs with advisers quickly. Many advisers are 20 and 30 somethings with little or no background in finance, they do the bare minimum for planning and only want to sell products and managed accounts. There is little incentive to really deliver a sound plan because that actually takes time and who has time with 1000 clients?

Overall - the reality is Fidelity is good for “mass affluent” financial help but they are too big and cookie cutter to truly help people with more than  $3-$5 mil. Due to size they have to reduce services to lowest common denominator to ensure consistency.

Title: The base salary is not competitive but the overall "benefit package" is good I guess
View5: Not super expensive health insurance. Good 401k match and profit sharing (yearly into your 401k - avg. 10%)
View7:
The environment in the regional centers is not very modern. Males dominate the industry and it's very clear when looking around. If you aren't one of the "it" people or popular, you're out, or they will not be on your side like others. 
The benefits are somewhat skewed to a specific group of employees, so not everyone gets to benefit from them. 
They aren't very competitive with base pay and put a lot of money you could be making in your pocket into your 401k.

Title: Very good company to work for
View5: Very good name recognition.  The company has a strong history of performance.  A local Boston-area company that has gone national.  The profit sharing plan is excellent (10% of base salary), which is on top of the 7% 401(k) company match.  Salaries are competitive to the rest of the job market.  Overall, a very good company to work for and one I'm proud to be employed by.
View7: In downcycles of the market there are often many rounds of layoffs, so job security can be tenuous.  Certain depertments can be highly stressful, and the work culture is one where those who stick to a regular 8 hour day are frowned upon.

Title: "Would not suggest  working at Fidelity long term"
View5: The company has very good benefits (aka golden handcuffs). The company is also good at training its employees to understand the basics of the investment industry.
View7: The management is poorly run, and is only concerned with it's bottom line. This is ironic because we work for a private company, yet profits are held to as high a standard as it would a public company with shareholders. The company expects it's clients to be treated well, however they choose not to treat their employees well.

Title: Overall good place to work if you like a large company with entrenched culture
View5: Fidelity has good benefits package and there are opportunities for growth for well qualified and competent, talented associates.  The company has a strong set of core values.
View7: Fidelity can be slow to move and recognize industry trends and seems to be stuck in the old mentality that someday Magellan will rise again.   Senior management seems to be willing to spend money even when an opportunity has little market value.

Title: Challenging environment, until they kick you out
View5: Good challenging work. If you thrive on pressure, this is good for you. You should be able to get opportunities to work on new and interesting tasks. Compensation is good - bonus and benefits.
View7: It seems that management learned to avoid plant-closing laws by phasing their layouts over time. From roughly 2009 through 2011, we would hear about a layoff at one business group or another on the first Tuesday of each month. Later in 2011 and 2012. there was a heavy push on "site strategy", where they were moving jobs out of Boston and other Northeast offices to Texas, North Carolina and offshore. Lots of disruption with that.

Title: Cushy jobs, but not an IT industry leader
View5: Great office facilities. Good benefits. A pro and a con, the office is empty at 5pm, literally. Good if you've got kids, bad if you're a workaholic. The company belongs to the Johnson family so you don't have the "make the quarter numbers or bust" attitude you'll find at publicly traded firms.
View7: Sparse vacation, only 15 days a year. Company is constricting, merit raises were half of inflation across the IT groups this year. Technologies used internally are well behind the leading edge and well behind peer institutions.

Title: Need to be a Brown Noser
View5: Decent benefits overall but more expensive than other firms in the industry. You will learn a lot if you know nothing about the business to begin with.
View7: Overcrowded, work area is smaller than an elementary school desk. Advancement is based on arbitrary targets and how much networking you can fit into your 30 min lunch. Previous education, experience and overall ability matter very little and can be detrimental as everybody starts in the same place. The entire organization has a culture where they have customers and most employees believing they are all about service and not profit.

Title: Good company to work for
View5: Decent opportunity to develop skills, very established infrastructure. Company provide very good benefits. Good life work balance overall. There is a certain degree of on job training as well.
View7: Bureaucracy and process driven sometimes. Expectation for more junior level people can be more on the process side. Highly driven by needs of the senior management. Sometimes it will take a long time to go through process and get something done, which can be painful.

Title: Senior Management Enjoys While The Rest Suffer
View5: Still incredibly profitable company, but lack of new products and vision becomes clearer everyday.
View7:
They should look at top 2 layers of management to see why they are where they are, not the layers down that actually do work.
Review system sets goals, you exceed them but then they tell you that the best ratings are only available to the top 5% who exceed at kissing butt,
If you are not a mindless sycophant you will just be lumped in with good performers.
Off shoring jobs, moving jobs to NC and Texas as the answer to poor leadership.

Title: A Job to nowhere with a very low compensation at all levels
View5:
Mostly good honest people to work with. Diverse.
A good company for entry levels positions (but that's it).
Very nice and large campuses nationwide.
Can jump between departments if you want to make a change (but mostly horizontal movement that can last for years with no pay change)
View7:
The fund a accounting group methodology of work is one big mess of excel spreadsheet macros with errors written by very few people at Fidelity and hold the knowledge and responsibility of why/what this job is about. The rest just push buttons and fake it. 
If you took 1-2 finance classes in college you will probably learn nothing new to help you in the industry. The monitoring and problem solving skills learned are 100% based on troubleshooting of departmental chaotic/confused processes of using excel and/or internal softwares. 
Managers don't (mostly) have any managerial skills or passion to manage and do so in order to climb the latter. In reality, they are analysts who stayed at Fidelity the longest (or when everybody else left after 2-3 years). 
Those who leave (which is almost all employees except managers) do so after realizing they will never be able to support an adult life/family with the low pay (including all "unique benefits"). 

In conclusion, 
To demonstrate the shortsightedness and focus on internal computer troubleshooting I will use this fact: Most managers and directors can tell you a lot about how to find a variance due to miscalculation of an Excel's spreadsheet formula but no very little to nothing about the stock market, bond market, and most importantly the nature of mutual fund investing. 

After a while it becomes a very sad, and discouraging, work environment. 
Not a long-term company for go getters

Title: Good, But Not What It Once Was
View5: Benefits - numerous benefits outside of the standard package. Take advantage and it will pay off later for you personally.
View7: The mantra at Fidelity is "Do more, With Less". Every year you are asked to do exactly this. The work is 24/7. When you are out of the office there are no backups and you are expected to check in on vacations. You can be very succesful here and have a great career; just know that your work is priority number 1, 2, 3. Everything else is a distant runner-up.

Title: Tax Exempt Rep
View5: Easy to get in the door as a way to get experience in the financial industry. Company will pay for you to get your Series 7 and 63 if you are interested in that.
View7: Management in the call center has little to no management skills for the most part and tends to be too friendly with their staff. Most employees on the phone are there to just punch a time card and then leave at the end of their shift they don't want to excel at their job. There  is not much room for growth even though they will promise it.

Title: Good place to work
View5:
Cannot beat benefits
Great training for FINRA exams
Flexible work life balance with benefits
Tons of opportunities for lateral movement into new departments
View7:
Call center position, easy to get burnt out and little to break up your day
Pay isn’t great, but when factoring benefits, it makes up for the few thousand that you might miss in direct compensation. 
No clear path for upward mobility into roles off the phones

Title: Great role, great benefits
View5: Great overall company. Benefits are best in the industry. Company is well managed with integrity and long focused business plan (due to the company still being privately owned by the Johnsons). Work/Life Balance, 10% profit share at year end and 7% 401k match is top notch. Salaries paid are decent, in line with competition.
View7: Management is constantly micromanaging and breathing down your neck. Every single dial and metric is closely scrutinized. Because fees and price compression have taken a deep hold on the retail brokerage industry, management has been raising monthly goals for years. It can feel like a hamster wheel with no end in sight

Title: Wide range of career options if your are flexible and willing to work hard.
View5: Great people, The company makes getting in the door a really hard process.  A sense of team exists once you start working here.  Good balance between work and life.  Most phone site campuses are loaded with activities such as baseball, basketball & soccer courts.  Also onsite gyms and food services as well as laundry services
View7: A lot of silo work results in re-runs and overlaps in effort and technology.  Poor communication between different business units.  Still plenty of Chinese Walls between Retail and Institutional services.

Title: Fidelity: Another transition
View5: Great brand name.  Able to work with newer technologies. A sense of empowerment is given but some managers are micro managers.  Others are so hands off you do not get any feed back at all.
View7: lower pay, expected to be available 24x7, poor recognition, only the managers get the credit, slow to promote. There are a lot of job positions but the qualifications are such you do not have the background necessary to be considered.  Definately more of a who you know than what you know.  In order to advance, it seems important to network instead of working more on an actual skill set.

Title: Ok place, great benefits but lots of politics
View5:
1) Great Benefits
2) Ability to move within the organization
3) Great pay if you negotiate it upfront .
4) Good work life balance in some groups
View7:
1)  Lot of politics
2)  Frequent re-organizations and changes within the company. No stability in senior management.
3) New hires can be hired at much higher salaries.A person hired at a lower level could have much higher salary than yours.
4) Work life balance can be bad in some groups.
5) Lots of employees in IT are not proficient in their fields.

Title: a once great place to work
View5: Strong benefits packages, many smart people, top technology,.   You will be challenged.  Lots of exposure to a variety of issues in financial services
View7: Ever since the economic meltdown, coupled with mediocre investment performance, and significant competitive pressures, Fidelity has turned into a place where most people are constantly looking over their shoulder for the next RIF, or move to another locale.  A lot of management by fear which eliminates any real risk-taking by employees.

Title: Stepping Stone
View5:
Decent pay for a phone job.

7% company match 
10% profit sharing match
Good benefits

Good culture from a team member perspective.
View7:
Survey's are unrealistic. Score scale is from 1to 7. 7 is extremely great service and only 7's count. Very subjective grade scale. Way too much emphasis is placed on surveys. Surveys affect 100% of your bonus. 

You can't short stocks or buy long puts in personal accounts. Employees should have the freedom to short stocks in their accounts because of their trading strategies. 

Lots of politicking and favoritism.  You learn which managers like who very quickly.

Title: Cheap.  is this a non profit?
View5:
They are all about benefits  17% free for 401K. 
Great campus. 
Great work life balance.  
Cafeteria and gym on campus.
View7:
base pay is super low.  Accounting and Finance majors expect better.  
No Pay for Performance/  no bonus
no long term advancement / opportunity for a campus of 5000
whole industry is putting money towards automation and offshoring 
Some have to get second jobs

Title: Technical Intern
View5: During this internship I was able to learn many new things and concepts. I was on the QA track where I learned about automation testing for many of the applications that Fidelity Create and use on a daily basis.
View7: The only cons of this internship were that I was more interested in the software engineering track. Unfortunately I was interviewed by the Quality Assurance group first and they really liked me so they chose me before I got to interview with the software engineering group.

Title: Conservative investment firm with excellent benefits.
View5: After 2 year service, dollar for dollar 401k match up to 7%, additionally an extra 10% (of your gross wages including OT) profit sharing bonus deposited to you 401j each January. Most workers are hourly and receive 1.5x OT for their efforts. 10k per year toward higher education expenses.
View7:
Five year vesting for employer 401k contributions, in 20% increments.
Start us out with more vacation time! How about a sabbatical every few years of service!

Title: Account Executive
View5: Good benefits, extra retirement/health care account if you work there over 10 years
View7: Regional managers and some branch managers have been employees for over 25 years and do not have insight or experience to understand the competition.  Also they were in "sales roles" when Fidelity was pitching mutual funds and they don't have experience or understanding of how to perform consultative sales.  They are not leaders, they follow orders and pass them down.  Very military and micromanaging.  They have said in meetings that the WAS program and those RIA's are their competition.  Definite conflict of interest when selling advice to clients.

Title: Customer Service Role
View5:
-Great benefits such as PTO, 401k Match after 1 year, tuition assistance, even student loan assistance

-Intelligent coworkers and employees

-In Denver they really want to help you enjoy your career

-Management genuinely cares about you and will do what they can to help
View7:
-Taking phone calls for 8+ hours a day can be rough when clients are rude

-Upward movement can be limited based on where you are located. Denver is a small market for Fidelity and therefore not as many opportunities

-The list of benefits keeps growing yet cost of living raises were more preferred

Title: Has Pros and Cons
View5: Nice modern facilities. Company promotes healthy living (cafeteria food, fitness, etc) Company promotes training and education. Industry leading health, dental, and vision benefits. Excellent bonus program.
View7: Extremely high stress environment (for me) which actually made me ill. Divisions in the company are competing and not working together (like the US Congress) Too many CIOs which causes nothing to get done. Senior executives (along with the chairman) react violently to market changes and government regulations causing big layoffs.

Title: Director
View5: Great benefits and training opportunities.
View7: An employee may be delivering great value to the organization and receive great reviews from peers and business partners but if your VP/SVP management doesn't like you forget about career growth.  It has a high school mentality only the people in their 'clique' get opportunties for career growth and guidance. Very sad as you have great employees who are disengaged because of their management employee treatment.

Title: A great place to start, but it can take a while to make a decent salary.
View5: Great place to learn about the financial markets and great benefits.  Tons of customers to work with, don't have to worry about building your own book of clients.
View7: Not a lot of variety in most of the roles at Fidelity.  Need to try hard to make the phone jobs exciting.  Too many campaigns and changing goals in the sales roles.  Tiered approach to bonuses, someone is always at the bottom, no matter what.  Not necessarily paid for what you do (but that's the rules of a salary plus bonus structure).

Title: Good place to work when they want it to be
View5: Fidelity is one of the only equity research jobs where an undergrad can immediately become a lead analyst on 20+ companies with good access to top management of the companies they are researching.  There is also a strong history of talent that you will be surrounded by.  Pay is fair to good for the job.
View7: Management is not honest with employees about current situation of the company and compensation outlook; there has been significant turnover in Fidelity C-suite, and it is unclear what direction the company is heading; limited real time feedback on how well you are doing your job.

Title: good company to work for but can drive a great, devoted employee to quit.
View5: Good benefits, understanding management, encourage personal business developement.
View7: management lack of communication, too much layering, political when it comes to promotions and hires, salary not competitive with industry, company always wants blood from a stone, they rather pay an external higher more $$ that their own who are more capable to do the job, can never get a straight answer about anything.

Title: Ability to learn many industries under one company umbrella
View5: Fidelity offers many different companies and industries to move around in while employed - many opportunities to learn different things. The 'Fidelity' name is very strong to have on your resume. Fidelity provides a fantastic total compensation/benefits package that other companies have a hard time competing with and there are many perks to working on the campus too such as a gym, running trails, softball field and league, etc. It's a home away from home.
View7: Over 36K employees, it's easy to lose your voice and become a number. You're at the mercy of Exec and Sr management making decisions on projects you are working on and invested in. Tough to move up and increase grade level.

Title: Software Engineer in Development
View5:
My team was pretty open minded and technically strong
Your ideas and opinions are valued. They were open to suggestion for new technologies or coding practices
Conducted software engineering meetins, coding mojos and similar things for self improvement
Pretty good work and social life balance
View7:
Salary is not that great for full time employees compared to contracters
Fidelity is pretty diverse in nature. So, the team and location plays a major factor on how technically rich it is. I have seen some teams use outdated technologies

Title: GREAT foot in the door
View5: This is a great company to start off with.  Excellent training (biggest pro I would say), great team atmosphere and great benefits
View7: The double-edged sword for the great benefits is very low pay and right now there is a very low cap for raises - mostly because businesses are tightening their budget. There is a lack self-improvement.  No recognition for performance or improvements as meeting the status quo only matters.  You're only recognized if you have a negative perception.

Title: Let Fidelity pay for your Series Licensing!
View5: Fidelity paid for my licensing
View7: If you have legitimate health issues and must use FMLA, you may as well start your job search now. Don't affect your manager's bottom line or he'll find a way to fire you.

Title: Stable company that plays it safe - not great for innovators
View5: Good products and diverse markets lead to strong revenue and stability.  There is a lot of software in use within the company and therefore lots of technology jobs - though there is pressure on them.
View7: Senior Management is busy playing politics and trying to position themselves for personal gain instead of doing what is best for the internal customers.  IT is being pinched due to less than stellar product revenues and management is holding on to an overweight organization instead of streamlining and making things more efficient to deliver business value.

Title: High Net Worth
View5:
This job is technically a "call center", but don't let that dissuade you, Fidelity an amazing place to work. The benefits, training, and exposure to the financial markets are invaluable. For those wanting to enter the industry that do not have degrees from overpriced private colleges, Fidelity is the place to be. You will work alongside some of the best and the brightest, ambitious individuals who come from a wide array of backgrounds, all sharing a common desire to help the uneducated investor find success.

I can only speak for the Jacksonville, FL location, but the training is phenomenal. The series 7 instructors, alongside the rest of the learning and development team will make sure you are successful. You will have to be self motivated though, every day during the initial training you will be coming home to take 1-3 hour tests, but if you ever need assistance with a concept the mentors are there for you - and are actually encouraged to help you by being paid overtime.

Whether you want to move up in Fidelity or leave and go to another firm, this is a great place to get your foot in the door in a normally very competitive industry.

Benefits are amazing. Make sure you take advantage of everything.

With the brand new systems in place, schedules are more flexible!
View7:
If you want to go to a role involving financial analysis, or anything unrelated to the direct relationship with the clients, it is almost impossible to do starting from the phone roles, you will easily get a job at another firm with the training and certifications you gain, so you may have to jump around from firm to firm.

The advisory/guidance roles in Fidelity are less "sales" related in comparison to say Merrill Lynch, but they are still sales related. At the end of the month if you did not speak with a single customer that needed an annuity, you should not see any form of negative impact for not putting someone in one. Fidelity should be leading the industry in the charge towards a more "fiduciary" standard.

The compensation was recently increased to 42k for the entry level, which is okay, but honestly everyone across the board should receive about an extra ~10k. Fidelity can afford to do it, and the retention rates would drastically increase. Most of the employees are recent college graduates, so amazing healthcare and benefits are not as important as cash money to invest.

Title: Long hours and high turn over
View5: Good benefits: 401k, paid time off, vacations, etc. They want you to move up and succeed. There's always a manager around to go to for help. Training is extensive lasted almost a month but necessary to prepare you for the concepts of the stock market industry.
View7:
for the whole month of January and throughout the year when the stocks are up and work is demanding they make you work 11 hour days. 
There is high turnover for a reason
Everyone hates working on the phones. Long hours plus demanding participants can mentally get to you

Title: Good Company if you like Politics and Bureaucracy
View5: Decent pay, Vacation Policy, 401K matching, good healthcare, many benefits.
View7: I felt the company was very political and many managers are quick to be "YES" men in order to impress their executive leadership. This brings a lot of stress to the employees in the lower ranks doing the actual work. I felt you don't really get rewarded for the amount of work you put in, but more so who you know and who likes you. Didn't think it was a very healthy environment to work in, but at least the pay and benefits are there.

Title: Trader
View5: Great group of folks to work with. Entry level opportunity, but little chance for anything else. Benefits are good. Paid time off, 401k with good match, hsa.
View7: Phone center is relentless. Always must go faster. Top down management is disconnected from reality. Even directors are given little autonomy. Disconnect between what upper level management wants to achieve and reality on the phones. Get in, get licensed, get out. There is no opportunity for you here as evidenced by the HIGH turnover rate in the first twelve months.

Title: May be going downhill
View5:
Fantastic benefits
Friendly environment
If you're liked, it's easy to move around to different positions
Great for a sales environment (not pushy to customers - always what's in their best interest) - I would highly recommend Fidelity to anyone who really likes sales and a high intensity environment
7% 401(k) match + profit sharing contributions every year
Great training if you start off not knowing anything about the financial industry
Recently they've been trying to (at least act like they are) make changes to make the employee experience better
Industry leader and well known
View7:
A 529 plan is a tax-advantaged higher education savings plan made possible under section 529 of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC). A 529 plan allows individuals to save money for a beneficiary by contributing up to $14,000 (or $28,000 if married and filing jointly) annually without incurring gift or generation-skipping transfer tax liability. Earnings in this plan grow federal income tax-deferred and the distributions are federal income tax-free as long as they are used for qualified higher education expenses. There may be additional state tax benefits to participants, contingent on their state’s tax regulations. 

Nepotism
Who you know can get you a job
If your manager doesn't like you, it's going to be nearly impossible to move up in the company
Last year they bumped up the new hire pay by I think $5,000 to get more people interested in applying, but none of the pre-existing employees have gotten any type of compensation adjustments to make up for it
The annual salary review (and usual salary increase) is being pushed back this year, so that it's a year and a half from our last increase
Don't get settled into what your role is defined as, because it'll most likely change without your opinion being considered
Everything is going full-blown sales - they push a "customer first" attitude, but all of the compensation and management feedback is exactly the opposite
We used to be able to take time to do research and follow up on our clients' needs, but they're punishing us for taking the time to ensure our customers have good experiences because we're not constantly taking phone calls/chats/emails etc.
The only things that our bonuses are really based on are how many interactions we're taking per hour, how many sales leads we can get, and then our customer feedback survey scores - but they keep lowering the amount of impact the feedback surveys have... it seems like they're caring less and less about the customer's experience, and more and more about how much money they're making (to be honest, it's a dog-eat-dog world out there for investment firms right now though)

Title: Leader
View5:
1.GREAT benefits! 
2.Truly a place to make a career if you are patient, goal oriented, and deliver results.
3. VERY focused on personal development; there are hundreds of ways for you to grow within your roles and progress your development.
4. The associate experience focus is just fantastic; we are striving and working to help everyone feel like they have a voice and are cared about.
View7:
1. Do NOT apply if you are not a self starter. The culture here is not one for people who cant push themselves and who don't set personal goals.
2. (not a con for me but could be for others) this place will demand your very best every day. If you are afraid of a challenge and would rather be chill and relaxed please don't apply.
3. The associate focused culture stops at the front line associates. From there up it is all about results and there is substantial pressure to deliver. 
4. at a certain level in management "promotions" are not achievable. You are given a laundry list of personal characteristics  that you need to develop. You are told to get a masters degree. Once you achieve these grand goals; a promotion is not "guaranteed". you need to wait for a manager above you to retire or get promoted. Then the promotion process is done as a round table discussion of your senior directors/vps. So even if you fill all the requirements for a promotion it still comes down to advocacy. Advocacy is based off your ability to network and your overall "personal brand" .

Title: It's like every other financial institution
View5: We don't need to cold call customer they just walk in to see us because of our name recognition. The pay and benefits are great too.
View7: It's definitely a boys club. As a women right out of school at my first job I have been sexually harassed weekly here, and no one in branch sees a problem with it. They all just think that that's how these specific men act. I reported it to HR and the solution was to move me to another branch (our satellite which is much worse) or to move me out of state.

Title: COVID has shown their true colors
View5:
It used to be a pretty relaxed and laid back job...but that's all gone now. They've even redesigned their phone system in the midst of a pandemic to make sure that everyone takes every call and is talked out of their voice by Tuesday, but you better show up and sound cheerful for Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday...or else.
The benefits in terms of insurance coverage is decent. On the surface their retirement plan looks good with all the match and profit sharing, but their vesting schedule is draconian and traps you working for them for YEARS before you would ever get to take any of their retirement contributions with you when you leave. And you will want to leave quickly.
View7:
Metrics. Matrices. Benchmarks. Expectations. Goals.
Forget Fidelity being a Finance company. Their business, what they do best, is perfecting the art of micromanagement. Think you've learned how to do your job effectively? Think again. Every few months they've designed or redesigned a new system for you to learn to use because it is NEW AND IMPROVED with many more reporting features to keep an eagle eye on every single insignificant facet of your job performance - all in the name of assigning a number and a statistic to what you do that they can then set the goal for just high enough that they can use your performance as a reason to short you on a bonus or deny you a raise.
And they have no sympathy for their front line workers being abused on the phones either. They cleared out their offices and sent everyone home in March, but everything else has been business as usual ever since. No changes in expectations even an inch even though everybody in the trenches has been putting up with 3-4x the work they were doing 100 days ago. No guaranteed bonuses. No time off availability. Overtime has been expected and mandatory from the beginning, otherwise you're labeled as "not a team player" and "hurt your Fidelity Brand"
FIdelity Green is for Greed.

Title: Fidelity, not your fathers investment company.
View5: They are flexible and have good benefit packages.
View7: Fidelity is ripe with politics. It's unfortunate but you often get ahead based on how well you manage up not the ROI to the overall company. This creates a lot of managers that can't think unless they are told how to think and creates an environment where reports are neglected. There's far too much energy spent on positioning yourself for success instead of positioning the company for success.

Title: Fantastic  company back  in the 1980's; now struggling to regain its footing.
View5:
Smart, talented people.
Great environment for learning more about investing and personal financial management.
Excellent benefits.
Huge firm with worldwide presense and many different operating companies offering, in theory, many different types of opportunities.
View7:
As you advance in your career there, your opportunity to move to a new position is difficult; as with
any "triangular" organizational structure, there are fewer and fewer jobs the higher up you go on the corporate ladder.

Title: Good place for college grads
View5: Great benefits, Life & Health Insurance as well as tuition reimbursement program. Competitive starting pay. Great training to get your licenses.
View7: It has been said before, micro-management. Whoever your manager is will determine your like or dislike of Fidelity. Unfortunately managers move around fairly quickly, so odd are you will get a bad one more often than you can stay with a good one. If you can transfer to the good manager's new area.

Title: Benefits and people are great.  There are vast differences between business units.
View5:
Benefits are fantastic
Professional attitude in all they do.  Facilities are very nice.  Fidelity tries very hard to be a good employer.
View7: While one business unit is laying off and moving jobs offshore, another business unit in the same building is hiring (often from outside the firm).  THERE ARE NO RAISES.  Once you are hired, say goodbye to annual increases.  Cash pay is far below average.  They try to make it up with bonuses, but that can be hit or miss.

Title: Good Company, management should focus on employee satisfaction.
View5: Good 401k, great benefits and Paid time off is satisfactory.  Work environment is reasonably accomodating as I only work at the Data center. Internal staffs and managers are flexible to employee demands.
View7: Upper management does not put employee satisfaction as priority. Cutting employee overtime already built into schedule is not an ideal way to save capital and operating expenses.

Title: Senior QA Engineer
View5: Learned so much about investments, trading and saving for retirement. Worked with some really great people who were very helpful and I had some great teammates there. I received a great financial education from Fidelity.
View7: Unfortunately, Fidelity is too quick to staff up during good times and equally too quick to staff down during bad times. This instability makes Fidelity a difficult place to work. I would not advise somebody that Fidelity is the type of company where you can expect to retire from.

Title: UX Developer
View5: Fidelity UXD has some of the most talented, hard working, genuine people in the UX design space. It was a pleasure to come into work every day and get to know my coworkers on a personal level.
View7: Very little guidance from management on expectations and performance. The onboarding process was garbage. They hire contractors because they're easy to get rid of when their budget gets slashed.

Title: Excellent company, yet significant politics and definitely competitive peers.
View5: Location, wage and benefits. Flextime is dependent upon the area and your boss. Many many people in WI worked way passed a normal work week...and easily into 60-70+ hours.
View7: They will change strategy, change direction, change information and/or change complete scope and you are still required to meet deadlines no matter the cost to personal or family life.

Title: Good Company overall
View5: The majority of the people are nice.  Pay is on the lower end compared to other financial firms and everyone says the benefits make up for it. That really depends on what benefits appeal to you. Personally, it doesn't since I don't use their heath/dental etc. It is a call center that I'm in so the normal struggles you experience anywhere. No scheduled breaks/lunches which is great. My manager is very relaxed so not much micro managing. Just keep your metrics up and no one bothers you.
View7: Very conservative. Might be a pro to you but its a con to me. Lots of "politically correct" type of people.

Title: Expect to work after hours a lot (unpaid)
View5: Healthcare insurance, generous 401(k) match, onsite cafe and gym
View7: It depends on the team you are in. I definitely know people who are happy at their job. However, everyone on my team hates it! There is always a lot of work!!! I cannot think of one week when I did not have to work overtime. And it is, of course, unpaid. Every one is buried in work so nobody has the time to help you when you have a question. Low morale. People are waiting to leave after 5 years tenure so they get fully vested 401k money.

Title: A pressure cooker-Under Abby Johnson the company became something I wanted nothing to do with
View5: Excellent benefits, Good employee resources and rewards (if you are not on the phones), and Great support groups for Women, LGBTQ, & Minority employees
View7: Demanding Overtime, Poor Work-Life Balance, Culture of Micromanagement is perpetuated by the leadership, While once a customer-driven company it is now driven by numbers, If part of contact center employee resources and rewards are very difficult to participate in,  If an employee becomes tenured while on the phones they are stigmatized rather than rewarded for dedication and perseverance at a difficult job

Title: Terrible
View5: Health benefits and 401k are decent.
View7:
The call center environment is unbearable.  You’ll be on the phones constantly with your breaks scheduled for you. You only get time off of the phones to be yelled at by your manager for stupid, minuscule details. Nothing you do will ever be good enough.  The constant barrage of awful customers on the phone and negative feedback from management will wear you down.  And trying to get a role off the phones?  Don’t even think about it!  You’re stuck with the stigma of being a call center employee. 
Bottom line - This place will suck the life out of you. The day I walked out was one of the best days of my life.

Title: Great place to gain experience.  May need to look elsewhere for growth.
View5: Great pay & benefits compared to the same position at other gigs.  Good for college students and recent grads.
View7: Limited opportunities unless you are into sales.  Like the others said, there are a lot of politics involved.  In the regional centers, most job functions and advancements is to go into sales.  However, that may not be everyone's cup of tea.  Also, it seems that service is really second to sales regardless of your function.  The better the salesman you are the better you will do in the call centers.

Title: Decent Internship
View5:
- Despite being an intern, I was handed a sizeable amount of responsibility
- Worked on meaningful tasks and treated like any other equal employee - not given the undesirable work that others didn't want
View7:
- Praise for hard or good work isn't handed out as often as it could be
- Promotion structure seems quite rigid; working at a position for a number of years seemed almost a requisite for any sort of promotion

Title: Fidelity Investments environment
View5: During bull markets Fidelity can offer many opportunities to grow, gain new experience, and receive decent monetary rewards.   Since the great recession like many large firms, the company continues to reduce management layers and discover that it can deliver quality service with less resources.
View7: There is high turnover at upper levels of management and many reorganizations that introduce many shifts in strategy and management style.  The lack of consistency makes it hard for many associates to stay focused and understand how goals cascade down.  Also, the HR function is practically non-existent for many of the lower levels (except for transactional support from a shared service area).

Title: Great place to start your career.
View5: Great place to start you career out of school. They pay you to study for you series 7 and 63. You are paid hourly so OT can help bring up you pay amount. The training if one of the best in the business.
View7: Tough to go to other departments. They try to get you to go to other roles that are on the phone. Very hard to get a role off the phone. After a year the job becomes very repetitive.

Title: Overall, satisfied
View5:
Time allotted for personal training and improvement
Innovation encouraged
Flexible as regards working from home, coming in late/leaving early if something comes up
Reasonable deadlines... I do not generally need to work much beyond the standard 9-5 type hours to meet my deliverables
View7:
Salaries err on low side of competitive

You may end up on a team where none of the pros apply, especially the last one. Look to join a development team attached to a specific business function, rather than something like their Corporate Technology Group (which manages various services shared across the enterprise)... the "closer to the money" you are, the more you will be looked after.

Title: Company with great benefits package gave little else in terms of advancement and innovation.
View5:
Benefits are great.
Investment platform is the cream of the crop.
Mutual funds given in managed accounts are truly the right ones for the client.
View7:
You have to be friends with the right people to advance.
The company makes it very difficult to find a job outside the call center.
Feedback from managers is a drag -- managers love to point out what you do wrong.
Management are a bunch of puppets who have to do what they're told.
Managers (and senior managers) don't fess up to their mistakes.
Trade Support is ruthless.

Title: Rare supportive team culture for financial advisors
View5: My branch office in New England has an outstanding team culture where the focus isn't just on doing the right thing for your customer, but also doing the right thing to support your colleagues. The culture of collaboration  is rare in the world of financial advisors, but that's due to the unique branch office model which is based on a team effort and results. An added bonus - the branch manager publicly acknowledges staff who have done a good job in weekly team meetings.
View7: None. I've worked for 3 financial service companies and this is, by far, the best in the business for financial advisors.

Title: Career Company with Clear Expectations and Retirability
View5: Good people, nice work life balance, company has solid foundation and long term stability, excellent benefits and retirement plans, awesome 401k matching
View7: really big company with a lot of employees, could be a big fish in a massive ocean, I left in 1999 because I wanted to be a big fish in a smaller body of water, and it worked for me with a smaller more flexible firm, this might be one of those companies where you might start to get your foot in the door to the industry and then leave to satisfy ambition, and then go back as a quicker way to advance within the management pyramid

Title: Over 10 years
View5: I've worked on many projects and on so many different teams.  My co-workers are always friendly and supportive and the teamwork is invariably amazing.  I've learned so much working here!  Everyone has a great work ethic and is highly ethical and devoted to providing the absolute best products, services, and value possible to our customers.
View7: Unfortunately an issue common to myself and many of my coworkers is lack of career advancement.  The performance review process is cumbersome and the required grading methods force employees into performance categories their work and contributions don't deserve.

Title: Great place to work but can be demanding
View5: Great training and lots of continual support makes you feel like a  team.  Great company benefits. Feedback is readily given for continual self improvement.  There is always something new or interesting to learn.
View7: Pay is a little less than the industry standard. Work/Life balance is not very well supported at times. Overtime is paid but expected which can be good or bad depending on what your looking for. Communication with management can be very poor. When I took my job I was told it would support my Series 7 license however 6 months later I was told it would no longer be supported and I would lose it.

Title: Grew up with this company
View5: Great benefits, meritocracy 95% of the time, quality working environment, willing to promote from within (I started on the phone and ended up in development).  Allowed me to be adventurous and try three careers in 11 years.  Smart and talented people.  Good support for women and many women in management. Beautiful campuses.
View7: Can get stuck in a position if your salary is too high for lateral move.  Bad managers can ruin the experience.  Mission not deeply satisfying.  Low diversity.

Title: Not a bad place to start off
View5:
Flexibility: This entry-level position allows me the ability to set my own schedule. As long as I work 40 hours in a week and make a certain number of calls a day, I can show up at 7 AM or 10 AM. (This is uncommon throughout the company)

Time off: Fidelity starts at 18 days of paid time off per year.  After two years, it is bumped to 23. I love this. It's higher than what a lot of companies offer people with years of experience - at Fidelity it is standard. The negative, however, is that this PTO encompasses all personal time - you don't get any sick/personal/voluntary time off in addition to your PTO. (Excluding federal requirements, maternity, etc.)
Benefits: Fidelity will pay up to $10k in student loan debt over the course of 5 years ($2k a year, or $167 a month.) They'll also reimburse you (you pay up front) 90% of college tuition/coursework costs, up to $10k a year. I am taking advantage of both these programs.
Advancement: Fidelity is not a meritocracy and you cannot move up just by doing your job well and going home at 5. That being said, there is a 'Fidelity way' of doing things, it's pretty simple, and only requires a little bit of off the clock time. In addition, I've never met anyone that won't tell you what their job is or how they got there. Upper management is easily accessible and they often participate in career coaching or mentorship sessions/programs. 
401k benefits: After one year of service, Fidelity will match you dollar for dollar up to 7% of your paycheck. Also, profit sharing at year end can be 10% of your annual salary deposited one time to your 401k. (10+7= 17% of your salary for free to your 401k.) Benefits vest 20% a year for 5 years.
View7:
Pay: You'll get less in salary than at other financial services firms. Fidelity tries to compensate for this with their generous benefits programs. I don't have much experience to compare these to other firms. 
Networking: As mentioned above, networking is necessary to move up here. It doesn't come naturally to me, so I put it in the cons. It does require extra time and thought, and the company won't pay you to shadow other positions.

Title: Fit their mold or else
View5: Merrimack site has really nice walking trails outside and great open spaces for collaboration inside
View7: Management does not act quickly on serious health issues, they may appear to be listening to your environmental concerns but really ignore what is happening right under their nose despite doctor's notes.  You can't ask for much in the way of consideration for health issues, you either fit their mold or you are considered a problem and they find a way to dismiss you.

Title: Financial associate
View5: Great 401k match if you can afford to contribute. Profit sharing, PTO is given at the beginning of the year, the people work with, training program was good when I went through it, they help pay back your student loans.
View7: It’s a typical call center with hours all over the place. They will tell you there is no “mandatory” overtime but there is and if you opt out of it you will get nasty messages. Bonuses are based off of call surveys which sometimes you will get a bad survey that wasn’t even from a call you took and there’s nothing you can do about it. Even if you move to another product you will still be overloaded with 401k calls. If you have to go to the bathroom and it’s not during a break or lunch it counts against you. If you don’t plan your days off at least a month in advanced it counts against you. There are more things that count against you then for you. The environment has gotten really bad lately and you can feel it when you walk in the door. Fidelity throws benefits at you but then doesn’t bother to check in on the call center. Turnover rate is really high.

Title: Fidelity offers growth and strong reputation.
View5: Good training program. Large company with room for advancement, and areas for growth. Because Fidelity is privately held, the company is able to avoid the large scale layoffs common to its competitors during down markets. Strong benefits package: 10% annual profit share, and 7% 401k match.
View7: Average pay is below market for many positions. Although billed as a meritocracy, promotions often go to those with tenure first. Very tall structural heirarchy, built around 'good old boys' network in Boston. Employees not given incentive, freedom, or resources to take ownership or creative stake in company.

Title: Fidelity Investments
View5: Fidelity provide great oppertunities to those willing to put in the effort.  Hard and smart work is rewarded with promotions... like most thing in life should be it is what you put in to it.  Health benefit are great.  The company also encourages employees to complete thier educaiton or to persue advanced educaiton.  Work / Life balance is important.  Managers understand this balance and work to accomodate request.
View7: Benefits are great but the starting representative and manager pay is average.  Company wide career planning is some what lacking.  Many career conversations with your manager are limited to your current company.

Title: Fidelity's an excellent ship but it navigation systems may be flawed
View5:
- Willing to take risks on emerging technologies
- Excellent benefits and pay, 401k and profit sharing are industry leaders
- Excellent work life balance, vacation time and personal time is encouraged
- Respected industry leader, with major market share in most sectors
- Large company with ample opportunties for movement
View7:
- Company has lost its direction, doesn't seem to be able to be the market leader
- Focus on technological innovation has become second to financial accounting
- Organization impedes risk tasking and innovation
- Difficult to navigate the complexities of the new organization structure
- Operational processes often impede productivity and progress

Title: Benefits are great, but job satisfaction is poor
View5: Benefits are great. The 401k program, health insurance, and the amount of vacation time is very good. Tutiion reimbursement is also very good.
View7: Little opportunity for career growth, and work was often extremely monotonous, with little attempt by management to improve the environment. Also the company lacks focus. Projects, programs, and initiatives are constantly rolled out by upper management to large fan fair, only be dropped weeks later as failures.

Title: Great place to work - especially if you stay a long time.
View5: The management is terrific - my direct boss provides feedback, makes it fun to come to work, and the salary and benefits are great.  Medical plan is awesome (every doctor I've known is in it!) and when you rise higher in the company you get shares.
View7: They keep moving people around to different buildings - I've been here for 5 years and have moved 4 times!  I really wish we were in one location.  Some people don't like senior management and talk about it - A LOT!!!

Title: Former employee, satisfied
View5: I enjoyed my time at Fidelity, and I regret leaving.  I was one of the young kids out of college, but I took the job seriously and did the best I could to learn.  They helped me to really enjoy this industry and want to make my career in the industry.
View7: The downside, was the less than competitive pay, but they did give everyone raises when they realized this.  They also paid well considering it was not a sales position and we were required to do very little to bring new money in to the firm.

Title: Amazing experience
View5: Working with great people, exposure to cutting edge technology with no fear of spending what is required to get the job done, and a sense of being part of a team with direct impact on the success of major initiatives are just a small part of what was amazing about working for FMRCo.  Also
View7: The high pressure environment isn't made for everyone.  The department I was in was also left hanging occasionally by being left out of inter-departmental project meetings and then still left to deal with the decisions and timelines that resulted, leaving us in "drop-everything-and-work-on-something-different" situations more than once.

Title: Decent pay, good work/life but culture stinks, lack of communication
View5: I worked in IT. My immediate team was nice, the pay was good, and I didn't work every weekend. My job was ok. To do my job took wayyyy longer than it needed to take.
View7: I think the culture is competitive to the point that people don't readily share knowledge. They hide it from each other in order to make themselves look better. That kind of behavior doesn't help a company move forward. They are also way too conservative and never want to take responsibility. Instead, they make decisions by consensus so that no one is to blame if something goes wrong.

Title: A good place to work right out of school
View5: There are some really great benefits and it ranges to fresh out of college to retirees. If you have just graduated, it's a good starting place for your career where you can grow and learn more about retirement and future savings. They are always hiring and all you need to know is customer service where they'll teach you the rest.
View7: It's a call center and you sit at a cubicle all day which can be a bit tough. Plus and can get stressful depending on the call volume. Turn over rate is a bit high due to either people leaving for another internal or external position.

Title: Awesome place to work!
View2: Workplace Planning and Guidance Consultant I
View5: Fidelity sincerely cares for both their employees and customers. They provide amazing benefits, opportunity to grow and learn in your role and my managers cared about me. They are a responsible firm in that the clients experience always comes first and Fidelity keeps one step ahead in the financial industry. Now that I no longer work with Fidelity they are still the investment firm that I and my family (per my recommendation) have accounts with.
View7: Having an endless opportunity to grow in your role and need for your work means long hours. It can be difficult to maintain a work/life balance. Particularly during tax season.

Title: Terrible place to work
View5: Amazing opportunities for incompetent people.
View7: Only incompetent people get promoted. Managers and upper management are extremely insecure and have no idea what they are doing. Constant lies are feed to the employees on a daily basis. The good performers are stuck in their roles and do not get promoted so that the manager can benefit from their stats. Terrible employees always get promoted so that the manager does not have to deal with them anymore. If you are a woman here you will immediately get promoted and preferential treatment. Lots of stress here and terrible work environment. Management and upper management in this company are the most conniving narcissistic people you will ever meet.

Title: Emerging Leader Program
View5:
Fidelity at large is a good company to start your career in, there are great people at the firm always willing to lend a hand and offer career help and connections. Different from other financial services companies, Fidelity doesn't work its employees all day and night so you'll have a social life and get sleep.

I joined Fidelity after college as a part of the Emerging Leader Program - a new 18-month rotational program for college graduates based in New England.  The program pros are: 
- Exposure to senior leadership: many 1:1's with VP's, SVP's and executives once in a while
- Opportunity to travel: ad hoc and there is a trip ELP plans to tour the different Fidelity sites
 - Working new jobs/roles: you won't get bored for too long since you are rotating every few months 
- Comradery:  You do the program with other new college grads and you build a great comradery and makes the experience fun as well as gives you great new friends. 
- Connections: different from networking, you will meet great individuals along the path that will be sincerely great mentors, rotational managers, and friends at the firm.
View7:
Though the Emerging Leader Program was designed to allow liberal arts graduates to learn about financial services in an "elite" program, it has its severe downfalls and ultimately I do not recommend this program to anyone considering starting their career with ELP. My cons are as follows: 

- Commuting: for New England based associates, you are expected to travel to your assigned rotations in either RI, NH, or Boston. These assignments are chosen subjectively by your manager, and you do not know up until 3 or so weeks before your rotation begins. Though you can express interest in rotations that are based in Boston, NOTHING is ever certain or clear, you may be left surprised at your unsatisfying assignment. Not everyone in the program will get assigned a rotation that requires 2+ hours of driving so you may be a part of the unlucky few that is left to drive into the woods for a dark 4 months. You cannot log your miles driven so you do not get reimbursement for gas, the low compensation does not help  cushion the cost either.

- Rotation assignments:  The program  gives associates three 4-month long rotations in different business units within fidelity. If you have an interest in a certain group - finance, strategy, personal investing, etc. there is no certainty that you will be able to work with them as the rotations are assigned by topics - operations, product, and data analytics (which they don't even stick to half the time so it's unorganized). The way these are assigned are subjectively your manager who you share your interests with but they ultimately decide where you will go. You may be left unhappy and confused at what you are assigned and the lack of skills developed in 4 months. Management hammers into you to "trust the process" but I caution you not to. The lack of structure to how placements are assigned is the single biggest downfall of the program since final placement is correlated to the work experience you have or haven't been able to build in the past 18 months. 

- Compensation: the comp is way too low for an "elite" program and compared to similar programs at other firms!!

-  Diversity and Inclusion: though efforts are being made to advanced inclusion in the firm and program at wide, don't expect Fidelity to be as socially aware as your liberal arts college. You'll find people with similar social consciousness but as a firm they still have a ways to go - though sincere efforts are being made, culture changing is slow at a large firm. This lack of D&I inevitably trickles down to ELP management and the decisions made so enjoy :). 

I see the program thriving in 5-10 years when large structural changes have been made (which are being considered to be transparent). 

TO BE CLEAR - most of my feedback is for ELP and not Fidelity at large, there are great parts of the firm that are healthy and great career drivers that I would highly recommend.

Title: White Collar Sweatshop
View5: Co-workers, benefits, good education about finance industry.
View7: Stress unbearable. Now I know why they mostly hire college grads. Gave 3 stars because my co-workers were great and made lifelong friends. 3 out of 4 managers I had were wonderful. One was a complete sociopath. This company is a white collar sweatshop. Don’t let the “Fidelity” name fool you. It’s mind boggling the good reviews. I wonder if people are getting paid to give them cause no one in their right mind would say this is a great place unless they were a masochist.

Title: once you get your licsence...get out
View5: The six month training program is a nice introduction the industry.  You earn the Series 7 and 63 which are marketable in the industry.  The trick is getting out of Fidelity as soon as possible.  Once you get close to exam time (Series 7), start applying to companies.
View7: No career mobility, low pay.  With a base salary of around $36,000 and life tied to a phone all day...this is a thankless job.  People stick it out because they think there is vertical mobility in the company.  Fidelity is good about giving the illusion of a promotion every 6 months or so (if you work hard), but these only horizontal moves where they add a new skill set.  Unfortunately, these skill do not translate elsewhere.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to start a career in the financial industry and can be a great place to make a career.
View5: Great management, employees and customers. Plenty of opportunity to learn the industry. Career opportunities in management and sales. Benefits are excellent. Privately held company which makes for a great environment.
View7: Compensation is at the low end for the financial industry in service, sales and management. There is no exposure to outside sales, no cold calling. This is a con because it makes moving to another company a bit of a shock.

Title: A good experience and very busy and often other offices had power out  issues creating more work for other offices.
View5: Great insurance, Cool co-workers and good training and education from company.
View7: Managers did not treat everyone the same they had their favorites and everybody knew it.  Little praise but when an error occurred you sure did hear about it and even if it was a small error it would go down in your chart/record and go against you when review time came around.  Not a lot of room to grow.

Title: Good company overall
View5: Great benefits, 401k, match, profit sharing.  Private company, run well, they have the fundamentals solved which most companies do not.  Fundamentals being defined as connectivity between work and cost, established quality control, right sized spans and layers, simple interfaces with the customer, etc
View7: A bit regressive in terms of future state.  Middle and upper management are complacent and lack current knowledge of corporate culture (want to manage like the good old days, more political in orientation versus meritocratic and performance based).  Need to focus more on problem solving than fire fighting.  Lack of proactive thinking and execution.  Over reliance on historical success and failure to recognize competition.

Title: Do yourself a favor, Run Away from Fidelity
View5: Benefits were good, they match 7% after 1 year of service, but, not fully vested until 5 years. Most people do not stay 5 years.
View7: Call center is a "sweat shop" in my opinion. Make you eat lunch, 30 minutes, at your desk-they call it a "Working Lunch". The calls are non-stop and you are limited in a career due to this being a call center. Very political place, no room for advancement. You are coached and everything you do is recorded both on computer and phone. Adherence to your schedule is a big thing, also, if a customer give you a bad survey, and its not your fault, you still get in trouble. Blah!!!

Title: Staid employer, reliable opportunity
View5: The ability to personally contribute to a leading financial services firm and the undisputed number one online broker, structured call model that allows for personalized customization, tons of exceptional products/services to offer clients, great deal of PTO each year, enormous opportunity for voluntary overtime, tasty cafeteria food at reasonable prices, beautiful campus, tremendous opportunity to work in different business units at the phone sites.
View7: Call center drudgery, uninspiring site leadership, inadequate work reference material, broken service satisfaction grading model, zero authentic corporate culture, working for a firm as risk-averse as Fidelity is cumbersome.

Title: A Great Place to Work...for Most
View5:
Good work culture
Good work life balance
Interesting Projects
Great Internal Mobility
Friendly/Respectful Coworkers
View7: Since Fidelity is so large, a few of my coworkers have had very different experiences.  Unfortunately, some people get put on projects where there is not enough work to go around, or were the work they do doesn't feel meaningful. Fortunately, Fidelity prides itself on its internal mobility. If you are ready to try something new, you can always speak to your manager and they will help you move around.

Title: Smart People, Poor Management
View5: They hired a lot of smart data scientists who work on some cool projects
View7:
There is a lot of politics, management has very little AI skills and seems like they were selected just because of relationships, as a result all they care about is how to please their bosses and not so much about the actual work. There is no much room to grow as an individual contributor. 
Also at fidelity in general there is a lot of benefits that kick in only after a good number of years, that's how they keep people around which feels like a trap.

Title: Everybody Should Work Here At Somepoint
View5:
Fidelity is filled with passionate experts that can cover any topic imaginable .  Need an expert on any finance related item? You can find them easily.  Need an opinion on application security or office furniture?  They are present and available.  
The firm will challenge you to learn and improve each and every day.
The culture is focused on the customer experience.
The benefits are outstanding.
View7: Some of the transformation efforts are hollow.  Nobody is managing the details of the transformation itself.

Title: A supportive, fast moving and rewarding work environment
View5:
An industry leader who will show you the ropes

Open and collaborative culture where Say It Like It Is is regularly practiced

Smart, motivated people who want to help you develop your career

Culture of deep integrity and focus on customer well being as well as employee well-being

Wonderful work life balance

Benefits and comp are very good

Employees get professional money and investment management services free of charge

Women are empowered to lead, from the CEO down to entry level employees
View7:
Typical big company challenges around complexity, it can sometimes be a bit slower to get things moving than at a smaller place

Some view the brand as "not as sexy" as a big tech company

Title: Great Comp/benefits but not a good workplace for some...
View5: The best reasons include terrific pay and benefits along with the ability to work with some very accomplished professionals.  There are a wide variety of opportunties across the corporation both domestic and international.
View7: The environment is difficult and the hours often long.  There can be significant red-tape in making decisions or moving projects along.  Certain areas are very political.

Title: Good pay and benefits, but you earn every penny of it and more.
View5:
Fidelity is a company that is impressive on the resume. 
Excellent benefits.  The health care insurance, 401k and profit sharing are better than I have seen elsewhere.
You get to work with some excellent people who care about what they are doing.
View7:
Poor work/life balance
Very much a "good old boys" club
Right now there are a lot of re-orgs and comp plan reviews going on, leading to instability.

Title: Overall, Fidelity is a great place to work
View5: Knowledgeable coworkers, outstanding benefits, great training. Opportunity for advancement is there. Very strong, stable, quiet giant in the industry.
