View7: In service, you are stuck to a phone all day. It can become monotonous very quickly. But you should know going in that you are going to be on a phone all day every day so it shouldn't come as a surprise. Also, it's tough to get a 5 day, 9-5 type shift. They have some odd shifts that they need to fill, so your options are limited and you can get stuck in a shift you really don't like.

Title: Don't do it.  Don't even think about it.
View5: A good opportunity to get professional licenses, job experience, a good benefits package, and salary opposed to commission.
View7: The job sucks the soul out of people.  You will get paid next to nothing because Fidelity is the Walmart of the financial services industry (i.e. low cost provider).  The company is top heavy and bottom heavy..  Middle management are complete puppets with cozy jobs but no input.  The company has a sweatshop mentality and does not see its employees at added value.  They breed mediocrity in all aspects of job performance.

Title: Hard work is rewarded at this premiere company
View5:
- Fidelity cares about its customers 
- You learn how to help customers achieve their dreams (retirement, financial independence, etc)
- Pay and benefits are competitive 
- The work is meaningful
- You will be treated with respect
View7:
- New ideas are always welcome, but it takes too long to get them installed
- Promotions are slower then other companies I've worked for in the past
- Senior executives are not clear in communicating directives and do not know how to prioritize 
- The workload is much larger than companies I've worked for in the past

Title: Account Executive PAS Relationship Officer
View5: Quality company overall, good benefits, vacation time, etc.  Great Christmas party, onsite gym.
View7: Variable compensation is more and more dependent on manager assessment with a focus on irrelevant things like number of calls more than 4 min long.  Can end up with poorly qualified managers.  For sales positions, your base pay will never get a COLA bump.  Seems like the comp plan changes every six months....and beware of the "it's comp neutral and you have a chance to make more money" song and dance from management.

Title: Good Company
View5: Amazing benefits, good work/life balance, nice coworkers, decent work flexibility (working from home allowed), immediate management is good
View7: Awful base salary for industry, lots of politics/bureaucracy, not enough upward mobility, upper management is awful at engaging with employees/providing good career growth opportunities, working for the company for a long time is actually worst than leaving and coming back as your base salary will not increase to keep up with the market

Title: Don't Drink the Kool-Aid
View5: Good benefits, room for advancement.
View7: In short: This job is absolutely soul-sucking.  You'll spend 8+ hours every day fielding inbound phone calls. The customers are usually unpleasant and irrational. The training is inadequate given the daily risk assumed in the role. The corporate Kool-Aid is flowing like a coursing river. Performance is measured based on metrics which any 100 level psychology class says are irrelevant.

Title: Investment Consultant
View5: Great benefits and decent pay. Managers in my experience really do want to help their reps succeed. I have not had a micro manager in the 6 years I’ve been here. Great coaching. For a sales position it does not really have much stress.
View7: There is no creativity in the advice you give clients. It’s all prepackaged investment advice... you simply gather the data and turn your computer screen to the client. This role is financial product sales... with little to no input for the consultants themselves.

Title: Good Pay / Head Games / Verbally Abusive Reviews
View5: Fidelity offers a competitive compensation package
View7: In the financial center I worked, the monthly review was a verbally abusive situation.  It would involve personal insults  and create a "damned if you do, damned if you don't" atmosphere. When achieving stated goals, you would be berated in the "way" you achieved the goals. The corporate culture at Fidelity claims an "open door" policy for its employee's. In reality, an employee is committing career suicide by complaining about an abusive situation. In my 25yrs as a financial professional, I have never worked in a more toxic unprofessional environment. Perhaps brought on by age discrimination.

Title: I enjoy working for Fidelity
View5: The people are good.  I really enjoy the overall culture of the corporation.   I have also found that some internal departments go out of there way to support their employees.  Though this tends to be ‘department’ specific, I love the fact that Fidelity allows this.  Overall Fidelity is a great place to work!
View7: Pay is sometimes on the lower side.  Also since things are departmentalized so much, sometimes you don’t feel as connected to the overall picture.  Sometimes you get locked in your own world and it’s hard to see how you relate to everything else or to other companies within Fidelity Investments.

Title: Fidelity Investments Branch Representative
View5:
Profit Sharing
401k Match
overall pay and benefits
View7:
Inflexible hours
Constant unnecessary stress due to unstructured branch duties
There is little distinction between employee job functions in local branches.  Financial Consultants handle nearly all aspects of financial planning, account service, answering service related phone calls all day and even handling walk in traffic at front counter.   Planning any given day is next to impossible due to conflicting job functions

Title: Somewhere in the middle...
View5: Reasonable salary and better than average benefits and corp perks. Have established procedures and good access to subject experts. If you get a manager who is in touch with you, you are in better shape
View7: Can be hard to locate who the experts are at times. Could do a little better at managing transitions during organizational change and uncertainty. Seems like formal authority still resides up north even though workforce is in many other states

Title: Excellent Company
View5: Fidelity is a great company to start your career. i am forever gratefull for the job. If you dont mind talking on the phone its a nice stable job with great people
View7: tough to move up without making a few lateral moves potentially

Title: For the Cincinnati area, it's not a bad place to be
View5:
The people you work with are great. All focused on the customer.
Nice regional campus.
You can build career there without moving.
Invests in the people and technology.
Decent benefits.
Supportive of development of the people.
View7:
Hit or miss with SVPs. Some are great (visionary, smart, approachable, open, advocates, fair). Others will do what they can to take care of themselves at the cost of others.   The HR rules to not apply to that level and there are known issues that are kind of ignored.  They are hired for driving to metrics and not the ability to manage, lead or inspire. Just do your homework to determine if the leadership of the function will align to what is important to you.

Also understand the bonus opportunity and how it is structured.  Your bonus percent is always immediately reduced by the funding level (fund at 85% for example)  and then you get  a percentage of your bonus eligible amount depending on performance. .85 (funded level)  X .85 (decent bonus based on performance) X.40 (eligible amount) = 28.9% is really what your 40% "bonus opportunity" turns out to be. And that is for a solid performer. Just be fully informed as  you negotiate your salary.  80/20 rule applies here -Only 20% get the top bonus which means you actually get the "opportunity" tied to your grade level. Don't get me wrong here - is 28% a nice bonus? Yes. Is it far away from 40%? Yes.  What is supposed to be motivating you to perform well just becomes exhausting.

Title: Great Company, Great people
View5: Internship, very relaxed, with a few presentations. They let you have a lot of free time and you could really do any sorts of research you wanted to. A few easy, informative tasks and the ability to shadow financial advisors. There were 6 other interns, and we did some equity competitions as well as some bookkeeping for advisers. Many lunches were paid for and the interns were invited to alot of activities not in the workplace, which was really neat. the CAMPUS is GREAT
View7: None. I wish we got to see different positions and move around a little more but all in all it was a great opportunity and I really encourage everyone to consider Fidelity.

Title: Burn Out from Politics - Not from Call Center Work.
View5: Health benefits are great, with different options/price levels to choose from. Great 401k/Profit Sharing. If you come in knowing little to nothing about finance - they are willing to train, if you are willing to put in the work. The sponsor & pay for licenses. If you are a personable person and like working with the public, you will enjoy the customer base for the most part. Their technology in the call center has come a long way since I first started, so those that might complain about it here with less than a year of service should consider themselves lucky. Finally, misery loves company - so you'll have some great camaraderie with your fellow employees!
View7:
I don't know about other call centers in the company - but in ours, they schedule overtime automatically into your schedule then you have to opt out by a specific time otherwise you're expected to work it. People on here keep calling the vacation time "PTO" but it's not truly. It's accrued vacation time, max of 4 weeks a year (depending on years of service), and it's use it or lose it (no carry over to next year). The NH call centers are "triple AAA" rated, meaning if there is a weather event or crisis in another center, we cover for them if they need to close, and if we have bad weather here - we're still open regardless. In the call center, you have to schedule your vacation time about a year in advance, but they do give you the option to change dates through the year. Vacation date availability is doled based on seniority in your "gate," but to be honest, this is really the most fair way to do it. Just don't expect to have any big holidays off in your first couple of years there is what I'm saying. 

There's little upward mobility. They have a Management Apprenticeship Program, but the people I've seen go into it aren't those that work their tails off - it's those that buddy up to their manager. When you come out of the program, you might go right back to your old position, until a manager position opens up - eventually. Also, on this vein - I started the company working a late second shift, but needed to change to a first shift for personal reasons. My manager at the time was resistant to have me move - not because we were shorthanded on the 2nd shift - he said 1st shift was reserved for those who "earned" it, and that it was a "reward." Now there are times when people are actually HIRED for 1st shift, so how is that a reward for those who are just hired? Nor am I a lackluster employee. 

As a rep over 6 years, I've probably had 10+ managers - and my position hasn't changed. So it's very hard to know what is expected of you, and to truly succeed. With having so many managers, any goals that I've set with previous managers have gotten lost and I've had to start from the bottom. If you want something for yourself, such as a new position, you better work for it, and work fast. Also, don't ever get comfortable at your cubicle, you will move. Alot. 

If you ever take a Leave of Absence, expect that when you come back, that the call center may have been reorg'd and your position as you knew it when you left is no longer available, and the new position that is taking over may not be offered to you. 

There are no COLA raises. 

Finally, if you ever have a problem with a manager, the burden of proof is entirely on you to prove you are being mistreated somehow. Management sticks with Management, and HR will listen but is more likely to provide "helpful" advice for conflict resolution than to step in, unless you're accusing them of a major infraction.

Title: Very good, but could be great with some improvements.
View5:
Private ownership and long term investment.  
Strong corporate values that are mostly lived up to
Fantastic benefits for those that want to make this a life-long career
Broad businesses to move to many different areas.
View7:
Very large size = very large bureaucracy
Too many leaders with golden parachute of great benefits - should leave but never will and hang on too long.  As a result don't aggressively drive change (go with flow is dominant and safest choice that too many make.
Less meritocracy more, play safe and conservative and survive.  Hierarchy more important than ideas.

Title: Overworked but paid well
View5:
The pay is pretty good, I was in a call center. They paid for me to study and obtain my licenses. Training is really intensive, and want to make sure you know what you're doing when you start talking to clients. 
Management can be very supportive about helping you move up in the company.
View7: Management can also be very unsupportive to employees. There were some who were clearly not equiped to be managers. Nepotism is present. There is a big push on networking to get better jobs, instead of by merit. (but isn't that just corporate culture?)

Title: Electroinc Response Representative
View5: Very safe place to work... it is extremely rare to be laid off. Nice profit sharing and 401(k) match.
View7: Run like a non-skilled call center. Handcuffed to a very rigid schedule (breaks, lunches, etc are monitored to the minute). Some really bad managers. Too much company politics going on... managers aren't promoted based on ability to manage, but who you eat lunch with and how good you kiss up. Bad managers are never demoted.

Title: Financial Consultant
View5: Excellent benefits. 401k had 7% match and 10% profit sharing. Occasionally there is free breakfast and lunches. Room to grow in the company if you are willing to move
View7: On the surface the Financial Consultant position seems great. They give you a book of clients, there's no cold calling since they provide leads and you can make over 6 figures with average effort. But in reality it's a pure sales role with very little concern about what's right for the client. Definitely not a fiduciary advisor and the turnover is extremely high.  It's all about selling product and filling the buckets. Fidelity FCs are managed by the ever present spreadsheet. Everyone is stacked ranked and if you are below average on any category your branch manager or RPC ( who are usually inexperienced coaches that stink at sales) will come talk to you to see how to improve. The problem is there are like over 20 categories of things they measure you on. So you will always be below average in something! Another annoying thing is every click on the computer, every phone call, every email is tracked like big brother ! They also continually roll out some new method or spreadsheet and say this is the way things are going to be so get used to it. 4 months later you never hear about that spread sheet again. There is no adjustment if you are new, if you are in different markets or have a smaller or a more established book. There is a certain level of gamesmanship with the numbers too. Click here it counts, click here it doesn't even if you did the work. Talk to a client for like 30 seconds and tag their deposit and you get credit. Drop this client from your book without the client knowing and you won't get hit with an outflow.   The people who do well in the role game the system the best. All the managers are ok with this and all they care about is selling managed money, annuities and bringing in new assets. Who cares what's right for the clients. That's really the sad part the clients think you are helping but in reality you are just selling what pays you the most basis points and hope they never call you after the sale. My advice is if you get this position plan to work it for 2 years then find something else in Fidelity not in the branch network.

Title: Benefits can't be beat
View5: Fantastic benefits w/ 401k match and profit sharing, generous PTO, HMO and high deductible insurance options, tuition reimbursement and student loan payoff assistance.
View7: Though it is a meritocracy, politics tend to be important in upward mobility. They have become a little more friendly to parents in the workplace with some departments offering reduced hours, but its typically in lower-level positions so once you've advanced to well-paying positions, you have to take a significant pay cut to keep working.

Title: If you're looking at the Financial Rep Role, read this.
View5: Decent benefits(which they've recently begun to cut back on). It's a mellow work culture, your co-workers are quite friendly and helpful in general, it's not a cutthroat environment at all. You will learn a lot at this job, and they do foster development within the constraints they provide. They're incredibly flexible with scheduling and accommodating for sick days etc, which is a huge plus for me.
View7:
This pertains specifically to the Denver site, but is also relevant to the role as a whole;


1) In the FR role you're essentially forced to burnout. The efficiency metrics are high, and when you good at the role you will take 70-100 calls a day. If you haven't done this before, you have no idea how exhausting it can be, people are pissy, impatient and dump their problems in your lap every day. Despite having a Series 7, you will quickly learn you're not really a stock broker, you're a frontline customer serviced rep in a call center. I rarely trade, most of my day is spent playing clean up with banking,tech support or paperwork issues while playing damage control with inconvenienced clients. You will quickly learn how insane people can be, you WILL have a client cussing and irrationally berating you because you can't make their check clear on a Sunday. 

2) The career opportunities are narrow, particularly for the Denver site. During training they will tell you that everyone is promoted within 4-5 months, and some promoted out of the training class. This is misleading at best. I'm a top performer in the site and now over a year in role, there are serious issues with favoritism in hiring, I've seen stellar candidates passed over countless times. Even with a promotion, it doesn't change the fact that 90% of jobs are on the phone. It's not easy to be leashed to a phone for 8 hours at a time, there are no projects, or tangible accomplishments, your tasks are often monotonous and dry.

3) There's a massive morale problem in the role, more than half the people I talk to are actively seeking other employment or are despondent and burnt out. If you don't drink the company Kool - Aide 100% (which you never should at any job) you will quickly see a lot of the problems with the business decisions, common practices and client t treatment are frustrating. With this being said, there are people who enjoy the job, and stay in it for years, just be very self aware when you consider the job. 

4) For the licenses, you're underpaid compared to the industry. They justify this by giving you a "culture" that is superior. To a degree it's accurate, compared to other phone sites and financial firms, it's pretty decent. 

5) Your central metric, upon which bonuses and promotions are centrally focused, are customer surveys, which are graded irrationally and unfairly. You can correlate higher, but it is largely random, and it can be infuriating.

Title: Financial Representative
View5:
*Good benefits

*18 days of PTO right off the bat (sick and personal days are combined).

*Friendly, helpful, and intelligent co-workers

*Loose attitude towards using cell phone at work, as long as you're doing your job

*Quarterly bonuses are based off of customer service, not sales

*Training is paid and very, very thorough

*$2500 bonus for passing licencing exams

*If you're moving more than 50 miles for accepting the position, they will give you a relocation package. But, you have to ask BEFORE you sign the acceptance agreement. You will not be eligible for the package if you have already signed.

*Work stays at work, no home-work

*Voluntary and unpaid days off for when call volumes are low, typically come up during the summer
View7: This is a CALL CENTER, you will spend 7.5 hours a day taking INBOUND CALLS for at least half of the year with no breaks in between. They will tell you when you get hired that you can be promoted within a few weeks, that only applies to 1% of employees, and they usually have years experience in the industry. And if you do get promoted, all they do is change your title, give you a very small pay increase, and stick you back on the inbound phone line. Usually takes about 3-5 years to get off the inbound phone line, as most of the non call center positions are filled with external hires. They will give you a list of regular ol' business day schedules before you sign, then change your schedule to something vastly different when you get licenced.The sign in bonus is great, until you find out that you have to stay at Fidelity for more than a year to avoid repayment. It seems like they are using it as a tool to artificially increase retention. This job is VERY monotonous, and you will be burnt out after 4-5 months after completing training. Most people in the office are either trying to get into a position where they aren't on the phones, then applying elsewhere when they find out there are none. Service reps are the front line, so when other groups have meetings and off phone work between calls, you will not. Constantly changing rules about what you can/can't do on the phone, and very little communication about changes. The worst part is watching upper management coming in 30 min late and leaving 30 min early, while you are tied to your phone, taking inbound phone calls from slightly rude people for over 7 hours a day.

Title: Overall an excellent learning experience & true work life balance.
View5: Very commensurate salary and benefits package. Higher, mid and employee level level Management have innovative ideas and always trying to improve. In my eleven years with Fidelity, I only had two managers who micro managed their employees.
View7: Communication and ground level employee feedback was seemingly lost from time to time in the "Silo" en route to Upper Management. Also, intention of high level decision makers was lost in translation in the other direction​, as one would expect.

Title: Great at first
View5: Fidelity loves young go-getters fresh out of college. Chances for advancement quickly after starting are high, and the pay is decent. They have decent benefits as well.
View7: They promote new faces quickly before they are ready to take on additional roles and put them in a spot of plateau where they can't get any higher because they were out in a spot they were not prepared for. Most managers play strong favorites and one black mark on your record from a biased supervisor shuts down any hope of advancement in the future. HR is reluctant to help with issues.

Title: It's who you know or who you are
View5: Great place in general, it meets my basic needs. Great company match, Great profit sharing program, if you work there long enough the pay becomes sufficient depending on your lifestyle. I've been here over a decade and would love to retire here but would love a true opportunity to advance.
View7: There are so many people in one place that advancement becomes next to impossible unless you know the right people are of a specific group. My experience might not be everyone's. There are a ton of business units and opportunities but it seems most jobs that are posted appear to already have a specific type in mine if not a specific person already, but they go through the motions. When the company makes a push for something they are singularly focused, the push for millennials means you see tons of your people advancing which means older, tenured workers are relegated to associate roles. When the push is to empower women, there are networks, seminars and women helping women, sometimes to the detriment of males, especially if the manager is a woman (this is not a misogynist statement). My demographic, african-american male is the bottom rung of every category it seems. There are few leaders in my part of the country with no Sr. Level leaders that I am aware of on the national level? I've been searching the corporate hierarchy for years, while I don't have time to cycle through all 30-40K employees to try and find one that looks like me, it also shouldn't be that difficult if the company is truly as diverse as it thinks it is. I am not saying affirmative action is needed, I'm saying there has to be some qualified person of color (black) that can advance? I realize advancement is based on merit, but as previously stated merit is not the determining factor, it's who you know or your demographics in the vast majority of decisions. The company would rather invest time, effort, and energy in selecting and grooming a mentee that fits the bill than hiring a more experienced individual and doing the same. If you are over 40, black, male then you can work there, you just can't advance.

Title: No growth in this role - despite what they say
View5:
Tuition Reimbursement
Match is good if you give 6+ years of service
Good name on the resume

I know of one person who moved to a non call center related job - after working there for 7 years.  Great people and I love the company, just stay away from anything call center related.

Title: Out of Control, but could turn it around in 5 to 10 years

As of late, management has been good at trying to strike a work/life balance (only recently however).  Management has improved as of late to get a handle on workflow and communicate.

Fidelity is absolutely out of control.  Fidelity promotes firefighters and not strategic thinkers.  I've worked at other highly political companies and Fidelity is absolutely the worse.  This is because how one should succeed is not clear.  Since success is difficult to measure and no career path has been mapped out, the schoozers win the day due to an ambiguous environment .  I see that many cutthroat, but ineffective managers are continually promoted. There are a handful of good managers out there however.  

In general, I find Fidelity a very difficult place to accomplish anything since the focus of mid-management changes and priorities change.  

Merit review and the fact that its called that is a joke, and we all know it.  If an employee wants to find his/her true market value, find a new job.  Don't wait around for Fidelity to make an adjustment for you.  
Things are not clear when are recruited as far as the benefits package, profit sharing, and the 401K match.

Title: Depends on where you are in the company

You also can have the Portfolio Advisory Service manage your 401k free of charge as an employee, and you have access to beautiful grounds (the complex is thousands of acres large with a pond and hiking trails and two cafeterias and a couple gyms, tennis and basketball courts and softball field and volleyball court). The health insurance is a little pricey but the plan itself is the best I've ever seen in terms of what it will cover. And last but not least, if you do your years i the dumpster up front, there is excellent income potential within the company.

In WPS, we are underpaid for what we do (median in New England for our job type would be closer to $70k), the expectations are always changing, applied inconsistently, and you are prodded and driven to do overtime because they choose to understaff for the busy seasons to save money. In the call center positions, you're on a clock, you get the legal minimum required breaktime, and there is a general lack of respect for work/life balance. Everywhere else in Fidelity, I hear the experiences are great, so I would say this is a reflecting on being within Workplace Participant Services, not Fidelity as a whole.

Title: Private Client Group Trader
View5: Pay is better than most call centers
View7: It’s a call center. Few opportunities for growth. They only care about metrics. Culture is hit or miss depending on your manager/team. HR is incredibly unorganized.  If you don’t meet their performance metrics they will take away your benefits (student loan reimbursement). No raises after three years of employment.

Title: Incredible place to learn the industry
View5:
Fidelity offers outstanding benefits and perks, from fitness and computer reimbursements to solid 401k matching.  The Financial Representative role is highly team-based, and there are always campaigns going on to see which team can land the highest metric scores.  The prizes for performing well in the campaign are often substantial.  It is quite possible to set aside the gift cards you win from the campaigns to fund an entire Christmas shopping list.  A good friend of mine won a 4-day, company paid trip to the Bahamas as a campaign reward.  Plus, the campaigns are a lot of fun.

The team structure is great.  Nearly all of the managers are incredible.  Some are more hands-on than others, but they all make sure you're developing as a representative and getting the training you need to stay sharp.  

During the summer, things were incredibly slow and we were often offered VTO (Voluntary Time Off), meaning we could request to leave at a certain time of day and take the rest of the day unpaid.  While getting addicted to VTO was extremely hazardous to your paycheck, it was cerrtainly nice to have that option, especially during the summer.

During the winter and tax season, overtime is offered and encouraged.  Unlike VTO, overtime was a paycheck savior.  While it was strongly encouraged, it was not mandatory, meaning you essentially have control over how much you want to make each day.  Because they only offer OT when things are incredibly busy, its pretty safe to say that every hour of OT put in is going to go by very quickly.

Training is INCREDIBLE.  When studying for the Series 7 general security license, you are paid for 20 hours out of the week to study.  If things are slow, you spend half of your day at work studying.  If things are busy, you work through the day and are expected to study at home, and that time is PAID overtime.  Huge win/win.  In my new hire class of 17 people, every single one of us passed the Series 7 on our first try, something largely unheard of in the industry.
View7:
Career growth potential is low.  While there are a number of roles to move into that are still in the call center (retirement specialists, stock plan services, premium service, sales, etc.), they are all essentially call center jobs.  Typically, if you're an outstanding rep for a number of years, you may get promoted to a team manager, and from there I'm not sure where people go.  In my year at Fidelity I never saw a team manager leave the position, except to be a team manager with a different group (i.e. going from managing a trading/service team to a retirements team).

Also, a POTENTIAL downside is that it is a shift-based role.  Upon completing new hire training, you rank the available shifts from 1 (most desired) to 18 (least desired).  They try to put everyone in the best shift possible, but the needs of the business come first and some people are going to end up working 10 hour, 4 days shifts, Sunday through Wednesday, starting at 5 AM.  Fidelity customer service is available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, so they need people to cover all shifts.  I got lucky and got my second pick, which was one of the many M-F 9 to 5's (my first choice was Monday through Thursday, 10 hour shifts), but there are a few people that aren't as lucky.  People that work night shifts (any shift starting at noon or later) are given a 8% pay bump while working that shift, however, so there are often people that WANT the later shifts, decreasing the chance you'd be stuck with one if you didn't want it.  Also, people can bid for a new shift once per year, so your shift is never permanent.

Title: It's a great place to work, in spite of what others might say.
View5: I've been working at Fidelity for 6 years and it's still a great place to work.  Senior Management does sincerely seem to care about you and help you succeed.  The benefits are awesome and the people are great.  All in all, it's a dream job:  challenging, interesting, and rewarding.
View7: I wish we could keep good talent at the senior level.  It seems there's a lot of turnover at the top.

Title: Great place to begin a career in Financial Services
View5: Fidelity does a great job at teaching their employees the basics of financial services. Their benefits are some of the absolute best in the industry as well. 401k plan match is 7% dollar-for-dollar with profit sharing of 10%. Health plans are especially good. The pay is also fair for a discount broker. Ultimately, Fidelity is one of the best places to work in Financial Services, because they have a long tradition of placing top priority on the customer experience. The Johnsons are good people who truly value their customers and their employees. When you are coached, it will be to whether or not the customer's needs were met, not whether you were able to sell them on an inappropriate product. Even working in sales, I always made more money off great customer surveys than I ever did due to sales results (although sales results are important as well). Lastly, the company is very conservative on a number of different topics. You are very unlikely to become involved in litigation working for Fidelity, because they stay as far away from "the line" as possible. Also, due to their conservative nature, FIdelity tends to be a safe place during times of layoffs unless you work in middle management.
View7:
As great as Fidelity is, they are not without fault. Many negative things that I can say about Fidelity, I can also say for other firms as well. The Johnsons are good people. They do a great job at spreading their gospel of customer service, but sometimes the message is lost on middle-management. Middle-management tends to stress too much on day-to-day figures such as Sales, number of calls taken, and the "customer experience indicator" (surveys) rather than focusing on the actual interactions that reps are having with customers. 
Managers (especially in sales) also tend to not be entirely clear on what they expect from their employees. My opinion is that this is done intentionally, because they know that they can't coach you to sell something inappropriate that makes them look better on a piece of paper, but oftentimes, they won't call you out on it either if you do in fact do just that. 
Like most big firms, Fidelity can be bureaucratic in many of their operations. The main problem (which is a good problem to have) is that Fidelity is a leader in Employee retirement plans such as 401(k)'s and 403(b)'s and a leader in personal investments such as IRA's. These are technically two separate companies, but under one roof under one name. I've worked in both sides of the house, and it can be annoying to go back and forth with colleagues on the other side of the fence who have these incorrect preconceived notions about your side of the firm. It's exhausting, but it's part of working for a big company. 
Technology is one of the biggest headaches. I can honestly say that while Fidelity invests billions of dollars into technology, much of this is to improve the website. Don't get me wrong, we have a great website for customers, but they don't spend nearly enough money trying to improve quality of life for the employees. Their systems are so complicated, it was almost always easier to tell the customer how to do transaction online rather than through a rep (which is probably what they're aiming for). Also, in this modern world of e-mail, skype, facebook, etc. Many of our employees are still unable to e-mail customers which would be fine if other firms kept the same policy. Other firms have changed with the times. While, I can say that Fidelity is "on their way." They've also been "on their way" to implementing e-mail correspondence for years now. I mentioned in the Pro's that they are conservative from a legal perspective. This is where some of the cons of being conservative come into play. 
Lastly, middle management is way too politically correct. It's annoying to many employees of all backgrounds. This especially rears its ugly head in the form of reverse discrimination. Being PC is fine as long as you continue to hire good people. Usually Fidelity does a good job in hiring the right people, but occasionally I've seen them compromise just to check a box that they're a diverse firm of employees. This can especially become annoying if you're looking to get promoted.

Title: Stable Company but lots of red tape
View5:
Great career place.  Many people stay there for 10+ years.  
Depending on your department and manager, very flexible with work/life
Salary is average to good.  Benefits and bonuses are great
I stayed over 8 years because of how well I was treated.  Decided to move on just to expand my knowledge but I wouldn't rule out a return some day.
View7:
Advancement is difficult due to the sheer number of employees.  They can't have everyone it a VP level so some people will stagnate.
Sometimes the red tape would get in the way and cause a small decision to take weeks to resolve.

Title: This is not a career. Use it for experience only.
View5:
It was easy to get hired. I made some mistakes and they still hired me. I really needed a job so I took it. 
I really like the people I work with. They are intelligent and genuinely friendly, except for a few people, who happen to be in decision making roles. A college education is encouraged and most people have that or have had years experience in customer service, business or finance. This makes for a great group of coworkers, but makes it more tragic given the cons.
View7:
I have been at the company for 7 months as a 401K associate.

I feel like the culture and environment turns my good co-workers into fearful drones looking out for only themselves. 

And now from here down are just facts:

You have to have your computer system up and running with 4-5 applications by the start of your shift. if the computer locks up, which happens at least once a day, more for others, you cannot let the customer know, keep talking, reboot, refresh etc. they are now transitioning us into a different computer system but coming up this month. I'm not optimistic. 

My Veritude hired co-workers were on the job for 6 months until transitioning into non-Veritude, or I guess "regular Fidelity employees" were not eligible for the mid year review raise. Also, the day they transition, their computer systems were locked up and it took all day for IT to fix. The company was not prepared. This is how I found out how many there were at my site it was about a quarter of the DC associates. Many of these people were some of the best members of my team. I didn't know what Veritude was until I read Glassdoor this evening. it is actually a Fidelity hiring department. It is a temp to hire. So Fidelity hires some employees and gives them the same job as other regular employees but they do not get the mid year review raise or quarterly bonus.

My manager purposefully plays politics and does not hide it.

The salary is very low. 

You get sick leave throughout the year but each time you call in sick it counts against you as an "incident". Each manager has discretion on what will be used against you. This is unfair period.

The company match is 7% on the retirement savings acct. but only after you have worked there 1 year, and you are not 100% vested until five years. 

Each site in the nation has only specific job roles available. 

Our job is to go above and beyond for the customer and work for the customer, which, if done right, means printing out statements and literature by hand and sending them in envelopes or calling out to our solutions desk to do research on complicated issues or submitting research requests which are complicated forms where we have the least bit of training on. Any work done that is not on the phone is going to be counted against your hold time, your idle time or if you are unlucky and do not take your lunch on time, your adherence time.

We get two 15 min breaks and 30 min lunch. It takes 15 min to walk down to the cafeteria to acquire food after standing in line with the slowest people in the world (management knows this) You eat in 10 min, go to the restroom and rush back to get system ready to start again. that is assuming there are no tasks to wrap up after getting off the phone and starting your lunch clock, and there always is, along with some trying to talk to you.

Title: High Net Worth Representative I
View5: Lots of options as far as career paths are concerned. Wonderful training program, so it is a great place to begin your career in the financial services industry. Fair pay. Very very good retirement benefits.
View7: The measures of performance make it easy for management to micro-manage, and be overly critical of what would normally be considered very hard working employees. Unfortunately, although there are a great deal of career paths, these same measures of performance are used to evaluate employees, and can sometimes lead to wonderful employees being overlooked for advancement.

Title: Fidelity Investments is a really great place to work!
View5: The people are very nice and supportive, especially my manager. I had a recent death in my family, and everyone was beyond supportive, which meant a lot. You may expect an investment company to be stuffy and old school, but Fidelity is quite the opposite! The perks and benefits are great, as well as the pay.
View7: Coming from a creative background (art and theater), being in a very corporate environment can be sometimes challenging for a right brained person.

Title: What you need to succeed - NOT
View5:
Competitive Pay
Some coworkers are great
Great benefits package offered
Great 401k match

Great potential for advancement
View7:
Fidelity - who is a recordkeeper for who knows how many companies 401k plans, has a 5 year cliff vesting schedule, and you're not even 20% vested in company contributions until 2 years.

The systems provided need a MAJOR overhaul.  There are procedural specific systems and client specific systems to use when handling calls.  These systems are not updated, so 1/2 the time you are under a constant worry if you are handling something incorrectly.  When cross trained on multiple products, you are not trained completely, so customers can ask questions you are supposed to be able to answer, but you can't because you don't know.  The answer is supposed to be searchable while you put the customer on hold to get the answer.  But holds can only be for 3 minutes, and it can take a lot longer than 3 minutes to find the answer because 1/2 the time when you search something the system comes back with no results. 

If a customer escalates, they don't go to your immediate manager, you're to call your "solutions desk and escalate the call" and that rep is supposed to handle the call from that point.  However the solutions desk reps are extremely lazy and will do anything and everything to push the call back on the tier 1 rep because they don't want to handle the call, thus causing the customers to become completely frustrated, yelling and screaming at us over why we are not transferring them to a supervisor, and then give us a bad customer survey.

If you need to enter a work item, they are shipped off shore to some reps in India to handle who have no idea what they are doing.  So they resolve the work item incorrectly, and we need to enter multiple work items for the same exact thing over and over.  We promise customers a 5 day work around timeframe and something so simple can take over 1 mo to resolve because the India reps just don't care.   The customers become very upset over how long it takes to resolve a simple error. 

While the company offers great potential for advancement, it is all in who you know, not what you know.  I had an interview for an internal transfer once, and while I was nervous as I didn't have a lot of interview experience at the time, my interviewer was constantly yawning and looking at his phone even before the interview started.  I don't think I was that boring, but that was extremely unprofessional and I can't believe he got the job he did because while I didn't get it, once trained I'm sure I would've been way more suited for the position. 

When you do need your manager and not a "solutions desk rep" they are nowhere to be found because they are always "in a meeting".  

This job creates a lot of extremely stressful situations, but when you become frustrated and voice your opinion, you're in the wrong and put under review or fired.  You can offer suggestions on how you think things should be and how to correct it, and management will pat you on the back for it, but then nothing is ever done to fix anything.

Title: Business Acquisition
View5: Smart colleagues, good compensation, nice offices, interesting work, great opportunities for advancement.
View7: Churn and burn organization full of type A personalities. There's a bit of a "what have you done for me lately culture." People feel expected to work a lot of hours and are overly busy, which means that the common niceties are sacrificed to get the job done. Seems like a good place to build a career if you are starting out, but only if you are very driven. A lot of meetings and not as much time to get work done.

Title: You are just another asset, and nobody is irreplacable
View5: Average/decent pay but superior benefits, long-standing culture of success.  Great camaraderie with fellow employees.
View7: You are just another asset to be controlled, and management considers you easily replaceable.  Multitudes of levels of managers when few would actually be required.  Once you have been there 10+ years, there is a target on your back for money savings by bringing in someone younger and with less experience, or nobody at all to leave your work for someone else.

Title: Weak in the knees
View5: The company offers good compensation and solid understanding of work life balance.  That plus the deals on food from the chef enabled cafeteria.
View7: Upper middle management is weak in the knees and leaves their people to swing in the breeze when obstacle teams make noise.  Instead of backing the troops in the field they turn and run because it appears less of a headache.

Title: Great place to work if you enjoy status quo.
View5: Great benefits. Job will last as long as you perform at average levels. Top performers get rewarded with company shares, bonuses etc.
View7: Old fashioned policies when it comes to promoting. Your advancement is conditional to your current position, qualifications notwithstanding. Company seems to love status quo. Challenges to it are met with resistance. Too many layers and bureaucracy makes everything slow. Project management is stuck in the 90s.

Title: High Net Worth Representative
View5: Amazing trillion dollar company with amazing resources, thousands to employees and an enormous and loyal customer base.  Think:  MEGA aircraft carrier!  Try slipping that baby into a small dock.
View7: Too many layers of managers who are too focused on playing internal games to claw their way up the ladder and not focused enough on understanding customers' needs and how to empower employees to meet those needs.  We give what we tell 'em they want!  And they'll like it.  Or else!!

Title: Good benefits and coworkers but too political and an empty focus on being green on internal reports.
View5: Great flexibility and branch mojo. Honestly felt like my coworkers cared about me and my family. The sales reps helped to develop my career where needed. 401k and 10% profit sharing were the best benefits.
View7: Very political and difficult to move from one branch to another without a connection. Base salary was below industry average. Lack of focus from management as the goals seemed to change from week to week. High focus on clicks just to make a report look good.

Title: Associate Software Engineer (Leap Program)
View5:
Good benefits (compared to other companies with the same base salary).
401k matches up to 7% of your salary.
Total compensation (bonus, profit sharing, retirement contributions) becomes high if you stay there for a long time (5+ years).
In general, difficult to get fired unless you really mess up.
There are established Leap communities to hang out with, where ever you are placed after completing the Leap Program.
View7:
Low base salary and total compensation for new graduates. If you don't plan on staying at Fidelity for at least 5 years, your total compensation would be better if you moved around companies or started your career at a different company.

Average software engineers. There are a few software engineers that perform above and beyond. There are several that plan to do the bare minimum and collect a paycheck. The technical interviews were not very hard, and the ability of the software engineers reflects this. This is not a great place for top (new grad) software engineers. It takes too much time (5 years) for the total compensation to be worth it.

Risk of disliking the business unit you are placed in after the Leap program. You don't get to talk directly with your after-placement manager, your Leap manager will place you after getting to know your interests and personality. I feel like 1 in 3 Leap graduates are not satisfied with their role after placement. With some bad luck, you can be placed in a business unit that offers no growth in useful technologies, no learning opportunities, and no help from senior engineers (my experience). Or with some good luck, you could be using the newest technologies with good mentors, and learning a lot. In general, they expect you to stay at least a year in your current business unit before moving, but you can tell within 6 months whether or not if the business unit and its progress are good enough for you. It is a huge gamble to enter the Leap program, knowing there is a decent chance the business unit you will be placed in will not be that worthwhile. It's up to you if you want to roll the dice. 

Emphasis on company loyalty. They tell you to focus on the "product knowledge",  which is useful to you only as long as you are working for Fidelity, but it's not great if you plan to leave Fidelity at any time in your life. They entice you with a total compensation that increases exponentially from 0 to 5 years. This means a below average total comp at 0 years and an above average total comp after 5 years. Many are promoted based on years of service. Even if you perform twice as well, you will not be promoted twice as quickly - it would be better for you to just switch jobs.

Slow moving technology. The company is slowly moving towards agile, cloud, and other new technologies, but change is extremely slow for financial companies. This means you might not be developing skills that are useful in your career the moment you leave Fidelity. Fidelity claims to be a technology company that specializes in finance, but improvements in technology are often hindered by business desires, such as excessive spending on contractors, and not enough spending on code refactoring and architecture improvements. Its not great for your career to be constantly one step behind everyone else.

Title: Investment Data Analyst
View5:
Leadership has a vision and goal to achieve.
Great benefits
Flexible Time-Offs
Advertising healthy life choices
Job stability and security
View7:
Hectic Middle Management
Too many people who are under-qualified are at their positions due to job security culture
Lacking technologies despite how company is looking to become Fin/Tech
Too much company politics at lower level

Title: Don't drink the kool-aid, Fido is still a corporation.
View5: The benefits were good at the time I left. 7% 401k match and 10% profit sharing.
View7: The culture is terrible. Yes-men and women with no substance are the ones who get promotions while the employees who are actually knowledgeable get shown the door. It's extremely difficult to be promoted or get the raise you actually deserve.

Title: Pockets of strong talent, but too much general mediocrity and not enough merit-based turnover
View5: Private company (so no knee-jerk market-driven reactions to dumb analyst reports).  Pays well.  Some bright people in pockets.  Civilized and polite environment. Still strong franchise.
View7: Private ownership implies occasional arbitrary/crazy decisions.  Eg, the misguided "site strategy" (aka, kick 'em out of Boston) will drive substantial IP loss and talent bleed. Instability is on the rise.  Top-down decision making, run more like a club than a company. Entrenched passive-aggressive approach to discourse.

Title: Retirement Solutions Representative
View5: The benefits are outstanding.  Great licensing programs.
View7: Business units operate in silos.  Hard to move up if you start in a phone role.  Senior management is disconnected from representatives.  One year requirement to stay in a phone role each time you change positions.  Six sick days per year and only 4 weeks vacation time no matter how long you have been with the firm.  Technology is outdated and they layer applications on top of old platforms.  Signifcant barrier to doing your job effectively.

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Benefits are probably the best out there!!!  This company invests a lot of capital trying to compete with other firms in the brokerage realm and with great success!   Company is well-managed.   Depending on the area, job opportunities are abundant!  I feel that Fidelity truly focuses on the customer as an effective business strategy.
View7: Increases in pay are small but quick up front.  After 2 years the pay increases slow down drastically, even for good performance due to the control point compensation schedule they have.  Too often individuals are hired for reasons other than tenure and performance.  Politics too often play a role in advancement.

Title: Great place to work
View5: Very strong franchise with good product support in an exciting marketplace.  Excellent benefits too.  Culture is outstanding, everyone is motivated to work as a team.  There are products and services managed for the local market and also managed for the larger market south of the border.
View7: Market pressure is intense.  Competitors are strong and Fidelity Canada is not one of the biggest players.  Investment management is not a business know for having a lot of natural work life balance so be prepared to work hard and sometimes long.

Title: Great place to work and the people/ managers are really nice.
View5: strong solid company with great reputation. managers really help you succeed and progress in your career/ goals. flexible with your schedule and work with you if something does not go as plan within work and outside. paid training.
View7: the compensation could be much better for the amount of tedious work and dedication to ensuring customer satisfaction.  large corporation so politics are often involved in decision making.

Title: Great place of employment.
View5: Really great culture and wonderful people to work with and alongside. Benefits are great, and the work-life balance is more than you could ask.
View7: Depending on the manager, they may not be as invested in your growth. In my time, I've been under three managers, two of which were great and one not-so-great. It's difficult to move within the company, but there are an array of possibilities, so as long as you know the right people and where you want to go, you can move around.

Title: Great training and supportive team, but job feels irrelevant to real future growth and you are in a true phone center
View5:
Great training
Supportive management
Available to get OT
Many diff schedules
401k, insurance, profit sharing 
Can move up quickly with decent customer service skills
View7:
Metrics
Feels like big brother is watching 
Micromanagement
Push sales in every role just called by a different name
Can move up, but only through a phone site. 
You will do one thing all day
20% OT requirement
Lower salary for industry

Title: Great Company with benefits!
View5: Great company benefits, great overall culture of the firm. Working in the phone site, there is a lot of flexibility with schedule and a lot of perks that employees have the opportunity to earn.
View7: Working in a phone site for 8 hours a day can get exhausting extremely fast. Not enough roles within the phone site that is not phone based. When seeking promotion opportunities, external experience can make very little impact when being considered for new role.

Title: Many different experiences
View5: Fidelity has a strong culture, but it’s a large company and there are many different sub cultures, which can mean different experiences for different associates.  The right culture fit for you will be a good experience. Benefits are amazing, pay is excellent and the work environment is becoming increasingly progressive. Most groups have good work life balance and development opportunities are abundant.
View7: If the culture is not a match, you won’t survive. Demanding, goal oriented, customer obsessed (can be a pro and con).  Time off policies are the only thing that may lag competitors.

Title: VP
View5:
Opportunity to learn
Great People
Benefit
The organization values talented employees
View7:
Unrealistic workloads - especially after Voluntary Buyout program.  Showing any weakness or dissatisfaction regarding this issue kills any future career growth. Lack of work/life balance is a problem you need to keep to yourself.  At the same time, a surprising tolerance for some below average teams that  
support clients or or internal partners.

Title: Work you like a mule, but great work experience
View5:
Fidelity is one of the most well known companies in the Financial Services industry, so this experience definitely boosts my reputation  as a financial professional. I worked in a call center for 2 years where I took 40-60 inbound phone calls per day and man, this was brutal but I gained an immense amount of knowledge about the economy and financial services in general. 

This position is a great starting place if you want a career as a financial consultant/planner.
View7:
- You're a small piece of a very large company
- Lots and lots and lots of calls

Title: Various roles within multiple business units.
View5:
*good benefits
*positive workplace culture in some business units
View7:
*distrust among business units
*lack of mobility 
*low pay
*culture that disrespects women in risk and compliance functions

Title: Management is more worried about how many shares they get at the end of the year then helping clients.
View5: Great place to learn about the industry.
View7: Branch managers just care about managing spreadsheets.

Title: Great place to work!
View5: In the time that I worked there, I was most impressed with the management.  Opinions were heard, recognition and incentives were given.  Everyone seemed to care about what they were doing and the overall development of the team.  Opportunities for advancement.  There was a general positive attitude in the workplace.  Also, decent hours, pay and benefits.  Comfortable physical work environment.
View7: Expected to work overtime when needed, even if that's not your thing.  At times, it seemed as though management could play favorites with whom they were looking at for promotion.  Good if you were a favorite, bad if not.

Title: Decent place to work, employees treated well
View5: Decent place to work, employees treated well and there are good opportunities within Salt Lake although these are some what stacked towards direct contact with clients.  During busy times there is a lot of flexibility with overtime.
View7: The company can be slow moving sometimes, positive changes and feedback seem to be planned but take a long time to get acted on.  Career advancement past client focused or operations jobs will probably require you to relocate.

Title: Principal Software Engineer at Fidelity Investments
View5: Compensation and benefits are very good. Able to work from home when I need to.  Training is always available. Tuition reimbursement is very good.
View7: Can be stressful at times to finish projects. Sometimes we make shortcuts which can be troublesome later on.  A lot of redundant systems but they are working on consolidating them.

Title: Great company, but non-phone jobs are very hard to get...aside from moving across country to a branch office.
View5:
-Top notch benefits
-Industry-leading entry level training
-Pretty intelligent and social group of workers
-Name recognition
-Nice facilities
-Fidelity cares about it's employees
View7:
-Extremely difficult to get a job off the phones.(During the interview, they love to tell you that we promote from within. What they fail to mention is that literally 95%+ of the promotions are to other phone jobs)

-Getting into a branch/non-phone job is possible if your are willing to move out of state to one of about 100 locations across the country...even though most branches have a maximum of about 10-12 people per branch)

-Management is a loose term. Managers basically grade your calls from their desk and you get an email telling you to review your score.  Otherwise they are in meetings..  There literally isn't any "managing" or developing going on and self developement is rare b/c it's all about taking or making as many calls in a day as possible.

-Burnout is very common because of the monotonous nature of the job...one call after another all day.

-Many of the mid level managers were in the call center job for years and this is all they know and can be hard to relate to if you have ideas outside the box.

Title: Great financial products and great place to be a financial advisor, VERY political.
View5: They offer the most cost-effective financial product solutions.  Very focused on customer-service and have some of the best employee benefits a private company could offer.
View7: Extremely political environment for managers in their call centers.  Pay for managers is horrible.  When financial crisis hit in late 2008 they quickly lost my confidence as an employee-centric company as they unloaded a ton of people and talent.  They also cut employees pay in a massive way.

Title: Elephants cannot survive off peanuts; and yes, they count them often.
View5: Mobility and other opportunities abound if you are patient. Good name within the industry and loyal client base. Great inexpensive investment lineup.
View7:
Corporate politics abound here. To move up carry toilet paper around often to wipe your nose. They only want to hear the truth if its what they want to hear. You can be #1 in sales but if you dont further their agenda you will stall your career. Micro management is well over the top. Worst I have ever encountered. The compensation is extremely weak (My gross income here is what I used to pay in taxes at my other jobs and I am in the top 20 people out of 300  in the nation for 2 years running) Great place to get hired if you are desperate or looking for a stepping stone but will never be long term. They are short term focused but always talk about the long term. Do not let this fool you!  Middle management and some mkt mgrs truly have no clue how to manage. They are failed sales people with brown crust on their noses that micro manage and have little to zero outside experience ( this is their only real job since college).  The work and dealing with clients is ok as the Fido client is a cheapskate and know-it-all. It takes time to build trust, realtionships and for the client to self discover they need your/Fido help. Management wants you to slam them into products today. A "what have you done for me today" mentality. If your response is "built a deeper relationship 
based on trust and confidence" the branch mgr will look at you like a cyborg and keep repeating  "that does not calculate" until his brain starts to smoke. Corp vision is a lie. They say they want to retain top talent and build long term relationships. Look at their actions. It is a lie. 5 top Senior Accountt execs left in the last 12 months. Everyone of them were threatened on the way out by their mgr rather than spoken to for retention measures. If this were a public company I would buy a put 3 years in the future so i could put it to someone I hated and make a killing from their lose. It is a truly broken system and the mend is at minmum 5 years away. Possibly a decade. Lastly, once you do sell something you have to track it and a third of the time sent up exception as they are not crediting it to you but atbthe same time will be delivering you an oral warning of termination for low production which they will not rescind once its credited and also become part of your HR file. It is purely about power, fear and control at this place. It is only for the weak and timid not top talent.

Title: Acceptable if you're out of ambition
View5:
If you're married with kids and a house, and you want to go home at 4:45PM every day, Fidelity is for you. I've never worked less anywhere else. When I've had visitors in on a Friday in the summer, and only 6 of 30 team members are in, they ask "where is everyone" and I have to explain that this is normal. Largely "Working From Home" is used more than it should.

As far as ambitions go, Abby and Ned own the company. What they want goes. As such, you can expect fiats from on high and many people and divisions shuffling along, getting by. This is not a terrible thing, but you'll not find floors of teams rushing to "get it done" and invent the "next great thing" despite the corporate newsletters the champion such internal trends. Rather you'll find bureaucracy, process, and more process taking weeks to do something as simple as write a single line query. One fiat was all applications moving to Linux servers from Window servers. Why? Ned had met Bill Gates at a conference and decided he didn't like him, so we needed to get rid of Windows.

Pay is slightly below market, but health benefits are good ($140 for top health plan), bonuses not bad, and the hours are great. Good training budget. OK vacation policy (15 days). Nice facilities.
View7:
Big Warning: Fidelity is divesting in Boston and New England. They are moving all the jobs they can to Raleigh (NC), Westlake (TX), Ireland, China and India. Every year more Boston teams get sacked and given the "chance" to move 2000mi or more, though usually only 10% take the offer. Be careful if you're not deeply entrenched in the front office, your days are likely numbered.

Everyone keeps to themselves. Passing people in the hall, they stare at the floor. In the elevators you could hear a pin drop. Folks are not outgoing and I've seen many teams that sit 10 yards apart and don't know each other at all. This helps breed the internal silos and technical fiefdoms. If you behave gregariously, people will be surprised.

Fidelity IT loves to talk about Agile, but we actually use FAM, the Fidelity Agile Methodology. During your interview, ask deep questions about how so called "Agile" teams work and you'll be in for a laugh. FAM is a broken application of Agile and little better than classic waterfall. If you've really learned Agile elsewhere, people are going to laugh at you your first few weeks here.

If you're looking to grow rapidly in tech, look beyond Fidelity. Our systems are laughably behind the times, though our "architectural conferences" will swear they're cutting edge (i.e. IE8 anyone, Java 6, Tomcat 5?).

Title: Good place to settle.
View5:
Work-life balance.
Flex schedule for students.
Good benefits.
View7:
It's a call center.
No vision insurance, which is weird.
Unbelievably outdated phone system. Highly fragmented and poorly integrated software systems. You'll have to learn a dozen different systems to efficiently accommodate the variety of customer interaction types.
You'll work nights and weekends.
Coworkers are not very inspiring or motivated people. Most have given up on their dreams and settled for mind-numbingly dull work and mediocre pay.
It's almost impossible to get fired and there isn't much recognition or compensation for exceptional performers.

Title: Good training, taxing work environment
View5:
Lots of support to get your Series 7 & Series 63
Supportive management
Friendly people
Learned a lot about industry
Decent benefits
View7:
Company has no respect for your life outside of work
You are constantly urged to work overtime
Long hours on the phone leave your feeling burnt out
You are tethered to your desk at all times
Low pay

Title: Ok place to work, but not all its cracked up to be.
View5: They recruit you with the promise of quick promotion and fast track to a 6 figure income. Its as they promise - atleast in my previous roles. Fantastic 401k matching and PSP. Great benefits, great training. Overall pleasant company to start with if you're new in the industry or ready to retire
View7: Its a machine and you get treated like a replaceable cog. Heavy micromanagement to control output of product (ie what you say to clients) They're like the mcdonalds of financial services - you know what you get, whether good or bad. Working there you're forced to adopt their processes and procedures with exact scripts, very robotic - often times reminds me they want you to be a parrot (ie repeat what they say with greater enthusiasm, then they feed you a cracker like Iago from Aladdin). Management recruits you by promising you a book of business and that its like you running your own business but with fidelity's resources and support. Further from the truth. Once you're in, you always have to continue to generate revenue for the firm. This doesn't lend a good hand towards servicing your existing customers. Good pay, but its a hamster wheel. The moment you stop running, you get slapped.

Title: Pretty good, great company, nice people, excellent health benefits, limited career opportunities in Utah
View5: Nice people, lots of training, prep for licensing exams. Large focus on customer service. HMO they provide one of the best there is for the price as a benefit.
View7: Really only customer service jobs and management positions in Utah in service or sales. Nothing that involves analysis. Moving to similiar positions at other sites possible but not completely different business units.

Title: Its Blah!
View5: Good benefits, good salary and good work-life balance. Marketing roles are exciting since they play in a commodity industry that is highly competitive and undifferentiated.  Also Fidelity is not really about growth, it is one family's estate plan
View7: Politics. Many people have titles of VP Politics. People get moved around all depending on who they like and who they associate with.  Growth internally is quite limited, again depending on who likes you.

Title: Professional Organization
View5: Competitive salary and benefits but the best is the working environment.  Most employees strive to achieve world class results.  The firm is ranked #1 or 2 in many financial, HR, 401K and other businesses. Employees are given fantastic resources, training and professional development in order to be successful in their roles.
View7: While pay overall is very competitive, it feels like senior management comp is disproportionate to pay of front-line employees.  Large firm, sometimes new ideas are tough to get through or are unduly complicated by silo-style business units.

Title: great benefits
View5: very structured compoany, great benefits, work schedule, flexibility, learning opportunities, they pay for graduate school or other degrees or courses plus they have internal certifications
View7: horizontal hierarchy,  not much room to grow at the site i worked it was a site director, a lot of managers who reported to her and then everybody else. but still a good place to start your career and Fidelity always looks good on your resume

Title: Good place to work overall
View5: Fantastic business overall - great franchise.  Particular strengths in retail brokerage and 401k administration.  High-quality people. Good benefits and culture. Enjoyed working there overall
View7: Family ownership can create weird politics for those in corporate roles or more senior business roles. Company spends a lot of time and money on "side businesses" through private equity arm. Detracts focus and takes money away from core business

Title: Good place to start your career
View5: There is some great talent and fun people to work with at Fidelity. The company has good benefits and fairly good pay. I got some great experience starting my career here. I grew thick skin dealing with the daily client abuse. Training is good, they will hold your hand and spoon feed you through anything to get you certified.
View7: Welcome to Corporate America. Promotions can be a nightmare with hurry up and wait mentality. sometimes there will be 6 months between job opportunities. In Denver there is a very limited amount of opportunities, managers will tell you to move to the east coast if you don't like the jobs available. Trade support will witch hunt you if you get a trade error, even if its for 1 cent. Trade errors are used to punish employees and lowers your chances of getting promoted. Managers will use fear tactics to push the bottom line which has more to do with customer surveys than anything else if you are in service. I wish I could write some of the profanity the customers will say to you over the phone, truly horrific dealing with the general public. Training in large classes of 20+ young professionals feels a lot like high school and its not ideal for education. Classes tend to get "clicky" and like managers, the facilitators always have their favorites. Unless you are a great "suck up" don't expect to get promoted based on your merits here.

Title: Financial Service Associate
View5: The ability to help people with their financial needs and provide them with the benefits of their financial accounts.
View7: Not enough people to do the work. Work lots of overtime and which affects work/life balance.  Implementing agility plans but have not figured how to calculate the other assignments into your group metrics.  So there is no process in place at this time to include the extra work into your personal metrics.

Title: Great
View5: Amazing benefits, match 100% up to 7%. Plus a profit sharing to all employees for 10% into 401k. Work life balance and finding ways to make the vibe work with millennials. Cafeteria that subsidizes healthy eating, and education reimbursement up 10k per year.
View7: At times feels like very limited opportunity for growth. Roles can be very tedious at times and wear your down.

Title: Great, young atmosphere, a great start or career
View5:
Paid study time for series 7 is a huge pro
Young atmosphere
Currently hiring and promoting people quickly
Great campus
Great benefits
View7:
Pay could be higher
Might be hard to promote out of the call center
performance is based on customer surveys that do not reflect performance accurate

Title: Constant grind
View5:
- Great benefits
- Good learning experience in the financial services industry
- Leave work at work..no stress when out of work
View7:
- Sit in a cube all day..constant grind
- Prepare to be attatched to a phone all the time besides 2 measly 15 min breaks and a lunch
- Glorified customer service
- Managers for the most part are self appointed by who the upper managers "like" and shouldnt be managers...everything is delegated like this from upper management, down
- Forced to work OT because they don't hire enough people

Title: Great Company, but phones are too much.
View5: Great benefits, 7% 401k matching, excellent healthcare with HSA, Fun & smart people co-workers, good location.
View7: The phones are awful, I hated having set 15 breaks and a scheduled lunch that rotated every day. They try and make you believe you have growth opportunities in Jax, but don't be fooled. It's all on the phones. If you like that, great, if you hate the phones do NOT take this job. Managers rotate way too often. They bring in a new manager every few months, ones that have no clue about your subject matter.

Title: Frustaing place to work for engineers
View5: Good benefits, plenty of opportunity to work in different roles and a good place start off / learn about the financial industry.
View7: The company is organized and run like a bank which has a negative impact on the technology divisions. There are multiple layers of management who don't really know anything about technology. Unfortunately they get to make the important decisions which leads to expensive and wasteful engineering practices. Good engineers typically get frustrated with all the politics and beauracracy and leave after a few years.

Title: Great Company-Not much room to move up
View5: Forward thinking, Professional work-place. Promotes employee health by providing incentives for check-ups and to stop smoking. People are friendly and courteous.
View7: Management plays favorites, very hard to advance especially if you don't kiss up. Even if you out perform co-workers, and go the extra mile with the customer, you still may get passed up for promotions for those who are "buddies" with the boss.

Title: Great Benefits and Firm
View5: The spirit of entrepreneurship is very evident at the senior management level which drives a lot of innovation in finance. It's a great family company with unparalleled benefits and there is a prestige in being associated with Fidelity Investments. It's a beacon for transparency and innovation.
View7: The mid to lower level management don't often carry the torch forward in terms of entrepreneurship. There is a lot of territorial behavior from certain silos, which firm can do without.

Title: A Really Good Company to Work For!
View5: Privately-held firm with tremendous values and a mission to inspire better futures for their clients, their employees and, of course, the firm itself.
View7: The con is also a pro.  Fidelity is a very conservative firm and, because of that, sometimes slow to embrace change particularly if there is risk involved.  Being risk-averse isn't necessarily a bad thing....but it can keep you from being a first mover.

Title: 529 College Savings Specialist
View5: Fidelity has a fantastic paid training program.  They also offer great benefits which far exceeded my expectations.
View7: I had to spend over eighty percent of the time on the phone.  I only took inbound calls, but eight to ten hours (depending on five eight-hour days or four ten-hour days) of being on the phone was too much after a couple of years.

Title: Very hit or miss.
View5: Many business units have authentic genuine leadership that does the right thing the right way.  Find your way to those couple of groups. The rest are overworked and have little incentive to stay.
View7: Non client facing groups are treated very poorly. Overtime is very high because those groups don’t have exposure to customers so their headcount targets are insanely low.
