Some of that is understandable but here the disparity in the treatment of people in those business units is beyond unfair.  Senior leaders run those groups with a “bully” mentality.

Title: Brutal micromanaged understaffed underpaid call center
View5:
-- Prestige of getting to tell people you work for Fidelity Investments, which everyone knows to be a good company.
-- Good benefits/401k etc.  I cannot stress this enough.
-- Still better than many other companies out there
-- You get to see some VERY interesting accounts daily and have some very interesting conversations.
-- Some of the employees (read: not managers) are friendly.
View7:
-- Highly Tracked minute to minute punching in and out for every conceivable activity during the day.  This gets old VERY FAST.
-- Obsessive compulsive, paranoid, schizophrenic, micromanaged culture in which you are constantly under the microscope.
-- Damned if you do, damned if you don't culture.  They will find a way that you did something wrong, ALWAYS.  Especially trade support.
--  Pay not commensurate with job duties. (These financial phone conversations are extremely difficult, involved and stressful, especially with some of Fidelity's high net worth clients).  
-- Most of the managers are truly awful human beings.
-- Horrible work schedules, hours, and and team inconsistency.   Part of this is the nature of the beast, but they make NO effort to reduce the volatile and brutal nature of everyones schedules, teams collapsing every month, etc.  
--  Not much potential to truly learn.  They teach you the Fidelity Way, which is useless for the rest of the world outside of Fidelity.
--Poor work/life balance

Title: Excellent company with good benefits and decent pay
View5: Open ideas are encouraged and a strong work/life balance is encouraged.  It is easy to move around within the company and find your niche.
View7: Overall the people are easy to work with and the atmosphere is positive.  I really don't have many negative things to say.  The overall benefit package is very good but when people leave the company it is usually because they have found a similar job that pays 10-15% more than what they currently make.

Title: Best place I ever worked. So far ...
View5:
Great work environment. Promotes advancement, continued learning, and a healthy social work environment. Compensates well for the employees that work hard to make the company successful. 

Pay was on the higher end of competitive work. We had potlucks and team meetings. I always felt like I could talk to any of the managers. Sometimes we would go to 7 eleven for treats like little kids. I met several life long friends there and that really made it a worthwhile place to work.
View7: The financial industry isn't really my thing. So I don't really have any cons for my time with fidelity.

Title: Great Company.. Westlake, TX
View5:
Benefits
Company Christmas party
Cafeteria
Great work/life balance
Employee Engagement
Career Development
Training
View7:
Compensation - It is best to negotiate salary as much as possible before taking the offer, if not you will be unsatisfied for the work that is required. During the negotiation of the salary if not offered what you want do not take it because it is extremely difficult to get good pay increases. Average merit raises were about 1.5%. Pay also depends on the area as well but for the most part it is not very competitive amongst other financial firms.
Sometimes things can be too micromanagement

Title: A great place for young college graduates to build a career
View5: The facility is very nice and the people are very nice, friendly and supportive.  The training is good and you get a lot of support.  Management encourages feedback and evaluation of everything.  Fidelity promotes from within.  If you are a young person just starting out in a new career, it is an excellent place to get started and move up.  They like to train people into their own culture and reward those who comply.  When you apply for other opportunities, they give you feedback if you are not chosen.   The benefits package is good.  Even though this is a call center environment and it can be busy, it is a pleasant place to be and I have never felt overly micro-managed.  The callers are usually nice and pleasant and management encourages helping the customer no matter how long it takes.  Customers routinely tell us how they appreciate the service they get.  There are often potlucks and employee appreciation events and fun things going on.
View7: The facility is in a somewhat remote location and is a long drive.  If you are an experienced person, unfortunately opportunities to move up seem to be more limited.  The company tends to prefer training inexperienced people instead of promoting people who have experience from elsewhere.  The recruiters will promise you career opportunities, but there are some interesting politics involved in getting the other opportunities that they do not tell you about.  There are a lot of very young managers who started out with the company, but who do not have a lot of management experience.  While everyone is very nice and friendly, sometimes they seem to be intimidated by older, more experienced staff and look for ways to deny opportunities instead of trying to fit people in where they are most qualified.

Title: I have had great experience working with Fidelity Investments. The company provides great learning opportunity.
View5:
I have have been working with Fidelity Investments for more than 3 years & my experience has been wonderful. The company adopts to latest technologies, thus keeping us techies in line with the latest happenings in technology.
My personal experience has been great, where in i have been promoted multiple times have joined as an Associate straight out of Masters Program. The company recognizes talent and promotes the same, through opportunities for learning & perks.
View7: Like many other companies the production installs occur during business off hours, hence you are expected to participate in the same.

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Fantastic company and a great place to learn, they have a generous benefit program paying for things like CFP , gym etc. This is dynamic place to work with a great culture
View7: Far too much politicking necessary to get promoted. The introverts that work hard rarely get a mention , Stingy in there raises. Inflation is 3% yet consistent dont give that

Title: Good company but job functions are unclear
View5: Fidelity is a good company because it offers a ton of benefits and the salaries are fair and they treat employees well.
View7: Job functions for the most part are very ambiguous and employees are left to try to figure out (or carve out) how they to shape their functions. I worked in a department that service multiple Fidelity companies and was in charge of trying to figure out prioritization for multiple projects. Decisions were being made all over the place and constantly overriding previous agreements. I know that is how most large companies work but Fidelity takes it to a different level.

Title: Good company, not great
View5: Culture is great here and the company really tries to maintain a higher retention rate by building careers internally. They want to see you advance. Work life balance depends directly on the nature of your job.
View7: Upper management has been trying to improve by having reorganizations. This causes a lot of confusion and discomfort among associates. On boarding process can be a lot better. Minimal training was offered and little team building exercises. Personally speaking, my onboarding process was nonexistent because management was tied in with reorganizations and retention rate was low.

Title: Director
View5: Once a really great company, good benefits, some places have onsite Gym, cafeteria selections fit full range of food choices, if you are motivated you can take training classes
View7:
No loyalty 
In the 12 years i worked here i was NEVER once asked whether or not my manager was doing a good job.  There is really no tangible process for promotion, pay increases, bonuses.  If your manager likes you and you have a decent relationship then you get raises & bonuses.   I have never seen so many mgmt people afraid of conflict, afraid to tell employees they were not performing, etc.  The culture is one of fear to tell the truth, when people are asked they do not tell the truth because they fear retaliation.   I personally sat in a senior mgmt meeting and heard a Sr. VP, tell another manager to tell her minions to stop sending feedback to Sr. Mgmt, they may ask for it but dont really want to hear it.  When they downsized a few yrs back they laidoff some of the best most knowledgeable talent, i suspect bcuz they made the most money, but many left were clueless which meant that those remaining had to do twice as much and cover the clueless.   When employees are having heart attacks in their cubicles something is very wrong

Title: World Class Organization
View5: Fidelity invests lots of training, resources and time for new employees. Not everyone makes it in the first 8-10 weeks of training and they either quit because they find out that the job is not for them or they fail the Series 7/63 tests. It's a great feeling of accomplishment after you get through the initial training program and pass the financial licensing exams and you feel like you belong to a strong reputable company. From there you can move on to other departments like sales, stock and options trading, 401K investment guidance, pensions, operations, management, training and education, support desk help, compliance, etc depending on your interests. Everyone that I worked with in management was very supportive of my goals in wanting to move up in the company or try different areas of the business. As long as you have a plan and show interest in another position, they help you secure the position by working with the managers of the group or department that you are interested in. The 401K/health/reimbursement benefits are the added incentives to staying with Fidelity long term and the 401K matching/profit sharing is the best in the financial services industry, maybe even most of corporate America.
View7: The downsides to Fidelity is that you are working in a call center and sometimes day to day activity can become boring, mundane and very repetitive. Some managers are known to micromanage when you can take breaks including how often and they monitor operational metrics very closely (number of calls taken, average handle time and how much time after every phone call). They are very persistent about coaching on what is the best language to approach each customer, sometimes to a point of emphasizing perfection. If you are there for 5 yrs or more, base salary becomes stagnant and it becomes more challenging to apply for positions and roles that offer more compensation potential because the people in those positions have been there for 10 years or more.

Title: Catch 22 - Internal movement limited to deep subject matter expertise, but want to move to grow
View5:
Profit Sharing
401k match
Private company - no earnings expectations with the street
View7:
Fidelity's biggest competition is internal.  Siloed businesses only interested in their vertical.
Culture wants speed and execution, but risk taking and failure is not an option.
Everyone wants 100% of data and details before decisions can be made - nothing truly agile.

Title: Bureaucratic & Political
View5: Satisfaction at Fidelity is all about your manager and the your SVP.  If you get lucky with a strong manager and SVP Fidelity is a decent employer.
View7: The culture is highly political and performance evaluations are not based on merit.  My new SVP has a political agenda to promote females and thereby promote herself.

Title: Good place to start right out of college, but rampant incompetence
View5:
- There is a big focus and investment on education, training employees
- There is a strong focus on diversity and Employee Resource Groups
- Colleagues are friendly, managers treat their employees with respect and kindness.
- The company has a new talent pipeline in its internship program, and a great bootcamp program for new hires. The company's best employees come from this program.
- Embrace of Agile Scrum and Kanban
- Upper technical management is staffed by good, eager, and talented people that want to change things for the better.
- If you are a go-getter, there is much opportunity to make it up the ranks.
View7:
- Low technical talent: The company uses about 45% contractor workforce (even in the US). A lot of technical knowledge leaves company every year. Huge turnover rate in the technical ranks. Many of these contractors have low skills that do not match their resume.
- While it is good the company gives people low on experience a chance (sometimes the first chance of their career), the flip-side is that there are a lot of people that don't know what they are doing. Huge brain drain in the early 2000s at this company that the company never fully recovered from (many firms in the same industry experienced the same).
- Very incompetent teammates. "Very" with a capital "V". You have to constantly get on people just to get the work done that they promised to do. Sometimes takes weeks to find an administrator to grant access or turn a setting on. Sometimes requirements are completely misunderstood.
- Agile scrum meetings go on for too long. Oftentimes, over half a day is spent in meetings. The prevailing attitude at the company is that strictly adhering to Agile ceremonies will magically get the Sprint work done.
- Non-technical people are scrum masters (SMs): Although it is technically not a requirement, it is a bit of an obstacle to have non-technical people as SMs for Software Engineering work. Despite my 17 years of experience as a Software Engineer, I often found myself being contradicted by SMs with less than 5 years experience, and zero years as a Software Developer. Sadly, most (but not all) SMs have very little interest in understanding the the work they were SMing for.
- You ask a question, and people are either too busy to answer, or nobody knows the answer. Either way, You are basically on your own to figure things out

Title: A Great Place To Work
View5: At FMR, you are given a lot of freedom to do your job.  FMR also provides tremendous access to resources.  Since it is such a large institution, FMR has superior access to management.  Job performance is quantifiable.
View7: It is a very large  corporation, so it is difficult to make a name for yourself.  Additionally, the job is very independent, so you must be comfortable initiating conversation with other members of the firm.  In isolated instances, there is a lack of interaction among team members.

Title: Stable company with many opportunities for growth.
View5: Fidelity recognizes individual contribution - hard work pays generally pays off with increased bonuses and profit sharing.  It is a large company so you can be pidgeon holed if you don't work hard to expand your sphere of influence.  Over the years, Fidelity has tried hard to treat employees fairly.
View7: It is easy to just come and go and meet the minimum requirements of your job.  You'll have stability but will be quickly marginalized as a serious playmaker.

Title: Short and simple
View5: They take care of the employees. Great training. Laid back environment at branches. There is a lot of training. I traveled to california and texas to get the right training i needed for my job. It was far better than just having someone teach me in the branch.
View7:
They are quick to let employees go. There are a lot of people willing to work for less so they have a revolving door of employees. 

The branches push contests quite frequently. You may be urged to sell something in order to meet some sort of goal, even though it might not be right for the customer.

Title: Good leadership program
View5:
- Easy going, casual dress
- Laid back work atmosphere 
- Cyclic installation schedules (free at times, busy at others - this can be seen as a pro or con)
- Excellent on-site facilities
- Intern program is excellent, group-intern speaker sessions give you a lot of insight about the company
View7:
- Stagnation in the technology department after the tech boom in the 90's
- Lots of middle managers leads to lots of reporting (and reporting about reporting) 
- Lots of activity up top leads to many organizational changes

Title: Enter at your own risk...
View5: Great benefits - fantastic retirement package, company match, health, dental, various commuter and fitness reimbursement type offers. Great brand name, so looks good on resume
View7: Otherwise.... mostly cons. The culture is one in which (fair disclaimer: in my division. FMR is obviously a huge company, things may very well work differently elsewhere), in which employees are expected to essentially forgo personal life. The company has a rep as a bit of a meat-grinder for a reason...

Title: Challenging culture
View5: Fidelity employs some of the brightest, most innovative and dedicated people in the industry.  The culture is high energy and fast-paced so you'll never be bored.  Most people are willing to step up and share their expertise while fighting fires (if you know which group/s and which person, within that group, to ask).  Most people in support/ops are required to work an excessive number of hours each week (usually 60+) but you can learn more at Fidelity in 1 year than you would learn at another investment firm.
View7: The culture can be highly stressful at the best of times but numerous Reductions in Force (RIF's) over the past several years have impacted morale and compounded the stress level.  Entire groups have been RIFed, regardless of the criticality of their function or their individual performance ratings.  I know of numerous high-quality, highly respected people who have been let go as part of the on-going re-org, so performance, dedication and a good review rating won't save you from a RIF if your group is a focus.  Reviews for bonuses and raises seem to be based less on performance than on the corporate review paradigm, which dictates that a manager must assign a specific number of satisfactory, sub-standard and outstanding ratings (example - a manager with 10 direct reports can be given the directive that of their 10 direct reports, they must have 1 employee rated sub-standard and only 1 rated outstanding.  The other 8 must be rated Proficient/Satisfactory, regardless of performance.  Due to Fido having such a high number of exceptionally bright and dedicated people, who step up when they see a problem, it is fairly common to find groups where the majority (if not all) of the team members deserve an Outstanding rating.  With the existing paradigm, only 1 can receive that rating and receive a fair bonus/raise.  Eight of the others will receive a Proficient/Satisfactory rating and receive very small bonus/raises.  And one of those 10 people will receive a rating of  N ('Needs Improvement'), which prohibits a raise/bonus and tags them as a probability for the next RIF - and you can't internally transfer if you received a rating of N).  Promotions are also tied to review ratings.  Before I left, the policy was that an employee had to receive 2 consecutive reviews of above Satisfactory/Proficient to qualify for a possible promotion.  That did not ensure they would receive the promotion, it just meant that they qualified for a possible promotion, if one was available.  There is little to no work/life balance and based on the review paradigm, there is no financial incentive for regularly sacrificing your personal life to protect their reputation and business interest.

Title: Great place to start out from after undergrad
View5:
Working within the strategy function:
- Gain the full consulting skill set (analytics - quantitative and qualitative, presentation and communication to senior management, working in team settings)
- Be exposed to senior management within firm (BU heads etc.)
- Have great in breadth and depth in financial services industry (retail / institutional asset management, retail / institutional brokerage, retirement services / administration)
View7:
- Very political work environment: it's all about who you knew and who would go to bat for you
- Very hierarchical / many management layers

Title: Difficult work but you feel appreciated
View5: Market or better pay, good benefits, and open feeling office space.  Lavish christmas parties and more than most company fun events.  A "Nice" place to work where nobody is allowed to look too scruffy. You can't wear jeans or baseball caps or certain items of clothing.You can feel the money. If you are interested in understanding how big brokerage  companies like Fidelity manage to keep track of it all you would like it.  You usually feel engaged. There is a lot of software development so it's not always legacy applications if you work in technology.  Generally you will be thanked for your work and told you are doing well (unless you suck at your job) . There are lots of kitchens scattered around and there is lots of free food there often leftover from being served in meetings. Whenever you have to  work nights you often get to order out free food.It's a cube farm, no way around it. Cube walls are not too low but not as high as other places.
View7: You have to work hard there, sometimes nights and weekends, there is a bit of the workaholic culture there. Sometimes for extended periods for a big important project. The job security tends to wander with the market. When it's up you're okay, if the economy is really bad watch out. Sometimes people seem a little mean, like they don't screen for it very well in employees,  You always have a long walk from the parking lot.  Much better to be a contractor so you don;t have to work extra hours as much.

Title: Entry level learning experience
View5: Licensing, great benefits if you have a family. Always friendly folks that aren't cutthroat finance people
View7: Slow company, low pay. Management gives the appearance of taking advice and change, but seems to want to keep everyone happy and may not actually act on suggestions

Title: Overall Fidelity is a good company to work for, however not all departments are run the same.
View5: Fidelity pays well and has great benefits, including generous time off and provides a year-end bonus based on performance.  The company also has a year end celebration every year, which is always well done.
View7: Upper management does not always recognize problems that may be in the department.    An awful lot of company politics.  No cafeteria can make it expensive if you don't bring your lunch.

Title: It is not what they make it seem
View5: The have great benefits, they offer different reimbursement programs, and get a lotbof vacation days
View7: You get an occurance for using your paid sick time. You movemnt through the company is based on politics not your actual ability to perform the role. Your manager has to sign off on everything so if they dont like you then you are screwed. There is a lack of integrity.

Title: Good company, awful role
View5: If you are successful, and that's a big if, then it should open up a lot of options for you with the company. If not, you should consider leaving. This role is also really good at teaching the art of selling
View7: This role has goals that are almost triple industry standards. And whether or not they realize, it doesn't set up for a good experience for the employee.

Title: Financial Representative
View5:
Good way to get licensed. Extremely focused on making sure you pass the 7/63. Free material, a retake if your scores are close to passing and an overall good atmosphere in training..

very boring, but very thorough.

Ok job for a fresh college graduate, but other than that I would advise one to stay away.

Good food on campus. They hire good cooks to feed us while work. Decent pricing too
View7:
Once you get licensed and "get on the floor" that is when the trouble begins.

The job is extremely boring. Dealing with people calling every second of the day from about 9-4pm is horrible. Most of the time you are resetting passwords, not actually doing anything finance related. And when you do get the chance to do finance related things, all you do is enter trade tickets and hit send.

In training, they sold to us that we are "financial professionals," however, I would beg to differ. The only difference between "service associates" and a regular CSR rep is that at Fidelity, you are licensed.

The job sucks. It sucks your soul. It is not a fun environment. IF you enjoy  answering calls all day for $16-20 dollars a hour, have at it.

**Also, it should be noted that promotion to the sales side is extremely hard. There are 200 apps a year for 25-50 sales jobs. You have to kiss major butt and kill your metrics to get ahead. It is just too many people applying for those jobs. Managers will say that there are so many positions you can work in, but in reality they are all the same job, with a x<5000 in pay differential in the service side.

AS OTHER REVIEWS HAVE SAID, ONCE YOU ARE HIRED IN A PHONE SITE, THE CHANCE OF LEAVING TO A BRANCH OR TO ANOTHER DIVISION OF FIDELITY (fund management, analysis, etc). IS EXTREMELY SLIM. PLEASE KNOW THIS.

Title: VP of Finance
View5: I only have positive thoughts about Fidelity which is a great company to work for.  It provided me with the latitude to perform my role in an independent and professional manner and rewarded me generously for my efforts.
View7: There are very few thoughts I have on how I might have helped Fidelity improve its business decisions.  One of these would be to minimize turnover of key staff and provide more stability at the most senior levels of the company to ensure that its strategic goals and objectives remain on track over time.

Title: Great entry level opportunities
View5: Fidelity has great entry level opportunities, especially for recent college graduates and it's easy to advance once you start working for the company. The benefits are great and the work environment is top notch!
View7: Phone roles are the same as most other call centers as far as the customers go, but the company is very employee oriented so they won't allow clients to abuse reps on the phone for the sake of a good survey like other places.

Title: HNW Associate
View5: Great benefits including profit sharing, high 401k match, student loan payoff and tuition reimbursement, matching gifts to education, fitness reimbursement, computer reimbursement...
View7: High stress, mandatory overtime, micromanagement, limited career and location mobility, politics of who you know rather than what you know/can do...

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Benefits are good. Student loan repayment, 7% 401 match and a very flexible schedule.
View7: For people like myself who crave interpersonal connection and helping people, the job will feel like you've sold your soul. Make no mistake, this is a call center, plain and simple. Many people are not mentally suited for it, and the role habitually burns out incredibly talented and valuable people.

Title: Fidelity is a good company to work for
View5: Trustworthy company, professional atmosphere, good benefits (401K match, profit sharing, bonuses and more), good people.  In Covington KY location - on site medical office, full cafeteria (breakfast, grill, deli, salad bar, entrees and Starbucks coffee), on site gym, no dress code, beautiful campus
View7: Can be hard to get hired, temp if you have to, but don't give up if it's what you want.   Best way to get in the door without temping is to be willing to work a phone shift.  If you can get in the door, you can have a fulfilling career here.

Title: The organizational equivalent of HazMat
View5: Really great people, can be easy to excel if you have people who support you , a lot of innovative ideas if you can get your hands on them
View7: A lot of reorganization right now that’s causing a ton of inefficiency and instability. HR acts as major gate keepers and prevents top performers from moving upwards— yet leaders don’t know why there’s attrition

Title: Great company to start in the financial services industry, and have a long term career as well.
View5: Training, their L&D department is awesome. The trainers teach you what you need to know to start. Fidelity supports your continued growth if you want to though. Benefits are amazing! Low deductibles on Health plans and on High Deductible plans they give you money each year for your HSA. They have 10% profit sharing on your gross if you are hourly, 7% 401k match (yes 17% total, you read that right). Their fringe benefits are amazing, too many to list. Sales bonuses are based on how happy the clients are in my role and then you get extra on meeting or exceeding department goals. My boss is supportive as well as the team and if you need help with sales  language or tactics there are specialists that help you. Basically you can succeed if you want to.
View7: If you are not top of the pack you may find it hard to advance to the next role, but thats how sales works. To get to Branch offices from the phone sites is sometimes difficult, but if you are willing to relocate it can make it easier to make the transition. When you first start out you don't have as much vacation, about three weeks, but by year five you finally get to about 6 weeks.

Title: Inconsistent leaders
View5: Benefits, 401k plan, vacation days increased with seniority.
View7: Turnover of managers, not uncommon to have a manager change in less than a year. Standards for managers was quite varied as was their expectations. Manager training program started and abruptly stopped, focus of leadership changed regularly. Took advantage of manager apprentices, they have the same responsibilities as a manager without a pay change. One can be an apprentice for a year or more without pay change, then they rotate another apprentice in and take advantage of them.  Upper management and directors also changed frequently.

Title: Great company, but in a tough situation due to the market
View5: Fidelity is a blue chip company which looks great on your resume. It's also large enough to provide plenty of opportunities for growth internally. If you are a self starter and deliver results, you can advance quickly.
View7: While most private companies are somewhat protected from the pressures of the market, Fidelity is not due to the nature of it's business. There is a very strong focus on cost cutting right now. The company has more office politics going on than other companies I have worked at. Constant reorganizations.

Title: Fidelity has its challenges just like any other place, but the strong upside remains...
View5: Smart people, strong culture of accomplishment, diverse lines of business, good environment to learn and grow as a leader
View7: lack of strong planning and business discipline; fundamental changes at the top of the house have not yet trickled down to the next level of leadership, can get very political and turf-oriented at times

Title: It's a great company going through some painful changes.
View5: The company is highly profitable; compensation is on the generous side; there is a lot of diversity among the people; there are many opportunities and challenges for growth; the benefits are generous; there are opportunities to be an entrepreneur.
View7: Current and prospective employees should be careful in the short term as the transition is causing a lot of turmoil. You can get purged no matter how good you are. Some of the generous benefits are being trimmed back, such as the pension plan.

Title: Case Manger/ Basic Financial Planning
View5: Great training and very good prep for sec licenses. Truly is a merit based company and if you perform well you can get promoted very quickly. Some of the best facilities that I have even worked in and have some many job opportunities at the Westlake center.
View7: Overall the pay is probably somewhat less then others companies but the 410k matching and other benefits make up for that and most likely create an equal compensation package.

Title: This company breeds mediocrity.  Cares nothing for your professional growth
View5: Very good benefits. 100% match of 401k up to 7%. Decent annual bonus opportunity and about 10% salary profit sharing. No vision coverage however.  What they don't pay you in salary they try to make up for it with benefits. They fail.
View7: Absolutely no career or personal advancement. This company is content keeping employees in an entry-level position with entry-level pay for 6+ years.  They do not recognize talent, hard work, or those deserving of a promotion.  Very beaurocratic.  Very strict "quotas" on how many people get raises and promotions each year.  As a result, unfortunately, the rewards go to the brownnosers and suck ups.

Title: Best decision ever!
View5: Many firms won't give you a salary while they sponsor you to get your broker's license- Fidelity does and also provides a very thorough study course.  Supports employees immensely.  Love the people- great environment.  You might think call center and think of Office Space, but it's nothing like that.  So much fun.  Lots of opportunities for promotions and bonuses.
View7: Doesn't pay the highest, but when combined with all the benefits and bonuses, I think it's worth it.

Title: Great company to work for.
View5: I worked in the Workplace Investing business managing corporate 401k clients.  My business units, ECM and Mid market both functioned as their own groups, which personalized the feel of the corporate structure without getting lost in the big company.  The people are mostly very high performers and driven to exceed expectations for their clients and the business.
View7: As the operations departments continue to streamline their processing, the staff is getting slim, institutional knowledge is being lost and support functions necessary to keep the client satisfied are diminishing.  This puts a larger burden on the relationship manager to keep the client satisfied.

Title: Typical Corporate America
View5: They have great benefits, paid time off, and great training to get licensed for the financial exams. Thy also have some 4 10-hour shifts you can work instead of 5 8-hour shifts.
View7: Moving up in the company is completely up to whether or not your manager likes you. Until you move up you're forced to work in service, at the bottom of the pole. You are also typically required to work weekend and nights starting out. Low pay compared to other financial companies. Only work here if you're ok with sitting at a desk answering phone calls all day.

Title: Over worked under Paid
View5: Family oriented, smart co workers, great managers, great experience and lots of knowledge to be had if you want it.
View7: PAY SUCKS, will suck the life out of you, poor work/life balance, most teams are hard to deal with.

Title: Opportunity Cost
View5: Incredible employee benefits. Kind, caring supportive colleagues. Access to education and cutting edge resources and training.
View7: Extremely low possibility of advancement once additional training- CFP, CFA, MBA is acquired if acquired as an existing employee. The Company is organized with recent college grads in mind who have no life experience. The structure does not work for mature, experienced, tenured professionals to move ahead.

Title: Great benefits
View5: Great place for a recent college grad, pays well and has great benefits for something that is entry level and looking to find a good job right out of college.
View7: They say they hire from within, which is true but it's really hard to find a role you are qualified for even from within. The work becomes monotonous and you can get into a rut. They base a lot of bonuses on surveys from participants but don't take into account if that survey is actually for you or for someone else.

Title: Overall Great Company, Truly Hampered By Floor Managers
View5: The total compensation including benefits and 401k contributions is good. As a phone representative the number one benefit is the colleagues that share the role and the customers we get to hear from. Really enjoy the interactions with the diverse active and retiree populations!
View7:
Huge downside at the Durham NC location. Many of the floor managers are unprofessional and constantly an impediment to helping the customer and helping employees develop. This is the first and only organization that I have worked for that will actually discourage you from applying to an open position within the firm. Has happened on a few occasions now and so appears to be the norm where to apply you need to go through current manager and they never follow up to discuss or confirm if an intent letter was forwarded.

Most of the managers I have interacted with were never able to answer serious inquiries on customer accounts and push back greatly when a customer requests to speak to them. Very sad to think I could be treated that way when calling in as a customer.

These same individuals are commonly loud in the call center environment where it is common to not be able to hear the customer on the line. Just recently I had to put a customer on hold while doing a death notification because I did not feel it appropriate for the caller to hear the loud laughing from a manager and team leads. This is a very common occurrence at this location. Finally, quite a few give me the impression that they do not do much at all during the day besides going to the gym (1+ hr), out to lunch (1 hr), listening to calls, and meetings. Back to the serious customer issues, have only had one manager that ever seemed to care about the issue and helped to get it resolved.

At this time it does appear this situation as a whole is why I will leave Fidelity and transfer all funds immediately thereafter.

Title: Good place to work. Low relative pay
View5: Good work environment. Easy going. Not overwhelming.  Friendly people. Good bosses.  Nice campus. Has a gym and cafeteria. Great benefits.
View7: Very low relative pay. About 20-30% less than comparable positions at other companies. The idea, I think, is that they make up for it by having good benefits  (which they do) but really the benefits don't come anywhere close to the benefit of having making 50-60 vs 40. Also promotions are mostly "sideways" and come with negligible pay raises.

Title: Can be a great company
View5: Amazing benefits and really trying to change the culture for it's employees.  10% profit sharing, 7% match in 401k, great insurance benefits, and continuously looking to get better.
View7: Autonomy is disappearing.  Micro management is growing and compensation is becoming more elusive.  They like many companies in the industry are feeling the pinch and employees are feeling it.  The work environment is getting more stressful and work life balance for some roles is going away.  Post DOL sentiment has gone down in my coworkers.

Title: Used to be a Great Company
View5: Some of the smartest people to work with anywhere in the industry, reasonably good pay, very good benefits, fairly generous work-from-home policy
View7: VERY bureaucratic management system, extreme "meeting mentality" - nothing gets done with several worthless meetings, upper management no longer cares deeply about the average employee (a break from longstanding Johnson tradition)

Title: Great firm, but not divisions created equal
View5: Great benefits, great locations / office conditions.  Smart and hardworking associates that usually are willing to collaborate.  Technological and product leader.
View7: Internal candidates for promotion and lateral career changes are rarely considered. HR is terrible in this regard. Values and senior mgmt core beliefs are not practiced by middle mgmt as there are too many personal agendas and constant infighting.

Title: Forward thinking company
View5:
- Inclusive
- Plenty of room to move throughout the company
- College grad friendly
- Diversity
- PTO
- 401k
- Health/Pet Insurance
- Great pay
View7:
- In the tech space, you'll work more than you imagined. 
- Some corporate restrictions on employees (e.g. purchasing a sticker to your favorite political party requires corporate approval) due to specific guidelines.

Title: Great place to start, but staying there may be a mistake for your career
View5: Great place to start a career in the financial industry.  Great training and they pay for licensing
View7: Fidelity claims to be a "meritocracy" but that is simply not the case

Title: Very controlling place to work, political, not fun
View5: I worked at FITSCO (which is no longer in SLC) servicing 403b accounts.  The only bright spot about the company is that you get to learn a lot about mutual funds and about investment products.
View7: Management is incompetent.  Management says Fidelity is a "meritocracy" which is not true.  Very political in order to get ahead.  Managers don't have your best interests at heart.  You will do the same thing over and over again until you want to throw-up (no job rotation).

Title: very stressful work
View5: The reasons to work at Fidelity are that you get a great benefit package, a pretty place to work, and can meet some good friends.
View7: The downside of Fidelity is that during the downturn of the economy, they quickly let a large number of people go without any particular reason. They opted to cut their resources before cutting some of the extra spending that they do. Think about that indicator of the loyalty that they show people who have dedicated their lives to the company.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to work.
View5: Fidelity is a fair company and encourages the employees to be creative and drive change in the organization.  It has had an entrepreneurial spirit for many years but recently the trend is shifting to "driving only the numbers".
View7: Constant consolidation and cost cutting.  Do more with less.  The more you cut the more successful you are.

Title: Leap Associate Data Engineer
View5: They pay to train you at their brand new facilities in North Carolina in the field of your choice. After, they place you on a team they think best suited to your strengths.
View7: The place in upper levels of management are not inspiring. Thus far, they have been disorganized and not ready when they show up to work at 8 am.

Title: Mezza, mezza
View5: Great benefits, just can't be beat...
View7: If you get stuck in a group where there are some snobby people, look out, and get out as quickly as possible. Never stab anyone in the back because the next day they could be your manager.

Title: Giant companies are a mixed bag
View5:
There are incredible, bright people
There are plenty of exciting challenges
Great benefits, bonus, 401k opportunities, etc
Honest desire by management to continuously improve
View7:
There are ... less incredible, not-quite-as-bright people
The challenges are there because there's a lot of ancient cruft
You might find higher base pay elsewhere
Entrenched financial companies are conservative by nature and bold ideas are hard to shepherd into reality

Title: Great company to start your career
View5:
Private Company
A lot of opportunities
Great benefits
Gym on site at certain locations
Decent work/life balance
View7:
You have to play the game for high pay increases. Each department is different and will cap your pay increase.

The important roles are in Boston. Don't let others fool you

Title: I have had a long tenure at the company and have had many opportunities as the firm has grown and changed.
View5: My managers in the past have been flexible and reasonable. The 401k match and profit sharing are great benefits. Younger employees are taking advantage of the new College loan benefit program.
View7: Our management and employees in many departments don’t reflect our customer base. I believe this will erode our ability to connect with our customers over time. We will build solutions that will miss the mark.

Title: Working at FIS is a great experience
View5: Salary and benefits are good. There’s plenty of opportunities for exploring things.
View7: It’s very slow paced in terms of innovation. The management is not very technologically aware and struggle to catch up with industry. Makes unwise decision on technology direction. On business side there’s next to zero innovation.

Title: Great environment and Learning Experience
View5: Lots to learn and they will give you an opportunity to start working on real projects instead of "Intern side projects".
View7: Luck of the draw with managers and teams. Some teams have very involved managers while some don't. Also there can be bigger teams of interns assigned to a single manager while some interns might be the only one on their team. It is very easy to become isolated there if you are the only intern on your team.

Title: Fidelity used to be a great place to work
View5: As an employee, you get cheap access to Fidelity's products, such as brokerage account, mutual funds, etc.  If the assets are under Fidelity management, you get it cheaper.  For example, a person with an HSA account at another firm pays annual fees, because Fidelity runs your HSA, you don't get hit with fees.  Also, Fidelity spends a ton of money on technology, so you will have nice desktop hardware and software.  The facilities are generally nice and well stocked with coffee and tea.
View7:
As an employee, you are forced to use Fidelity's products, e.g., you can't have a brokerage account anywhere else or a financial advisor if he or she places trades and if you buy other company's mutual funds, you have to report it.  
The culture is almost like a fuedal manor with a benevolent lord.  The employees are expected to show tremendous loyalty to the firm.  To hear some talk, there is no other place they could ever work.  This used to be okay when Mr. J was more involved and the managment reciprocated some of that loyalty.  But it just isn't the case anymore.  At any given time you could have your job moved to a cheaper state, India, or just plain eliminated.  Sr. managment communication is full of sports metaphores and lofty vision statements, but surprisingly silent about long term plans related to employees such as site closures or changes to business lines.  Increasingly we have stealth layoffs.  The only way you hear about whole areas being eliminated is if you happen to have a friend that works there.  People just disappear off the company directory.  At least in 2001 and 2002 they bothered to tell everyone what was going on.  Lastly, it has become almost impossible to move internally.  They recently added another HR layer between a candidate and a hiring manager, so now if you want to post you have to go through your manager, an "internal staffing rep" who will decide whether you should even be thinking about moving, a staffing rep who will decide if you should be considered for the position, and then finally the hiring manager.  Most of the time the hiring manager never even sees your resume.  If you do happen to get that far, the hiring manager is prohibited from making an offer until he or she has gotten a reference from your current manager.  If you do apply for a position and you aren't being considered, no one ever bothers to tell you.

Title: Historically good company struggling with change
View5: There are a variety of opportunities and moving between business units is encouraged, so you get to build on your skill set.  Historically Fidelity has been at the forefront of inovation and has been a market leader.  The company has strong business ethics.
View7: The business has moved into a "mature" phase.  It's more concerned with protecting business than expanding business.  It used to feel more exciting to work there than it has the past few years.

Title: Good and bad
View5: Pay is decent for young college grads; also good benefits.  401k - they potentially match up to 17% after some tenure,  Most of the people you work with are decent people.  Almost everyone realizes it's not the most exciting or fulfilling job; it's like everyone's in the same boat.  We can always connect with each other based upon bad calls we've had or some worthless reprimand from management.
View7:
Since the first day I've been there, it's felt like we're in elementary school or some nice form of a concentration camp.  You are almost told verbatim what to say.  The call model is a decent model, but management needs to understand that not every call is worth the whole effort.  Not client needs our guidance services, not everyone is an active trader.  

Also, there is a large amount of knowledge that is needed.  Not that it is necessarily a bad thing, but the environment is horrible.  There are several different computer programs we use for various things.  One for trading, one for problem resolution, one for money movement.  A small mistake or overlook is looked heavily down upon.  If, God forbid, you make a "trade error," you are reprimanded even if it had little to no impact on the company (I've also had trade errors that made the company money).  

Even if the mistake was question that 99 out of 100 people don't know about how our internal systems work, there is supposedly always an answer in OLR.  It stands for OnLine Reference.  It's basically the Fidelity bible for trading and service.  Problem is that OLR must have been written by either a mad robot or Ned Johnson himself.  It's not written well at all and even sometimes contain mistakes that we still "should have known."  

We are given several metrics that we must meet that grade us on various call aspects; these include: average call time, scheduling efficiency (how closely you fit into a minute by minute schedule daily), and % of time either in available to talk to on a call.  

As reps we are expected to "put the customer first" at all times.  They should really rephrase that to "put the customer first only on that phone call."  After the call ends, so does any contact that we have with that person.  Why is this a problem?  About 25% of the calls you take are problems that may take awhile to fix.  There is no researching or following up on problems after the call.  Managers criticize calling back customers.  

Also, about 92% of managers are really horrible people.

Title: Your Experience at Fidelity Varies Depending on Your Manager; CONSTANT reorganization
View5: Benefits, including tuition reimbursement, 401K match, and annual bonuses are excellent; for the most part, it is a stable place to work, earn a good salary and interact with nice, smart people.
View7:
If you decide to work at Fidelity, make sure you like change -- there lots of it here (or Kaisan as the chairman calls it) especially within leadership.  Often times a new manager is brought in with a new "strategic vision" and you basically discard all the work you've done over the past 9 months and start over...this can happen again and again and can be frustrating...

I worked in several different business units during my 9 years with the company, and because the company is simply so huge, I found that if you have a good manager, you'll have a pleasant experience and receive appropriate performance and financial reviews and feedback, etc. BUT if your manager is one of many who are not good at being managers or for whatever reason don't "click" with you, it can become a miserable experience. HR tends to side with management, and it's extremely difficult to remove an incompetent or toxic boss from Fidelity.  Normally, you can weed these individuals out during your interview, but as I mentioned previously, Fidelity re-orgs so frequently, 90% of individuals hired end up working for different managers and doing different work than they signed on to do.  

You need to be prepared to roll with the punches and have a very flexible nature if you choose to work at Fidelity.

As far as promotional opportunity, there's no set rule such as after 2 years, you get promoted - i've seen individuals be promoted after 6 months or never promoted after many, many years.  Because your individual manager basically exclusively drives the promotion process, making sure he/she likes you is key.  When it comes to advancement, doing good work is often secondary to building a good relationship with your direct manager.

Title: Do NOT trust them
View5: If you are lazy and dim, you might be overpaid by a large amount long enough to accumulate real wealth. The name carries weight on your resume. Because of the very high turnover, you might get promoted into a vacancy, but will not have to worry about the pressure of higher pay.
View7: Whatever pay they promise will be total fiction. Layoffs happen monthly(for the last 2 years!). Most everyone is trying to get you fired, especially at bonus time. Bonuses, raises, and long term comp are often cut even when the company has record profits. Senior managers live in fear of the Family and will throw you under the bus if it helps them. We have a saying: the bullet that will kill you has already been fired, it is just a matter of when it will catch up to you. And I say this as someone who has been successful here and still am. Politics exist everywhere, but this place is a viper pit. Many, many successful execs have been hired and fired in under a year simply because the old guard decided to poison the well on them. Unless you started here twenty years ago or are part of The Family, you are dead. No manager will ever extend his personal political capital to save you.

Title: Fidelity Investments/NFS
View5:
Total benefits package ( base salaries are  low and not competitive but the profit sharing and matching make up for it)
Employees can participate in the share program 
friendly atmosphere
View7:
Senior management has no clear direction
Too many organizational changes 
Few advancement/growth opportunities as current managers stay in their jobs for decades.
No training opportunities in NY.  
Since 2007, there have been major layoffs, no doubt more to come.

Title: Was "Office Space" based on this place??
View5:
Great company/reputation for your resume. Very nice 401k match and profit sharing. Bonus's are great if you're in the top 5-10% of the company.  I believe Senior management is very good. The Johnson family has been good.

Kathy Murphy was a great addition to the company.
View7:
I find there is a complete lack of respect for the regular employee.  Very low pay and bonus's for most employees. As you move up with in the company a culture of superiority is fostered and encouraged. You have royalty and the peasants. 

Most middle management  has been brainwashed and this is their only professional experience, thus they think and act a like.....very scary if you've worked anywhere else.  If you ever express an opinion or disagree with those folks.....you're permanently branded.  You can do that with the highest levels of management and it would be respected (they are far away and only get to visit a few times a year). 

Employee turnover is unbelievably high (this is good for creating opportunity), however, it's a reflection of how employees are treated.  Management encourages people to be given warnings  to increase job performance vs. rewarding them.   

e.g. You have 10 business goals. You could be doubling your results with nine of them, however, you're just below goal with one that's not up on the list of importantance.  Instead of averaging out your overall performance, they will focus on that one thing again and again. The person who just barely made the goal with all 10 is far better than you are.

The company will waste money and spend lavishly all for show but a great majority of employees don't benefit from this.

Title: Fidelity has a great internship program.
View5: Fidelity has a firm reputation in Boston. Many companies value that they are a conservative firm that has weathered the financial crisis very well. They are a leader in what they do. They provide some of the best compensation then other comparable firms around.
View7: Fidelity may not have the nationwide recognition for being a private company so it may not feel the same as it would feel if you were working for a publicly held company.

Title: Wonderful place to start and grow; now at a ceiling
View5: Job Diversity. Many opportunities to move around.  Ability to interact with many different businesses, people, walks of life. Fantastic employees - brilliant, innovative, passionate! Strong ties to community. Great salary and benefits.
View7: Recent (last 3 years) Market downturns, recession, and significant turnover in upper management coupled with major layoffs have seriously dampened morale.. the "IT Transformation" and 'transparent communications' failed.  New management is now getting settled and there is some optimism that the ship will be led by a strong leader and things forgotten and sour will be 'righted'.

Title: I shouldn't complain but there are greener pastures
View5: Pleasant physical environment, short commute, flexible work schedule, work from home option, good benefits package, good raises, good bonuses, good project work.
View7: I feel unappreciated, management seems to only care about themselves advancing and I think they try to keep everyone's salaries low so they can get good bonuses... that is a bad perception of management even though I maybe completely wrong but nonetheless it is what it is.  I've had to ask for promotions and more money rather than being rewarded for the hard work I do.

Title: Great benefits, good starting pay,  great training program, decent incentives...
View5: Company fully trains and pays for you to get your financial licenses. Great health benefits. Company 401k match and profit share is good. Products and services offered by firm are great for customers. Offers tuition reimbursement and gym reimbursements. There are several different positions on the same level to move to within phone sites.
View7:
Micromanagement - clock in and out for your scheduled breaks - metrics to make sure you follow this exactly as planed.
Bonuses are based off of customer surveys of your entire team (not individually) you get % based off phone metrics. 
Metrics are not designed for you to keep the customers interest in mind (ex: if you have to call back to a customer - break between calls to finish a project or do some research for a customers issue - your metrics take a hit). 
You get 3 calls/month monitored and graded on if you said what your manager wanted you to say (can be a little childish at times and not a good measurement  3/500 calls graded) 
Days you will take 60-70 phone calls a day for 8-10hrs (cant focus on customers individually - turn and burn).  
Branch employees are viewed as more valuable to the company and are told to "dump" issues to phone centers (they do not know how to complete any processes for clients). 
Limited movement: most managers in current roles have been there for 10-20 years with no position to move higher into.
Pay is lower then other financial firms in the same market.

Title: Amazing company to work for
View5: Fidelity is a great place to start your career in the financial services industry.    They will take you in, get you licensed, teach you all of the fundamentals, instill great work ethic in you, and always encourage career development.  And with how spread out the company is, you can essentially work anywhere and know you'll have a great job with great people.  The pay is ok, but the benefits are amazing which is truly what helps you setup your retirement savings.  They offer 401(k) match and profit sharing, and that all adds up quickly.  Many people spend their entire working careers at Fidelity.
View7:
There aren't a lot of cons other than some of the people--a lot of middle management can be extremely obnoxious with inflated heads & egos, and they are also the ones who somewhat control your career, besides yourself, of course.  
Fidelity is way too conservative too, which can also be a 'pro.'  And their compliance policies are some of the strictest you'll see anywhere.  
They need to show their employees how much they value them with better pay--a lot of the positions deserve to be paid a bit more for the hard work that is expected, but again, it's hard to complain about that b/c of everything else that is positive about the company.  
Even with its cons, I would recommend Fidelity to anyone who is a solid, sharp, hard working, & committed worker.

Title: Glad for having worked there, glad I'm no longer working there
View5: I loved working for a company that provided excellent customer service.  I felt proud of the products we sold and knew that people really put their energy into doing the best possible thing for the customers.  From the chairman down this was how the company operated.  There was never any question about that.
View7:
There is an unusual culture of politeness, but not in a way that is productive.  People nodding and smiling did not mean your idea had acceptance - outside of the meeting people nodding and smiling could work vigorously to defeat the idea.  The lack of openness and vigorous debate was unusual.  

The compensation at the executive level has a highly variable component based on the company's performance.  People who had been successful getting internal "shares" tended to become more and more protective of their position and their turf.  They had to continue to look good to get more and more shares and would actively undermine anyone with ideas different from theirs.  I think this compensation model stifled innovation.  People who rocked the boat didn't last very long; many of the people I admired in the executive ranks were eliminated during "reductions of force".  There are antibodies to thought diversity that are really difficult to overcome.

I'd thought I'd be a lifer, but lost my job after 15 years during the 2008 recession.  Since then I've had a lot more personal freedom than I experienced working at Fidelity with a more rapid pace of personal growth both consulting and starting a company.  I am far less secure financially, but am happy.

Title: Be careful relocating
View5: Good pay and good co workers.
View7: I was hired to help start futures for retail customers as a Compliance Director and was relocated from Buffalo Grove, IL. to Providence, RI. After 18 months Fidelity decided not to  go forward with futures for retail customers and was laid off. Prior to accepting the position I asked HR and the senior managers that I interviewed with if there was any chance that starting futures would fall through. They said that was impossible.I jokingly said I don't want to live in a teepee with my son. I left a good position at Prudential, sold my home and moved for what amounted to the biggest mistake of my life.

Title: Moving in the wrong direction as they try to capture more of the DC and pension of the retiring baby boomers.
View5: Great Benefits. Client surveys are extremely important, almost too important. Company is strongly client focused and looks out for the clients at most levels. Walking a fine line between companies best interest and clients best interest as of late.
View7:
Lots of shuffling around, but little advancement. I see the same co-workers and management moving around, but little advancement, even at the VP level. Managers are chosen by metrics and "Personal Brand" which is simply hear-say. Advancement is limited to very specific paths. It's rare to see someone move outside of these paths. 
So many managers with so little formal education in management or prior experience. Stunned at lower level management incompetence, although they are powerless to promote change as upper management directives and metrics are etched in stone and beyond reproach as the higher level VP's strive to hit their own metrics at the expense of their departments well being. No happy work balance here. Voluntary/mandatory overtime is the norm, as the company is completely understaffed on the front lines. Do not give your opinion if asked, it can and will be used against your for the rest of your career and becomes part of your "Personal Brand". Better to just enthusiastically agree to whatever one of the many changing priorities for the month, smile and give your whole hearted support.

Title: Excellent Company!
View5: Excellent company, atmosphere, and benefits! Fidelity provides a lot of resources and training which most companies will not invest with new employees. Plus, you can't beat the 7% company match!
View7: Typical issues when working for a large organization. Very structured and lack of control over your day to day. However you are provided with an opportunity for rapid growth and job progression. The more effort you give to Fidelity, the higher your satisfaction.

Title: Left for Fidelity for greener pastures and found them
View5: Good people, interesting work. Great company in general but culture is made by leaders and varies by workgroup.
View7: No consideration for work/family life balance, good old boys club membership required for promotion, too political. Raises and bonus do NOT live up to what the recruiters say, be prepared for no raise for several years.

Title: Financial Associate
View5: Great team environment and the benefits are above industry standard. It's a great place to learn your craft and determine whether this industry is what you want to be apart of or not.
View7: Don't get to excited on pay day because you are going to work very hard for below average pay. Also if you are a great butt kisser (networking) then you will move up quickly. If your not good luck.

Title: Good Opportunity for Growth
View5: Had a lot of great opportunities for growth. They have a great training program, although it almost makes it seem like they want cookie cutter employees. If you're getting licensed they will give you half of your day off too study and pay for the exams.
View7: It seems like everyone is constantly being micromanaged. You're working with people's money so you have to be very careful with what you do. Being on the phones all day is a hassle and people are constantly blaming you for laws or other regulations.

Title: Great place to work
View5: Amazing company with an excellent reputation. It is the leading financial company in the industry in a wonderful place to not only work but invest on your own
View7: There really are no cons. Some rolls our destination rolls with limited development opportunity for career advancement. But there are so many different areas to explore or other locations.   If you keep an open mind you can go far

Title: Good place to work
View5: Great organization with strong foundation, good benefits, great work-life balance, good overall culture, flexibility to move between groups with internal job postings. Overall relaxed atmosphere
View7: Extremely hierarchical place, too many managers, a lot of bureaucracy, things tend to move VERY slow, innovative ideas are not heard unless it's coming from certain folks, less cooperation among different groups, middle management tends to do too many unproductive meetings, less career opportunities unless you jump from one group to other. Not a place for bright individual contributors.

Title: High Net Worth Representative
View5: Excellent training and community atmosphere. They provide a great introductory position and help get the required licenses to be successful.
View7: Constantly on the phone with a strict schedule. They suggest that there will be "off the phone time" but it is never delivered. Mandatory overtime during tax season and manager coaching is negligible.

Title: Lots of politics
View5: Decent benefits, ok pay, somewhat stable environment.
View7: merit increases do not come close to cost of living increases, inflexible work environment, lots of politics, performance and bonus  have no relationship, boring environment in a sea of cubes,. Don't be fooled by the glossy photos, this is corporate America at its best.

Title: Call Center Job. Avoid if you have the choice.
View5:
-They hire good people.  It is nice to assocaite with other representatives when there is time (which is almost never).  Almost every one of my peers had a friendly personality which went a long ways on the bad days (which was most of them).  
-Management was reasonable and let me leave the phone position to an internal operations position before I had been working there one year.
View7:
-First of all, it is a call center job.  The title makes it sound fancier and in the interview they might make you think you are going to be doing a lot more things related to investments than you actually will.  Probably 80% of calls are password resets and simple financial transactions.
-Benefits are good as a percentage, but my base salary was so much lower than what I made after I left that 7%  401k match AND 10% profit sharing was less than 4.5% 401k match at my current company.  There are a lot of benefits that most people don't use that they use to justify how great the benefits are.  Like adoption assistance, tuition reimbursement, college loan assistance.  Just do the math with what you will use and how much you'll get with your salary.  Remember that your base salary grows exponentially with raises and your benefits grow based on that.  Lower base salary now = even lower base salary in 10 years.
-They say they pay for the CFA; they don't.  They specifically told me in the interview that they pay for CFA prep classes.  It also says that in the tuition reimbursement documentation.  There is one stipulation though.  It only qualifies if you take the class from an accredited university.  I don't know of any official universities that offer specific CFA review classes (you take the review classes to prepare for the test, not to get college credit).  I had a friend who took Kaplan review classes and then fought with them for months for the reimbursement and ended up just giving up.  I took and passed two CFA tests while there without a penny going towards the classes.  I don't know if they are intentially tricking people or if nobody knows enought about the CFA to know that the stipulation the put on it makes it null.
-The job itself is miserable.  So many metrics that you have to hit, fielding literally thousands or random questions and complaints.  Constant coaching (telling you what you do wrong).  One time I got "feedback" for saying "no problem" because "problem" is a negative word.  There were days when I would get up, take a shower, get dressed and then call in and go back to sleep because I just couldn't bring myself to go back there again. Some people were ok with it though.  Most, like me, were not.
-Schedules can be bad.  I worked every Saturday after I finished training until I left.  Other people got it much better and others got it much worse.

Title: Have a 2-year exit strategy the day you start working here, and keep it secret.
View5: Great medical benefits, campus is nice, and this is a good place to begin a career. They have tuition reimbursement.
View7: Long term they do not value their employees, and you have to leave the company to get reasonable compensation. Management does not value different opinions even though they pretend to.

Title: Fraternity like culture
View5: The benefits are decent. They offered an HSA account with company contributions (not sure if they still do this), health care and dental at a decent monthly cost, vacation, sick time, and PTO.
View7:
The managers are high strung and a bit too interested in your personal life, almost seemingly desperate to make friends with you.  If you don't want to join your team members or whoever works their for lunch, every working shift, they look at you funny. No, joke the culture is overwhelmingly in your personal business. Not recommended for the reserved type or the "I need a break from you all" type. There's also a company ball (no joke) that they request all of their staff to attend. It's like a company prom, because yes you need to wear a gown or suit. WTF. And if you don't attend, then they look at you funny.

The series 7 training is a joke. The trainers that we had were aweful. One used weird metaphors constantly to teach, and when he was told that his metaphors were confusing he would smile and use additional metaphors to explain the other ones. WTF. The other trainer was on some sort of stimulant, and would constantly speed walk from one side of the room to the other waving his arms around like a monkey swinging on a branch, but missing the branch.

Title: Good company to work for
View5: Depends which group you work for, that will decide your work life balance.
View7: Ppl are promoted to Ppl manager role even when they are not qualified for that role and this can make your life hell, if the mgr turn out to be an non qualified professional.

Title: Headed In The Right Direction
View5:
1. Above Average Pay Mostly. Great Benefits! Great Retirement. Match 100% of your contributions up to 7% after a year and 5-year vesting program. Plus a 10% profit sharing contribution each January! Tuition Reimbursement and more.
2. Numerous different business units and sub-groups, many different career paths, multiple locations. Working remote up to 100% a possibility for many positions (off-phone), depending on business group.
3. Mostly good opportunities to improve your skills and knowledge.
4. Massive population to network.
View7:
1. Bureaucracy still reigns. Common Sense doesn't always prevail. The simplest things are made complicated... Every time a new senior leader arrives, there is a re-org or re-alignment... They say associates have a voice and they do survey associates, but if you speak up otherwise, do so at your own risk...
2. The company is making great strides towards improving career mobility but many legacy barriers remain in place, including attitudes of hiring managers and their superiors.
3. Very conservative company when it comes to risk...decisions are made by "committee" after exhaustive discussions, even over the most smallest and trivial things. Many times your work gets trapped by becoming all about the process and not the outcome.
4. Top Heavy. Appears to be a large population in the lower pay grades, but very few in the middle (managers, sr. managers), and an enormous Director, VP, and above segment. The top segment is all about taking care of each other when not competing or fighting one another.
5. Unless you sexually harass someone or get caught stealing something, no one gets fired unless it's an overall reduction in force. Lazy or inept associates are coddled or passed along.

Title: Not a great place to start a career in tech
View5:
Competitive benefits package
Flexible work schedule
Most people have good intentions
Seems to be a good enough place once you get to a ~Principal level as the pay + bonus potential + 401k contributions begin to stack up
View7:
Pay is considerably below average for software engineers, or tech more broadly
Rising through the ranks can be difficult and incredibly frustrating as there is a lot of politics involved
You can go a lot farther doing mediocre work on side projects rather than outstanding work for your project team (which, by the way, typically has well-defined KPIs and revenue implications unlike the one-off side projects)
Possibly depends on business unit, but rarely feels like the work has substantial impact on society
Can be a very slow process to adopt new technologies and paradigms

Title: Great Company

Title: Feels like a dead-end into Fund Accounting and that you will never be able to leave.

Title: A great place to work IF you pick the right business unit

View7: Work life balance might be impacted.  Really take care to ask anybody you know in Fidelity before taking a position the reputation of the business unit that you are considering.

Title: Great Entry Level Job to Get Licensed
View5: Insurance and benefits, flexible time off, series 7 training program
View7: One person grades all your calls, the metrics of handle time can be tough to meet if someone isn't knowledgeable on investing, advancement potential limited, more of who you know than what you know. A phone is a phone whether you are in service or a specialty team.

Title: Ten years of dog eat dog
View5: There are some smart people there, and the pay is above average.
View7: The culture is toxic. Most SVP level and above are more interested in how they are perceived over actual business results. The result is small groups of people that prevent senior management from seeing the real issues that prevent true growth. Everyone in the 'group' is doing the best possible job, and any poor results are the cause of non-group members. Poor results are rarely reported voluntarily.

Title: HR is non-existent for non-managerial employees
View5: Good place to work for a few years to get all-round finance industry experience. However, be prepared to work like a slave, because it is all numbers game for performance metrics. Quality & customer service does not matter.
View7: Employees are disposable assets. Skills and experience does not matter. No emphasis on building able and skilled work force. High attrition rate. Upper management is all about numbers game on excel spreadsheet because that earns them huge bonuses. Little accountability in management rung. If they screw-up, they abandon the group/business and jump-shift to another business like sinking ship.

Title: Annuity Sales is a senior sales role at Fidelity
View5: Pay is good. target is $107000, with most everyone hitting that or better. (Top end around 180k, but alot of OT required to hit that) Sales are geared towards the clients best interest. Everything is looked at through a very conservative planning lense. Team is small and solely based out of SLC (15 reps reporting to director) highly thought of role within company.
View7: Work-life balance can be tough given OT expectations 55-65 hours per week. Given the high demand for role, employees are put under strong pressure for underperformance, though top reps are given great leeway.

Title: Overall, one of the best places to work for business or IT
View5: A privately owned thriving large company that is always trying to improve, not afraid to take risks and grow in new directions.  It's essentially a meritocracy so if you are willing to work hard and be flexible you can succeed with it.  Industry comparable salary and good benefits, a decent work environment overall.
View7: If you don't like the organizational structure you are working in, just wait 6 months and it will change.

Title: Fidelity Investments is not an environment for women who have families and involved in their children's lives.
View5: Good benefits (employee accounts, healthcare, vacation policy)
View7: Not much upward mobility for women and not very understanding when it comes to pregnant women in the workplace regardless of years of experience and capability/expertise. HR personnel does not work in favor of the employee. Very bureacratic environment.

Title: Best in the industry
View5: Fidelity does a top-notch job in developing their associates. You have unlimited opportunity if you are committed and driven. Their benefits program is fantastic, with a 7% 401k match! I know I will be able to find any role in my future career path at this firm.

Title: Great Experience as both Intern & Part-time Employee
