It seems the people at the top are getting higher and the ones at the bottom have no where to go. Good company and benefits. Hard to make your mark and grow due to large number of employees. It seems the people at the top are getting higher and the ones at the bottom have no where to go.

Title: Premier Employer
View5:
Excellent growth opportunities, management support, engaging and challenging work, incredible compensation model.

They provide you with the tools and training necessary to do your job.
View7: As goes the market so goes the company. Hard decisions sometimes come out of nowhere and without any warning, just like any other financial services firm.

Title: Financial representative
View5: Decent working environment, good salary, opportunity for advancement. The company is also involved in making the community a better place; lots of volunteer opportunities. I worked there 101/2 years. I was offered a buyout package due to my age so I took it rather than chance being laid off.
View7: Employees own their career development. I had to make sure that I took time and developed contacts and relationships with more tenured folks so I could navigate the advancement process. It was based on knowing the system better than others.

Title: Customer Relationship Advocate
View5: I just started, but their training seems extensive and thorough. The people I work with seem very pleasant.
View7: I'm supposed to cover and retain a lot of information over the course of six weeks in order to pass the series 7. It seems a bit challenging so far.

Title: Young pro turned off by overbearing policies
View5: Lots of small employee appreciation events that help break up the day. Clean, open office.  Great 401k plan.
View7: Newer policies essentially discourage personal relationships of any type. Any behavior that is not 'workplace appropriate' is also banned at any social event no matter how unrelated to work. This generates an uptight culture and is not great for those of us who move here and plan to make friends at work.

Title: Good company with good benefits
View5: Lots of areas within the firm to work. Pay is reasonable, benefits like 401k matching/profit sharing are excellent. Tuition reimbursement and student loan assistance also are very good.
View7: Can be difficult to move outside of your department. Variable pay has been adjusted - goals changing but not identified. Still difficult to tell what measured on post DOL changes.

Title: Below Industry Low Pay, Doesn't live up to promises
View5: Brand recognition and wide network of offices in addition to regional centers.
View7: Doesn't live up to promises made or advertised. Pay is very low compared to industry standard. Financial Advisors on average make in the 6 figures., but not anywhere close at Fidelity. That is why they hire college grads who are desperate for a job who look past it and they shouldn't.

Title: Working at Fidelity
View5: Benefits. Office culture. Work from home.
View7: Grind. Inconsistency from management. Unable to properly train new hires

Title: Decent place to work if you have a family, but if you are just starting your career, my advice: run away screaming.
View5: Salary and benefits are the only key reasons that I would recommend anyone to work at Fidelity
View7: If you cherish the ability to get things done, and to grow yourself from an overall career perspective, I would highly recommend you look elsewhere

Title: Fidelity could become a good place to work again.  How much time will it take?
View5:
If you are motivated you can gain alot of valuable experience and know how.  But you have to be motivated on your own.  Fidelity as an organization, despite its claims, will not assist you nor look out for your career.  If you are cognizant enough to see certain situations as opportunities, you can at least gain the experience.

In the past sr. management has funded the important business initiatives.  Still not clear on how this will shake out.   

The technology investment has always been strong.  The implementation has been less that optimal at times.

Until the recent RIF, you could usually count on having the best and brightest people to work with.

In the last few years, high performers seem to be rewarded significantly higher than average performers from a compensation perspective.  For many year has not been the case.
View7:
Across the entire organization, there are alot people who are in the wrong positions.  This applies to IT, general management , Senior management , etc.  Overall,  management ability is poor.  Despite the bevy of management training required, it would seem that some people are just not cut out to be management.  This poor management performance also prevents line management from removing poor performers.  When its clear that a person is mismatch for the position he/she holds, the line manager does not have the skill/ability to make the change.  This goes on for years on end.

In the IT world, the various organizations have conflicting agendas and business plans.  Very poor coordination if any across the various IT and business organizations.  This causes high costs, high risk and significant inefficiencies.

It used to be that the average Fidelity associate was very passionate about his/her job.  Not so sure now.  Its clear that the new management is shoring up cost containment and streamlining and maybe cleaning out the under performers.  That's just good business, if that is in fact what's happening.  I'm afraid that days of working with truly dedicated and passionate people are over.

Title: Hopefully Ned can turn the company back around- iceberg dead ahead.
View5: Fidelity has a great brand, a great product, it is always looking to change and improve, is very modern in its outlook. Because the founding family still owns the company, management is very committed to keeping true to the company's original core values. Offices are modern and HR is progressive, offering the cutting edge in benefits and employee development. Up until the past couple of years, it was a great place to work- hands down with lots of opportunity for advancement, personal development etc.
View7: In the past several years, the company got too big, It became a huge bureaucracy and "old boy's network".  Those people (mostly men) who were "buddies" with their business unit's  Sr. VPs advanced quickly. The rest of us were worked very hard with small raises. Employees all spent a lot of their time trying to negotiate a huge bureaucracy. This had not been my experience of Fidelity in the past. The good news is, management realized this. They wisely picked up from employee surveys that employees were feeling frustrated. In recent years they shook up upper management and have been working to get rid of the dead wood. I hope for their sake they can return to Fidelity as it used to be. I used to love working there, but in recent years was so frustrated. My co-workers all experienced the same thing.

Title: You Can Be a Star Today, Gone Tomorrow
View5: Total compensation and benefits package. Good place to get some experience. Work for a few years, then think about moving on.
View7: Too much politics, red tape, and committee-based decision making. Little opportunity for lateral training and transition. More internal promotion and assignments based upon who you know rather than what you know.

Title: My thoughts on working at Fidelity for 5 years
View5: Bennefits the 401k match and profit sharing are great.  Good place to get some experience in the financial services industry when you are first getting started.  They also pay for your training and licensing.
View7: Pay is not great seems like they should pay better for a professional position.  Yearly raises are small and moving between positions is about 5% bump if anything.

Title: Great place to start a career in finance, SLC is not a great place long-term for high level talent
View5:
- Excellent training program to obtain knowledge of the industry and financial licenses
- Good company culture with mid-level management that cares about your work/life balance
- Industry leading benefits package (health, dental, 401k with 7% match and 10% profit sharing bonus - essentially a 17% match if you contribute 7% to your 401k, tuition reimbursement is $10,000, Company covers most or all of the cost of mass transit passes, etc.)
View7:
- Benefit package is great at the cost of low base pay compared to industry competitors.
- If you get an MBA or advanced degree, there are virtually no opportunities in SLC to take advantage of that. The only high paying career opportunities are in phone sales and management.  However management has virtually no turnover which is because of the great situation they have (Many have +10 year tenure), but this is bad if you want to try to get into management - be prepared to wait years for that opportunity or be forced to find an opportunity somewhere else.
- For those in SLC who want to move elsewhere in the country most of the opportunities are only for representatives who want to go to branches, if you want to go to a higher value added position in Boston or any other location good luck if you don't have connections or years of experience. Getting an advanced degree while working means nothing if you are trying to get in the door outside of their conventional channel of campus recruiting at mostly Ivy league or east coast universities.

Title: Great in some areas, lacking in others
View5: Overall good benefits package: medical, dental, retirement. Medical insurance tends to be on expensive side, but coverage was good as well. Retirement benefits are awesome once you actually vest and are eligible for a match.
View7:
Work environment was lacking. Vacation days (15/year) were okay, but definitely not enough to reward for the amount of work and stress for employees. Amount of sick days (6/year) was absolutely horrendous. A family of 4, like my own, could eat up that amount of time in a matter of months, and I didn't even try to abuse the system.

The area most lacking was employee appreciation. They attempt to appreciate by focusing on some areas (i.e. generous retirement package, perq points, team competitions), but overall falls very short. 

The perq points are based on performance during quarterly competitions. I exceeded goals every competition, but received no more than equivalent of $60 each time. Those who didn't really try and wouldn't meet performance goals would still get about $40 each time. 

My team won about half of the site competitions among teams. We were a very good team. However, the rewards (usually a increase in budget based on head count) would get paid out months after the fact. When it actually did get paid out, for some reason we never seemed to have enough money to do anything fun anyway. Something was amiss in the entire process. Maybe it falls on our manager, maybe the site management. I don't know.

In my 529 college planning specialty role, recently more and more tasks were being added to our plate. It was as if they were using 529 was "Fidelity Special Forces." We took on the Canadian Remediation in the summer of 2012, started backing up PAS with their overflow toward the end of 2012, and gradually took more and more general service overflow. When I arrived, 529 had a seasonal workload where it was very heavy during some times of the year, and a little lighter at other times. When I left, we were constantly "lit" (meaning calls waiting to get through to us). Most calls we received were general service or something other than 529 calls. The 529 customers were being neglected because we couldn't provide them service in time.

The increased workload would have been fine by me if they would have done a few things:
1. Inform us in advance of how, why, and when the workload is increasing.
2. Provide an increase in compensation (or bonuses or something) since we were not originally hired to do the increased work.
3. Hire more employees to do the peon work of general service. Since they worked us a lot of overtime, you would think that it wouldn't cost as much to hire another employee with a lower salary than to pay me at time-and-a-half with my higher salary.

My last point of review on what was lacking at Fidelity is the career opportunities. Ultimately, EVERYONE needs to go the sales route to accomplish anything. All career paths on the service side reach dead-ends very quickly so employees are stuck with low salaries. My being a non-sales type of person, I realized very quickly that I needed to jump ship. Thankfully, I had the opportunity to take a job I had been wanting to do for a long time. I didn't even blink before I accepted the offer.

Title: Great benefits and peers, poor judgement when selecting managers.
View5: Great retirement benefits, above average insurance, and generous when it comes to professional training. Very customer focused, which is a pro if you are a customer/client.
View7: My manager loves to over coach you to the point you feel as though you are incompetent. There are others that do the same. This is part of the coddling Fidelity does to their clients. If you are in a service role in a phone site you will be expected to place trades that fall into the complicated and varied internal rules that often defy logic. If a client wants to place a trade and you place it without questioning the client on why and how they are wanting to place it, you will be scrutinized. Fidelity's internal trading and distribution rules imply that all of their clients are idiots and we must save them from themselves. If you miss the opportunity to save the client from their own actions you will be charged an error. They will tell you how easy it is to exceed the quarterly bonus and get a full payout, but it is far from the truth. You have to trade error free, have efficient calls, meet sales lead goals, and have positive client surveys. The entire team has to meet their goals in order to maximize payout. Without significant experience most error free traders don't have efficient calls, because they are spending ten minutes a trade to make sure one of the silly rules isn't being violated. If you receive good surveys then your probably not meeting your lead goals, because despite the belief, not every client wants to be probed for opportunities. I am currently seeking a non-phone based finance job elsewhere.

Title: Great company to work for!
View5: Fidelity is truly committed to helping you develop your career. The office culture is one where professionalism and mutual respect are fostered. They truly practice what they preach and provide the tools for career and retirement savings success. It's up to you to use them.
View7: They still have some issues with breaking down silos, but they are actively seeking ways to break down the barriers between groups.

Title: Really great place to get a start in the financial world
View5: Fidelity cares about your progress, and doing your job well gets you promoted. Benefits are some of the best I've seen.
View7: Taking phone calls from customers all day every day gets old fast.  Technology is pretty awful. Even when it's brad new, the user interface typically stinks, which leads to lots of confused and frustrated customers calling in.

Title: A wonderful place to work, all things considered.
View5: Amazing benefits, wonderful people, and strong management.  I would certainly recommend working at fidelity to a friend.
View7: I don't love all of our products, so it can be tough to sell something you don't have full faith in.  That said, I do believe fidelity is one of the "good guys".

Title: High net worth rep
View5: Great benefits, flexibility with schedule when you have senority.
View7: It used to be a great place but has been downhill with upper management constantly finding ways to pay you less and expect you to do more. Morale is low so they implement small fixes that they always renig on and avoid the bigger issues. This year they increased metrics dramatically while cutting bonuses avoiding mid year raises and asking us to take over other departments work. The longer you work there the less you will make.

Title: Good company for younger workers
View5: Benefits are outstanding.  Great bonus at the end of the year.  Opportunity to learn new skills, if you are one of the lucky ones.
View7: Forget about it once you enter middle-age and you have been there for some time.  They start looking for reasons to eliminate your position.  They also start limiting your merit raises, because you are up in the salary range.

Title: Truth be told
View5: Honestly there were none...it was a horrible experience
View7: It is a private company that is based in Boston.  So if you are not based in Boston and you never were, then be prepared to struggle in this network.

Title: Not as bad as it seems.
View5: Privately held allows for long-term investment.  Great pay for people willing to put in the effort, however, that might all be changing.  Great benefit, even with recent reductions.
View7: Priorities and management is always changing.  Too many senior people working to protect their careers versus taking chances to grow the business.  Most recent changes handled poorly, way too many people kept in constant fear of loosing their job...tough to focus on the work to be done.

Title: Perpetual reorganizations & layoffs caused them to shed their best talent & left behind mgmt. that disdains employees.
View5: 401(k) match - There's not much else.  The thing I hear most from my coworkers is that this used to be a great place to work, and now it's just a job... just a paycheck.  I keep hearing people say that they can't wait for the economy to recover so they can find a job elsewhere.
View7: Low morale, little room for advancement, poor work/life balance, little regard for employees.  Poor lower and middle management that's insecure and willing to burn out their direct reports in order to keep their own jobs.

Title: Great Place to start. Many employees returning -  that says something!!!
View5:
Decent Training program
Employees and managers are very concerned about each other
Fun and enjoyable
Challenging
Competitive pay and benefits 
Plenty of room to grow within company
Promotion from within is a huge priority
View7:
Training is quick with a lot of information thrown at you all at once
You tend to learn a lot of actual work skills on the phones and as you go on in your career
Hours can be long, 10 hr. shifts
working on phones can be a pain and get monotonous

Title: not so bad
View5: great environment to work in with good benefits. Management is willing to hear your opinions and help you enjoy working or them. I like their corporate perks and their discount of car insurance and corporate perks.
View7: the constant "strategic relocation" since this started to happen i have seen many team members leave the team due to location. Team members leave and the work load increases and it starts to get hard to balance your work life and social life.

Title: The people are great and there is good work/life balance. The work isn't always creative enough.
View5: Dedicated, smart, passionate people in every department, including design. A huge focus on great user experience. Great benefits and pay. Flexible hours.
View7: Slow pace. Don't always have the tools or help you need. Frustratingly behind the times technology and development. Development that has been almost completely outsourced overseas - working closely with your developers is next to impossible.

Title: Great pay but employees not valued in layoffs
View5: Great pay and benefits, very easy to get to and a commute you can really be thankful for. They spend money on technology where needed and help you get your job done.
View7: Who in management knows about you and what you do is somewhat luck when new mangers are always coming in. The review system is awkward and can't possibly reflect your achievements correctly.

Title: This is a great company to work for with awesome benefits and thorough training.
View5: Very nice, non-backstabbing people, lots of upward mobility, fun company and team events, stable company, great training. This company working here for a few years looks great on any resume.
View7: It's average pay, mostly phone roles, it feels sometimes like there are not enough representatives on the phone to handle all the calls coming in back to back. Most roles are very structured.

Title: Human Resources Need to Look in the Mirror - Shameful
View5: Fidelity for many years was a great place to work.  Times have changed. Think twice before accepting an offer.  Many of us are miserable here.
View7:
The human resources group can't seem to set an example for others.  They have leaders to lie and treat others poorly.  These leaders twist stories and examples to benefit their own agenda.  

Constant change in company direction and leadership.  Lots of wasted time and money.

Title: Great work/life balance
View5:
Challenging work and talented software engineers
Great work/life balance, generally not expected to work outside 9-5pm
Working from home allowed generously as long as it does not impact productivity
View7:
Many software roles are outsourced to Ireland or India making communication difficult and slowing things down.  Not uncommon for a team to be split half in the US and half overseas.
Performance review process is not transparent

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Good entry level salary for recent college grad. Nice people. Healthy meals available.
View7: Sort of felt like being thrown to the wolves. Never-ending calls. Some employees will be filled with a great amount of stress.

Title: Solid employment, benefits, work environment and work life balance but expect to work  your fingers to the bone.
View5: Job security and routine daily tasks with few surprises allow for each day to go smoothly once you get the hang of all of the rules and soft skills to serve customers.
View7: The job itself gets monotonous and frustrating so if you don't move up the ladder you might just go crazy answering the same questions day in and day out.

Title: Financial Rep
View5: great leaders that take care of their people as far as going out to nice places to eat for fun
View7: you will literally be a number at a desk. I wish I didn't have to put it that way, but that's the truth. After working there for 3 years I still experience people not having an idea of who I' am after going to meetings, outings, and plenty of other events with them.

Title: Director
View5: The 401k matching is generous at 7% dollar for dollar.  The cafeteria is very nice with discounted rates subsidized.  The campus suroundings have woods and trails.
View7: The management is very insular and strategy does not match needed direction.  The company is not run very efficiently.  For many employees they feel that they are often at risk of being moved, outsourced or laid off.

Title: Technical Intern
View5: All the employees are really nice, very supportive work environment. Also everyone there is very smart in the sense that many people had masters degrees.
View7: A lot of employees on work visas, yet all the interns are from U.S. universities. Sort of sends a weird message to the type of employees they value. Disorganization within the company, sometimes hard to get things done.

Title: The grass is not always greener along the green line
View5: A lot of the people there were great to work with
View7: Could not figure out who they wanted to be. People who drink the green kool aid are all in and rah rah. Mgmt does not want you to elevate if you are good at your job. Financial consultants think they are CEOs with demands yest have no clue how to connect to clients that pay them.  If you want a new job, be prepared for a paycut.

Title: Financial Associate
View5: Decent benefits.  Education reimbursement.  On-site gym, medical office and cafeteria.
View7: There is extreme pressure to meet quotas or acquire certain metrics depending on the position.  I was fortunate to work under great managers my first 3 years.  My last year there was a nightmare.  I saw co-workers bullied and the overall morale drop to an incredible low. HR was informed. Unfortunately,  there was no change. It is a high stress place to work.

Title: Senior Fund Accountant
View5: Organized. They have a system in place so it's possible to follow procedures while you get a hang of things. You're not thrown into work without someone there you can ask questions. They take pride in their work. There are some great managers that are in your corner.
View7: Location is secluded. It's such a huge company and campus so it can be hard to navigate and advance your career especially if you want to move to a different team.

Title: Financial Representative in TEM
View5: Fidelity truly cares about their employees.  They are very careful about who they hire which really correlates with their work enviorment, everyone i worked with was fantastic!  The benefits were over the top and the management was always very knowledgeable, helpful and trusting.
View7: Because it is a call center, their were alot of opportunities to grow but most were still talking over the phone all day everyday.  Getting employees off the phone for a few hours a day to complete operational tasks would really help keep employees happy.

Title: Sr Manager
View5: I can't think of another firm that has more integrity than this company.  It is all about doing what is right for the customer and doing it right the first time.  The people that I worked with through the years are incredible.
View7: The only thing I have negative to say is that this company is catering to millennials and college grads.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to work
View5: Extensive opportunities for employees who show dedication, believe the current corporate goals and don't complain. Goals change frequently, as does your departments management structure.  Benefits and profit sharing are great.
View7: Frequent management changes can make it complicated to get settled, but if you're adaptable and go with the flow, you'll be rewarded.

Title: Not a meritocracy in higher levels
View5: Tremendous resources and good pay
View7: Difficult to get Vice President based on hard work and ability.  You have to be exceptional at managing up, and skilled at waxing eloquently while really saying nothing of value.  Sounding good and being liked by your manager is more important than being effective, liked by your colleagues and trusted by your direct reports.

Title: Great Culture but Terrible Pay
View5: Nice people, collaborative culture, decent work life balance, good benefits
View7: The pay is laughable for Boston . By far the lowest across the industry for many positions. Tout their share program as a way to make up for low pay but they have been giving fewer and fewer shares every year but not increasing the base salaries at all.  The culture is great but it can be too relaxed and there isn't much pressure to work hard.

Title: Little work/life balance
View5: Great benefits (PTO, medical etc)
View7: Good luck using your PTO- they don't approve time off if they deem themselves too busy, mandatory overtime in "peak" seasons (but they will require you to do it throughout the year), unrealistic expectations of calls taken per hour while trying to talk clients "off the edge". Promotions are based on your surveys you receive from clients and if your manager likes you- and alot of surveys are bad scores due to long wait times so it's an unfair scaling system.

Title: Bring Your ' A ' Game to Fidelity and Your Opportunities are Endless!
View5: The collegial atmosphere allows employees at Fidelity to work together towards solutions by bringing diverse knowledge through cross-business teams.  Instead of working in Silos we communicate with business partners having experience in multiple industries.  This allows quicker responses to client needs as well as the most efficient process to bring the most relevant new products to market within budget and original timeframe.  The benefits packages include health insurance, life insurance, short and long term disability, corporate perks, share ownership in a private company, and 401k.  Management is very flexible when time is needed for personal needs.  The properties are taken care of and kept current and the food at Sebastians(internally owned caterer) isn't half bad!
View7: It can be tough to see people promoted or hired for choice jobs because of who they know or where they went to school.  This problem though seems to be endemic to the entire business world.  You have to manage your time appropriately to allow you to keep up with your current tasks as well as learning more skills and making the right connections to be properly positioned to advance your career.  If you are not a Type A personality you can get stuck in a role performing the same tasks over and over without much growth potential.  You have to take initiative and make it known that you want to move ahead.  Some management will not support your career goals as it causes them to have to backfill which can be a challenge.

Title: Great place to work, but here's what you need to know
View5: Fidelity is a large company with many different business and product lines - this means there is a great deal of opportunity.  It also invests a great deal in new technology (almost too much without thinking through the on-going production and operations costs).  Fidelity also has a fantastic benefits package which makes up over 30% of total compensation - excellent healthcare options, dental, 401(k), etc.  Fidelity also has some of the smartest people I have ever met or had the pleasure to work with, they are creative, driven, articulate, and for the most part have a good sense of humor.
View7: Even though Fidelity says career advancement is about the people management, managers are still promoted for technical ability, no people management skills.  Also, while Fidelity talks about work life balance, my experience is 'face time' (late nights, early morning, vacations on email, giving up most of your vacation days) is how you are taken seriously.  I've heard managers say that even though the work week is 37.5 or 40 hours (depends on site) that if you don't work at least 55-60 hours/week then you are not doing your job and contributing to the firm.  Employee recognition (at the individual department and manager level) is virtually non-existent, most often employees get back handed compliments, 'you did a great job but here is how you could have improved...'.  Kaizen (continuous improvement) is great, but my experience has been strengths are minimized and areas of improvement are the primary focus.  This approach can be very disheartening to a business team or group as well as to individuals.

Title: Great benefits, nice work culture.
View5: Great benefits, pay for licensces, pay is decent for call center, reputable company to work for
View7: Do not see to much advancement between functions; managers are really picky on call reviews; managers really push you to work overtime when available; commission are based on customer reviews, even if you hit numbers if team review is bad no payout

Title: They are lost and need to resolve leadership transition.

View7:
A once great company now in serious decline.
Below average pay.
Ridiculous statistical model for performance evaluation.
Focus is on employee weakness instead of strength.
Apparently Abby is not ready to take over so Ned can't officially retired.
No real leadership due to uncertainty during this transition.
Not open to outside influence so incestuous amplification effect is in full force.

Title: Great place to work but low efficiency

- Good technologies
- work in Financial industry
- good company culture

Title: Growth opportunities consistent of lateral movement only, not much else

The company is always understaffed so there are nearly always calls holding waiting for you to answer.

Title: Great company, but inflexibility is the name of their game
View5: Great training program, friendly people, just like "office Space", unbelievable benefit package , insurance for all needs, and discounts on gym and pc, and other niceties
View7: middling pay, bonuses unrelated to effort, leadership too limited to experience in-house

Title: Supportive, customer-focused company with a big-company feel and a lot of horizontal/vertical growth opportunity.
View5:
Benefits (health, tuition assistance @ 10k/year)
Compensation package (base + bonus (% depends on level) + profit sharing + shares awards + 7% 401(k) match)
Growth opportunities - big company
Very customer focused, feels like we're doing the right thing
In my department, great work/life balance
View7:
Bureaucratic and political, in almost every department
Multi-site strategy is a good thing, but most meetings are over the phone or spotty video conferencing; sometimes seems impersonal
Not every department treats/pays their employees well
Incredibly high amount of mid-level management

Title: Great Company Overall, However
View5: Benefits are great, vacation and personal/sick time is adequate and having a gym onsite is the best.  There are some great people that work there.
View7: Every business unit is different and I have found that in the one I'm in it's very different than others.  The admins usually do a lot more in other business units than the one I'm in and it makes for a very unsatisfied feeling.

Title: Great company, if you get into the right organization
View5: Great benefits, many services to employees such as health center, gyms, concierge, discount programs, tuition reimbursements, bonuses, there are many opportunities offered to their employees that makes life easier
View7: Not all organizations within the company operate the same, many processes are not documented for easy learning if you are new, not all organizations recognize work-life balance culture that Fidelity promotes, not all candidates are qualified for their roles

Title: Big company with a range of talents and many opportunities
View5: Fido as it is affectionately known is massive private company with businesses spanning the globe.   Being private allows it the benefit of making long term decisions without needing to kow tow to shareholders.
View7: Like any massive company the experience of each employee can vary greatly.  Cultures can be fairly different, even within a fidelity company or a specific location within a fidelity company or business unit.

Title: Great Organization for a long-term career
View5: The company is privately owned enabling it to invest in technological advancement.  The retirement benefits are world class  Abby does a great job of keeping employees informed and there are countless networking and career advancement resources.
View7: Process improvements have to be prioritized and the resources are often stretched thing.  There are opportunities around inter-departmental communication and collaboration.

Title: Undefined goals, lack of leadership
View5: Benefits are great, the 10%. 401k drop each year excellent.
View7: Constantly micro managed, sales team told not to pedal products, however failure to sell PAS or annuities results in performance management. Calling strategies for Relationship Managers are not clearly defined. I worked 10 years for them in multiple roles, including sales and would never go back. They jump from objective to objective and tell people its all about change and to adapt. Fail go list to employees good suggestions and management is very political.

Title: Great company to work for
View5: Good variety of jobs available, great benefits, consistent work environment. Excellent place to start and develop your career and in many cases retire
View7: Lower base compensation than competitors, growth opportunity varies by function and can be limited in certain cases. The positive of a lot of jobs can be a negative as well with high turnover.

Title: I hate what I do, but I love who I do it for.
View5:
Fidelity had the best benefits package I've ever heard of.  Also has the best managers I've ever had.  Each one of the several I have had genuinely care about me as an individual and about helping me meet my definition of success.

For individuals wanting to move up in the company, there are plenty of routes to go.
View7: It's a call center.  Dealing with clients will never be fun.

Title: Financial Consultant
View5: Blue print for sales process & plenty of lead opportunity. Good benefits overall with solid profit sharing plan.
View7: Company feels like more focused on process itself rather than providing solutions with end goal in mind.  Extreme micro management as managers are expected to manage their branch personnel in a spreadsheet.  Be prepared to "click" your way through everything at Fidelity as that's how you will be measured.

Title: Great Company to Work For
View5: Very flexible with regards to working from home Great benefits Moving to agile work methodology Moving to open, unassigned seating - allows for more collaborative work environment, great team work and problem solving Great open, collaboration spaces with whiteboards, large monitors (32") that can be used for either video conference or reviewing a document with your team
View7: Large organization - can be difficult to navigate and find what you need Some in-house systems (purchasing, travel & expense) are difficult to use Too many video conference options

Title: Loved It!
View5:
If you're in Westlake, you have access to just about every role at the firm
Great brokerage licensing training program
Fantastic benefits (didn't realize how good it was until I left and experienced other companies' packages strong brokerage onboarding practices
Good work-life balance
Intelligent, skilled co-workers
Management encouraged skills development
View7:
Hard to move out of Texas if you don't want to be there
Raw pay was less competitive (this may have changed since TD and Schwab moved into the area)
Management didn't have a good understanding, or desire to understand, how to move from one business silo to another (i.e., PI to an Enterprise function)

Title: Take some time to consider your options
View5: Great benefits and starting point for a career.
View7: Office politics, managers shifting in and out, minimum raises or recognition for hard work. If you're coming from Leap make sure you know what role you're walking into, movement out if you don't like your position or is not what you expected can almost never happen- unless taken to HR. If you come in during organizational changes, you WILL slip through the cracks.  Speak up for yourself.

Title: Not a bad place to work for a couple of years but wouldn't build a career there
View5: Had the pleasure of working with some very intelligent people top of their field. In general a nice culture particularly at the individual team level. Enjoyed varied technical challenges throughout my career there.
View7: A lot of internal politics which can be challenging to work through particularly as you advance. A lot of red tape so can be slow & frustrating to make progress. Loyalty is not neccesarily a 2 way street either so would be careful wasting too many years there.

Title: Amazing potential, great community, cares about culture fit!
View5:
Honestly they care a TON about making sure you fit within the culture of the team/company. The technology community is really helpful and full of such a variety of people. There's good events, they invest in you as a person from internal onsite training, to in-house education platforms to big name course platforming tools (not even counting their benefits package, that's incredible, especially for families). You can really "Blaze your own trail" when it comes to your career and people will support you as much as they can. The connections you make there can/will extend far after you leave and most of their networks are very far reaching across other large companies (or even internally).

Additionally, work/life balance is AMAZING. Most managers (particularly technology, since call center workflows are different) will let you handle life because they know that it can be unpredictable, and will help you adjust however works for you (obviously within reason), whether that's having to leave somewhat early to pick up kids or have an extended lunch because of a crisis or appointment. There's a trust that you can develop with your team and manager that you can truly make the experience less stressful, and they're willing to work with you in whatever way they can.
View7: If you're coming in as an entry-level technology role, make sure you get the best offer you can. They've historically paid under market even in their industry (though it's much closer these past 2 years) because of their benefits, but total comp is still somewhat lower than anticipated for their size. Depending on the team, it may be hard to rise up the ranks past a point due to too many managers, and organizations find it difficult to cut them, especially if they've been there a while. It's pretty hard to negotiate any pay change since raises only happen at the end of the year, and there's not a pay discussion until they're locked in.

Title: Good work-life balance, below average pay & management
View5: Lot of room to learn, promotion opportunities, the profit sharing can be quite nice.
View7: The pay is far below financial industry average for entry-level employees and drastically below that of the technology industry. Furthermore, the management structure is outdated and there is not much transparency in the review process.

Title: The "new" Fidelity, again.
View5: Great overall compensation and benefits package.  The employees are the company and make it a worthwhile place to work.  The collegial atmosphere is fantastic, especially in the information technology area.  Information share among colleagues is open and there is a genuine desire to see peers across the various platforms and internal companies succeed.  Collaboration between teams is good.  The infighting, back-stabbing, "step on each other to get to the top" mentality is rare.  Those sort of individuals, for the most part, don't last long among the people who are actually productive and get things done at the line levels.  Leadership at the first-line levels is phenomenal.  Some managers are former military service who understand how to lead people to achieve company objectives while showing genuine concern for the well-being and growth of those they lead.  In fairness, the numbers of those types of individuals is shrinking.  The "silo" mentality of the different companies within Fidelity and their corresponding initiatives that used to be prevalent throughout Fidelity has greatly diminished over the past several years.
View7: While the line level employees and line managers are some of the most competent you will find in the industry for any of the job families that fall under the Fidelity umbrella (trading, finance, information technology, etc.), the executive management fails to understand the talent pools they possess in those areas.  This is readily apparent in the recent turnover among the upper echelons of management and the corresponding restructuring coming to be known as the "Rodger Lawson" era by employees.  The executive leadership that built the company over the last 10-15 years is out.  New executive management is in with the focus on cost-cutting that takes no regard for the Fidelity specific institutional knowledge and talent that is a key strength to stability.  The "private company"  and "family owned" environment that made Fidelity a great place to work and employees proud to laud the company to their friends, family and any one who would listen has evaporated.  Executive management failures to properly define goals and thereby engage the talent in the labor pool they possess is abysmal.  Some of the best and brightest with great knowledge and talent were assigned to projects that incoming executive management had no stomach for seeing to completion.  Rather than reassign that best and brightest talent to retain it, a slash and burn has taken place in the form of layoffs in November 2008 that has placed that talent on the market, ripe for other companies to cherry pick.   The new executive management isn't done and layoffs are coming again in first quarter of 2009 to reach some idea of a model organization.  This is definitely throwing the baby out with the bath water.  Consider this an announcement to all other companies, especially in the technology arena.  While the individual writing this commentary was not affected in the Q4/2008 layoffs, there exists an opportunity for you to profit from Fidelity's unfortunate rush to meet a model organization concept.  Those of us that remain at Fidelity will have to suffer through this bungling until a level of equilibrium is achieved and the people that matter, the ones who actually make Fidelity work, can again overcome this idiotic endeavor.  I love the Johnson family.  Over a decade of my life has been spent at Fidelity.  I've seen the good and the bad.  Why the new executive team being brought in by them is thought to be better and brighter than the people that have built the company is a mystery to me.  Rodger Lawson is a retread, having worked at Fidelity before, but many of the executive management being brought in are coming from failed Wall Street companies that are the focus of the recent $700B bailout.  These people are better and brighter than the individuals they replaced?  Many with long track records of productivity in the lower ranks and that have made this company great are less than inspired.  All we see is the continued evaporation of work-life balance and yet another step closer to a sweat-shop.

Title: Great place to work
View5: I feel that Fidelity Investments has many good attributes .  I feel that employees receive fair treatment by managers, good salary and benefits, and have plenty of opportunities for advancement.  They also encourage you to develop your skills as a planner and provide lots of support.
View7: Very conservative corporate culture, sometimes it's difficult to navigate the different parts of the company.  Sometimes it takes a while to get things done.

Title: If you are looking to build a carrier and develop sales skills LOOK ELSWHERE
View5: Great 401K and profitsharing benefits, decent vacation paid time off, great for starting and entering brokerage and investments world, great training , awesome tools and platform, a lot of hand  holding towards begging in one word, if you are just starting this is a place to be.
View7:
Company is privatelly own ,which means top managment is forced upon , as natural way of passing on wealth.One of the top executives has no knowledge of various market segments which impacts potential growth of certain areas in the market, example fixed income. This company has so many products and many are Great , affordable and trully sell themselves but managment is lacking fundamental  marketing and sales skills. Lower end managers have came to their positons because they stayed many years with a company , and trully if they were that good they wouldn't stay in those places long.A lot of managers don't understand what company and business growth trully means and are very micro oriented on to a specific task and unable to view and understand a big picture. 
For someone very ambitious and creative there is no place within this company it's too big and there are many barriers when it comes to sharing ideas.Once you get to higher level sales there is no proper training , it's lacking because managment is lacking those skills.

Title: Great place to start not to finsh
View5: there is a great culture at fidelity. i was able to get along with all the other employees. i was very pleased with the managers i had which makes a big deal
View7: the worst part is that  you are tracked to the second every day and everyday is the same there is never any change and their never will be

Title: Decent place for college kids, new grads & retirees
View5: Great place to earn some cash and pump up your resume. Not much upward mobility at all from the service rep position... dont drink the kool aid.
View7: way too scripted. you will often have to choose between whats right and whats scripted. You will be liable for the mistakes that the call flow tells you to make or you will be penalized for not following the call flow

Title: Good learning experience but not long term position for me
View5: Learn a lot and given the chance to earn licenses and have a well known financial services company on your resume
View7: Training for getting your licenses is quality, but once you get your licenses the trainings from that point on are low quality and not strategically planned. Managers will come and go so have to stay flexible

Title: Good
View5: Investment knowledge and industry knowledge learned.  Fidelity's systems are fantastic.  The company makes sure that the tools needed to complete you job are there.
View7: The downside would be that you need to have a really good idea where you want your career to go long term right away.  It is easy to get labeled and almost imposible to loose the lable.

Title: Spectacular benefits package

Superior benefits, great co-workers, and a highly ethical company.  It's genuinely committed to doing right by its clients.  You can work in a corporate environment without feeling evil...

I doubt there's a better benefits package out there.

Co-workers tend to be smart, decent and pleasant people.

Title: Great Company, Limited Skilled Positions

Most roles are within a call center or mail processing facility so there is heavy clerical work.  Not much in the way of skilled operational or financial opportunities.  Those roles are primarily outside Covington - New York, Boston, Rhode Island

Title: Fidelity is a solid, trustworthy company with great opportunities

Management is smart and flexible
Middle of the road salaries bolstered by tremendous benefits and profit sharing

Beautiful work buildings -- and green footprints!
High integrity among all employees; always doing what is right for customers first.

Hierarchical, so getting approvals is often time consuming
Highly regulated, so external communications are reviewed very carefully and sometimes heavy handidly.

Title: Shifting core values
View5:
Great benefits
Amazing environment
Very friendly people
Lots of career opportunity

Company seems to me shifting it's core values
-More focused on overwhelming employees and not replacing people when turnover occurs. Company appears to be taking cost cutting measures while not being transparent with it's employees.

-salary increases not based on performance but rather "cost of labor"

Title: Solid Company
View5: Fidelity provides excellent benefits, competitive salaries, and a challenging work environment. Tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment program, medical and dental, profit sharing, and annual performance bonus are some of the best benefits offered in NH and MA. If you work hard and take charge of your career at Fidelity, you will find many opportunities to progress your career.
View7: Starting salary can be lower that market, but the total compensation package is often at market or above. Also, like any other large company, you can find pockets of bad management, but it is not representative of the company.

Title: Great environment, but mentally strenuous
View5: Great culture environment and benefits.  Great opportunity for licenses and professional development. Everyone is friendly and genuinely cares and is a joy to be around
View7: Call center struggles. Psychologically draining. So many possible calls and metrics can go wrong with little that can be owned up too.

Title: Investment Solutions
View5: Great benefits, 7% 401k match, HSA deposit, cheap insurance, etc.
View7: No one ever seems to check on the upper level/senior management. Most are doing the right thing, but some are only looking out for their own best interest and will take it out/target employees to get ahead.  Also they severely underpay compared to other firms, but this is because they feel the "benefits" make up for the lack of $ in your pocket.

Title: Do you want to be reminded how expendable you are?
View5:
Good not great benefits.
Flexible scheduling but remember overtime is mandatory so that will go out the window during tax season.
View7: Out of touch management that is completely disconnected from the realities of the job their employees are doing to the point that it is not uncommon that even your direct supervisor will have no idea how to do your job. You will be treated like number and constantly threatened with your goals (oh and they're going to change often)  even if you're meeting them. If you don't want to go into sales or management your going to be eventually treated like dead weight pushed to the side.

Title: Fidelity Investments needs on it's old time values.
View5: Fidelity Investments has a good reputation and cache. Additionally, Fidelity generally uses recent technology and is not way behind the curve in this regard.
View7: Company is downsizing and it is unclear what their future direction may be. In particular, the beaucracy and level of management precludes individual initiative.

Title: Fidelity Technology Group (subsid. of Fidelity Investments) seems to run smoothly, but is falling apart at the seams.
View5:
- Decent Pay & Benefits, it's that's your main priority
- The company is moving away from working in silos; that's a plus for those whose skills lie in developing projects.
- The strength is in the contract people who are serious about their work and are very professional. If you have a choice to work with the contracted groups of people, you're more likely to have a good experience and can minimize interactions with the main tech support people and their management.
View7:
-  Probably the worst aspect of working at FTG is the "high school environment" and complete lack of professionalism. When you begin working there, the environment smacks of high school popularity groups. Yuck! And it only becomes worse with time. As much as one tries to remain professional it is difficult to avoid being pulled or pushed, one way or another.  I watched the group of support staff ostracize a former team member and leader because that person was promoted to a position that was ancillary to the support tasks. As I said, it is like a group of mean girls in high school and the guys just kind of follow along. What a sad environment.

-There are 'team leaders" within the support group, and those who are serious about getting their work done and doing an excellent job, easily standout from the rest.  Worst seems to be the bizarre nature of relationships between Senior Management and some of the employees who have been around for along time. These "older" support workers as it turns out, started at FTG at the same time as their now manger.  However, once the other person was promoted, and now holds a position of superior management over the first worker, the relationship between the two naturally has an uncomfortable strain even if it is not clearly evident to all. What was most obvious to those of us outside of this type of bizarre relationship is that the people still hanging around among the worker bees could easily see the passive aggressive behavior. In addition when a fresh new employee full of ideas is assigned to work with one of these people, the older worker bees exploit the new employees mercilessly. Since the newcomers are likely on the outside of the group of people, they don't stand a chance and if anything doesn't go as planned, the newcomers end up getting reprimanded by Senior Mgmt. in place of the worker bees. This ultimately creates a watch out for #1 environment in addition to the vicious "get rid of #2" nature of the workers. If you work there, always watch your back - trust no one - be friendly, but make no friends - and document everything you do to CYA.

- Poor leadership in management - mgmt. often does not realize (chooses not to realize?)  who is actually shouldering the work and who is slacking off. The nature of the "you're in" vs. "you're out" environment only serves to undermine anyone speaking up.

- Higher ups laid off the better managers in late 2008; all that left is those who don't draw healthy boundaries nor can they manage their own people because they have way too much on their plates.

- FTG component of Fidelity is shifting more and more of its human resources & capital over to India. The people we support are becoming increasingly frustrated with this as the quality of service decreases. Senior Management is aware of this but puts on a happy face to avoid being laid off as their own counterparts were.

Title: Contractor
View5:
Decent hourly rate for someone with no experience in the industry - as a contractor
Clients were great 
Very systematic methods which work well 
Bright people
View7:
High turnover 
Very political 
Contract to perm may never happen

Title: Reasonably good post-undergrad role (Financial Representative on phones for Retail Brokerage business)

Title: Good place to begin a career, but not a place to stay

The employees are treated like a commodity, meaning if you cannot do it I will have no trouble finding a replacement.  Employees tend to be paid below market value.

Title: Good environment
View5: Decent benefits, good work environment
View7:
Since about 2008, the company has been looking for ways to sharpen their pencils and cut costs at any opportunity.  Despite a positive market and improving business, it does not seem that there is an end in sight.

Employees in New England are increasingly the red headed step children with most opportunity being relocated to NC and Dallas.

Title: Awesome training & ability to grow

Not sure if I would want my daughter working under some or at all w/in this environment in the Service division.

Title: you're still a phone rep/clone
View5: Good benefits, decent salary. Good training.

You can choose the flavor of calls you want (i.e. trading, advisory, service, retirements) but at the end of the day its still just about AHT, ACW, and the same old call center crap.

Title: Associate Systems Services Support Analyst

View7: Amount of work to be done can be overwhelming at times.  Once you learn something new, be ready to teach it to others.

Title: You determine the outcome

Title: Exactly what I expected

Title: Stock Plan Representative

Title: How to Make Productive, Experienced Employees Quit

Title: Financial Associate I and/or II

Title: Intern
