Title: Highly political, bureaucratic environment
View5: Fitness reimbursement; online training courses
View7:
You're position is not "confirmed" until after your 1 year anniversary but HR does not tell you that, until then, watch your back, they will look for ways to make your life miserable enough to make you want to quit or give an excuse you don't deserve a bonus.  Full of bureaucracy, unless you're in the "in" crowd, you're pretty much on your own.
The workplace is like the Olympics, employees compete with each other to reach the gold medal, Don't expect you will get the kind of support you need from your peers or manager, it's not for the faint hearted.

Title: Great Company to Start and Finish a Career
View5:
Great benefits, especially retirement savings.  $1 for $1 dollar match on first 7% plus annual profit sharing contribution which has always been 10% of compensation.

Since the company is private, management is not working quarter to quarter.  

Fidelity offers a wide range of job roles.
View7:
The company can be on the conservative side.  
Weak internal employee development.
Weak middle management.
Outside local investor centers, Fidelity has only a handful of campuses.

Title: Used to be better
View5: Great work/life balance.  Great co-workers.  There are moments where you can learn a lot, and working in a global organization has great benefits.  Bonuses are really good, along with profit sharing.  Shares are harder to come by, which is a shame.
View7: Very political organization.  The leadership of the technology organization is more concerned about their own personal gain instead of actual technology, and make decisions at the expense of actual development.  Too many roles, hard to get anything done in a reasonable amount of time.

Title: Good company with strong training.
View5: Fidelity is a great company with a lot to offer. The benefits are great and the compensation is fair. Fidelity does an excellent job training employees and helping new hires get licensed.
View7: Like any company, you have to work hard to be successful. Fidelity can have very demanding goals, but if you are motivated and believe in Fidelity’s process, you can have a very good career

Title: Premium Relationship Associate
View5:
Good benefits
Good training
Room for growth if you want to stay in a call center or move to position at a branch.
Good flexibility within position (Starting to be cut back)
View7:
Strict schedule to be followed in most positions
The software used to make outbound calls is super slow and frustrating to use for long periods of time

Title: Fine
View5: Fidelity has a good 401k and provdes great benefits for all employee: for example they will pay 50% for gym membership, and have great health insurance, pay for school after 6 months of works
View7: It is a call center and the call volumes are very very high at this moment. Some supervisors are very micro managery and at the SLC location there is

Title: Best Place for Career
View5: Great place to have a career.  Extraordinary leadership, great opportunities.  Your success is determined by your attitude and work ethic.  Hard work is not easy, but effort pays off.  Great benefits, outstanding culture, and wonderful people.
View7: Some benefits are outdated, but they are making active progress and investments and we can see the changes.  A true investment in employees.  Flexibility can be a challenge in a regional center environment.

Title: One of the best financial firms
View5: Longer term outlook for business decisions because the company is privately owned, and not run based on quarter-to-quarter results. I work with smart people, who for the most part are motivated by more than just money.
View7: There's a lot of change all the time - sometimes it's hard to operate in the environment of uncertainty, and it takes its toll on morale too.

Title: Great company to work for if you can avoid certain tracked career paths.
View5: Great retirement, medical options, beautiful facilities to work in, average time off for starters, get for those with 5 yrs +.
View7: Bi-weekly pay is lower than average. This is intention as they give 7% 401k match and 10% more in profit sharing to every employee.

Title: One of the best in town
View5: Excellent corporate environment. Flexible schedules and lots of opportunity for advancement. Pay is average for the industry in the area. Nice workplace with all the amenities and lots of natural light.
View7: Outdated systems and vague resources makes accuracy very difficult.  Little to no manager oversight on a daily basis. You basically only see them when you've done something wrong. Very little personal coaching and development from your direct supervisor.

Title: Registered Representative
View5: Decent Pay, low work load. I literally do nothing and still make a decent buck.
View7: I cannot have a serious, intelligent conversation with any of my colleagues (especially about the market). They have the same IQ and ambition as Comcast phone reps. There is zero challenge, zero reward, and if you want a promotion there will be tons of brown-nosing. So if that's your thing, pucker up.

Title: Great Run
View5: Great place to start and maintain a career if you are flexible on new assignments and tell folks you want the next challenge.  Some assignments will be great because of great teams and focused motivated leaders, some will stink but the good ones will keep you here.  Over time benefits for mature employees have been degraded in favor of younger employees
View7: Politics, micro management of headcount and budget, High bar for ROI on projects.  Slow to change in a time when revenue under extreme pressure.

Title: Steady Paycheck, No Aggressive Sales
View5: Steady paycheck no matter what. Good match and good culture/work environment. Plus, you get to learn about the financial world, which most of us didn't when we were in school!
View7: Phone jobs can be a burnout (they always are) but it's better than something like Comcast or Verizon customer service.

Title: Guidance Support Specialist
View5: Fidelity takes the development of its employees seriously. The benefit package is great and makes it hard to leave the company once you begin to work for them.
View7: Fidelity is a large firm, which can make it difficult to change in a fast paced market environment. They can miss incorporating their front-line teams into change that takes place with the organization leading to a frustrated work environment at times.

Title: Senior Research Analyst
View5:
Good work life balance
Excellent benefits 
Competitive pay
Excellent communication from upper management 
Technology & resources are second to none
View7:
Extremely bureaucratic 
Office politics can make or break you
Like people who can conform to the culture and can be close minded 
Extremely competitive and career advancement can be limited
Some departments are very sexist

Title: Investor Center Management
View5: Truly client-centric, innovative and price competitive.  Salary is good, total benefits are amazing.  Focus on team results as well as individual achievement.
View7: Lines of business can feel isolated, hierarchy can make communication a challenge (both top down and bottoms up).  The pace at which focus changes can give associates whiplash, everything  is a priority.

Title: Good Company - People are a mixed bag
View5: Great benefits. Facilities and pay. Growth opportunities and some flexible work from home opportunity.
View7: The teams are oftentimes run by very young adults, many first time people managers. Lots of favoritism, inappropriate fraternizing and questionable unprofessional behavior. Most Senior Management is more professional. Very good experiences with older management.

Title: Great concept
View5: benefits are extremely good, 401k, Health insurance, pto.
View7: managers only look at the scorecard they don’t care how smart or how hard you work, a lot of the expectations are out of your control managers don’t care.

Title: Fidelity
View5: Flexible, competitive,  great benefits and profit sharing.
View7: Different business units can feel like you are working at a completely different company. Still plenty of improvement needs to be done around gender equality. Men are compensated at a higher rate than women and considered first for promotions.

Title: The Final Stop
View5:
- Campus has amazing amenities that truly serve the employees
- Leadership team is hungry to grow leaders and develop new talent
- Benefits are robust and extremely competitive 
- Tons of opportunities to serve the community through work sponsored outreach
- Company culture is fast paced but prioritizes work/life balance
- Best place to retire from... hands down!
View7: - Unique pay structure that incorporates ~25% of your income coming from a year end bonus; this could pose a challenge to someone who isn't used to a managing their salary in such a way.

Title: Workplace Planning Consultant II. Providing planning and advice on complex financial topics to high segmented clients
View5: Great benefits. 7% match on 401k and 10% profit sharing. They pay you a differential for working late and will pay you good for OT. Work from home 50% of your time if you’d like. Lots of opportunity, work hard and you will grow.
View7: Management can be stressful at times but it’s only to push you to succeed and progress to other roles. Mentally exhausting.

Title: Best year of my career ever
View5:
Open, thoughtful and empathetic work environment
Relentless focus on doing the right thing for the client
High integrity, high accountability 
Smart colleagues you can learn from everyday
A powerhouse where you can grow and develop
View7: Complex learning curve for someone new to the company

Title: Great place to work, excellent benefits but be prepared to be laid off every 1 - 3 years in a new management re-shuffle
View5: Opportunities for advancement and various different career paths.  Training is also very generous.
View7: New management and layoffs every year or two

Title: Overall satisfied employee, cautiously optimistic.
View5: Overall the benefits and compensation at Fidelity are excellent, and they are the main reason I joined the organization. The 401k matching is unbelievable, and the health insurance is outstanding (although the employee contribution is rising significantly in 2009). There is also a real sense of comradery within departments and my coworkers are some of the smartest and professional people that I have ever worked with. I think Fidelity does a great job at trying to have a good work/life balance, giving employees flexible work options and offering plenty of time off. I think there is also plenty of opportunity to succeed and grow at Fidelity, but you must perceiver throughout times of great change and recognize the potential.
View7: As with any large institution, you tend to get lost with the amount of people and how huge the organizational chart is. I also feel, that at least in my company (FTG, FISC, Infrastructure, whatever it is called this month) there is a disconnect between Management (directors and above) and non management. In my last company I felt like the organization was more of a family, and here I feel like I can not approach management because I am below them, very close door policy. Obviously 2008 was a challenging year, and the financial services industry as a whole has been a challenge, its sometimes hard to see past the turmoil when your job itself is unknown. Finally I think theres a lot of employees who are “lifers”, people who glide by just doing the minimum and not adding real progressive value.

Title: Fidelity wants Senior itizen employees
View5:
No age discrimination at all.  I was hired at age 62 as a beginning employee.  The training was intense and excellent,.  One of the requirements for staying is that you HAVE to pass the Series 7 licensing exam.  For a person who is interested in istock and fund investing, this is a great place to learn.  The company has a rigid insistence on integrity, which is a good thing.  I worked with persons who had been at Merrill, and other companies; they universally said that the expectation of integrity made communications with customers much easier for all parties.

Fidelity offers various Health Insurance and savings programs; insurance is very good.  Also, the 401K Program, Pension, etc are excellent.

Fidelity Phone Representatives are available 24/7,  In an on-the-phones team. at about six monts intervals, you have the opportunity to bid to move to a different shift.
View7:
The company requires a college degree for evey employee who will have contact with the public, but the starting slalary seems low for that type of position.  There are opportunities to earn bonuses, but you are competing with all other employees in your job type for the share of a fixed "pot" of money.  Since I was the age of some of my supervisor's parents, and I had also been a senior military officer, two of them appeared to fell awkward about advising me about job performance, and took a harsh tone to cover up their embarassment.  This was only two persons in eight years with the company;  most persons in Team Leader/Management positions are excellent.

The shift work requirements can become very wearing, especially late shifts.

Title: A challenging company, but successful
View5: They pay well. People are very polite, and the management structure is very clear.
View7: It is an extremely political corporate culture and you have to fit in to get ahead. There is one style of behavior that is considered appropriate and you are expected to act that way. You have to be very careful about expressing your opinions--getting along is valued very highly. You have to learn how to fit in with the corporate culture.

Title: People are treated with respect, most employees have a positive attitude and great place to start a career.
View5: The culture is one of respect for co-workers at all levels.  People really do care about your life outside of work.  I have met some wonderful people there that I will always stay in contact with.  Too many themes and flavors of the week to promote productivity and increase morale.  But they do really cute things like ice cream socials, all types of charity promotions, flue shot day, etc...  In the last few years, they seemed to have nailed down certain slogans that teams incorporated into their daily work.  I started my career there out of school, and learned how important image and perception is correlated to what opportunities your manager or senior person will give to you.  Great place to start a career.  I worked in Operations, so the raises sucked, but my hours were pretty much 8:30 to 5.  Most people are out by 5 in the Ops group.  All the internal systems that are meant for the employees to navigate through technology requests, benefits and pay are fantastic.  Most of the time, you are given the right tools to succeed in your job.  Metrics reporting sucked.    But if you come in with a positive attitude then you will get one back most of the time.
View7: I would say the salaries are not competitive and merit increases are insignificant, but at the same time, there was never a year when an increase did not happen, or when a bonus was cancelled.

Title: Can be a great company (depending on what business unit you work for).
View5:
It's a company with one of the best reputations in the industry, and it's especially good working for a privately held in the current market environment.  The constant internal message from senior management is that rule #1 is "what's right for the client"....no matter what your role is.  

I'm constantly impressed at the depth of knowledge at FMR (can't speak for other business units, but reference my "Cons").  I've worked at other firms and constantly feel that I work with some of the best and smartest people in the industry.  

Working for FMR (as opposed to other business units within Fidelity) is a real plus too.
View7:
It seems that compensation tends to be less competitive (at least in the non-supervisory roles).  I think Fidelity recognizes that their name cache on your resume is "value enough" in their eyes for future opportunities outside of the the company.

Because Fidelity has so many seperately managed business units under the "Fidelity Investments" umbrella, the cultures can vary widely.  I've interacted with some employees in other business units (outside of FMR) who seem to have a very relaxed work environment ("think I'll leave at 3 today...it's Friday, and it's so nice outside!") or generally seem to be less impressive on a talent level-- some business units' Directors or even VPs are less qualified/knowledgable than many of the non-managers in FMR.

That being said, there does seem to be either a little bit of arrogance from, or a little bit of jealousy toward, FMR in interactions between business units.

Title: Great Company with wonderful benefits.  Hard to move about internally if you want off a phones position once hired.
View5: Great Benefits and Professional environment.  They treat their employees well.
View7: Hard to move to different areas of the company as an internal transfer.  If you want to move off a phones position it is very hard to do.

Title: Weak Management
View5: Outstanding co-workers. Wages are fair. Offers health insurance, dental, and investment and plan. Facilities acceptable but quite a drive.
View7: Low level management reminds me of McDonald's. Issues are approached in a very negative way. No learning moments here. Favoritism, vindictiveness and worst of all: lack of integrity. Will actually lie when confronted with misinformation. VERY tense environment.

Title: Excellent Company
View5: Fidelity has many opportunities for advancement and offers great employee benefits.  The salary is generous and the raises and profit sharing bonuses are very impressive. I loved working for this company.
View7: Unfortunately, I was laid off. It may be best to join an internal team that is profitable.  When job cuts begin, it is usually with newer teams who have not gained profits within the company.

Title: A good place to get launched into the world of Financial Services
View5: Great training with lots of hands on instruction on how to accomplish the objectives of the position.  Routine meetings to review and assess the successes and shortcomings of the team's work.
View7: In the area that I started in, there was a significant amount of rote and redundancy in the work to be accomplished.

Title: Generic overview
View5: Great financial benefits - tuition assistance, student loan assistance, retirement plans, health care plans, long term employees, low pressure, great education possibilities, great cafeterias, great non-financial benefits - community activities, fitness center, beautiful building settings, and much more.....
View7: Takes time to advance, compensation increases are limited, long term employees might have narrow view of alternatives, most offices in cubicle have low walls and little privacy.....

Title: Financial Associate - Defined Contributions
View5:
-Company culture is very supportive and encouraging of employee development
- Lots of opportunities for movement within the company
- Horizontal organizational structure which provides plenty of opportunities for interaction with senior leadership
- Company is actively modernizing benefits package
View7:
- Phone-based role that can feel very repetitive
- Horizontal organizational structure has plenty of opportunities for lateral movement, but limited upward mobility

Title: Privately held company transforms to feel more like a publicly held company.
View5:
Fantastic people and team mates
Employee health benefits and retirement savings
Compensation is better than most companies
View7:
Old school leadership feels more dictatorial, top down "must do" rather than a rich collaborative style.  
Incredibly fraternal to the point of keeping long term ineffective leaders 
Employee layoffs always seem to be communicated most often right before the end of year holidays.
A pattern of job eliminations and layoffs with highly tenured, long time employees over the age of 50.

Title: Vice President
View5: Great people to work with; smart, interested, involved.  Great benefits and some perks.
View7: Some managers are promoted or hired because of who they know, not how well they manage or are open to other ideas.  Creates a tough environment for those who think differently.

Title: Solid Employer
View5: Great training and support, great culture and generally active in the community.  Pay wasn't always competitive but the overall benefits package was hard to beat.  Great people to work with most of the time.
View7: Too PC.  The company has catered to the new generation and era of politically correctness to the point that you feel like some changes are just to say they are making changes and you have to walk on eggshells and watch everything you do or say or someone will be offended and call HR.  Crazy sensitive

Title: Supervisors are tough and Unsupportive
View5:
Great pay
On the job training/ study hours
prepares you for the tough job ahead
View7: The hiring manager at the time was AWFUL. Told me several times he didn't believe I would succeed and then told me I wouldn't have a job much longer. Eventually I couldn't take it after he told me not to bother coming back. He called the next morning to yell and me and ask why I wasn't there. Safe to say I was glad I left before things got worse.

Title: Great Company, Poor Local Leadership
View5:
Compensation
Very little prospecting of clients since the business is there
View7:
Local leadership

Advisors answer the switchboard and double as receptionists.

Advisors are asked to work the front desk like a bank teller from time to time and this cuts into their day. Slows productivity to work on service, but we are measured on sales.

Their email system is antiquated and doesn't permit for clients to be emailed from Outlook. Slows down the productivity.

Title: Good stepping stone.
View5:
- Fidelity's downtown location can not be beat.  
- It's a great stepping stone for college graduates who want to work in the financial industry as there are (were) many job opportunities within the company.
View7: Sometimes you have to wonder how some colleagues in senior level positions ever got to where they are in the company.

Title: Annuitys are a small fun group at Fidelity.
View5: Great people, lots of talent.  Excellent benefits, strong company.
View7: Difficult to move into Management with such a small department to choose from.  Pay is minimum.  Job can get repetitive at times.  At time you can feel micromanaged.

Title: Good place to work and grow.
View5: Good location,  very smart people to work with and learn from, the compensation is competitive, benefits are good too. You get enough resources to get your job done.
View7: Given Fido is an investment firm, the investment professionals get all the attention. As an employee from technology side, people may feel left out a bit.

Title: Good job but too much bureaucracy.
View5: The team I work on is very cohesive and an overall positive experience.  When we get to do "agile" it works very well.
View7: Working with other groups within the organization tends to be very cumbersome.  Working together seems to be more of the exception than the rule.  Performance reviews are all about how well you're known to the organization, not what you've contributed to your team or how well you work.  Management doesn't seem all that receptive to problems brought up by the employees.

Title: On a downward curve over the last three to four years due to constant management and org churn.
View5: Fidelity has a good compensation program, which gets better at the most senior levels.  Has a greta number of very talented people who are always trying to improve business results.
View7: Company projects a sesne of uncertainty at the top.  Significant churn in the most senior ranks tends to lead to continous changes in direction.  Matters more who you know rather than what you know.  Constantly laying people off.

Title: Highly secretive organization that watches your every move.
View5: Incredible benefits and pay. Generous paid time off. Opportunity to grow your career is very good if you get out of call centers.
View7: Incredibly micromanaged, you are literally a number. Lack of any real diversity at the top. Out of touch managment in Boston. Nepotism at its finest at the most senior level of the company.

Title: Upper management tells a great story, but it's just window dressing
View5: Great training for getting Series 7 licensing.
View7: Fidelity is interested in hiring young people who are willing to live in fear just to keep their job. If you have a personality or are creative and think outside the box , you are not valued here. Super uptight environment, everyone is terrified that if they make one wrong move they will be in trouble.  If you are a yes man robot, without sense of humor, this is the place for you.

Title: Experience varies greatly with different groups, overall a sweat shop
View5: Good exposure and opportunities to learn in the Financial Industry. Fidelity is extremely dedicated to it's customers.
View7: Staffing reductions and off-shoring combined with constant reorganization and relocations make employment very precarious unless you're willing to up and move to Raleigh or Dallas. SME experience is undervalued. Bureaucratic and dilbert-like.

Title: Engineering Position
View5: I loved the people with whom I worked, they are a smart and talented group.
View7: The culture is a bit straight-laced especially when compared to newer companies run by generation X or younger people.  Also, it's a mutual fund company first and foremost.  The company has a history of technical innovation but they aren't a tech company so it seems like technical teams are hit hard when the markets contract.

Title: Good company; pay scale changes too often.
View5: Solid company, a lot of opportunities to grow and get promoted (especially if you're willing to move).
View7: The branch network is like a different company with high management turnover and a new bonus system basically every year. It's focused heavily on activity around new clients which makes it difficult to do a good job maintaining long term clients. That's how Fidelity tries to keep you from building a book of clients that might follow you to a private RIA

Title: Good opportunity
View5: I very much enjoyed my time at fidelity, had the opportunity to work with a great team, family environment.
View7: Must work with a lot of stubborn clientele. Lots of work with low pay. If management doesn't like you there will be no mobility in your career. Management is overly strict  and need to relax

Title: Defined Contributions Representative
View5: The benefits were good. Company match on 401k up to 7%, which is the best I've seen.
View7: Never ending calls. I would never recommend working in the call center. It's exhausting and highly highly monitored. You'll feel very insignificant to the company. It's all about metrics.

Title: 4 years at Fidelity
View5: It's a privately-owned company that invests a vast amount of money in its technology. Great training programming for entry-level software developers. Great company culture. Benefits are amazing once you've been here for a while.
View7: It's such a large company, you may not find a good fit with your first team and/or manager. The company actively encourages moving to other teams, so it's not hard to find a great team eventually. Majority of the tech teams are not agile, but use their own version of agile which is pretty much waterfall.

Title: High Net Worth Associates
View5: Good benefits, many opportunities for growth, lots of training and license support. Also, good to be in an environment with so many other representatives doing the same thing who you can collaborate and learn from.
View7: This isn't necessarily Fidelity's fault, but the nature of doing a phone role leads to little schedule flexibility and lots of micromanaging. Dealing with customer's in a phone setting is challenging insofar as its nonstop.

Title: Great Company
View5: One of the best benefits packages, great for those with families, campus is beautiful, lots of different jobs at the site to allow you to go what ever direction you want.
View7: Numbers game high quantity focus over quality, over 7000 employees make it difficult to build your brand and can get lost in the mix, lack of transparency when trying to navigate getting a promotion to a different role other then the suggested path.

Title: Very flexible, well trained and supported
View5: I had a good relationship with my coworkers and superiors, felt like I could move up with effort, and was listened to when I suggested improvement. VERY DIVERSE
View7: Large corporation which comes with its own issues - Fidelity does well to prevent many of them but there are certainly still corporate downsides like multiple moving parts, and rigid expectations in certain areas.

Title: Good training but it's a stalled and defensive culture
View5: hands-off management style, name brand company, stable, decent  benefits and work-life balance , product diversity and reach, competent co-workers, can always look elsewhere in the company (variety and diversity of jobs to move into), resources and deep pockets,
View7: Politics, management turnover (constant), hoop jumping as a result.  Individual stars rewarded versus team players, competition internally, good work can go unnoticed unless favored, engineering and technology driven culture often clashes with marketing elements

Title: Principled and solid company
View5: A strong sense of right and wrong and a very strong brand name.  The past year or so has seen a lot of transition withing the company.  Relocations and job eliminations are very nerve racking.  However, my impression to date based on personal experience and talking with other colleagues, Fidelity tries to ensure a seamless transition.
View7: As of the date of this submission, there are jobs being transfered to new locations.  Relocation is not necessarilly a bad thing, but does cause anxiety.

Title: Great company overall, but bad recent management hiring decisions.
View5: Great people, great culture, and overall great company.  Good opportunities to bounce around to different parts of the organization.
View7: The family owned company has recently taken in senior leaders from public companies, they shook things up, and now they are all gone with their golden parachutes.

Title: Good company, good benefits, good people
View5:
benefits are good - medical, dental, vision, short and long term disability, life ins, some locations have onsite gyms, most locations have cafeterias, time off, 
work life balance
opportunity for advancement
View7:
frequent reorgs create a lot of unnecessary noise
frequent manager changes cause day to day disruption, as you have to figure out how to manage your manager
inconsistent messages from first line management
lack of mentoring programs unless you are a new college hire

Title: Great for Recent Grads!
View5: The Financial Representative position is a fantastic entry level position at Fidelity. It exposes you to customer's fears and educates you on how to fix them. Expects you to get your licensing exams in a timely fashion with tremendous support. Overall, this experience laid the foundation for my career in financial services, would recommend it to anyone graduating.
View7: Repetitive. Almost too lax of a culture, professional standard sways

Title: Good place - capable management
View5:
Management very supportive.  PWIS systems and operations have a good learning curve to them. Master them and you are ready to take on anything.  People and business units you work with are great.
Many people I worked with had been within Fidelity for a LONG time.  Once you are in, You're in.  The accrued benefits seem to keep people around.
View7: Gets stale after a few years, the monotony of the type of work you do can be taxing.  Enrollment season can turn co-workers batty (busy season)

Title: Great company
View5: Great company to work for with great pay and benefits, talented employees, and a "do what it takes" spirit.  I personally have seen great career progression over the course of my career at Fidelity.
View7: Work-life balance has never really been Fidelity's strong point.  Constant change - some good, some bad.  Past 10 years has seen a significant amount of job movement to either the South or oversees.

Title: Phones
View5: it is a job with good overall benefits.  Nice campus setting
View7: terrible pay.  most managers should not be managers.  Management does not listen to their employees' concerns.  Favoritism.  Did not see promotions based off of business needs being accomplished but more who you know.

Title: Extremely diverse and challenging company to work for - Fidelity invests in their employees career with the firm.
View5: Fidelity places a great deal of emphasis on taking care of employees - from the on-site facilities, to health benefits, compensation packages, retirement, promotion of personal development, etc.  They are the most employer centric companies I've every worked for.
View7: Depending on department or your work background, it can sometimes be difficult to move between jobs.  Also, at times the work/life balance can be lacking.

Title: Great IT jobs at Fidelity
View5: Fidelity spend $3 billion on IT providing many great jobs in IT.   There are also many opportunities to move between business units for career growth.  Fidelity has a very rich benefit package.
View7: Fidelity's global site strategy is constantly relocating positions across United States and overseas.  Sometimes you are given the opportunity to relocate if the job is within US but never if it is overseas.  Also you could be relocated with your position and then a few years later your job could go overseas.

Title: Great Benefits
View5: Fidelity takes good care of its employees. Its a culture of ensuring that employees are well taken care of. Benefits include wellness center; gym; cultural clubs; social events
View7: There is a lot of politics at higher levels. The impact to the financial market, immediately impacts the program funding, and leads to budget pressures

Title: Client Manager
View5: Great benefits, good work hours, paid lunches when asked to work through your lunch
View7: Management is not trained to identify and grow talent. Too many layers of management. Not enough intelligent people in higher positions. Very shovanistic and hostile environment.  Too many managers bullying you.

Title: Used to be great
View5: Benefits, licensing opportunities, flex scheduling, and great people to work with
View7: The pace at which the company is changing so rapidly its hard to keep up.

Title: Financial Consultant role- an introductory financial planning role at the very best
View5: A small bit of flexibility, income potential, benefits and an organization who is attempting to move in the right direction.
View7: - very repetitive - extremely sales oriented rather than planning or relationship oriented - lack of transparency amongst management - a firm attempting to evolve as a full wealth management firm but still manages in an extremely transactional manner

Title: Great pay, confused management, terrible HR/Employee relations
View5: Salary, bonus and Benefits are great - almost too great because people tend to stay there too long because of the money.
View7: The semi-annual performance reviews are a bad joke.  Management has no idea what you're doing and they base the 'feedback' on nothing more than their gut feeling of what they think you do.

Title: Educational at best.
View5: Excellent wages, superior benefits, new buildings, great perks during AE, lovely coworkers, great annual bonus potential, some good management personnel.
View7: Major differences in job descriptions and the job you were actually hired for, extreme security measures and documentation, too much business required by phone conferencing, "good ole boy" promotional system.  Very workaholic, A-type, metrics driven work environment.

Title: Tax Exempt Representative
View5: Supportive Management. Excellent Training Program. Great Benefits. Consistant Feedback. Career advancement opportunities are available for those who put in the work. Flexibility is key to being successful.
View7: Managers can sometimes overlook hard-workers. Some shifts are late since the TEM department is open until midnight. The environment is constantly changing (may be a good thing for some).

Title: Excellent company overall
View5: Great atmosphere, no back-stabbing, everyone is very helpful.  Low-pressure environment because you are paid based on customer satisfaction rather than commission.  Good training program and lots of potential to move up in the company.
View7: Relatively low pay for this position, company tends to be a bit overly conservative, company is hemorrhaging 401k customers so overall, the customer base is shrinking.  Hold times can be atrocious.

Title: Good Place to work
View5:
Benefits... 7% 401k match, 10% profit sharing, good health insurance along with $1000 in HSA money each year given to you, fitness reimbursement.

You don't take your work home with you and also time and half anything worked over 40 hrs, no weekends.
View7: Call center environment. Constantly on phone and can be mentally and emotionally exhausting. Hard to move to position that is not on phones.

Title: Good Company for Entry into the Industry
View5:
Sponsored Licensing which they pay, great benefits, though the bonus structure is fairly complex and someone "team based" around Customer satisfaction.
Turnover/flow through fairly high and able to promote quickly
View7: IT support lacking in area. While feedback is accepted on systems and product development it seems upper management doesn't have a good understanding of what should be prioritized for updates/fixes for client facing roles.

Title: Not really all it's cracked up to be
View5:
Food - excellent cafe and great selections that are IF healthy options subsidized by Fidelity
EXCELLENT BENEFITS!
View7:
Managers treat people as though they are expendable when in reality we no longer are - not at the rate that people are retiring!
There is NO accountability among senior management
People in Management Position really and I mean REALLY don't seem to know what they are doing!
Excellent Benefits will only keep the lazy not the innovators or leaders of today.

Title: great company
View5: great company, better benefits, lot of improvements to keep employees interested and motivated in the work place. would suggest to any recent graduate
View7: some people do not prefer to work on the phones, but in my area specifically there are many branch locations to move too which counteract the phone center atmopshere

Title: Financial Associate
View5: The company has a great amount of benefits that allow you to be successful in life. Great campus to work at and the systems are state of the art.
View7: Salary is not as competitive like other Financial firms but you can offset that with the benefits that are being offered. Company culture is great but it does depend on what department your role lands into.

Title: I worked for the company for 12 years.
View5: Pay is ok, bonus are a nice incentive when aligned to a manager who isn't after their own profits.   Most of my years with the company were profitable and tolerable.  The last two years were miserable, at best.
View7: The hours are dreadful in operations.  Expect 80-100 hour workweeks and managers who believe you have absolutely no life outside of the firm

Title: Bully Culture/Old School
View5: Great Pay and benefits were progressive.
View7:
Bully culture and old school top down management teams in place. Experienced it first hand from senior leadership across company.
Constant time spent on identifying areas of innovation/new business ideas but nothing comes from it.

Title: Full trader
View5: Amazing culture, management is top notch. They treat you the same way they focus on investing. Invest in their employees heavily up front and then allow you to grow where ever best fits your own personal goals.
View7: Not much of anything honestly. The work/life balance ensures you can’t get overwhelmed or bogged down IF you don’t want. It’s a great place

Title: Financial service associate
View5: Great benefits with decent pay for what the job was
View7: Call center environment.  Extremely hard to move out of the call center into actual roles within the organization. You have to make multiple lateral moves before you begin to move forward and roles typically require you be there for at least a year.

Title: Be ready to work!
View5: Incredible benefits - 10% profit sharing, 7% $1 for $1 401k co. match, terrific health insurance and numerous other benefits like student loan assistance and tuition reimbursement.
View7: Super busy - cutting costs, as everyone else, but Fidelity is really conservative and putting a lot more work with the VERY smaller groups

Title: Software Engineer
View5:
Flexible schedule
Good support
Big company
Stable job
View7:
Mediocre developers. Low pay and hard to move up. 
Work is not challenging lots of functional web apps.
HR is corrupted my coworker and I have encountered very rude, disrespecting scrum masters or managers but HR did not do anything. 
Demotivated and depressed to work here. I am not recognized for tech skills but networking skills. Also I was being monitored and micromanaged all the time.

Title: Supportive culture and great benefits
View5: Tons of useful and valuable benefits, career mobility opportunities and leadership that cares and supports you through career and family changes
View7: Occasional layoffs and frequent org changes and put associates at unease about where they fit in.

Title: Everything was better when Uncle Ned was in charge.
View5:
Overtime 
Really nice co workers and leadership
Health Insurance is top notch
Merrimack NH has an awesome cafeteria
View7:
Unless you are in PAS you are pretty much looked down upon as garbage

They will build a department up just to tear it down.

Title: Great company if you can put up with BIG company politics
View5: They take care of their employees and you will work with intelligent people. Expect a lot of autonomy in how you do your job.
View7: Like any large company you have to cope with office politics. Innovation is not easy to push through the layers of management.

Title: Great place to work if you're ready to roll up your sleeves and apply yourself!
View5: Great variety and opportunity for learning. Good people stick around. If you're intelligent and know how to apply your talents, you'll excel. Fidelity has great online tools to help you get your job done.
View7:
Contractors are treated with different standards, and there are a whole lot of them.
Fidelity's online workplace management tools can be overwhelming.

Title: Put in the work and it's so worth it.
View5: As long as you aren't a phone rep, Fidelity is supportive of growth. Unlike a lot of these reviews I entered as an entry level right out of college and moved up through Team Lead in the matter of 3 years. Put in the effort to do your job well and it WILL be recognized. The raises have been small lately, but so has the economy.
View7: Co-workers who are not happy in life will trash and smash the work, their employer and their pay.

Title: Meh..
View5: They have great health and 401k benefits as well as vacation.  There are a lot of great people and they really promote a team atmosphere.  A lot of continuing education and reimbursement opportunities for education.
View7: You are chained to the phone.  You have a ton of measures you have to hit and very little independence.  They micromanage you to death and beat the Fidelity way into you.  The growth opportunities seem to be confined to the phone site.

Title: Great place to "have" worked for.
View5: People were fantastic!  I never worried about the stability of the firm, or the leadership of the company... except during the Lawson years.   Difficulty moving out of the phone site.
View7: Lack of opportunity as a manager to really progress.  Log jam at the next level.  Didn't want to do the "manager merrry-go-round."

Title: Fidelity
View5:
You never have to take your work home with you.
Benefits are great.
Lots of 20 somethings, fun people to be around.
Pretty easy job - which can be a con, too.
Great company in general.
View7:
The day to day responsibilities can be mundane.
You can get stuck with an incompetent manager, however, most are fine.
Few career paths to choose from.

Title: great work but hard on people
View5:
- outstanding technology and resources
- best compensation around
- a lot of different business units means a lot of opportunities to grow
View7:
- chaotic
- constantly revolving door for senior management 
- very tactical - seems to lack strategic vision
- constant flux and fear of lay-offs makes for an extremely unproductive workforce. focus is more on keeping your job than doing a great job

Title: I think it was a great place to work, but not for me.
View5: There was a relaxed environment within my department, however I know that it was a unique situation and driven by the VP within our operations. I could have stood to be in a different environment.
View7: The recruiting within some teams seemed to be heavily slanted to those based on a friendship basis over merit or ability at times. Overall the company seemed fair, but the department I was in seemed to overlook some who were dedicated.

Title: Great company, if you don't get stuck with a terrible manager.
View5: Great benefits, paid training and they pay for your licensing.
View7: The company promotes reps into management and most of the reps should not be in management. The managers aren't required to have a college degree and are more of trading specialist rather than managers. If you get stuck with a bad manager your career development is shattered.

Title: Big company with great benefits
View5: Benefits, large co that spends on tech, fast paced, lots of areas to work in, challenging

Title: Great organization with teamwork and sales as a culture
View5: Leading financial service provider that does what is right for the client. Feel good about positioning products that you know are a great value to the customer. Good culture and recognition of accomplishments.

Title: End User Support Technician
View5:
Fair pay and great benefits. Earned 70k in my 401k over 7 years in an customer service job.
Clean, professional work environment. 
Clearly defined objectives. Lots of opportunity for internal transfers, moving up, etc.
View7:
You are a number. 
It's all about who you know. 
No creative thinkers, please.
Outsourcing.

Title: Great Place to Work
View5: The office environment is great. I love just about everyone there. You even have the chance to interact with the Senior Management Team from time to time. All employees are very knowledgable. Always open to new ideas and the Work/Life balance is great.
View7:
Compared to other places the base salary is not that great.
Unnecessary training
People with less seniority seem to do more of the administrative work

Title: Work Place Guidance Consultant
View5: Is a great company to work for will help you get your security license and teach you good sales skills.  Opportunity to move up if you are willing to look for it and flexible to move. Also the benefits are excellent,

Title: Great Place to Work with Some Caveats
View5:
- Great compensation and benefits, especially after you've been there 3 years

- Lack of transparency about decision making
- Can be very paternalistic toward employees

Title: Director quality assurance
View5:
Great benefits...great people and great opportunities to move around.

You can come here to stay...Overall great place to work.

Poor vision and lack of strategy by senior management. Heavy on politics...Lacks work/life balance for some key individuals.

Base Pay scale is low compared to Industry...

Title: Great Place to Work
View5: Great medical and dental benefits and profit sharing. Great work/life balance. Good starting salary. Four weeks vacation after five years. A great place to work!
View7: They are outsourcing their print mail work to outside vendors. If the market goes down, Fidelity does budget cuts and reorganization. Those two things usually mean lost jobs.

Title: Trading Execution Representative

View7: The commute sucked due to where I live, and the role changed so much.  What used to be a fun job that was highly quantitative and fast-paced turned soft and became nothing but sales, attempting to bring in new money and maintain it through sycophancy.

Title: Financial Consultant
View5: Private company. Salary and variable compensation. Good benefits. Largest retirement company in the US. Full suite of investment options. Discount broker with full service capabilities.

Title: Director, Communications Consultant
View5: The company has excellent benefits, feels like pay is above industry average and it lives up to what it says, there is a lot of integrity there.
View7: It needs to continue to promote more woman and find more diversity of employment.

Title: Come for financial industry licensing, stay for benefits and career opportunities
View5: One of the most generous benefits packages and lots of opportunity if you're willing to work your way there.
