Branches provide sometimes a faster advancement opportunity, but promote a more competitive, less friendly environment. Having a good manager is key to advancement, so you have to be wise about every step forward or sideways you take.

Title: Outstanding Place to Work
View5: Great place to start your career given the breadth of opportunities available post-entry level job, as well as best-in-class benefits such a contribution matching.
View7: One of the only cons I think is a general lack of geographic diversity among particularly in the Boston area offices.

Title: Working at Fidelity
View5: I didn't know what i was getting into 24 years ago, but I am so glad i made the leap!  Fantastic job opportunities and growth/development, culture where everyone cares about you as a person and not a number or a means to an end, benefits that are top-notch!
View7: Not many to be honest - not all roles have the same flexibility for things like working from home/working from anywhere, but even the call center front-line customer roles have a WFH option after a certain period of time

Title: Not bad entry
View5: Good entry level financial experience. They like to promote from within. Decent pay for the work that you have to do.
View7: Call center is extremely micromanaged. The managers can make a difference. In the end they just want you to do your job but they have so many people who do the bare minimum that it makes it necessary to micromanage, which ruins the job for those of us who take pride in what we do.

Title: working at Fidelity
View5: Even though it is not the same company as it was 10 year ago it is still a good place to work if you have a drive and can work in fast paced and volatile environment
View7: A lot of turmoil and politics, management has good talks, but don't really follow up on their words and policies.

Title: 20-Year Vet Reflects
View5: Fantastic benefits over the years, although these are being cut back.  Great people, although the level of tension has increased in the last few years.
View7: See the "pros" section, too.  Once you reach a certain level (somewhere around the high Director / low VP level), there are fewer opportunities to advance and you're more likely to be cut.

Title: Plenty of opportunity, but hampered by poor leadership at senior levels.
View5: bright and dedicated people, international opportunities, good work environment, salary and benefits commensurate with industry, lots of interesting work to do
View7: senior management not impressive, lack of leadership shown, direction of company not clear, mistakes repeated numerous times, despite international opportunities, appalling lack of cultural understanding

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Excellent company to work for with great values. Management cares for their employees and their career development. Its a great opportunity for a recent college graduate to learn about the financial services industry.
View7: I was interested in a career change and had a difficult time moving into a different position within the company. There is a specific career path for Financial Representatives and is difficult to move into other positions that fall outside of that path.

Title: It's been a great learning experience.
View5: Gain tons of market knowledge and get great training. Work with good people, and it is a respectable firm. Good place to start a career
View7: It is hard to advance within the company some times. They don't pay fantastic and if they hire someone into the same job you're doing from an outside firm, expect them to be making a lot more than you.

Title: Great company to work for, most of the time.
View5: Competitive pay, treats employees well, lots of unique benefits, continuously improves employee experience & opportunities, strong ethical standards.
View7: Many policies set in stone without consideration to individual employee situations.  Loyalty is not always rewarded.  Very competitive and sometimes political internal advancement and mobility.  Strict & methodical salary grades.  HR screening process for applicants could be better.

Title: Solid company to work for, but not cutting edge in terms of technology.
View5: Good benefits, above average pay, great bonuses, stable company. Senior Management is older and mostly promoted from internal groups which shows you can have a long career here.
View7: Technology groups moved slow to market, used older technologies that legacy systems are based on. Many times there is a mentality that if it's not broke don't fix it, even when systems have the potential for improvement.

Title: Great place to work
View5: As an IT professional, this is a great place to work.  The company invests in technology a lot and is proud to be one of the best companies in the technology field in the tech magazines.  Benefit package is one of the best in the industry, with exceptional company match/profit sharing for retirement.  Abundant opportunities for training.
View7: The general salary level seems a bit lower compared to the industry average, which is compensated by the great retirement benefit package.

Title: Corporate cult environment
View5: You get great benefits - everything from health insurance, disability, to shopping discounts. It pays rather well considering that you don't need much experience beyond customer service to get hired here. Fidelity also embraces diversity and community service.
View7:
This company has an uncomfortably cult like environment. Everyone has to put on an air of completely loving Fidelity and loving their job like they are brainwashed robots; if you don't play along, you will have problems. If you want to reveal your true feelings about the job, or you have something remotely negative to say, think carefully about who to confide in. It's actually pretty vital to be over the top pro-Fidelity if you want any chance of transferring around or getting a promotion one day. However, plenty of people still don't get to move around or get the promotions that they deserve because they don't act brainwashed enough and/or they're so good that they are kept trapped in the call center forever. Some managers have all but lost their call center skills and they basically serve as cheerleader coaches. They might "coach" you on what to say, but rarely will get on the phone themselves and have lost touch with what the job entails.

In the call center you are micro-managed severely. Co-workers and managers will sit down with you and pick apart your calls word for word. You'll be invited to pick apart other calls as well. Every second on the job is recorded and timed. If your call extends into your lunch break or you have to take an extra bathroom break, you'll be out of adherence which you will be reprimanded for and which will affect your next bonus. Your bonus is completely up to your manager's discretion, by the way, which has quite a few implications. Your team will compete with other teams to have the best stats and you will receive judgment for yours, even though most of it seems nonsensical and/or out of your control.

Orientation frames the job as pretty great. You have a blast with your new co-workers and are spoiled with fun activities and long lunches. But once you are out on the floor and the novelty has worn off, you see the job is more about statistics than anything else. Customer service is heavily emphasized in conversation, yet all that really counts is call lengths, schedule adherence, how much your manager likes you, being fanatically pro-Fidelity, and being subjected to constant and excessive micro-managing and taking it all with a smile and nod. 

It's hard not to even have the support of your co-workers. The gossiping is incredible. For some, this place is really their life's career and they will never leave, so you must be careful about what you say about the company and you have to navigate the strange drama of people who have worked there for years. There are also so many people in the call center that you will regularly have other people's mistakes dumped on to you via a livid customer and/or will find that co-workers don't care to take a transfer or help you during a difficult call. Burnout here tends to make people curt and apathetic toward each other, which is no fun when you have a customer on the line and a manager who's constantly looking to find fault in your actions. I constantly felt stranded. 

I should mention that the job itself of answering calls is not easy. In short, there is an entire book behind every retirement plan. You have customers throwing all sorts of crazy and complex questions at you while you have to stall for time while browsing an extensive encyclopedia of information. You will find that your resources are incomplete, confusing, way too elaborate, and/or misleading on a regular basis, which renders a lot of stressful and difficult calls. Have I mentioned all the abuse you have to swallow from customers? They are way worse than customers face-to-face. Some days you feel like you are being attacked on all sides. 

Although everyone has to act like Fidelity is utterly amazing, give it enough time and you'll see what's really going on - the nonsensical promotions, people becoming trapped in the call center - denied every opportunity to take a new position, and unable to leave the company because they have no transferable skills - people's relief to get off the phones whenever allowed, the apathy, etc. it's depressing. It's the unhappiest work environment for a customer service job because you have to act completely fake all the time with everyone you work with and every single thing you say and do is watched and usually ripped apart by co-workers and managers. I had a lot of awful days on this job and was so happy to get ou. 

I guess this place is okay if you have no other options and/or you like being micro-managed in a corporate cult. Otherwise steer clear.

Title: Great company Benefits, Work can be VERY demanding
View5: Excellent benefits, IT employees are well equipped with hardware and software, campuses are very nice, managers are very flexible about time away from office and working from home (when there is a real need)
View7: Little direction from managers (you might only speak with your manager twice a month), way too much work to do, way too much red tape to deal with, way too many evenings spent working

Title: Security Lending Specialist Review
View5:
- I came in with a group of associates who were young and my age
- Fidelity always provides stable job security in rough times
- depending on the department, its a good work/life balance
View7:
- the overall environment is very negative, you can tell that lots of people just do it for the job, which in my case was not enough money to justify staying
- not a lot of lateral growth outside of the operations department
- the pay is just below average and bonuses are laughable

Title: Used to be a great place to work....
View5: Fidelity's benefits package is amazing, I don't know of a company that has better benefits.  Every group I have worked in has an array of diverse, intelligent and super friendly people.  I have made life long friends throughout my years at Fidelity. For a newly graduated college student, Fidelity is a great place to get your feet wet, to learn (their training programs are topnotch) and for an entry level position, the pay is very competitive.
View7: I have been with Fidelity almost 12 years and made my way through a few different departments along the way.  For the first few years, there really seemed to be a Fidelity culture, we were all proud to be working at such a great company with such integrity. But as the years wore on and I sat in a role where I felt doomed to stay because moving up beyond my current position at the time was not an easy feat, I did finally land that "destination role" position, the one I thought I would be with until I retired. Fast forward to today, currently two year in the "salaried" position and miserable. I am doing the work of three people because they won't back fill our department, we work some times 80 or more hours a week just to stay on top of what is put in front of us. The promised "big" raises, we were told was nixed from above. The morale is horrible. I have been sick more than I care to mention from the stress. I entered this role knowing very little about the position and there wasn't any training, I was handed 130 clients to start with and told, you'll figure it out. My laptop has never worked properly, mail doesn't go out or come in all the time, to name one of the many issues, no one knows how to fix it, nor will they replace it.  I never thought I would say this about Fidelity, but I do feel like a number. I have talked to many of my co-workers in other groups who are feeling the same way, so it's not just the group I am in. Right now, until I can find (or have time to find) another job, it's just a paycheck, not a career.

Title: Support Role
View5: Fidelity has a lot of great benefits.  Over the last few years they have tried to do more for clients. With the right manager the branch teams are wonderful to work with and feel like family.
View7:
They say there are client focused but the goals would say otherwise.  There seems to be a disconnect on what senior managers want ($) and national wants (client relationship).
They move onto other projects before fixing bugs on old projects.

Title: Great Place to Work!
View5:
The people who work here  are smart and innovative people who love the work they do and most are willing to share their their knowledge and experience.
Technology is state of the art with many opportunities to learn something new every day. 
Some jobs have flexibility and the benefits package and salary is above average.
View7: Most jobs here are not strictly 9 to 5.  If you aren't interested in being challenged every day, learning, and continuous improvement - this may not be a good fit some.

Title: Bully environment
View5: Good benefits. Gym on campus
View7: Fidelity has a culture of junior high bullying. Associates will defame a colleague and lie in order to elevate themselves, and HR will support these Associates in order to protect the firm. This firm is not interested in retaining the best and the brightest but rather sacrifices them to the childish antics of those who are threatened by the more competent employees. The work environment is hostile.

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Great people, great management overall, great benefits and pay, room for growth, I would highly recommend it. If it wasn't a call center job it would be perfect.
View7: Unless you transfer to a physical branch which typically requires moving to a new state, you are stuck on the phone. The phones are ringing nonstop.  Being on the phone sucks.

Title: Fun while it lasted
View5: Flexible environment and work schedules.
View7: High demands as it is hub style position needing the individual to know a little about everything with little room for error and not enough support structure.

Title: Great Career
View5: Fidelity is a great company to have a career with. They really live their values day in and day out, unlike many other companies. They are forward thinking and truly do right by the employees and customers, even if there is an impact to the bottom line.
View7: As with many companies of their size, there is a good amount of red tape and politics the higher you get in the organization. Change can sometimes be slow or not happen at all, depending on size and scope of impact.

Title: Caring
View5: I believe they put people first. The higher level management really cares about the employees and ways to make everyday better for them. Fidelity is a large company that has kept a family feel.
View7:
No part-time positions. They say they want to accommodate people that don't want/need full-time work, but the policies and shift structure do not support that. 

If you stay in one position too long you can get stuck and it becomes difficult to move around.

Title: GREAT Company, mixed priorities
View5: The company treats employees very well. The firm's focus is customer-centric, you have a lot of support, and you're NEVER asked to do anything that's not in the client's best interest.
View7: While the firms mission is good, occasionally the mission is lost by management who misinterpret their role and impart their opinion as if it's the firm's.

Title: Do the benefits out way the cost of career advancement?
View5: Great Benefits. You will not find better in the financial services industry. Low benefits costs allow for more take home pay. Lots of young people and a business casual work environment
View7: Management keeps information close to cuff and does not share. Individuals can be very possessive of their department and valuable information.  Hard to get promoted out of the director level.

Title: Overall, a good place
View5:
Wonderful people - talented and smart
Challenging work - pushes your boundries and invites creative problem solving
Ever changing environment - never the same day twice
View7:
Spin the org chart - change is constant
Time to market is often the driver, over quality
Too many people have to wear too many hats - expect to do more than what you're hired to do.

Title: Great Place for Those Willing to Be Molded in the Fidelity Image
View5: Decent benefits and nice facilities.
View7:
Very autocratic management style.  Senior management would send their grandmothers packing if they thought it would fatten their bonuses.
Little room for diversity.   If you wish to stay as long as possible, opt for a lobotomy ASAP.

Title: In Constant Flux
View5: Great technology,smart people and good communication in a collaborative working environment.  Brought  in some strong outside talent to keep things fresh.
View7: Did not appreciate those who had been there a long time.  Constant reorganizing.  Expensive New York talent lasted a year or less.  Seems to have lost original vision.

Title: Was a good place
View5: great career potential, cool new programs, great strategy
View7:
I was part of a RIF and still stay in touch with some folks that work there.  I understand things have changed.  I hear this about many companies today.  
I basically had a really great job.  If you can do your job well, and you are competent, then you really did have a chance... that was prior to 2009.  Perhaps I am fortunate I can say only good things.

Title: hello
View5: their are many pros like salary, great environment, people are friendly, you will just love looking for employment here. thanks and god bless.
View7: the cons would be that the hours can be a lot longer than what you may be expecting from a job that you are working at but you will love the people you work with.

Title: Decent company, but getting cheap - heading wrong direction
View5:
Very flexible work schedules
Good work life balance
Low stress
View7:
Salary and bonuses are not great
Have cut majority of perks that were previously in place
Difficult to get promoted within the company
Told by a manager to leave company and come back - best way to advance yourself
Very little positive feedback from upper management

Title: Learned a lot...about Fidelity technologies!
View5: Fidelity Investments has excellent benefits (medical, dental, 401k, profit sharing, etc.). The tuition reimbursement program is top notch as well.
View7: A lot of the technologies I worked with are "home grown", making it difficult to transfer learned skills to future jobs elsewhere. Compensation levels are also not in line, in my experience, with similar jobs elsewhere.

Title: Awesome place to start a career
View5: The integrity, trust, honesty, benefits, stability, training, opportunities and people. Incentive to work hard and move up in the company. Learning new things every day. This is the best place to work for and I want to have a long career at Fidelity Investments.
View7: If you are working at one of the biggest, most successful, most stable financial companies in the world that offers the best benefits in the industry and gives unparalleled training, how could you find something to complain about?

Title: High intensity
View5: Great integrity.  You can leave personal items out among hundreds of people and not worry about theft.  Many intelligent people.  Great benefits.
View7: Huge on metrics.  You must stay within a few minutes of an ever changing schedule.  No face to face time with clients.  A call center for promotion after promotion.  Very few investor centers so chances of working in one are not great.

Title: 'Tech Project Manager'
View5:
Support from management is good. They trust their employees. 
Good projects - projects vary and are constantly challenging
Great workforce - nearly everyone who works for Fidelity is someone you would want on your side.
View7:
Lots of red tape
Big company feel - even for tech side
Change resistance - Not as open to change as an agile group should be. Agile methodology is in place but not agile mentality in most cases
Base pay & Grade - lots of emphasis into time at a grade level rather than rewarding performance

Title: Great info to the financial services industry
View5: Great company that really focuses on developing employees and providing them with a good work/life balance.  This is a great place to start your career and get experience working for a large private company.
View7: The biggest con that I have about the company is the low compensation.  The benefits are amazing but in order to be even remotely competitive you have to consider the big picture of 401k and medical insurance which is nice but it will not pay the bills.

Title: Terrific place to work.
View5: As a privately held company, Fidelity is able to invest for the long term.  This is evident in its systems and technology, its commitment to its workforce and its ability steadily grow.  Above all else it is not a firm whose integrity is challenged by the media like many of the big banks and brokerage houses that have been plagued by scandals
View7: decision process too slow. More decisions should be pushed down

Title: Relationship Manager
View5: Salary and benefits are some of the best in the industry.  Very hard to find any benefits that come close.
View7: Work Environment.  Very hectic at times and others not as much.  Too much on the politics and perceptions vs. the truth of the matter.   Too much focus on production and not enough on clients actual needs

Title: Customer Service Representative
View5: Great hours, great people. Really enjoyed my time there. The operation was well-run and the people knew what they were doing.
View7: Not many promotional opportunities. Day to day work was boring and and repetitive. Much of what we did could have and should have been automated.

Title: Pay is great and benefits are awesome
View5: The pay and benefits are unbelievable.  I have had others approach me to leave but when I start considering the benefits and pay I get I quickly stop looking.
View7: It can be demanding at times depending on the department you are in.  So if you are not part of the core business you can get overlooked.

Title: High level review of company
View5: Worked at a branch. The team was awesome. Worked with great people. Good work/life balance. Had my entire evenings to myself and no need to check emails. This part was great. You also have the chance to help people.
View7: You gotta drink the kool aid if you want to succeed.  Very hierarchical. In the end it's a sales job. You gotta sell stuff: managed portfolios, annuities, probe for and obtain outside assets.

Title: Class A Company
View5:
Great benefits, even including dental, vision, health reimbursements, computer reimbursements, workers comp, leaves of absence, 401k and retirement planning. 

Up to date systems and large availability to work from home.

Friendly, innovative atmosphere for all voices to be heard. 

Many opportunities to expand and grow within the company.
View7:
Unstable work needs, many layoffs and moving positions to employees who take less wage. 

Big changes every couple years in management, not bad for those adaptable.

Title: Excellent place to work
View5:
Support
Training
Benefits package
Opportunity for advancement
Client focused culture 

You will meet some of the best people at Fidelity.
View7:
Call center gets monotonous, branch can be great depending on management team.

Central West market manager is not a good manager, badgers his managers so that they badger you over metrics that are not important to driving the business.

Success will breed higher and higher expectations which can be your downfall.

Title: I will always be thankful for that they have done for my career.
View5: Great opportunity to move up within the company. Opportunity to get security exams. Amazing benefits, especially the 401k match and profit sharing.
View7: The pay is not as competitive as I would like. With Fidelity being such a massive company I would need to move to Boston in order to really make much of a difference.

Title: Culturally biased
View5: Great benefits, the role is easy, fast paced, lots of warm leads for sales roles, advancement for non-people of color. I have no more pros for working with this company
View7: No promotion for you unless you're caucasian. Preferably male. Upper management is completely unfair in their assessments. If you're a working mother for it. You will be ostracized and isolated. They wont fire you but they will make your existence unbearable until you quit.

Title: My time with Fidelity was generally positive.
View5: Great training, awesome people, decent pay with good benefits. Highly recommend Fidelity as a place to start a career and solid for 5 years.
View7: Promoting based more on who you know and a lot of luck when you picked up the phone. Goals always increased and have become mostly unattainable. Pay does not increase as company does better.

Title: Great atmosphere for the customer service type of person. However, not the best place for a finance-oriented person.
View5: Great atmosphere and benefits package.
View7: If you don’t like being on calls for the vast majority of your day there aren’t many roles that offer something different.

Title: Relationship Manager
View5: Great benefits, good work-life balance. Like any job it really depends on management. I’ve had my fair share of good and bad managers, unfortunately the bad resonated way more than the good.
View7: A lot of coaching from management that knows little to none about day to day operations of your role but Hey! That’s corporate America for you... Like to hire externally, which can seem unfair to a employee who has been developing for promotion. Also lower pay of you get promoted within.

Title: Mental breakdown
View5: Benefits, co-workers, you will learn a lot.
View7: This is a company to get experience and move on. The micro managing, insane unrealistic stats, and unbelievable stress will break your spirit.

Title: Regional Investment Consultant
View5:
Great Training. Some of the best sales training 
Great benefits 
My fellow RICs were like a family
Beautiful Campus(equipped with a cafeteria and health clinic)
View7:
-New senior leadership is heartless 
-If you make a mistake early it’s easy to get branded and hard to change that perception 
-Its a true numbers game.  Contacts are all that matter. Don’t let them tell you otherwise. It hovers over your head every day.

Title: Call Center position
View5: Really good benefits for secondary education. Good company 401k with flexible investments. Licensing program is very effective.
View7: It's a call center position that is mentally taxing. It requires a wide range of knowledge on broad topics, and also an understanding of Fidelity's intricacies for operations. The pressure to just take calls for duration of shift is a repetitive exercise with little relief. Most shift times that they provide are for off times with little flexibility unless you have kids.

Title: Crappy Sales Job
View5: Solid benefits, nice retirement plan match
View7: It's all about sales, sales, sales!

Title: You can't complain if you're not willing to leave.
View5: opportunities to acquire multiple skill sets are available to those interested.
View7: growth seems limited because of the number of employees. the bonuses are pretty silly. being a phone monkey is the only option.

Title: Good company for long term growth and work-life balance
View5:
- great benefits
- high level of workforce integrity and professionalism
- total compensation package
- smart people
- polished management
View7:
- lower base compensation
- large corporate environment with structured chain of command
- Risk and HR run the show
- lack of horizontal collaboration
- business complexity
- constant change of priorities

Title: Not the company it used to be
View5: Great benefits, some really hard working people.
View7: Sr Management, promotions handed out to friends not qualified, hiring outside consultants to take on vp jobs that lead to no value for the company - yet the folks are retained.  Its an old boys club where getting ahead is dependent on how well you flattered not how well you did your job.

Title: An ok place to work, but easy to be overlooked
View5: The base pay structure is just ok, but the entire benefits package including matching 401-k, profit sharing, etc makes for a decent compensation.
View7: The majority of the local management at this office tends to show that they are just out for themselves and their career advancement. This seems to be the example set by the upper management team.

Title: Great Place To Work
View5: Fidelity was a great place to work, with plenty of opportunities for growth and learning.  It's also clear that they like to grow from within, bringing people along throughout their careers.
View7: There can be some siloing within certain parts of the organization, but this can be overcome with work and good communication.

Title: Exemplary Campus
View5: The campus is amid a wooded area with a lake teeming with wildlife.  Makes for a relaxing time when you take a break.  They have a robust learning system so you are able to expand your skills.
View7: The gears work a little slow when coming on board, but once you get one, they are a stable place to be.

Title: Real world version of the office space
View5: Salary and bonuses are nice
View7: Environment is horrible.  You are a resource not a person.  Its all about self promotion.  If you are a technical person, you will likely be managed by people who have no technical background.  No HR presence.

Title: Micro management, double standards, and politics reign supreme.
View5:
~401k and profit sharing are excellent. 
~Education reimbursement. Will pay 90% of CFP certification.
~Health benefits are good, but a bit expensive, and in order to reduce the expense quarterly, you must engage in an online "wellness" program.
~High volume business allows for lots of opportunities to hone in your investment and retirement planning skills.
View7:
We are hired for our past successes in planning, sales and relationship management, but then mircro managed and questioned for every single action beyond belief. It is hard to work here and maintain a sense of self respect and dignity! 
~Phone calls are listened-in on by management, and then your conversation with an existing elderly client is called in to question, like, why did you waste 5 minutes talking to her, continuing to build that "relationship", and looking up the status of the TOA for her, when you simply could have forwarded her to the call center cust service team? Seriously? Every rep in my branch has suffered a similar type of encroachment.
~Management will occasionally either sit in to observe an appointment, or they will have you dial their extension and listen remotely from their office phone. It is an arbitrary and random decision as to which appointments they "join", but really, nothing shakes the confidence of a HNW prospect more than thinking the advisor they are here to see is undergoing some sort to management oversight!! It doesn't matter how well the manager justifies it to the prospect, they are thinking, "run"!! Every rep in my branch has suffered a failed appointment due to this hideous micro-management.
~Fidelity preaches the relationship model, putting the customer needs first, holistic financial planning, blah blah, then really only cares about what products you "sold" to each client. Management is very very short-sighted. An appt where you meet with a multi-million $ prospect preparing for retirement in a few months, building the relationship, developing trust, laying ground work for all future wealth planning, is not regarded as a successful appointment or very good use of your time, because it did not result in actual "business" today.
~Fidelity is bombarding their clients with a never-ending barrage of email, mail, just non-stop marketing, all on the S/AE behalf, which drives most clients absolutely nuts.
~They only care about whether or not you are completing the menial "tasks", like clicking all the appropriate buttons in siebel. You are tracked and watched and measured on every single little thing you can imagine. How many clicks you clicked. How many times you dialed out...And all your numbers that are tracked are not only to ensure you are being a busy little bee, but the manager is rated on how many little clicks and menial tasks his/her advisors are doing. It's really all about how to make the manager look good to his/her manager!
~Management at the branch level is extremely lame. They want to treat you like a child, and keep you fearful, knowing every little move is being tracked and watched. Like I said, it is hard to maintain a sense of dignity and self respect in an environment like this. Those who can brown nose management, and are otherwise spiteful, political and backstabbing (to fellow colleagues) do well here. Success is: just tell management what they want to hear, and slam clients into products to satisfy management... Those with little talent and integrity stay, endure, and ultimately get promoted, perpetuating the bad leadership. They stay, put up with the games, and endure because they realize they could not make it anywhere else (except, perhaps, on a used car lot). Those with talent, integrity and truly good planning skills leave for a saner environment. 
~Clients in the S/AE book are very frustrated by the fact that every time they get assigned a new S/AE, and they happen to like that advisor and feel that they are working with someone with knowledge and integrity, that advisor ends up leaving. They keep getting turned over, until ultimately, they will end of in the book of one of the talentless, low-integrity bozos that never leave, or, they will just TOA out of Fido.
~Management, by their own admission, have never worked in our S/AE role as it is currently designed. The "relationship" model is relatively new, and as reps, they only served customers that were fed to them by the "green machine" on a transactional, not relationship, model. I think that disconnect helps explain the double standard; why they focus on tracking/forcing transactional business while falsely preaching relationship development. They like to talk about how successful "they" were in the role...but yeah, if all I had to do was take inbound calls and leads, roll the assets over and slap the client in PAS, funds, and/or FILI, then just move on to the next one with no follow up or relationship accountability...well, heck, any moron could do that.

Title: Good company but lots of bureaucracy
View5: Stable family run company, great retirement benefits, investments in future. Folks seem to stay at fidelity for 20 plus years and culture of people leaving the company and coming back which is telling.
View7: Stagnant pay, difficult for upward mobility, company feels too big and you are too anonymous at times. No transparency into how decisions are made concerning salary and promotion so difficult to know how to advance.

Title: Enjoyable
View5: The people here legitimately care about the clients and the work they are doing. Really great group, for the most part.
View7: Sometimes (though rarely) it really does feel like a big company. Sometimes management/HQ in Boston feels really far away. Lots of buzz about how great they are (which I believe,) but because it is such a large company, there is still a feeling of separation. Hard to stop that.

Title: Account Executive
View5: Volume of new cases provides a steep learning curve for Financial planning process
View7: Same volume eventually becomes a problem with no real support. Your not building anything / no equity in business. Management is militant they can end your career I'd you say something they don't like.

Title: Call center is a great entry point into the Industry
View5: Great Benefits including 7% match and 10% profit sharing match at end of year. Great culture and atmosphere, company really cares about the customers. Rapid advancement through company and ability to relocate to different parts of the country or to a branch.
View7: On a phone all day, tracked how long you are available for taking calls. Churn and burn environment at times. Can make more money doing same thing at other firms but environment may not be as good.

Title: Technology Director
View5: Technology driven company with expansive resources, great benefits, including 401K matching, free financial consulting services and internal profit sharing program.
View7: At times there seems to be a conflicting interpretation of executive direction.  Technology organizations sometimes suffer from a lack of central oversight.  Everyone is doing great things, but sometimes more than one group is doing the same great thing, or no group is doing the great thing that should be getting done.  Still, a really good company to work for.  Plenty of opportunity.

Title: Great benefits, terrible work culture
View5: They contribute 17% of your income to your 401k, on top of your contribution. Great health insurance.
View7: Very resistant to change. An attitude of "We've made it, so there's nothing to improve." They send out surveys to customers but disregard any input that doesn't praise them.

Title: Stain on my resume
View5: Not a lot of pros here but the hours weren't bad I guess...
View7: This is a call center environment.  Pay is minimal and management has poor communication over all.  Actually that's not true, they have NO communication over all.  You are always being monitored.  What I mean by this is that all the calls are listened to and graded, if you stop calls to go to the bathroom, it counts against you.  If you don't take your break/lunch EXACTLY at the specified time, it counts against you.  If you're stuck on a long call and you go past your break time, you're SOL.  And it counts against you.   The computers are so old and constantly freeze and crash on you, which gets increasingly frustrating everyday.  You would think for a multi-million dollar company they could provide their minions with some semi-functional equipment in order to do their jobs efficiently.  But I guess not.  Fidelity also boasts about all the opportunities they have for their employees to branch out to, and frankly the opportunities are few and far between.  They sell you the dream.  And even if you are lucky enough to get a different position, you'll still be on the phone all day taking ~60+ calls per day.  The job descriptions are very vague as to what you'll be doing.  And the little information that is conveyed is very deceitful.   No where was it ever made clear that this is a call center.  Had I known this, I wouldn't even have applied.  I did not go to college to work in a call center.  PLEASE do not apply here!!  Run far and fast!  If you really want to work at a call center, find a different one.  Do your future self a favor and DO NOT WORK HERE!  You WILL regret it.  You'll be thinking about this review while you are sitting at your desk and be thinking "why, why didn't I listen to this person!"  This job was such a joke and a stain on my resume.

Title: Pleasant but right now company is not doing that well
View5: Compensation, work life balance, & friendly co workers. Attracting talent with benefits rather than base pay. Very nice facility all over US and lot of opportunities within the company.
View7: No vision, all over the place and some managers are individual contributors and needs lot of training. Spend ton of money on party and dinner and then formulate a story expenses are going up to support lay off.

Title: A company that sincerely cares about it's people!
View5: I work in Personal Investing, and have been impressed with how well the employees are taken care of. The leadership has implemented a number of initiatives in last few years to improve the vitality index and it has made a serious impact. like better maternity / paternity leaves; open work spaces; less hierarchy; more transparent working model
View7: it has way too many people to achieve the work; so we are overlapping in our roles sometimes.

Title: Good Employer, Won't Have Your Back in a Crisis
View5: Great company, excellent benefits and profit sharing. They take care of their employees while they're employees.
View7: If something happens to you they won't have your back. Your management team might, but upper management doesn't want to be bothered. Just know if something happens they won't have your back.

Title: Job is great until it's eliminated.
View5: Awesome place for new employees, great benefits.
View7: After working for the company 15 years, the department I worked in was eliminated, displacing several hundred reps nationally. They did the right thing and kept us as employees but put us into entry level positions. Once in that position it becomes very difficult to move back into a more well suited position as the preference for advancement is for the newer, younger reps.

Title: Excellent company filled with talented, intelligent people
View5:
- Great benefits
- Excellent company culture with intelligent, collaborative, supportive coworkers
- Management with a clear interest in the career development of associates
View7:
- Unnecessary corporate politics at higher levels
- A few out-dated, inefficient processes and systems remain in effect and present hurdles to accomplishing work

Title: great place to work
View5: Great people and many opportunities within the organization.  Pay is ok to start but after 5 years other perks start to kick in making it worth the investment.  Plenty of opportunities to grab a bull by the horns and conquer it so to speak with regard to projects and delivering.
View7: fairly large organization so it has it fair share of communication issues and sometimes employees are wonders what is going on. But all-in-all communication is better now than in the past.

Title: Great place to work
View5: Flexible, good pay, excellent benefits. They are extremely focused on their customer, which makes the company successful. Everyone I worked with was nearly always very professional.
View7: Lots of politics, very slow to advance employees, overly value soft skills in technical employees. They say that at Fidelity you're rewarded for what you do but my experience was that its at least half due to your political skill, as it is with many large companies.

Title: Overall a good place, but that can differ greatly depending on the business unit.
View5: Solid Benefits, flexible work schedule.
View7: Annual increases are small, and promotions typically only provide a minimal raise (exceptions with certain business units). Pay may be high getting in the door, but the trajectory will quickly plateau.

Title: Fidelity Investments
View5: A great place for entry level positions. Fair pay. A lot of female leadership. Many opportunities to move between groups within the company. Very little micromanaging.
View7: There is some bureaucracy in promotions. Employees ratings are expected to fit within a bell curve, so some employees may receive low ratings because "someone has to get it." Company changes are never done within the time frame that is set. Very little support from senior lever management

Title: It's Who You Know
View5: Steady work.    Great retirement.
View7: Heavy middle management that has too much power.  Too many chiefs and not enough indians.   Plays favorites.  Review process is a joke.   Moving up or lateral takes forever if possible at all,  unless you have some kind of relationship with the management.

Title: Learned a lot, hate being on the phones.
View5: You get to learn about a lot of the rules in the industry. Pretty good training, and very extensive. They have flexible schedules and working 4 days a week at 10 hours a day is a perk.
View7: Phone center with nearly no time to breathe between calls. Can get pretty tedious towards the end of a 10 hour shift.

Title: Great place to learn the business, but constant turnover of management hurts them.
View5: Generous benefits including 401(k) profit sharing.  Many different positions to choose from.
View7: Too much turnover of management team.  Very often you are working for managers who have never done the job.  Sometime there are unrealistic expectations.  You find yourself wearing "too many hats" depending on your role.  Very compliance oriented.  Depending on your manager they will very likely not go to bat for you if an issue comes up.

Title: many long time associates, says a lot about the positive environment
View5: a great community of hard working and very smart people.  many people have worked for Fidelity their entire careers.
View7: because people stay for so long, sometimes its hard to get fresh perspectives and new ideas integrated.

Title: High Net Worth Representative
View5: Very friendly atmosphere. Easy work/life balance. Very focused on employee career growth. Management is customer and associate focused.
View7: Everything is great except the schedules. The firm seems to be focusing on 24 hour customer service aggressively. So you can get stuck working really awful hours and are not compensated for it financially.

Title: Vice President
View5: Growth  opportunities and great training and benefits  diverse locations and many user groups and communities. Opportunities for volunteers and a diverse community
View7: High pressure, often organizationally disorganized   Slow to change and adopt new practices.  Has a tendency to keep people in roles that aren't a good fit for too long.  Although a female chairman there are not enough women on middle and upper management

Title: Workplace Planning and Guidance Consultant II
View5: Amazing company benefits, great price on healthcare, 10% profit sharing, 7% company match, 20% bonus opportunity, tuition reimbursement and student loan help
View7: Eventually you hit a ceiling and company is not great making you aware of other opportunities, Lack of mobility after a few years with the company; WPA department not as respected as others in the organization; salary is not as competitive as others in industry due to too much focus on benefits

Title: Relationship Manager
View5: Pushing  benefits to millennials, including tuition reimbursement, maternity/paternity leave, 7% match to 401k and healthcare benefits.
View7:
Words and actions differ, in suggesting work/life balance then pushing sales numbers and micro managing locally.  Stressful environment and suggestion customer service is focus takes back seat to selling proprietary products.

No career planning exists, left to individual to try to navigate the company and find a spot that fits.

Title: Good stepping stone
View5:
-Good work/life balance
-Benefits are generous
-Culture is more laid back compared to some other financial firms
View7:
- Promotions and raises are hard to come by. You'll have an easier time moving up if you apply as an external candidate. Even lateral moves to other departments can be difficult. 
- Despite record profits, upper management keeps finding new ways to cut bonuses

Title: Micro Managed Call Center with insane goals.
View5:
Benefits are good- not great.
The campus is beautiful!
Free coffee!
View7:
1. Heavy volume call center- there is no pause between calls! The beep in between calls doesn’t even fully beep. You can’t get a sip of water in- it is that back to back.

2. You will be micro managed! They have a system in place that has your schedule mapped out for the upccoming months ahead! (Schedule adherence counts against you if you don’t follow it to the t.) Oh! And if you have a meeting planned or your computer doesn’t feel up to the challenge of running for the day- that’s counts against you too! 

3.  You will feel like a robot. You have to follow there call structure, miss any built point in the call structure and that excellent call goes to just satisfactory. It is very demoralizing to feel like you have done an amazing job and the customer was happy with your service, but Fidelity and there impossible metrics- not so much. 

4. You are expected to know everything! There is a chat where you can ask questions and get the help you need, just keep in mind it’s one person helping a team of over 25+ people at once! It takes time for that person to answer the question, but all that time is counted against you in your metrics. They want 7 minute flawless calls (over & over) to the tune of there perfect script with nothing left out- even if it makes 0 sense to bring it up!

Title: Fidelity investments
View5: The pay and benefits are great. They look at the market to make sure they are staying competitive to other employers. They help get you licensed and will do tuition reimbursement. They will also pay towards outstanding student loans. You get inserance from day one. They do 401k match and profit shareing. With the profit sharing and 401k match they pay 17% into your retirement plan.
View7: They have started to more away from some of the things that have set them apart from other call centers.

Title: ISR Regional Phone Center
View5: Coworkers, free parking, decent benefits if you stay there 6 to 10 years.  Paid training time.
View7: Below low salary and low bonus structure.  Most jobs are narrow specialties. Goals for role shift endlessly, no one hit every goal there.. most managers at temp in roles then get demoted. Most moves are lateral for non managers.

Title: Financial Rep is THE WORST position
View5: Great health care and time off benefits, but you'll need the mental health benefits and the time off to actually get some rest from the constant grind
View7: Tons of required overtime, no breaks for lunch, culture of tearing everyone else down around you to get ahead, micromanagers,  forget about the client and their needs it's all about numbers even though they are constantly stating otherwise.

Title: Fidelity gives you opportunities
View5: Fidelity has vast opportunities in Finance,  Technology and many other areas. The ability to stay within a firm and move to a new position that is fresh and exciting is something that always kept my intrigue.
View7: It is a complex organization which lends itself to an intense environment that isn't right for every individual.

Title: Great place to start out
View5: Financial Advisors learn to operate efficiently at Fidelity. Compensation is good for advisors just starting out.
View7: Because advisors have upwards of 400-500 clients, it's difficult to go very deep with any client's financial planning. There is a focus on achieving certain metrics (ie. insurance, managed money) and there is no cumulative success - the clock starts over every quarter, which means there is limited upside potential for advisors at Fidelity. You will be judged more on what you're selling than on your financial advising.

Title: Fidelity stands for Integrity and Value
View5: The best reason for working at Fidelity is the people.  The employees are committed and very loyal to the company.  Most likely a reflection of management.
View7: Many qualified people are overlooked for promotions.  Unfortunately, like elsewhere, it's the individuals who can network (despite performance) that seem to get recognized.

Title: Great benefits, poor salary, no advancement.
View5: Great benefits.  Medical coverage and 401k are second to none.  Also very generous time off allocation.
View7: Overall, unsatisfied with the job.  It is what it is, which is a CALL CENTER.  Very little job satisfaction.  If you enjoy a call center job and being tied to a phone for 10 hrs a day, then you wouldn't mind it.

Title: With a strong focus on Benefit Communications
View5: Privately owned. Ethical company. Invests in technology to afford employees with the tools they need to effectively do their job.
View7: The environment and organizational structure is always changing. Management development program (if there is one) is not very apparent.

Title: Not the best run and most innovative place to work at, but benefits and people are good.
View5: FMRCo has good benefits and good people. In general, people really try to think thru their actions before acting. One can pick up a lot of good habits coming from a smaller less structured company.
View7: There is a lot of politics and things sometimes take a while to get done. There are days where you feel like you are in a meeting all day and got nothing of value accomplished.

Title: gained a lot of knowledge working at Fidelity
View5: Generally fair treatment of the employees; if you perform well, you will generally be recognized for your work.  Learned a lot in my 18 years working here.  Some good benefits.
View7: As with any large company, there can be some politics where you need to be careful of what you say.  Getting pay raises can be challenging.

Title: Great Benefits and people.  Easy to stand out in the call center.
View5:
It is easy to stand out among your peers in the call center if you are competent.  
Good managers who look out for you.
Extensive training
Awesome benefit packages
Good technology resources  
Nice people
View7:
Reluctance to fire under-performing employees which in turn effects team bonuses.
Many people are hired and let out of training who clearly lack the necessary knowledge to speak to customers.

Title: A challenging but fundamentally frustrating software development experience.
View5: Great offices, good benefits, excellent coworkers.
View7: High turnover, frequent burnout, poor work/life balance, slow to adapt to new technology.

Title: Excellent Company
View5: Great company to work for with lots of opportunity for personal development. The company is full of incredible people that you will know the rest of your life.
View7: Personal I would like more remote opportunities. In todays world you are seeing more flexibility in scheduling and working from home. Fidelity is limited in this area.

Title: Phone Sales: Great place to gain experience but not a place to stay long-term.
View5: Great experience and great culture. Most managers are extremely supportive and will coach their employees to get better. I was lucky enough to have managers who fostered development and helped me carve out a career.
View7: Pay was on the lower side comparable to the industry. Micromanagement was to the max. Being promoted or hired outside of the phone site was not impossible but not easy and could take a long time.

Title: People and organization are great job is monotonous.
View5: There are great benefits and a lot of really nice people, training programs are excellent.  Because there are so many locations around the country if you are willing to relocate there is a lot of opportunity out there.
View7: Call volume is too much, there is no way to enjoy your job when there aren't enough employees to handle the call volume.  They are understaffed and no one wants to be in the entry level position.

Title: Enterprise Infrastructure Internship

Title: Big corporate company with big corporate mindsets.

Title: Many opportunities
View2: Business Analyst and Software QA Engineer
View5: I held several positions within Fidelity and enjoyed all of them.  Management and employee development is important to the company, and Fidelity offers great growth opportunity.  Most of the managers I came in contact with are professional, fair.  Everyone is expected to work hard - many days I worked very long hours to meet deadlines.  The pay was much better than average, and the benefits, and career and personal development opportunities were excellent.

Title: Great company to start- plenty of ways to move around.

Title: You don't know what you don't know...

Company is generous and I will retire here.

Title: Sr. Systems Engineer
View5:
Competitive Pay, Good environment, Friendly colleagues, Great Perks!

Title: Good Place to work

Re-orgs are very common every 6 months or so.  Your manager never really gets opportunity to know you and your skills.

Title: Testing and Reporting

Title: Principal and inbound call center broker
View5: Colleagues make you smarter.  Strong culture of doing personal best and customer is king. Very high ethics - a cult but you get rich not poisoned from drinking their cool aid. Like college friends who are all down with working hard and drinking hard. Phenomenal quarterly team dinners in Boston's best steakhouses. Be yourself-that is why they hired you.
View7: Imagine a phone that, never stops wringing, and they always give you more work...but rarely take any work away.

Title: Financial Services options
View5: Over a 4 year timeframe I held 3 different titles. The ease of movement between business groups was very helpful for a recent grad looking to find my niche.
View7: Due to financial services regulations, the 'red tape' occassionally became tedious.

Title: Fidelity Investments- Branch
View5: Great benefits and culture. Branch environment feels like a small business but has the perks of corporate world.
View7: Upper Management tends to make poor decisions when hiring a branch manager. Recent manager hired for downtown Denver office has no industry knowledge and is strictly sales driven. Demands to have total control of all situations and has lost trust of employees. Fidelity preaches of putting the client first and being customer focused but he feels the opposite about it.

Title: Undervalued and Overworked
View5:
Great benefits.
Job security - second to none. Working in Finance and providing guidance or customer service is a job that only gets more secure as the economy gets worse.
View7:
Completely undervalued - we were told for over 1 year that we would get raises and we did not. All the other groups in my business function received pay raises, and 3 or 4 other functions in the company did the same job as my group, and they got paid 20-50% more. The only time I felt like anyone cared that I was working my tail off was when I announced that I was quitting.
Overworked - you are tethered to your phone, and you are required to take inbound calls constantly. It is a call center.
"Sales" - you are consistently told that you are in a sales function, you have a quota to hit, and you are held to metrics. However, you have no control over what phone calls you take or what customers you talk to, and the environment and pay are not reflective of a sales function.
Pay - the pay was pathetic compared to the rest of the industry/rest of the company.
Budget cuts - we were not allowed to work overtime, but our sales goals were raised.
Inconsistency - calls were transferred to my function by other sales roles. Those sales roles had very little idea what customers needed or wanted, and we were restricted from giving any type of pushback. We were required to take all calls that came to us, regardless of whether the customer's questions were in our job description.
Promoting based on politics - I saw multiple instances of people getting promoted that did not deserve the job. There was an explicit instance that I witnessed where someone was hired into a position because they were a woman, even though they were less qualified than another candidate (who happened to be male) - management made an explicit comment that they wanted to hire a woman to the position.

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Very active and engaging culture. There are a lot of ways to get involved with your coworkers. Though we are in operations, you get the feeling that everyone is working toward the same goals, and bottom level associates are made to feel valued
View7: Despite the numerous attempts at holding talent, Fidelity's flaw is a static career. Very limited mobility internally if you're looking to pursue a new career since so many reps are just trying to get off of the phone calls they take daily.

Title: Not a good place to be a manager
View5: Good benefits, free coffee and good parking
View7: Mediocre pay with limited upward mobility.  If you don't need medical benefits do not work here, go somewhere for more income.

Title: Poor technology practices
View5: The 401k in the USA is pretty good. You should get a return above 6% of thereabouts. No reason you won't have over $100k in your 401k account after 5 years. This is the only pro to working at this company.
View7:
If you're looking for a technology position, I would go to a technology company. Fidelity is a financial services company first, and as a result they have some questionable practices. They have their own version of agile which just doesn't work. Be prepared for hour long stand ups in the morning, project managers that are not technical and fail to keep track of meeting minutes.

From a salary perspective Fidelity is way behind technology companies. I left a senior position in Fidelity, and joined a junior position in a technology company. My salary went from $74,800 to $120,000. 

Once you get to senior in Fidelity, the path to principal, manager, director and above is almost non-existant these days. Your promotion path is not based on job performance, it is based on putting the time in with the group you're with. This much was admitted to me in my review meetings. If you join as a senior or get promoted to senior and want to be promoted to principal be prepared to put in more than 5 years before even being considered for it, and chances are the company will use a down turn in the economy as a reason for not giving you the promotion you deserve.

If you're near retirement you'll be fired so the company can save money by not giving you a full retirement package. I know a lot of people that this happened to in 2008, and again recently. 

The company keeps changing direction. When I joined in 2007 teams were organized by function - developers, testers, etc. Recently they re-organized by product. You can be sure in another 6 - 8 years they'll go back to being organized by function after an independent consultant comes in and makes the case for it.

Every 8 years the company sheds around 10 - 25% of their staff - most of them are the people it pays the most.

Title: Systems Engineer - Fidelity Investments
View5: Great benefits, great environment, beautiful campus.
View7: Common judgment performance rating system requires  at least 1 person from each team to receive unsatisfactory performance. Our team was only 3 people so only one person could get exceptional performance and one had to get unsatisfactory regardless of actual performance. We rotated but still taking a negative review because of a flawed system is unacceptable.

Title: Financial Representative - an exciting career talking to angry customers on the phone.
View5: The pay is decent, the benefits are good, after 6 months you are eligible to begin having your student loans reimbursed. Fidelity puts a substantial amount of effort into training you to pass the series 7 and series 63 tests.
View7:
Beyond training you to pass the series 7 and series 63, Fidelity doesn’t really train you for the job you will be performing. 
Most, if not all jobs, are customer facing phone center jobs. Half your time will be spent dealing with angry customers. Most of the time they were told the wrong way to transfer money, or otherwise service their account, by a poorly trained rep. Other times, a form will be rejected and instead of Fidelity sending an email or making a call, a poorly worded letter will be sent advising the customer to call the general service line instead of the back office group that can actually help with the problem. 
Prepare to be micromanaged. In an eight hour shift, you will get one paid 30 minute break and one unpaid 30 minute lunch. Other than that, you are expected to be on the phone. You will receive “coaching” from your manager if you spend too much time writing notes on an account, if you don’t enroll enough people in the voice recognition system, if you call the help desk too much because you don’t know how to help the customer, if your calls are longer than ten minutes, if you don’t take at least 6.5 calls in an hour, or if you don’t get enough new business leads. Also, your job performance will be judged based on what customers think of you. Customer surveys must be “top box” for them to count toward your bonus.  If you help a customer who was given bad information by a previous rep, even if you resolve the issue, if they’re still unhappy with the overall service Fidelity gave them (which they usually are), you get a poor evaluation. That poor evaluation is then used to assess how much of a bonus you get.
After passing the series 7 and 63 you get a retention bonus. Meaning, if you work at Fidelity for less than a year after receiving the bonus, you have to pay it back. This was put into place because of the huge amount of turnover that takes place once reps are done with the training and start the actual job.
Additionally, you will be taught how to avoid giving anything that resembles investment advice by directing customers back to the website for almost everything.

Title: Very good company to work for
View5: Great pay and benefits, many advancement opportunities. Tuition benefits are great, flexible work locations and times. Because it's privately owned there are a lot of great fringe benefits.
View7: Older company still working to become agile in a digital world. Many long-term managers are looking for their role in the new Fidelity and this can cause roadblocks for younger, ambitious associates.

Title: Stock Plan Associate

Title: Work hard and reap benefits

Not necessarily a bad expectation but tough for some to manage that over ten or twenty years without burnout.

Title: Decent place to work

work/life balance
fair pay for the work
professional environment
talented people

Title: Finance

Title: None
View5: Overall company culture of customer experience, great employees

View7: Very reactive to market change, can't seem to get comp right for branch sales, poor communication from the top management

Title: Punative Environment With Little Appreciation
View5: If you need a stable job it is ok
View7: They change the employee expectations for performance with no ramp up time and then threaten corrective action if you do not keep up. They nit pick on unimportant issues such "that sweater has a hood attached, wear it again and we will send you home." You are not a person you are a resource to be used as they wish.

Title: Overall a good company to work for
View5: Great health, 401k, and profit sharing benefits. The majority of middle management care about the employees. Good work/live balance.
View7: Compensation is very low. The only way to get a higher salary is to move around a lot, or leave and come back.

Title: Filled with people who have been working there too long and are afraid to ever work anywhere else.
View5: Great 401k matching, year-end bonus & shares. Good health benefits. Some quality people still work there.
View7:
Comparatively low salary, unless you come in at a certain level. I was at Fidelity for several years -- in the beginning I was excited to be there, and I got great reviews and I moved up, and I did meet some really good people, so I thought there was a future there for me. But after seeing behind the curtain and realizing every part of the business was messed up, I jumped ship when the opportunity presented itself.

In every business unit I was in, I saw a shocking lack of leadership. Projects are started and stopped in a haphazard, wasteful way based on whichever direction the political wind is blowing. Projects take years to complete when they shouldn't, and sometimes things launch and then they are immediately discarded. Or subpar work -- the standards, when you are talking about technology or communications or design, are way too low for a company of this size and reputation -- is allowed to launch and is weirdly celebrated. The website is terrible, and the technology at Fidelity is frighteningly behind, yet they spend billions on it every year.

Many VPs (and there are oh-so-many) are afraid to say what they think, so naturally everyone underneath them is. People who move slowly and don't make waves are rewarded. People who suggest new ways to approach things are often viewed as threatening by people who have been sitting comfortably in their roosts for too long. Very little actual work gets done and I think Fidelity customers would be shocked to see how much money is wasted by this company on people who are paid way too much for producing way too little by the end of the year. Typically you'll see a business unit with a couple of overworked worker bees and several VPs who go to a lot of meetings but don't do much except talk at each other in meetings and try to figure out how to work the politics.

HR is obsessed with the upper echelon of management, and could care less about the employees. They'll drive themselves crazy over how some memo looks to Executive A or all the SVPs and meanwhile they put very little forethought into a relocation strategy that affects thousands of employees and will bite them in the long run. For example, how many future genius fixed income portfolio managers will sign up to work in Merrimack, New Hampshire when they can go to the competitors in New York or London? And how many dollars is this firm saving by outsourcing HTML work to India when the work takes three times as long to be completed because every single piece of it must be explained, checked, and then checked and requested three more times until it is correct (and each round takes 2 weeks)?

The word on the street is with the up-and-coming leadership regime, it's all about the yes-men, and there's no heart there. Some of the old benefits have already disappeared, and most of the people in the know expect that when the Chairman retires, his successor wants to get rid of things like the long-loved employee shares. Believe me, this will happen. 

This company loves layers, and insecure management lets incompetence reign in those layers -- especially directors and VPs -- because they can manipulate those employees or because they're too afraid to fire people who are in over their heads. Management and HR love to market to themselves internally.

Yet Fidelity will continue to make money in spite of this because it has reached a certain size in the marketplace. When I left, I took my money with me because after seeing how the sausage is made, this really isn't the best place to put your money. (Unless you are a high net-worth customer, they push you into the Freedom Funds, which are consistent underperformers.)

It's sad, because from what I understand from people who were there for a really long time, it used to be a really great company. This sentiment is heard around the firm, but I know a lot of people are afraid to leave because they're shackled to the benefits.

Life is short -- there are a lot of companies out there. If you're not overly committed to your kids' private schools or college tuitions, get the heck out while you still can. There is a world outside Fidelity.

Title: Opportunities are there but are hard to find
View5: There are really smart people who work here and there are great opportunities for career growth (at least initially) plus their pay and benefits are competitive
View7: There are too many entrenched people who do the minimum and know how to survive, eventually it becomes soul destroying

Title: Work/Life Imbalance
View5: The Benefits are good, that is after all a major product offered by the company. This is a respectable company and a leader in the industry.
View7: Work life balance is non existent in the support software support role. The office culture is fairly hostile to change or improvments. Constructive critisism is a foreign concept, conform or be ostracized is the unfortunate successful path. The job role, responsabilties continually expand while the workforce shrinks.

Title: Micromanagement reigns as employees are left to wither away
View5: They will hire you right out of college and pay you a decent salary with good benefits. The facilities are nice and some of your coworkers can be friendly. Training and L&D structure is quite good.
View7: Incompetent management who are only around to spy on employees every waking moment of the day. They drill you with metrics and are quick to point out the negative aspects of your performance while glossing over any positive aspects. For example, you could be leading your team in trade accuracy yet they will berate you for the fact you take a few extra seconds in between calls to wrap things up. Your metrics suffer if you have to use the restroom when you aren't on a break (often times you go a 3 or 3.5-hour stretch without one). Your schedule is outside of your control and offers no room for any leeway (I would always have break and lunch at different times every single day of the week). If you work on a schedule where you have to work on weekends there is almost zero chance of you ever getting a Saturday or Sunday off. Many of your coworkers and managers are rude, narcissistic egoists who will do anything to get ahead. There is almost no room for upward mobility if you start in the call center - something made very clear early on. It's just an endless line of phone jobs, finding a spot where you aren't working on the phone is exceedingly rare. Despite the fact that it does pay well, reps are still underpaid for the amount of work they must do. Full traders are almost always sitting in a position where there are 20+ calls holding all day for the entire 10 hour shift. Soul-crushing monotony with zero work/life balance, this job will inevitably make you wish you would get in a fatal car accident on the way in to work.

Title: Financial Representative

Title: Good benefits

View7: Revolving door for supervisors/executives.  Can be very hard driving and they definitely are focused on performance.

Title: Director
View5: Good work-life balance, interesting work, nice people, large annual re-invest in the business is great for technology and business process management.  401K is great benefits are good.
