Title: A lot of manual effort from disconnected systems and lack of information goes into completing daily work.
View5: It's a good way to get a wide variety of experiences and assignments. There is always so much that's broken, so it's ripe with opportunities for improvement. There is a high frequency of change, which can also be challenging.  The environment at Fidelity is very friendly for those who work and play well with others regardless of how poorly you do your job. Overall, a pretty safe environment.
View7:
Fidelity has a lot of legacy software and hardware platforms, so it's not the place to be if you are interested in getting experienced with newer technologies or automation. Fidelity is addicted to faulty systems which require high levels of maintenance and manual effort, because they can get them "cheaply" through volume discounts and enterprise licensing. Approximately 15% of your time on the job will be required for mandatory "ethics" and "compliance" training, double-recording your time and work results in disconnected, deficient, and faulty systems. The ethics training is as much a joke as the company's stated values, which include honesty. As long as you aren't tossing midgets or taking kickbacks, honesty is not even valued (especially amongst management), much less promoted in ANY way. I personally know of managers who are told by upper management to lie to their employees. I'm not sure how "ethics" can even exist in such an inherently dishonest environment.
By the time you complete all of the "mandatory training" and administrative tasks required, you will be lucky to have 60% of your time left to do your job. They will schedule enough meetings to consume another 20% of your time, but management will still treat it as 100%.  Of course, while trying to complete your job tasks in this remaining 40% of your time, you will also be expected to train offshore staff how to do your job.  The offshore staff is culturally trained to say "yes" to everything and then delivering on 10-20% of what they promise.  But it's okay, because they are perceived as being "cheap labor", even though they can't seem to work independently and require that you do about 40% of the job for them.  A significant amount of time on the job is also wasted "shifting gears", as management is largely incompetent and doesn't understand the costs associated with changing your mind and focus constantly. Often, fake deadlines are created and things given an overblown sense of importance to pressure employees into working late. Many times I have arrived at work and started to work on an "important" task perhaps less than 1 hour in duration and still struggled to focus through the constant interruptions to complete this before the end of the work day, which is often late into the evening. My boss interrupts me 6 - 8 times a day for "emergencies", and then becomes upset because "he doesn't know what I am working on".
Penny-wise and pound foolish, Fidelity purchases systems based solely on the purchase price and doesn't seem to know the 1st thing about TCO (Total Cost of Ownership).  They build lavish and expensive bathrooms, while looking for ways to cut expense reimbursement, benefits, and bonuses, while they make billions shipping American jobs overseas. They have contributed significantly to the infrastructure and economy in India while they add to the unemployment lines domestically.
Talk about a hostile work environment! Making your boss look good here is the only thing that counts. The company's core values are an absolute joke, as is their dental plan, "ethics", and "compliance" training. Rather than focus on getting results, motivating employees and doing the right thing, managers spend their time sneaking up behind employees to see what's on their computer screen. If they see a similar screen that might have been there 2 hours before, the assumption is made that you have done nothing else within that 2 hour period, even though there are electronic records of all systems usage. Why check when it's easier for them to assume?
If you are technically incompetent and can lie like a politician, there is a comfy home for you in management at Fidelity. Once you're a member in this exclusive club, it's all about you and other than committing career-icide through political folly, there will be nothing you can do wrong. 
Also, if you ever want to invest on your own, Fidelity will make sure that whatever gains you might make will be more than offset by the paperwork, administrative hassles and threats to your employment status from their "compliance" department. And that's only IF they pre-approve every trade that you make.

Title: Hire from within
View5: Benefits and educational opportunities are very good.
View7: Jobs open to outsiders when competent, loyal employees exist in house.  This practice must stop.

Title: Negative Culture and Values
View5: Decent Pay and Good Benefits. A general willingness to invest in business development and IT. Modern and updated facilities with decent amenities. Tight security both physically and on the customer data side.
View7:
Does not pay for performance or set performance expectations well. There are unwritten or absent expectations regarding "success" in job roles; performance is not necessarily judged against what your assignments are and how you execute them. 

For example, recently I had achieved all of my performance goals for the review period, such as being ahead of project completion schedules, under budget and delivered targeted business scope. Two weeks prior to the performance review the performance assessment criteria was changed to "measure" me against targets that I had no chance to meet since they were completely different than the job assignments.  The manager conducting the review admitted that the assessment criteria was "new" and "unfair" and the lack of communication was deliberate in order to send a "message" to the organization.

After over a decade of service with eighty percent of my performance reviews being "above average" under the various grading scales (and never having had a poor review before), it was a very strange turn of events.

It appears as though it may be a targeted "reduction in force" or "desired attrition" by targeting people at certain pay and/or years of service, since I was only one of several colleagues who held similar positions that expressed a very similar situation. 

Rewards are more and more concentrated at the very top level, with the middle layer becoming hollow and the entry level positions are subject to RIF's regularly.

Exceptionally poor planning in just about every business unit, and the company as a whole. A general  inability to keep focus.

Title: Fund Accounting Manager
View5: Benefits are one of a kind.  Community environment promotes growth.
View7:
*Once you are hired, salaries are competitive but merit raises to existing salary is not desirable.  You will need a promotion to receive any significant increases.  
*Company stack-ranks employees.
*Company in some circumstances more concerned about cost than they do employees.

Title: Director -Operations
View5: Hire and support the best people,  most ethical company I have ever worked for,  great benefits,  really want their associates to succeed.

Title: Great company to work but few senior level individuals are bad apples

View7: Few SVPs are super political and fooling around with top management, saving their jobs, and keeping their buddies around them

Title: Play the game
View5:
401K 7% match is great.
Relaxed but professional work environment.
It's a big company and you have the ability to make your own path and build your career.
View7: If you start in an entry level position you'll generally face 3-5 years of a g-r-i-n-d. Lots of corporate question-dodging and a general sense of disconnectedness from management down.

Title: Great Benefits
View5:
Benefits:
-Top of the line health insurance
   not expensive
-7% 401k match
- 6 weeks paternity leave
Relaxed work environment
Reasonable bonuses for entry level.

Title: High Engagement Financial Representative
View5: clean working space,  decent commodities,  up to date workplace,
View7: Poor bonus setup, Forced OT in the 1st and 4th quarter, Never closes regardless of weather, tied to a desk due to micromanagement of KPI's,

Title: Solid culture but held back by
View5:
- Modern tech stack
- Challenging projects
- Good, fun people
- Starbucks, cafeteria, and gym on-site

- Massive company so solving problems outside of your team can be difficult  i.e. services go down and you have no idea who to contact
- Communicating with offshore teams is annoying and incredibly inefficient
- General corporate bureaucracy

Title: Company wants only younger people
View5: Benefits  and the gym onsite
View7: The company is only interested in you if you are YOUNG! There is no work-life balance, and after I left, I realized it was a good thing the company only hires recent college grads because it is only those with little to no experience that would put up with a job with Fidelity. They will get worked to death with little pay!

Title: Regret so much
View5:
Good benefits. 
Other people have said they like working here apparently
View7: Not much to do and no path out. Doesn’t give you any useful experience or transferable skills. Would NOT have taken position if managers had explained most of the day was downtime.  Group most likely stays overstaffed to justify high ranking directors’ position.

Title: Great company, terrible Industry
View5: They take care of their employees like no company, lots of PTO and help advancing.
View7: Taking calls for at least 8 hours a day and many times with disgruntled or disprespectful people. Not Fidelity’s fault but it is a terrible work life.

Title: This job is the grind

Title: Good Company with Some Downsides

Title: Overall good experience
View5: Amazing benefits. 7% matching on your 401k, 10% profit sharing annually. Good medical, dental, vision. Dozens of unique services you can take advantage of. Flexible work environment, including the capability of working remotely depending on the position.

Title: If you can handle change and are a self-starter, Fidelity provides significant growth opportunities

Title: FI Isn't Blessed with People Management Strengths.
View5: Overall compensation/benefits are above average.

Title: Awesome place to work if you in to finance or business

Title: Keep your head down here and pick your fights wisely

Title: Outstanding place to work

Title: System Analyst
View5:

The managers make sure you have everything you need to complete your work and are successful.
View7: The office culture is great and good place to work but if finance is not your thing, it could get boring.

Title: Great place to start career in investments.

Title: Old, slow and political
View5: Benefits - great package and bonuses.
View7:
Politics. There are people there who I honestly didm;t what they did. Once someone is entrenched there they never leave. Everything takes forever to get done. Toxic culture. 
They claim to be entrepreneurial but that couldn't be farther from the truth.

Title: Privately held firm with strong reputation

Title: Great company, however interview process lacking

Title: Good place to start, but do not stay here for long.

Title: Senior Technical Project Manager

Title: Great company

Title: Long term career
View5: Great for full-time employees staying for the long haul.  401k match is excellent, salary is high, perks are plentiful and offices provide clean, modern work environments.  Culture is very positive.  Always allows horizontal movement and relocation.
View7: None that i can think of

Title: Administrative Intern

Title: Good place to work
View5:
-senior leadership DOES care

-no vision insurance
-high OT expectations

Title: Great place to work.

On phone all day
Compared to competing financial firms, they pay less but provide better retirement benefits
Limited positions 
Very very busy certain times of year

Title: Financial Advisor

Title: Financial Rep
View5: Good benefits and very nice knowledgable people work at Fidelity

Title: Great learning experience
View2: Workplace Planning and Guidance Consultant I
View5: They help with licensing and have a great training program. The benefits are some of the best in the industry.

Title: Great Benefits

Title: Good work if you can find a place

Good people

Title: Great Place!

Title: Great agile environment

room for improvement
great management

View7: I can't think of one.  World class organization.

Title: Fidelity Investments
View5: Great culture. Great training program. Wonderful leadership. Strong team atmosphere. Educational employment experience.
View7: Lowest paid brokerage firm in the industry.

Title: Good company
View5: Workload and culture is a lot less heavy than other financial firms, great benefits and PTO
View7: Less stress comes with lower pay

Title: Vice President
View5: Great compensation package, very flexible environment
View7: Very political, completely decentralized organizational structure.  Makes it hard if your in a support function to move around.

Title: Senior Business Analyst
View5: Excellent co-workers.  Challenging assignments.  Executive staff really cared for their employees.
View7: Frequent organization changes - sometimes multiple times in one year.

Title: Good company but too much bureacracy
View5:
Good work life balance and great colleagues
Nice salary
View7: Too much bureaucracy and work is slow and little old-fashioned

Title: Great 20thc company, but 21st?
View5: Great benefits, beautiful buildings, convenient Boston locations
View7: Many re-orgs and unfinished initiatives make for a rather chaotic environment.

Title: Great people who hire well
View5: Wonderful people from Senior Leadership to brand new hires.
View7: You may not want to leave to go home.

Title: Fidelity Asset Management Intern
View5: People are extremely willing to help you if you are proactive. Exposure to many senior execs, and very important people.
View7: There can be a lot of downtime.

Title: Financial Representative
View5: Great Benefits, great place to start career as early training is excellent
View7: Politics matter more than production

Title: Operations Management
View5: Great place to work if you consider that it is your business not some one elses
View7: One has to be patient to get the reward

Title: Good company if you like taking calls and/or working with problem resolution, and/or data entry
View5: Great benefits and flexible hours
View7: Corporate favoritism can come into play here and there

Title: Publishing
View5: Benefits packages and good people.
View7: Poor, top-heavy management who redesign departments and entire divisions yearly to justify their position. Sub-par compensation. OT demanded with little or no notice.

Title: Ok place to work but call center environment
View5: Ok place to work with good benefits
View7: Not a lot of upward potential. Call center environment. Bonuses suck.

Title: Wonderful company, great people!
View5: Excellent training for FINRA licenses. Helpful Support team.
View7: Initial hours/schedule can be rough.

Title: Great Company
View5: Great environment, really put time and effort into interns. Made sure we got a good grasp of the company and our work.
View7: There were no cons at Fidelity

Title: Transaction Processor
View5: Great bonuses and benefits.
View7: There is a little opportunity for advancement and you don't get paid more for going above and beyond on your job. Also, workers feel highly underappreciated.

Title: Great work environment!
View5: The work life balance is fantastic and the work is very rewarding.

Title: Pinnacle employer
View5: Amazing people, workplace environment, benefits, growth opportunities, training and support
View7: I have nothing bad to say. If you work here, you have arrived.

Title: Good Company

Title: Call center

Title: Poor Middle Management

View5: Training, management, quick upward movement

Title: Great company with great benefits
